                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                              May 16, 2006 Tuesday

Refugees rich -- in gratitude

BYLINE: Doug Robinson Deseret Morning News

LENGTH: 685 words


"Oh, Amy, America, America; it's hard, but, oh, it is worth it for the peace of
mind. My children can run and play." -- Saran, Salt Lake refugee

SOUTH SALT LAKE -- Down at the South Park Apartments, which is located by the
railroad tracks, somewhere between nowhere and somewhere, the people don't have
much, except their lives, and that is enough for now.

They are mostly refugees, people who have fled Eastern Europe, Africa, Asia and
the Middle East to escape civil war and "ethnic cleansing." They all have a
story that could fill a Hollywood blockbuster.

Amy Wylie knows their stories. She knows all of the residents as if they were
uncles and cousins. Called by her church to be a service missionary, this
kindly, middle-aged mother of three is a mentor and friend to these refugees.
She is here almost daily to help refugees navigate America and its morass of
work permits, laws, welfare, doctor visits, school, jobs.

This morning, she stops first at the apartment of Zeinab, a tiny woman who
speaks no English. Her husband was born in Afghanistan, she in Lebanon and her
children in Syria. They were on the run until coming here seven years ago. When
she sees Amy, she rushes out the door to greet her. "They're always glad to see
me," says Amy. Zeinab searches her purse and pulls out her Utah I.D., which she
shows to Amy, beaming.

"Oh, you got your I.D.!" and they exchange a hug for this simple victory.

Amy walks to another apartment where she finds Esther, a Liberian refugee who
fled to a camp in Guinea. Amy calls each of the children by name, all nine of
them. They rush to greet her at the door, wrapping tiny arms around her leg.

"We love them and so they love us," says Amy.

The carpet is dirty, the ceiling is cracked, the door handle is missing, the
stove and toilet don't always work, but Esther says, "I'm glad to be here."

They lived in a refugee camp for 14 years waiting for asylum.

As she walks toward another apartment, Amy is talking about how badly more
mentors are needed. She is not wealthy. She does not write checks for these
people. She gives them time and energy. "I can't imagine life without it," she
says. "We waste so much time. This gives it meaning. We're needed."

The level of commitment is up to the mentor. For her part, Amy invites the
families to her home occasionally. In summer, they lounge on the lawn chairs in
her yard as if it were a great luxury.

"It's like going to a nice resort for them," she says, her eyes welling with
tears.

She stops by another apartment belonging to Saran and Joseph.

She was an accountant in Sierra Leone, he an economist. When civil war broke
out, they were kidnapped by rebels and separated for almost a year. She bore
their first child in a rebel camp. They were reunited and had another child.
Then Joseph went to get work one day and didn't come home for three years. Saran
gave birth to their third child in a camp in Ghana. When Saran and the children
were granted asylum, they moved to America without Joseph. For more than a year
she waited for him, never giving up hope he was alive, and finally he surfaced
in Africa.

Amy sent out a mass e-mail soliciting help. An anonymous donor paid Joseph's
passage to America. Amy watched the reunion at Salt Lake City International,
where Joseph met his third child for the first time, taking her face in his
hands and staring into her eyes.

Joseph and Saran are articulate, educated and hard-working.

Amy likes their chances of succeeding in the United States. They tend neighbor
kids during the day; she attends night school to study accounting.

They plan to open a day-care center, but they need donations. They are grateful
people. When a modest couch was presented to them, Saran protested, "It's too
good for us."

Gratefulness is the currency of these people, Amy's payback.

One young man called her one day simply to say, "Thank you for loving me."

"People ask if these people want a lot," says Amy. "They just want love." And
out of love comes her service. "Every single day I'm here, my life is better,"
she says. Doug Robinson's column runs on Tuesday. Please send e-mail to
drob@desnews.com.

                         The Chronicle of Philanthropy

                             April 6, 2006 Thursday

Clowning Around for Charity

BYLINE: Nicole Wallace

SECTION: GIVING; Pg. 6 Vol. 18 No. 12

LENGTH: 247 words


Refugee camps for people who have fled civil wars, orphanages for children who
have lost parents to AIDS, and shelters for survivors of natural disasters are
notfun places to be. But one charity hopes that a little clowning around   and
maybe even some juggling   can lighten the atmosphere and provide a sense of
normalcy, if only temporarily.

Clowns Without Borders was born after members of a Spanish circus troupe
performed shows in refugee camps in Croatia and Bosnia in 1993 during the ethnic
conflicts that raged in that region. Now, Clowns Without Borders also has
affiliates in Belgium, Canada, France, Sweden, and the United States.

"Humor has always been present in crisis situations," says Moshe Cohen, who
directs Clowns Without Borders-USA, in San Francisco. "It's a great way of
letting the lid off the pressure cooker."

Volunteers organized by the American branch have performed for children in South
Africa who have lost their parents to AIDS, residents of villages in Guatemala
devastated by mud slides, and survivors of Hurricane Katrina.

In addition to putting on shows, volunteers often hold workshops to teach circus
skills, such as clowning, juggling, or stilt walking, to children, teachers, and
local performers.

Each of the six national groups operates independently. Mr. Cohen says that
performers who volunteer for the American branch typically raise money for their
trips through house parties and benefit shows, a total of between $20,000 and
$30,000 a year.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             March 26, 2006 Sunday

Refugee family remembered

BYLINE: CRAIG REBER

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. a1

LENGTH: 495 words

DATELINE: PLATTEVILLE, Wis.


Platteville, a southwest Wisconsin community of 10,000, is far removed from
Rwanda - an east-central African nation that was engulfed in genocide in the
mid-1990s.

But for numerous Rwandas, Platteville has played a major role in helping the
transition from their war-torn country to American culture.

Consolee Mujawabera, a Rwandan woman who fled to the United States, arrived in
Platteville in May 1997 with three of her sons - Emmanuel, Adolphe and Francois
- and daughter Ephigenie. Another son, Aphlodis, who hadn't seen his family in
six years, was reunited in May of 2000. The reunion capped a remarkable odyssey.
It also offered an insight into the city's character.

The family has since moved to Dayton, Ohio, where a number of Rwandans have
settled - however, family members are still remembered.

"The family was very friendly and the boys were very curious, wanting to learn
as much as they could," said Steve Chandler, who helped the family's
assimilation into the community.

Assimilation included education in the city's public school system. Mary
Hardyman, a Platteville Public School teacher, remembered Emmanuel, then 16, the
oldest of the boys.

"He didn't speak anything other than 'hi,'" Hardyman said, adding the boy did
know how to count to 10 in English.

Hardyman began with the basics, and used French, which Emmanuel knew, and worked
from there - including the use of her daughter's beginning reading book.

Hardyman called Emmanuel an "amazing" child who learned quickly. He was also
tutored by a Platteville student.

"The (school) kids really accepted the family quickly," Hardyman said. "They
were so excited to help them learn. They loved to learn."

It ignited a process in the school system designed to address the needs of
similar students. The Platteville School District added an
English-as-a-second-language instruction that supports both teachers and
students.

"Sometimes it wouldn't be just Rwanda, it could be students who have been
adopted from Russia or Hispanics," said Barbara Daus, a Platteville School Board
member.

It has evolved into teachers developing a variety of flexible strategies to
teach English. And, Daus adds, each situation is different.

The University of Wisconsin-Platteville, where Daus serves as special assistant
to the chancellor, offers instruction in English as a second language. The
curriculum prepares students to teach English to non-native English speakers.

"The skills, the knowledge and the ability to assist in the learning
environment," Daus said.

The UW-P also provided Consolee employment in its food service department. It
was one of several institutions, organizations and individuals that assisted the
family. For example, Chandler ensured the family had housing, garbage collection
and a proper mailing address.

Chandler believes a community assistance net is securely in place for families
in similar situations.

"Area churches and groups are willing to help out anybody in need," he said.
"Things worked out well."

                                    Variety

                      February 6, 2006 - February 12, 2006

GOD GREW TIRED OF US

BYLINE: JOHN ANDERSON

SECTION: FILM REVIEWS; Pg. 92

LENGTH: 519 words


(DOCU)
  A Lost Boys of Sudan presentation. Produced by Christopher Quinn, Molly
Bradford Pace. Executive producers, Brad Pitt, Adam Schlesinger, Jack
Schneider. Co-producers, Eric Gilliland, Dermot Mulroney.
  Directed by Christopher Quinn. Camera (color, HD), Paul Daley; editor,
Geoffrey Richman; music, Mark McAdam, Mark Nelson, Jamie Staff. Reviewed at
Sundance Film Festival (competing), Jan. 25, 2006. Running time: 86 MIN.
  With: John Bul Dau, Panther Bior, Daniel Abul Pach.

   The male refugees of war torn east Africa were the subject of 2003's "The
Lost Boys of Sudan" and are revisited --- thankfully ---  in "God Grew Tired of
Us," Christopher Quinn's  portrait of three young Sudanese men and their
adjustment to life in the United States. Although shot over a longer period of
time than "Lost Boys,"  "God Grew Tired" is a softer, less complex version of
essentially the same story, far less troubling in its explorations and
implications than "The Lost Boys," but with far greater commercial potential.
  Any theatrical success will be aided to no small extent by the three
haltingly eloquent, charming young Africans at the center of Quinn's
four-years-in-the-making documentary. John Bul Dau, Panther Bior and Daniel
Abul Pach, along with thousands of their "brothers," crossed hostile African
terrain in an effort to escape death, slavery and the memories of their
families' murders and destruction.
  Many of the refugees died. The remainder had to make do in the Kenyan refugee
camp at Kakuma, where they are shown erecting a makeshift society while waiting
to have their futures decided.
  Quinn's is a gorgeous looking film, briskly paced and well-edited, perhaps
too well-edited. It doesn't give one a sense of spontaneous difficulty or of
the harsh realities these men must have faced, moving uneasily into mainstream
America.
  Once they are dispatched to various cities in the United States, the
similarities to "Lost Boys" grow closer and closer, and some of this is perhaps
unavoidable: Introducing rustic Africans to the workings of a Pittsburgh
apartment (which is very funny, but we've seen it), or American social
arrangements ("Only one wife," one boy says in bewilderment), or the mysteries
of the corporate logo ("In our country, we call this Coca-Cola," another says,
pointing to a bottle of Pepsi) are  endearing exercises.
  What we don't get is a sense of what it's really like being black Africans in
suspicious white enclaves, even if Quinn reports on some instances of
overreaction on the part of the whites, and the occasional meltdown among their
new neighbors.
  The most complex moment in the movie is the reunion, after many years, of Dau
and his mother. A towering, take-charge figure, Dau greets his mother with open
arms, while the woman emits a high-pitched, traditional keening cry of joy and
gratitude, collapsing in the middle of a runway --- while Dau looks at her with
a mixture of love and embarrassment.
  It's a conflicted moment for everyone, including the audience, and one of the
few where one gets a true sense of just how bizarre it is being a lost boy.

                             The Observer (London)

                                January 1, 2006

Review: CRITICS: FILM OF THE WEEK: How to find a way out of Africa: Radu
Mihaileanu's tale of an Ethiopian boy seeking survival by pretending to be
Jewish is brave and full of suspense

BYLINE: PHILIP FRENCH

SECTION: OBSERVER REVIEW PAGES; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 732 words


LIVE AND BECOME (140 mins, 12A) Directed by Radu Mihaileanu; starring Yael
Abecassis, Roschdy Zem, Sirak M Sabahat.

THERE are several movies in which Jews pose as Gentiles, most especially those
concerned with the Second World War. In Gentleman's Agreement (1947), liberal
reporter Gregory Peck pretends to be a Jew as a means of exposing anti-semitism
in postwar America. In cynical form, the arms dealer played by Nicolas Cage
enters America with his family pretending they are Ukrainian Jews and
immediately signs up with New York's Russian Mafia in Lord of War (2005). Most
painfully in Louis Malle's semi-autobiographical Au Revoir, les Enfants (1987),
Jewish teenagers in Nazi-occupied France are concealed as pupils of a Roman
Catholic boarding school and are accidentally betrayed to the Gestapo.

Radu Mihaileanu, a Jewish film-maker who fled his oppressive native Romania via
Israel in 1980 to work in France, draws on his complicated emotional history
(his communist father changed the family name to obscure the provocative racial
affiliation) in taking the deception in the other direction. The central
character of Live and Become passes himself off as a Jew or, rather, is
propelled by his Ethiopian mother into 20 painful years as an impostor.

The movie begins in 1985 when Mossad, with considerable assistance from the
United States, ran the clandestine Operation Moses to airlift thousands of
starved and persecuted Ethiopian Jews to Israel from refugee camps across the
border in Sudan. These dark-skinned 'indelible immigrants', to use a term coined
by historian Daniel Boorstin, known as the Falasha, are still not fully
assimilated into Israeli society. The nine-year-old hero and his widowed
Christian mother, last survivors of a family destroyed by famine and war, are at
the same camp. When the small son of a Falasha widow dies shortly after being
accepted for transportation, she agrees to take the Gentile boy in his place and
she gives him the name Solomon, or Schlomo.

His mother bids the terrified lad farewell with the words that gives the film
its title: 'Go. Live. Become.' 'Go' is the urgent instruction to find security
in Israel. 'Live' is her counsel to seize a sudden chance to survive and
prosper. 'Become' is more problematic, and the movie is constantly alert to what
it means in a world of emigration and immigration, asylum seeking and economic
migration, where identities are assumed, imposed, blurred and recreated.

The opening section is full of suspense and danger. Can Schlomo convince the
Israeli authorities that he's a Jew? Immediately before his interrogation on
Israeli soil, a boy a few years older has his cover blown and is roughly
escorted from the reception hall, shoved into a car and driven away to be
repatriated. Schlomo gets by, but his ailing surrogate mother dies. A Dickensian
episode follows in which, burdened by guilt and loneliness, he fails to adapt to
life in various orphanages. Finally, he's adopted by a kindly Sephardic
Franco-Israeli couple, extremely well played by French actor Roschdy Zem and
celebrated Israeli actress Yael Abecassis.

These foster-parents, left-wing, semi-secular Jews who initially think the
newcomer has been raised in the orthodox faith, draw the boy out and encourage
their son and daughter to make him welcome. They represent much of what is best
in the state of Israel and protect him from the prejudice, some of it truly
ferocious, to which the Falasha are exposed. These sequences are subtly handled,
with moral force and without sentimentality.

The years pass, Schlomo takes on a new identity, has a Romeo and Juliet -style
love affair with a Jewish girl, works on a kibbutz, experiences the tensions
engendered by the Gulf War and the intifadas and, as part of his journey of
discovery, attempts to contact his mother. At times, melodrama looms and the
film becomes schematic. The years Schlomo spends studying medicine in Paris,
when he becomes aware of how he might transcend his problems and give practical
assistance to his native Ethiopia, are condensed into a couple of minutes with
voice-over dialogue.

Still, Mihaileanu never lets us lose sight of Schlomo's guilt and inner turmoil
as his life becomes a search for healing, redemption and a fully achieved sense
of self. Brave, moving and compassionate, Live and Become deals boldly, yet
sensitively, with issues crucial to our times.

                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                            November 25, 2005 Friday

Refugees reborn in Pittsburgh

BYLINE: Andrew Conte

LENGTH: 810 words


Every day is a blessing for Bare Bule.

More than a decade ago, he ran away from his home in Somalia by walking for 15
days to a refugee camp in bordering Kenya. For food and water, he stripped
leaves from trees and eagerly lapped from muddy puddles of rainwater.

Trapped in the refugee camp, he lived there about a dozen years, meeting his
wife, marrying her and having five children -- two boys and three girls. But
like his home in Somalia, where government soldiers killed his mother, father
and brother, the camp never seemed safe enough.

The glare of ethnic hatred has been no more than a bitter memory for the past
year. Bule and his family were allowed into the United States last year, and
Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Pittsburgh helped them move to the city
along with 30 other Somali Bantu families.

Bule, 42, now lives with his wife and children in a narrow rowhouse along an
alley in Lawrenceville. He has a job turning license plates into handbags at a
Hill District factory. His wife is expecting their sixth child, a boy, in about
two weeks.

Life remains far from perfect for Bule and the other Somali refugees as they
struggle to find jobs and decent homes. But their arrival in Pittsburgh has
given them hope.

"I like America, first of all, because it is free and everybody helps you," Bule
said through a translator. "You see new people, and they say, 'Welcome to
America.' "

Catholic Charities moved 184 Somali Bantus to Pittsburgh over a period of 18
months, starting in February 2004. It's part of an effort that has helped about
11,000 Somali Bantu refugees relocate throughout the United States.

The Bantus are Africans without a nation. They descended from slaves taken to
Somalia from Tanzania and Mozambique in the late 19th century, and became
targets for attack when Somalia disintegrated into civil war in 1991.

The Bantus fled the war by the thousands, walking hundreds of miles to refugee
camps in Kenya.

Pittsburgh has not received Somali Bantu immigrants since September, since the
need for refuge has shifted to Meskhetian Turks fleeing Russia. Catholic
Charities has helped more than 10,000 refugees settle in Western Pennsylvania
over three decades, accepting people from Asia, Africa and Eastern Europe.

"Our goal is self-sufficiency as quickly as possible," said John Miller,
director of Catholic Charities' Refugee Services Program. "We don't have an
approach of letting them sit at home and get used to it. We encourage a fast
assimilation into American life."

Although scattered between Lawrenceville and the North Side, the Somali Bantus
have created a community. They elected a president, vice president and elders.

While they do not expect any new immigrants now, their numbers are growing.
About a dozen Somali Bantu babies have been born in Pittsburgh, and the group
expects to hold its first wedding next month.

Catholic Charities claims about 90 percent of the Somali Bantu men are working
but several said they recently had been laid off. Others -- both men and women
-- have found jobs working together in groups.

Six men work at Little Earth Productions' factory in the Uptown section of the
Hill District, mainly turning recycled license plates into handbags and purses.
They joined a work force that already included refugees from Bosnia, Vietnam and
other places.

"A lot of people who are refugees have a good work ethic," said Ava DeMarco,
owner and co-founder. "It works out well for us because we get great workers and
it provides them with the opportunity to have a job in this country with people
from their country."

Another 15 Somali Bantus work at CleanCare, a laundry for hospital and
hospitality linens, in Lawrenceville and the North Side. Susan Yakim, the
director of human resources, hired one Somali Bantu woman who knocked on the
door looking for work. She ended up hiring others as positions became available,
and now they make up almost 10 percent of the work force.

"They've been a really good addition to our little home," Yakim said.

The Somali Bantu women have been teaching her phrases in their language, and
she's helping them adjust to life in the United States.

"We've started Americanizing them," she said. "They know what a high-five is
now."

Other than getting a day off from work, the Somali Bantus said they didn't plan
any special gathering for Thanksgiving. As Muslims, they recently celebrated
Ramadan, a monthlong period of daylight fasting and small evening dinners.

Yet, they are eager students of another holiday tradition -- American football.

Osman Mohamed, 26, said he has been to one Steelers game at Heinz Field, and he
watches the other games on television.

"Everybody from Africa, if he supports ball, he supports soccer," Mohamed said.
"Now I try to support the Steelers because this is my city now, you know. I'm
supporting my Steelers."

                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                            October 16, 2005 Sunday

'Exodus' in black and white: wrenching photos of displaced world citizens on
display at Library Square

BYLINE: Dave Gagon Deseret Morning News

LENGTH: 863 words


BETWEEN APRIL 6 and July 16 of 1994, a genocide of unprecedented fury and
swiftness washed over the African nation of Rwanda. When it was over, more than
800,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus had been butchered, another 2 million had fled
the country, and another million were displaced.

The world witnessed these 100 days of depravity through newspaper and magazine
reports and TV news: it was horrific and often unbearable to view, and we
wondered at the time, what will happen to the exiles?

Today, the question remains, but is more encompassing; what becomes of all the
displaced refugees throughout the world, devastated by not only war, but by
famine, natural disasters and the widening gap between the rich and poor?

One of the more poignant answers to this query is "Exodus," a visually stunning,
emotionally charged exhibit by international photographer Sebastiao Salgado, on
display through Dec. 17 at The Leonardo at Library Square.

Presented by the Center for Documentary Arts, Salgado's inspiring
black-and-white photographs chronicle the global movement of populations at the
turn of the millennium.

Beginning in 1993, and continuing for the next six years, he worked among
migrants, refugees and exiles across 40 countries in Africa, the Americas,
Europe and Asia. He documented their places of origin, the circumstances of
their flight and their uncertain destinations and destinies.

"Exodus," according to the exhibition essay, "is a reflection on the global
phenomena that has broken down borders, created slums and refugee camps, and
produced conflicts over employment and civil rights around the globe."

Born in 1944 in Aimores, Minas Gerais, Brazil, Salgado studied economics in his
country and the United States. In 1971, he earned a Ph.D. in economics at the
University of Paris. However, in 1973 -- after borrowing his wife's camera -- he
traveled to Africa. The result of this photographic journey was Salgado changed
careers: He became a photojournalist and today is known for his peerless images
of man and his relationship to himself and the land.

Assembled and curated by his wife, Lelia Wanick Salgado, "Exodus" features 300
black-and-white photographs divided into five sections:

-- Migrants and Refugees: The Survival Instinct

-- The African Tragedy: A Continent Adrift

-- Latin America: Rural Exodus, Urban Disorder

-- Asia: The World's New Urban Face

-- The Children: 40 portraits of migrant, refugee and displaced children under
the age of 15 from around the world.

In addition to detailing the aftermath of the Rwanda apocalypse, Salgado's
exhibit tackles the displaced hordes in Angola who camp out near railroad
tracks, in movie theaters, schools or museums, as well as the thousands of
Mozambique exiles living in Tanzania.

"Exodus" also grapples with the Brazilian dilemma of five million rural workers
unable to acquire land to work, and poverty-stricken Mexicans displaced by
Zapatistas.

In the "Migrants and Refugees" section, Salgado starkly depicts the demise of
Kabul, Afghanistan, since the Soviets abandoned the country in the late 1980s.
Each armed faction that has conquered the city has provoked an exodus, and the
images graphically portray just how little is left.

The same section includes a series of photographs of the Vietnamese boat people.
Some 800,000 fled the country and Communist rule, only to wind up in permanent
detention centers in some other Asian country.

During the "Exodus" project in 1994 in Mozambique, Africa, children would
surround Salgado as he worked, hoping to have their picture taken one more time.
According to photographer Kent Miles, exhibit project director, Salgado would
"promise the children if they would line up and wait, he would take their
photograph later."

Eventually Salgado discovered he had so many good portraits of children they
deserved their own section in the show.

As the last segment in the exhibit, "The Children" is a compelling selection of
40 portraits, each with the ability to effect emotion. According to the
photographer, the children look "beautiful, happy, proud, pensive or sad."

The artistry throughout the exhibit is superb, and even though Salgado is
claimed to have been more interested in the message, each photograph is an
extraordinary example of lighting and composition.

Salgado created "Exodus" in the hopes that "as individuals, as groups, as
societies, we can pause and reflect on the human condition at the turn of the
millennium. In its rawest form individualism remains a prescription for
catastrophe. We have to create a new regimen of co-existence."

"Exodus" succeeds on every level, and the Center for Documentary Arts deserves
praise for spearheading the two-year effort to bring this major exhibition to
Salt Lake City. If you go . . .

What: "Exodus -- Photographs by Sebastio Salgado"

Where: The Leonardo at Library Square, 209 E. 500 South

When: Through Dec. 17

Dates/Times: Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday, 10 a.m.-6 p.m.; Wednesday, Friday, 10
a.m.-9 p.m.; Sunday, 1-5 p.m.

How much: $10 for adults; $7 for seniors, military, students, youths (12-17)

Phone: 531-9800

Web: www.theleonardo.org

Also: Not recommended for children under 12 due to mature content E-mail:
gag@desnews.com

                              The Washington Post

                            October 14, 2005 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Edward B. Marks, 94;
Aided World's Refugees

BYLINE: Patricia Sullivan, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Metro; B06

LENGTH: 778 words


Edward B. Marks, 94, who spent more than 50 years helping refugees of war,
disease and politics around the world find new homes, died of heart disease and
renal failure Oct. 8 at his home in Mill Valley, Calif.

Mr. Marks, an urbane and well-traveled man, worked since the 1930s on relief,
resettlement and rehabilitation of refugees on four continents. He hopscotched
around the globe with several government and nongovernmental agencies, turning
up near homeless people in postwar Europe, war-torn Africa and impoverished
Asian countries. He was an administrator who kept his staff focused on the
people who needed their help, a colleague said.

"In some ways, he was the repository of our collective conscience. He really
understood at a gut level what it meant to be a refugee," said Lavinia Limon,
president and chief executive of what is now the U.S. Committee for Refugees and
Immigrants.

Mr. Marks, a New York City native and graduate of Dartmouth College and Columbia
University, began his career as a journalist with the American Wine and Liquor
Journal. But from 1938 on, most of his attention was focused on refugees,
whether displaced by war, famine or governmental actions.

"He just had a genuine interest in people. I can't tell you how many times I
took cabs with him and he'd get into conversations with cabdrivers, ask where
they were from and usually had been to some little place in Africa or Asia,"
said stepdaughter Vivian Barad of San Francisco. "He was just interested in
people and just truly wanted the satisfaction of helping people."

After he received a master's degree in sociology from Columbia in 1938, he was
working at a magazine published by the Welfare Council of NYC. Mr. Marks
interviewed the director of the National Refugee Service for an article about
efforts to place prewar refugees in flight from Adolf Hitler and was offered a
job.

He worked there until 1942, when he joined the War Relocation Authority, the
agency responsible for resettlement of Japanese Americans who had been forced
from their homes on the West Coast by the federal government during World War
II. He worked briefly on public housing and veterans housing after the war
ended, then joined the U.N. International Refugee Organization.

Sent to Athens in 1950, Mr. Marks found thousands of refugees from Romania,
Bulgaria, Albania and Yugoslavia fleeing their homes in search of asylum. He
developed a way to register, examine and prepare refugees for immigration
interviews with representatives of Australia, Canada, Brazil, New Zealand and
the United States.

Mr. Marks stayed on in Greece with the International Organization for Migration
and, in late 1953, returned to the United States to open a New York office,
which was needed to help receive more than 100,000 European refugees preparing
to immigrate. In 1957, Mr. Marks was sent to Yugoslavia to help resettle more
than 20,000 Hungarian refugees.

He took a leave of absence in 1958 to become the first executive director of the
U.S. Committee for Refugees, established to coordinate the efforts of U.S.
agencies on behalf of refugees during the U.N. World Refugee Year.

Mr. Marks joined the Agency for International Development's Africa bureau in
1962 and served in Lagos, Nigeria, during that nation's civil war with Biafra.
He worked in Saigon and London and in the agency's Asia bureau, which required
him to leave his Leesburg home to travel to India, Indonesia, Thailand, South
Korea, the Philippines and Bangladesh.

In 1976, Mr. Marks received the agency's first Distinguished Career Award.

He also worked for UNICEF and became deputy director of the secretariat for the
1979 U.N. International Year of the Child. He was interim president of the U.S.
Committee for UNICEF in 1985, then was elected to the committee's board of
directors.

Throughout his life, he wrote freelance articles for magazines, including the
New Yorker and Playboy. In retirement, he wrote two books about U.N. art and
poster collections and a memoir, "Still Counting: Achievements and Follies of a
Nonagenarian" (2004). With a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, he
produced a radio show that celebrated the American comic song and was broadcast
in the Boston area in the 1990s.

Mr. Marks lived in Leesburg for about 35 years.

His first wife, Margaret Laurens Marks, died in 1980. A son, Thomas Marks, died
in 2003.

Survivors include his wife of 18 years, Vera Barad Marks of Mill Valley; a
daughter from his first marriage, Katharine Marks of Santa Fe, N.M.; a second
stepdaughter, Amelia Barad Humphries of St. Helena, Calif.; a stepson, Michael
Barad of San Francisco; and eight grandsons.

                     The Guardian (London) - Final Edition

                                October 12, 2005
                              Correction Appended

50m environmental refugees by end of decade, UN warns: States urged to prepare
for victims of climate change: Natural disasters displace more people than wars

BYLINE: David Adam, Environment correspondent

SECTION: Guardian International Pages, Pg. 24

LENGTH: 544 words


Rising sea levels, desertification and shrinking freshwater supplies will create
up to 50 million environmental refugees by the end of the decade, experts warn
today. Janos Bogardi, director of the Institute for Environment and Human
Security at the United Nations University in Bonn, said creeping environmental
deterioration already displaced up to 10 million people a year, and the
situation would get worse.

"There are well-founded fears that the number of people fleeing untenable
environmental conditions may grow exponentially as the world experiences the
effects of climate change," Dr Bogardi said. "This new category of refugee needs
to find a place in international agreements. We need to better anticipate
support requirements, similar to those of people fleeing other unviable
situations."

The Red Cross says environmental disasters already displace more people than
war. Such people are currently not recognised under international agreements as
refugees, Dr Bogardi said, so are denied access to assistance received by
victims of violence or political persecution.

Hans van Ginkel, UN under-secretary- general and rector of the university, said:
"This is a highly complex issue, with global organisations already overwhelmed
by the demands of conventionally recognised refugees. However, we should prepare
now to define, accept and accommodate this new breed of refugee."

Environment-related migration has been most acute in sub-Saharan Africa, but
also affects millions of people in Asia and India. Europe and the US face
increased pressure from people driven from north Africa and Latin America by
deteriorating soil and water conditions.

New Zealand has already agreed to accept the 116,000 inhabitants of the
low-lying Pacific island state Tuvalu if rising sea levels swamp the country.
Elsewhere, as many as 100 million people live in areas that are below sea level
or liable to storm surge. A total of 213 communities in Alaska are threatened by
tides that creep three metres further inland each year.

Tony Oliver-Smith, a natural hazards expert at the University of Florida, said:
"Around the world vulnerability is on the increase, due to the rapid development
of megacities in coastal areas. Combine this trend with rising sea levels and
the growing number and intensity of storms and it is a recipe for a disaster,
with enormous potential to create waves of environment-driven migration."

Dr Bogardi called for an intergovernmental panel on environmental degradation to
be established to assess the situation, feed advice to politicians and
distinguish genuine environmental refugees from economic migrants. "If you see a
group of young men trying to climb over a fence, it's very difficult to say
those are environmental refugees, because, if you are an environmental refugee
you bring your whole family with you. The whole population would be on the
move."

There was also a need for international agreements on how individual states
support people who move within a country because of environmental pressures,
such as those who fled the New Orleans region after Hurricane Katrina, he added.
The statement was timed to coincide with the UN day for disaster reduction.

guardian.co.uk/climatechange >

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                   October 5, 2005 Wednesday Michigan Edition

Pitch is sanctuary for war refugee

BYLINE: By MARK BRADFORD; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. C3; HS SOCCER/NOTES

LENGTH: 543 words


Kelvin Zelee's role in Adams' 2-1 win over Penn last week will be just a blip on
his screen when compared to his lifelong battle just to stay alive.

A refugee from war-torn Liberia, Zelee arrived in the United States last year
and immediately found himself at home as part of the Adams soccer team. Now he
is a mainstay on the Eagles' forward line, the possessor of that elusive extra
gear and the aggressiveness to match.

"American soccer players are very talented," Zelee said. "But in Africa, it is
the most popular sport. It is almost a religion. Here, you don't take it so
seriously. Not like you take American football."

Zelee knows he is lucky and he appreciates the help from the United Nations that
brought him over here.

"I don't think my friends appreciate the freedoms they have here in America," he
said. "To the rest of the world, this is like the Garden of Eden."

Conferences wrapping up

Nearly all the conference titles have been decided in local boys and girl soccer
as the regular season ends this weekend and sectionals kick off next Monday.

On the girls side, St. Joseph's, Marian, and Penn each were 7-1 in the Northern
Indiana Conference and all three of them are in the South Bend sectional.
Assuming that no upsets occur, the Saturday matchups between St. Joe and Marian,
and Penn and Adams could give unofficial bragging rights to the conference and
sectional crown in one day.

In the Northern Lakes Conference, Concord won the crown with a 6-0-1 record
after a slow, non-conference start. Goshen and Warsaw are at 4-2-1 after tying
Monday night.

In the Northern Indiana Conference, Culver Academy's strong start was derailed
by Westview last week. Despite the loss, the Eagles were still in charge because
Argos lost to Bethany Christian.

A win Saturday over Trinity gives Culver the conference championship. A loss may
see as many as four teams tie for the title.

On the boys side, Elkhart Central won the NIC crown with a perfect 8-0 mark. But
the Blazers met second-place (7-1) St. Joseph's early in the season and the
Indians have gotten better every week.

The NLC is still up in the air, despite an excellent season by conference
leaders Concord (11-2-2, 4-1-1) and Northridge (9-2-2, 4-1-1) before Tuesday
night's games.

In the NISC, Culver Academy ran away with the title, accumulating a perfect 5-0
mark with one conference game to go. All other teams have lost at least twice.

Among the independents, the Bremen boys team has had a stellar season after a
slow start. The Lions finished the regular season at 13-3-1, including their
first-ever Blueberry tournament championship. On the girls side, the little
school of LaVille continues its winning tradition with an 11-1-1 record. Both of
these small schools may have something to say in the tournament.

Perfect no more

The last undefeated team in the area took the fall on Saturday when Westview
(8-6-0) upended the Culver Academy's girls team, 1-0.

After an 8-0 start, the Eagles are 2-1-2 in their last five games, including
ties with Plymouth and LaVille.

"I have to give my defenders and goalkeeper credit," Westview coach Cecil Miller
said. "I think Culver Academy outshot us about 15-6 but we got one to slip
through and they didn't."

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                           September 8, 2005 Thursday
                                  All Editions

Hurricane opinions

SECTION: Pg. A8

LENGTH: 178 words


Amid the turmoil surrounding the effects of Hurricane Katrina, it seems
superfluous to nitpick over language. And I say this as a certified high school
English teacher.

The subtle differences in con-notation between the words "refugees" and
"evacuees" should not be a bother to anyone right now. However, it seems that
some people, both directly affected by the disaster and not, insist that "
refugee" has a political twinge to it, somewhat reminiscent of Third World
refugees fleeing their homes in Africa and the Middle East. So, we've come up
with an alternative, one that doesn't make us sound quite as poor or helpless as
those in other countries. Here in America, we're not refugees. We're evacuees.

Regardless of the perceived pejoration of the word "refugee," each word's
denotation embodies "one who seeks refuge; one who seeks a safe place." What's
more, both words are especially used for those fleeing war.

So let's not get upset over fellow Americans being called "refugees." Either
way, they are people looking for help. Let us focus on that.

Dusty Lavoie

Milford

Australia leaves door ajar for Uzbek refugees after UN appeal for help

BYLINE: CHRIS JOHNSON

SECTION: GENERAL; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 235  words


CANBERRA

Immigration Minister Amanda Vanstone said yesterday she would consider any
request from the United Nations for Australia to take more refugees on
humanitarian grounds.

Her comment came after calls from the UN's new High Commissioner for Refugees,
Antonio Guterres, that refugees be welcomed as victims of upheaval. In
particular, the UN wants to move hundreds of Uzbek refugees from Kyrgyzstan
camps before they can be forcibly returned to Uzbekistan.

Australia was named as one country that could take some of the 500 Uzbeks who
fled to Kyrgyzstan last month after troops fired into a crowd during an
uprising. Approaches would be made to Australia, New Zealand, the United States,
Canada and several Nordic countries to take some of the Uzbeks.

Despite Australia's tough stance on refugees, Senator Vanstone said the
Department of Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs would consider
all requests. "Australia works closely with the UNHCR in determining those most
in need of resettlement," she said.

"At present, most refugees, about 75 per cent, are coming from camps in Africa.
If at some time the UNHCR makes a specific request to Australia to take refugees
from other areas, that request would be considered by DIMIA and DFAT (Department
of Foreign Affairs and Trade) and responded to promptly.

"Australia's generous refugee and humanitarian program provides places for
13,000 people in need."

                                The Toronto Star

                              June 24, 2005 Friday

Still haunted by Kosovo bombs

BYLINE: Nicholas Keung, Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 707 words


Becoming a refugee is a decision borne of necessity, a path of no return and a
journey of no certainty.

But over the past 50 years, 929,895 asylum-seekers from around the world have
made that decision, chosen that path and taken that journey to Canada.

On Monday, the bravery these refugees have shown in their struggle for freedom
and peace was celebrated on World Refugee Day, proclaimed by the United Nations
five years ago to pay tribute and draw attention to those who leave everything
behind to find safety.

In 2004, 17 million people around the world were regarded as refugees by the
United Nations, including people who are displaced within their countries,
stateless, forcibly returned or seeking asylum: 6.2 million in Asia, 4.2 million
in Africa, 4.2 million in Europe, about 1 million in North America and 1.3
million in Latin America and the Caribbean.

Canada, following the United States and Australia, is among the top three
recipients of people seeking permanent refuge from abroad, with a
government/private sponsorship program that takes in 11,000 each year - on top
of the 20,000 asylum claims a year filed from inside Canada, roughly 40 per cent
of which are granted.

The Star asked five individuals who came to Canada as political refugees to tell
their stories. The five stories have been appearing in the Star this week,
concluding today. Read the entire series and hear audio clips at
www.thestar.com/refugee.

1995-05: Canada offers to take 5,000 refugees affected by the 1999 Kosovo war,
most of them ethnic Albanians.

The sounds of Serbian forces bombing and shooting her fellow Albanians in Kosovo
still haunt Vlora Rrustemi.

The 25-year-old part-time security guard at Pearson International Airport
remembers leaving her family apartment in Pristina on March 30, 1999, with her
father Nexhmi, mother Sexhrije and younger brother Blerim.

They drove toward the Macedonian border, which had already been closed to block
out Albanian refugees. Everywhere, Serbian soldiers were robbing people fleeing
the violence.

It was plain to Rrustemi, an English major at the University of Pristina, and
her family what their fate would be if they stayed. Among the first wave of
refugees fleeing Kosovo's capital, they found refuge in neighbouring Albania for
about three months before arriving in Canada on June 11, 1999, through a private
sponsorship organized by an aunt in Canada.

After several years of English study, Rrustemi has enrolled in a broadcast
journalism program at Seneca College.

It started in the villages first. When the actual bombings started, the Serbian
force just got wild. We couldn't go out, not even to buy food, because they were
just all over. We were just isolated inside in our apartment, with our phone
line and electricity cut off.

Before they came in, you didn't want to wait for the soldiers to come. That'd be
it. We decided to leave.

We just had the clothes we had. We couldn't take nothing. We didn't have time to
take anything else. We were stopped in the village, not sure where they were
sending us. We did not believe they'd lead us to Albania. There were a lot of
cars coming or backing up. People wanted to go back because they were afraid
they were leading us to a mountain to execute all of us.

We were stopped again and again. (The Serbians) stopped and robbed our money,
valuables and jewellery.

It was hard in Canada in the beginning. We were forced to come. As a refugee,
you don't have a choice. I missed home, my friends and everyone there. We came
here and had no idea where our friends, families and relatives were.

There are so many things I like about Canada. In Europe, refugees have no
rights. In Canada, we had rights like everyone else. It's a peaceful country.

One day, I'd love to be a journalist. I believe, in my country at the time, the
wartime, the media played a key role with everything going on. It's the only way
to see the reality. I'd like to get into this (profession) and be one of them.
We don't want wars. I don't wish (anyone to) go through wars, because I still
have nightmares.

I'd like to tell Canada, first, to thank them for their help. We felt welcomed
here. I believe it's the best country in the world. Be a leader. I believe they
are a leader.

                                The Toronto Star

                            June 22, 2005 Wednesday

'Canada is a promised land'

BYLINE: Nicholas Keung, Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 781 words


The 929,895 asylum seekers who have come to Canada from around the world over
the past 50 years represent just a small sample of a global issue.

In 2004, a staggering 17 million people across the world were regarded as
refugees by the United Nations, including individuals who are displaced within
their countries, stateless, forcibly returned or seeking asylum: 6.2 million in
Asia, 4.2 million in Africa, 4.2 million in Europe, 1.3 million in Latin America
and the Caribbean and about 1 million in North America.

Canada, following the United States and Australia, is among the top three
recipients of people seeking permanent refuge. A government/private sponsorship
program takes in 11,000 refugees each year, on top of the 20,000 asylum claims
annually filed from inside Canada, roughly 40 per cent of which are granted.

On Monday, the bravery of those people in their struggle for freedom and peace
was celebrated on World Refugee Day, proclaimed by the U.N. five years ago to
pay tribute and draw attention to those who leave everything behind to find
safety. The theme this year: Courage.

The Star asked five individuals who came to Canada as political refugees, each
representing one of the past five decades, to talk about the fears, joys,
dilemmas, challenges and successes - and their gratitude to the country they now
call home.

The five stories are appearing in the Star daily until Friday.

You can also hear audio versions of the former refugees' stories at
www.thestar.com.

1975-85: Responding to media reports of the "boat people" who fled Vietnam's
communist regime, Canada resettled 60,000 escaping refugees.

When the communist regime took over Vietnam in 1975, it first confiscated the
wealth of the wealthiest, then started attacking middle-class people, including
Lan Ho's parents, Ngan and Nam Ho, who ran a family housewares store in Ca Mau.

The Ho family had been bribing some senior communist officials to ensure their
safety, but that ended when they could no longer afford the increasing demands.
They knew they had to go.

On April 20, 1983, Lan Ho's 17th birthday, the family boarded a tiny boat with
60 other compatriots to start a journey on the Pacific Ocean.

After three days on the open sea, they were rescued by a crew from an oil tanker
and placed in refugee camps in Malaysia, where they stayed for nine months
before first being accepted by France as refugees. They later came to Canada to
be reunited with Lan's older sister in Thunder Bay.

After a decade running the city's Stages bar, which mainly served students from
Lakehead University, Lan Ho, now 40, and her new husband Quang Dao moved to
Toronto. She went back to school in 2000 and now works as a dental assistant in
Mississauga. She is also studying for a diploma in accounting.

My parents were business people. For the communist people, they just didn't like
us. They thought we ripped off the poor people. They assumed that. When they
took over, they went after the very rich, then the level down. They took your
house and kicked you out of the house.

My parents gave money to the high rank people in government to buy peace. They
left them alone. Finally, they were going to do something to my family. They
came and accused my father of arranging a trip to leave Vietnam. After 1979, you
couldn't go freely anymore. You had to escape. We took off in 1983.

I was in the boat exactly on my birthday. I'd never forget that. It was a small
boat for 65 people, really crowded and probably unsafe, too. I don't know how we
fitted in there.

I only had two pants, two shirts, that's all. My mom didn't allow us to bring
anything because it's so dangerous. The policemen were everywhere. If you
carried things around, they would ask and check where you're going.

I was very scared. When you are in the middle of the ocean, you're so small.
Anything can take the lives away with little waves and you're gone. When you are
out there, it's just water and water. It's dark. You don't see anything. It's
scary.

Pirates could come and take all the money and jewellery. Sometimes they took the
young girls, too. I ran into a neighbour, his sister was taken away by some
fishermen and he never saw her again. We were lucky. We were blessed because we
didn't get into anything bad.

The people in Malaysia gave us a number for the boat. Our number was 862. That's
the numbers of the boats in order.

Thank you Canada for giving me the opportunity to have a better life. Look back
in Vietnam, I don't know how I would be under the communist regime. Canada is a
promised land. If you know what you want to do, something that you dream about
and put all your effort into it, you are going to get it. I want to thank Canada
for that.

'People opened their arms'

BYLINE: Nicholas Keung, Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 806 words


Over the past 50 years, 929,895 asylum-seekers from around the world have chosen
to make Canada their new home.

Yesterday the bravery of these refugees was celebrated on World Refugee Day,
proclaimed by the United Nations five years ago. The theme this year: "Courage."

In 2004, there were a staggering 17 million people around the world regarded as
refugees by the UN, including people who are internally displaced within their
countries, stateless, forcibly returned or seeking asylum: 6.2 million in Asia,
4.2 million in Africa, 4.2 million in Europe, about 1 million in North America
and 1.3 million in Latin America and the Caribbean.

Canada, following the United States and Australia, is among the top three
recipients of people seeking permanent refuge, with a government/private
sponsorship program that takes in 11,000 refugees each year - on top of the
20,000 asylum claims a year filed from inside Canada, roughly 40 per cent of
which are granted.

The Toronto Star asked five individuals who came to Canada as political

1965-75: The overthrow of Chile's government in a 1973 military coup brought
7,000 Chilean refugees to Canada.

Marcela and Claudio Duran didn't see it coming.

On Sept. 11, 1973, the couple were getting ready for work as university
professors when they heard sirens coming from the military base near their
Santiago home. Turning the radio on, they were stunned to learn that the
democratically elected government led by Salvador Allende had been toppled.

Former supporters of the leftist government, including intellectuals like the
Durans, immediately became targets of the infamous Augusto Pinochet.

The couple, along with their 6-year-old daughter Francisca and 12-month-old son
Andres, went into hiding at the Canadian consulate, spending 10 days crammed
into the ambassador's house with 20 others in similar straits.

The Durans were among the first group of 25 Chilean refugees flown to Montreal
on Oct. 6, 1973. They moved to Toronto later that month.

Marcela, now 60, and Claudio, 65, never looked back. They relaunched their
academic careers, she as an education professor, he in philosophy, the following
year at York University. Marcela remembers how it was 32 years ago:

There was harsh persecution of everybody that would have been seen or perceived
as supporters of the government. The coup was on Sept. 11. That's our Sept. 11 -
in 1973! Intellectuals were persecuted. They were considered dangerous because
they supported a government that was going to bring an open democratic role to
socialism.

People were taken to prisons, to concentration camps. People were murdered
openly. These things had never happened in Chile in my lifetime, or my parents'
before.

We were very naive. We didn't think that a coup would happen. We were numbed. We
didn't know what it was. It's a very shocking experience, something not
predicted, not in your imagination, only read in newspaper accounts in other
societies.

I was very worried about the whole society. There was a curfew. The city was
occupied by military forces. We were kept under curfew. We heard shootings and,
not knowing what's happening, soon we heard people we knew (had been) taken to
prison, killed and disappeared. Even our president was being killed during the
bombing of the palace. Our house was raided, books were burned and the military
forces said our house would be under surveillance.

A lot of embassies were full of refugees. The government wouldn't let us go but
the Canadian embassy advocated for us.

When I was boarding the flight, the biggest emotion was non-emotion. I was
stunned. I was living a nightmare. It's not real. But survival is important.
Safety for children is important. You are grateful for the safety you're given.

Refugees are survivors. People were extremely kind and generous to us. There's
wonderful solidarity. Some friends had my husband meet with colleagues at U of T
and York University. He started teaching in January 1974. People opened their
arms and hearts to us - that was the experience of most of the refugees.

Surviving and having a good family life, loving relations, is a great
achievement for me in Canada. I think I have contributed as a citizen,
professionally, to train future teachers who are hopefully ethical, equitable
and understand what it means to live in a multiracial and multicultural society.

I'd like to tell Canada: "Thank you." We should continue to understand human
rights, to stand for human rights as a nation, and to continue to lead as an
ethical nation that stands for human rights for all peoples.

                                The Toronto Star

                              June 20, 2005 Monday

'Biggest move in our lives'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A07

LENGTH: 1027 words


Becoming a refugee is a decision borne of necessity, a path of no return and a
journey of no certainty.

But over the past 50 years, 929,895 asylum-seekers from around the world have
made that decision, chosen that path and taken that journey to Canada.

Today, the bravery these refugees have shown in their struggle for freedom and
peace will be celebrated on World Refugee Day, proclaimed by the United Nations
five years ago to pay tribute and draw attention to those who leave everything
behind to find safety. The theme this year: "Courage."

"It takes a lot of guts for people to take the decision to flee their own
countries, to go into the unknown," notes Jahanshah Assadi, Canadian
representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

Toronto will mark World Refugee Day with an all-day concert at Yonge-Dundas
Square, where a wide variety of performing artists and writers, themselves
former refugees, will gather to celebrate the new lives and contributions
refugees have made in Canada. The free show runs between noon and 7 p.m.

They represent just a small sampling of a global problem. In 2004, there were a
staggering 17 million people around the world regarded as refugees by the United
Nations, including people who are internally displaced within their countries,
stateless, forcibly returned or seeking asylum: 6.2 million in Asia, 4.2 million
in Africa, 4.2 million in Europe, about 1 million in North America and 1.3
million in Latin America and the Caribbean.

"However, less than 1 per cent of them will be considered for resettlement, and
we'd like to appeal the affluent countries to continue to be generous with the
number of people they receive," Assadi said.

Canada, following the United States and Australia, is among the top three
recipients of people seeking permanent refuge from abroad, with a
government/private sponsorship program that takes in 11,000 refugees each year -
on top of the 20,000 asylum claims a year filed from inside Canada, roughly 40
per cent of which are granted.

"Canada has had a very impressive record in responding to the global needs,"
Assadi says. "It has a lot to be proud of."

The Star asked five individuals who came to Canada as political refugees, each
representing one of the past five decades, to talk about the fears, joys,
dilemmas, challenges and successes they experienced in their journeys - and
their gratitude to the country that they now call home.

This is an edited excerpt from the first of those interviews. The rest will
appear in the Star on a daily basis until Friday.

You can also hear audio versions of the former refugees telling their stories at
www.thestar.com.

1955-65:

The crushing of the 1956 anti-communist uprising forced more than 200,000
Hungarians to flee.

When Geza Matrai returned to Hungarian soil, 36 years after his escape in the
dark of night, he knelt and kissed the ground.

It was shortly after midnight on Dec. 23, 1956, when his parents, Geza and Kate,
sneaked him and younger sister Judit through the border crossing at Bucsu -
ironically, the name means "goodbye" - to Austria, and freedom.

By then, the Hungarian Revolution, which had broken out on Oct. 23, had been
suppressed by Soviet-led forces. But the real nightmare had just begun, as
secret agents began tracking down and persecuting people who sympathized with
the anti-communist rebellion.

Matrai's veterinarian father and schoolteacher mother, who had treated injured
revolutionaries in Budapest, were among the 37,000 Hungarians Canada took in.
They landed in Quebec on Feb. 11, 1957, and eventually settled in St. Paul,
Alta.

Matrai's abhorrence for the Soviet Union and communists never faded, as he moved
to Toronto to study at the University of Toronto and later led a local movement
promoting the liberation of Eastern Europe in the 1970s.

Now 60 and a social worker in Mississauga, Matrai remained on a Hungarian
government blacklist until the early '90s. In 1992, he finally returned to
Hungary, where he tracked down childhood friends and renewed his memories of
life before the family fled.

The Hungarian secret police were looking for my parents, because they were
helping the Hungarian revolutionaries ... They wanted to give their kids a
future in a country where you don't have to live in constant political terror -
and be free.

Before we left, my parents sat us down and told us: It's going to be the biggest
move in our lives. My father, at this time, was 49 years old. For him, it was
quite a change to start a new life. It was quite an adventure. My mom used the
border pass of a friend's wife and put her own photo on it. So my mom got to get
through the border. The friend took me on a bike as his son.

(In Canada) kids in school called me "bloody DP" (displaced person). There was
some hostility in school here because I was different. But there were kids who
were super helpful and friendly. I had a lot of fights. I had to prove myself.
But for whatever hostility in school, I met people who more than made that up
and became my close friends.

I wasn't allowed to go back to Hungary because of my anti-Soviet and
anti-communist activities. These activities had been the focus of my life until
the early 1990s, with the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe.

It was quite emotional for me to go back to Hungary. I'm 100 per cent Hungarian;
I'm a 100 per cent Canadian. So I'm a 200 per cent person. I love Canada. I'm
grateful to Canada. But I also feel 100 per cent Hungarian. It was just an
emotional feeling to return to Hungary.

I met some of my schoolmates and childhood friends, and I looked at them and
said, "God, they got old."

Last time we saw each other we were 12; this time we're in our 50s. But it felt
like I had never left.Even though communism has collapsed in Eastern Europe,
there's still Cuba, North Korea and China and others under dictatorship. The
evil is not completely gone yet.

We must never forget the people who sacrificed their lives and were oppressed
and suffered and lived through those horrible years.

We, as Hungarian Canadians, are grateful to Canada for giving us a good life,
and a free and just society. We're doing our best to give back to Canada.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    May 15, 2005 Sunday 2 Late Tampa Edition

EASING REFUGEES' TRANSITION;
 Refugees get advice, services

BYLINE: DEMORRIS LEE

SECTION: TAMPA & STATE; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 680 words

DATELINE: TAMPA


They chased each other. They drew pictures, ate ice cream and won door prizes.

But behind the twinkling eyes and cheeks daubed with flowers at the
face-painting table, one could still see vestiges of struggle in the faces of
these children who've come so far and been through so much.

The struggle of having to leave your entire life behind. The struggle of playing
hopscotch with a friend one day and then never seeing her again.

Saturday, members of Lutheran Services Florida tried to help soften the
transition for about 100 refugees by hosting a Refugee Health Fair at its
facility at the corner of W Waters Avenue and N Dale Mabry Highway.

The fair included blood pressure and weight screenings, personal safety
instructions in three languages from the Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office
and children's health information.

The children from Somalia, Croatia, Columbia and a few other countries had their
heads fitted for bicycle helmets and ate goodies from red and green gift bags
while their parents tended to the business of putting their lives back together
in America.

"This is very, very much better, living here in America than where we were,"
said Hamida Ibrahim, 31, of Somalia. "In the (refugee) camp, there was a lot to
be afraid. America is better, not afraid here."

Through the use of a translator, Ibrahim said she and her family had lived in a
refugee camp in Kenya since 1999, before coming to America with her five
children in November. She said during the political turmoil in Somalia she
walked to Kenya for safety. She said Saturday's fair was helpful.

"Through this, we gain some more knowledge," she said. "There is much to learn."

The Tampa Bay area is scheduled to settle about 500 refugees this year, said
Rosa Rivera Mizzoni, director of Immigration and Refugee Services for Lutheran
Services Florida. Refugees must prove that they have a well-founded fear of
persecution based on race, religion, membership in a social group, political
opinion or national origin.

Each year, the U.S. president, along with Congress, sets the number of refugees
to be admitted to the country for resettlement. In fiscal year 2004, the number
was set at 70,000 admissions, but that many refugees have not been able to make
it to the country. In fiscal year 2002, 27,000 were admitted.

Mizzoni said that the Tampa Bay area has an "eclectic" mix of refugees,
including Vietnamese, Africans and Russians. She said it's important for the
newcomers to know how things work, their rights and the importance of health.
Bringing together other agencies such as the Department of Health, the Epilepsy
Services of West Central Florida and Amerigroup, which provides low and no-cost
health care to eligible families, is important.

"There is a rhythm to functioning in the United States," Mizzoni said. "We are
constantly reteaching them because for a while, everything is new. But the
minute they get the timing, things start working."

Deputy Juan Gonzales works with the Sheriff's Office of Refugee Resettlement,
which is funded by a federal grant. He was explaining the law enforcement system
to a Croatian family Saturday.

"In America, there are 25 guns for every one citizen," Gonzales said via a
translator to the family. "Having guns is a right that the Founding Fathers
provided for Americans. But if you can purchase a gun, come see me because I
have safety locks for them."

Gonzales went on to say: "It takes a lot of courage to leave everything and
start a new life. I respect you for that."

Alexander Ramirez of Columbia was at Saturday's fair and has been in the United
States since 2000. As his child pulled on him to go see Grimace and the
Hamburglar from McDonald's and to see if they were winners of the raffle, he
agreed that starting anew was difficult.

"It's very hard because it's a different culture, economic system, different
everything," Ramirez, 36, said. "But it's a safer place and that's what I was
looking for, a safer place to raise my children."

Demorris Lee can be reached at (813) 269-5312 or dalee@sptimes.com.

                     The Guardian (London) - Final Edition

                                 April 27, 2005

Society: Warm heart of steel: A UN programme aims to resettle 500 refugees a
year in the UK. But political jitters have led to only two councils signing up
to the scheme. Alison Benjamin reports

BYLINE: Alison Benjamin

SECTION: Guardian Society Pages, Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1165 words


As she walked back from her first trip to the supermarket, Esther Freeman became
aware of people staring at her incredulously. She could not understand why. "I'd
just got off the bus with these three heavy bags full of juices and things," she
recalls. "It was really hard carrying them with my hands, so I put one of the
plastic bags on my head."

It was not until her support worker from the Refugee Council explained the
conventions of shopping in Britain that the penny dropped.

"In Africa we always put things on our heads, but I'll never do it again,"
Freeman says, roaring with laughter.

Freeman arrived in Britain last April with three of her children after fleeing
civil war in Liberia, west Africa. The family was one of the first to be
accepted by the Home Office under the United Nations High Commission for
Refugees (UNHCR) Gateway programme, a scheme that has resettled tens of
thousands of refugees in the US, Canada and Australia.

Other countries, including New Zealand, Norway and the Netherlands, have each
taken several hundred, and the British government was hoping that in the
programme's first year of operation here, 500 refugees would be welcomed.

But the hostile political climate surrounding asylum seekers and refugees has
disrupted these plans. Only two councils - Labour-controlled Sheffield, and
Liberal Democrat-led Bolton - agreed to take part, and just 150 refugees have
arrived in the past 12 months.

The first Freeman knew that she was going to live in Sheffield, England's fourth
largest city, was when she and her children were put on a coach two days after
arriving at Heathrow one grey, cold morning last April. Their 20-strong group
was met by the Refugee Council, which won the Home Office contract to provide a
year's worth of support for the 69 Liberians, including setting up bank accounts
for those without conventional ID.

In addition, the city council pulled together a multi-agency team to ensure that
the job centre, GPs, housing associations and schools were all ready to accept
the families and meet their needs.

When Freeman, who with her family had spent eight years in a refugee camp in
Guinea, first set eyes on her family's new home - a three-bedroom flat in the
south of the city - she remembers turning to her support worker, Adam Hoti, and
saying: "Thank you God. Let us pray." Electricity and running water were a
distant memory to her, and the younger children had never slept in a bed.

An optimistic, warm-hearted person with a strong Christian faith, Freeman and
her children, Newman, 17, Florida, 13, and her twin Florence (who was reunited
with the family in Sheffield in January, having been separated by war) and
seven-year-old Mike appear to have adjusted well to their new life. Freeman has
a part-time job as a care assistant in a residential home for older people and
is learning about Sheffield's industrial heritage at the same college where
Newman is taking his A-levels. The younger children have made friends at school
and at the local evangelical church.

The council has shielded the newcomers from any potentially hostile reception by
keeping under wraps the location of their home and school, and employers' names.
It has also tried to draw a distiction between Liberian refugees and asylum
seekers. "Those who arrive in Sheffield will already have refugee status. They
have been through health screening and are in a position to start integrating
into our community straight away," said council leader Jan Wilson, welcoming the
first arrivals.

Moreover, Sheffield has a cross-party members' advisory group on refugees and
asylum seekers which seeks to prevent the usual gripes about jumped housing
waiting lists and benefit claims from being turned into a political football.
Sheffield council's asylum team manager, Belinda Gallup, says of the programme:
"The money comes (from the Home Office) with the refugees so they are not a
drain on health or education."

The council also says that because the 20 homes rented by the Liberians are all
in areas of low demand, they are not queue-jumping. In Bolton, where a further
87 Liberian and Congolese refugees arrived five months ago, the council has a
portfolio of 160 properties, half of them owned by private landlords, that are
used only for asylum seekers and refugees.

Jon Lord, Bolton council's head of community housing services, says this means
local lettings are not affected.

This has not stopped critics from attacking the council for putting refugees
before residents. Such views have led other councils to fight shy of joining the
Gateway programme. Earlier this year, a plan by Liberal Democrat-led Devon
county council to house 10 refugee families in Exeter were dropped after the
local Labour MP, Ben Bradshaw, made the the Home Office aware of the housing
pressures the city faced.

Expanding the programme remains an uphill struggle for the Home Office, which
remains committed to accepting 500 refugees a year under the Gateway scheme and
has turned to Scotland for help. "We have always said that we want to do this in
partnership with local authorities and continue to work hard to encourage local
authorities to participate," says a Home Office spokeswoman. Talks are being
held with three other local authorities, but she declined to give further
details.

Councils could find themselves in difficulty should the Conservatives form the
next government, since a central plank of the Tory party's immigra tion and
aslyum proposals are to expand the programme and make it the only channel by
which an annual quota of refugees could enter Britain. A Conservative party
spokeswoman states: "We're supportive of the scheme that takes genuine refugees
already selected by UNHCR and our ultimate aim is to only take refugees in this
way."

But UNHCR could scupper such plans. It has said it would consider withholding
cooperation from a Tory government that withdrew from the Geneva convention on
refugees. Commenting on the Gateway programme's limited success in the UK, UNHCR
urges patience. "It is too early to cast stones at authorities," says a
spokesman.

Bolton says it is considering whether to take more Gateway refugees. In the
run-up to the general election, Sheffield is more circumspect. Whatever the
programme's future, Freeman wants to dispel the myth that refugees are here for
state handouts.

"Refugees do contribute to the welfare of this country. It is wrong to think
they only come to live off benefits. Many are working very hard."

She plans to advance her employment prospects and take care of her children. "If
I see my son in college (he hopes to study engineering) I will say, 'British
government, thank you'."

Weblinks

Refugee Council is at www.refugeecouncil.org.uk

United Nations High Commission for Refugees is at www.unhcr.ch

Sheffield city council is at www.sheffield.gov.uk

Bolton metropolitan borough council is at www.bolton.gov.uk
