                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                     October 28, 2001 Sunday, Final Edition

ATTACKS ON U.S. IMPERIL REFUGEES' ALREADY THIN HOPES;
For many, the fragile and tantalizing dreams of American freedom are suddenly
uncertain.

BYLINE: MEREDITH GOAD Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 3438 words

DATELINE: Portland


Ben Omal and his brother, Charles Okongo, had lived their whole lives running
away from war and terrorism in rural Africa. On Sept. 12, terror once again
tried to keep them from their families and freedom.

They had gathered their few belongings and were excitedly awaiting their first
plane ride - one that would take them from their mud huts in Uganda to a Munjoy
Hill apartment in Portland - when immigration authorities announced that they
and other African refugees would not be able to leave that day after all.

"They said, 'OK, there is problem in New York. Everybody cannot go,' "recalled
Ben Omal, 26.

The two brothers had never heard of the World Trade Center, but they feared a
terrorist attack in New York might prevent them from reuniting with their
parents, brothers and sisters in Maine.

"We thought that things cannot even happen this way," Ben Omal said.

Last-minute disappointments are a way of life for many refugees as they flee
their homelands, languish in camps, and struggle to find their way to America.

The events of Sept. 11 have added to that disappointment, temporarily slowing
the usual flow of refugees into this nation because of wartime priorities and
restrictions on travel for immigration authorities.

The story of refugees' journeys to their new home in the United States is filled
with frustration, sorrow and separation from loved ones.

Among Ben and Charles' first visitors on their arrival in Portland was a cousin,
Ben Kanga, who in 1990 became one of the first Sudanese refugees to resettle
here after fleeing that country's civil war.

Kanga was the first link in the chain of people who immigrated to Maine. Over
the years, the immigrants have included not only his cousins, but also other
family members and friends - all of whom originally came from the same village
in Sudan and ended up in Portland, half a world away.

The soldiers came in the darkness, pounding on doors and demanding confessions.

"At about 4 a.m. a big area like Munjoy Hill would be surrounded," said Ben
Kanga, recalling life in Sudan just before he fled to Kenya. "Then they search
house to house. They arrest all the students and put them in jails. They beat
them."

Kanga was born in a large village in the south called Pajok, near the border of
Uganda, a place where people still live without electricity and cultivate their
own food. When he was old enough, Kanga left the village and started attending
school in Juba, a nearby city.

By 1988, the civil war began to escalate in southern Sudan. When soldiers
started rounding up male students over the age of 16, Kanga worried he would be
next. As the rebel army pushed closer to the city, mortar shells crashed around
him.

Kanga, his daily existence now shadowed by fear, decided he had to leave Sudan.
He became a refugee.

Refugees are people who have a well-founded fear of persecution if they return
to their native countries, and there are now millions of them worldwide. Many
would prefer to go home if they could, but the threat of torture and death is
too great.

"Refugees did not decide they wanted to leave their village," said Matthew Ward,
director of Catholic Charities Maine refugee and immigration services. "They
left because somebody was trying to kill them. If there was a flood in your
country and everything was destroyed and you left, you're not a refugee. If
there was a famine, you're not.

"Every single one of them is a trauma survivor," he said. "The greatest traumas
that you can live through in life are loss of a loved one, loss of your home and
loss of your homeland, and refugees have done all of those."

Today, one in 269 people on the planet are refugees or asylum seekers, according
to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The UNHCR is charged with
protecting the rights and well-being of refugees, helping them seek asylum,
resettle in another country, or return to their own country.

Kenya became Kanga's "country of first asylum," the place where the United
Nations granted him legal refugee status after fleeing Sudan.

After entering the country of first asylum, refugees can apply to be resettled
elsewhere. The United States is one of 10 countries that offers resettlement
through community-based, charitable organizations such as Catholic Charities
Maine.

The U.S. president decides at the beginning of each fiscal year, in consultation
with Congress, which countries refugees will come from during the next 12
months. During the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, for example, the ceiling for
the number of refugees who could enter the country was set at 80,000.

After arriving in Portland in 1990, Ben Kanga settled into an apartment on
Merrill Street on Munjoy Hill.

Once in Maine, there was little communication with friends and relatives back in
Africa. Once in a while, he'd get a letter from immigration authorities saying
that someone in one of the refugee camps had listed him as a reference on an
immigration application.

"Immediately I would sign it and give it back to them, and say 'Yeah, I need
these people to come here,' " Kanga said.

At that time, Kanga could vouch for just about anyone who wanted to follow him
to the United States, even distant cousins.

Today, the rules have changed.

The U.S. resettlement program now categorizes refugees in terms of need. Anyone
who is in danger in their country of first asylum - say, an Afghan refugee in
Pakistan who is outspoken against the Taliban - is considered first priority.

Next are groups of special humanitarian concern, such as the "lost boys of
Sudan."

Many Sudanese refugees who come to Portland fall into a third category - people
who have close relatives in the United States. A close relative is a spouse,
parent or unmarried son or daughter.


Helen Abwoch had no relatives living in the United States when she first came
here in 1995. It wasn't until she was being interviewed by immigration
authorities in Africa that she discovered an unexpected connection to Portland.

Her story begins in 1993, when she and her four children found themselves at
home alone in Juba because her husband had gone into hiding. The government
suspected he had been listening to forbidden radio broadcasts, and now she found
herself fending off soldiers at her door.

The soldiers said " 'Tell us where he is,' " she recalled. " 'If we don't find
him, you will have to answer for that.' "

Her husband was eventually arrested and beaten, his name added to a "death
list." After two to three days, a friend helped him escape; then they returned
for the family.

The family left Juba at midnight, walking toward a border city controlled by the
Sudan People's Liberation Army. Helen Abwoch was nine months pregnant. The
family's friend scouted ahead for trouble.

"It was a quiet night, calm," she said. "He would leave us a distance. Go ahead
and listen, listen. Watch. There was nothing. It was a bright moonlight."

The family found transportation to Magwi, a border town. There she delivered her
baby - a girl, Linda - and the family left for Kenya "when the baby was good to
walk with."

They landed in Ifo, the same refugee camp in Kenya where Ben Kanga had lived;
they stayed there for the next two years.

Life in this camp was a scary mixture of hunger, disease and danger. The United
Nations handed out a large cup of beans per person every two weeks, along with
some oil and corn flour. Refugees scavenged for firewood for cooking in the
unpredictable bush. Some people pooled their rations to try to stretch them, but
no one ate more than once a day. They ate not to be full but to keep themselves
alive.

Abwoch's 7-year-old daughter Lucy, weakened by hunger, contracted yellow fever
in the camp and died.

Some families formed groups for protection from bandits who raided the camp at
night. They'd fence an area with trees, then take turns standing guard in the
darkness.

Eventually, Helen Abwoch and her family were able to begin the long process of
coming to America, a process that begins by applying for resettlement with the
United Nations.

Once the United Nations decides that a refugee meets its resettlement criteria,
a local voluntary agency takes over the job of processing paperwork and, if the
refugee is being resettled in the United States, setting up interviews with
Immigration and Naturalization Service officials. In Africa, an organization
called the Joint Voluntary Agency performs this service.

When word gets out that immigration officials will be coming to an area, a
nervous excitement builds in refugee settlements in Africa and immigrant
communities in Portland. Everyone prays that their name - or a relative's name -
will be on an interview list posted on a board in the camp. For some, it is the
first real sign of hope for a new life.

Rumors about life in the United States - some good, some bad - are rampant in
refugee camps.

Above all, people want to know that their new home will be safe.

"Most refugees, because of their history, are obsessed with law and order and
safety," said Ward of Catholic Charities. "A safe place to live - and you hear
this all the time - is more important than a job, it's more important than
schools."

Ben Kanga has been asked about everything from the walking distance to school in
Portland to the frequency of drive-by shootings in the United States. One rumor
is that white and black people in America live in separate communities, he said,
"and when one crosses over to where the other one lives, you'll be killed or
you'll be beaten."

After a medical exam and security check, the International Organization for
Migration takes over the immigration process and makes the refugee's travel
arrangements to America.

Although refugees have no choice where they will end up, many say they would
like to go to California or New York because those are the places they've heard
most about in the camps. In cases of family reunification, the refugee goes to
where the family is living. Others could go anywhere.

In 1995, Helen Abwoch found herself sitting in front of immigration officers who
were asking where the family might like to live in the United States, reciting a
litany of possibilities from Colorado to Maine.

Abwoch heard the word "Portland," and it sparked a glimmer of recognition. She
knew someone in Portland. She had gone to school with a boy named Ben Kanga, and
she knew his parents in Pajok, the village where she was born. They were more
like acquaintances than friends, but still it was someone.

Send us to Portland, she said.

When Abwoch and her family landed at the Portland International Jetport, there
were two people waiting to welcome them - a Catholic Charities caseworker and
Ben Kanga.

Refugees who want their relatives to join them in Maine must fill out a form
called an affidavit of relationship, or AOR, listing all refugee relatives
overseas, "anywhere in the world, living, deceased or missing."

"The AOR form is a form that lets the government know that someone's willing to
take you in," said Beth Stickney, executive director of the Immigrant Legal
Advocacy Project.

Once she reached the United States, Helen Abwoch filled out an affidavit of
relationship for her remaining relatives. The form matter-of-factly documents
her family's sad history.

Her father, Joseph Ochan Apollo: Deceased. Her brother, Selestino Oling Apollo:
Deceased. Her sisters, Sabina Agut Apollo, Albira Akumu Apollo and Christine
Aloyo Apollo: All missing.

Still alive and awaiting a chance to come to the United States are her mother, a
brother, a niece and a nephew.

At night, Abwoch dreams about her mother, Seconda Ayero Apollo, whom she has not
seen in 15 years.

"How can a person in the world live for over 10 years without seeing the
mother?" she said. "It's very hard. It's like I live on one planet and she's on
another planet. Sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night because I've been
thinking, thinking about how to see her."

Abwoch lost track of her mother after the death of her brother, who was killed
by government soldiers for speaking English instead of Arabic. In 1995, just as
she was about to leave for America, she heard her mother was in the Kiryandongo
refugee settlement in Uganda. There was no time to make contact with her, so
before she boarded the plane in Nairobi she mailed a letter.

She has been in touch with her mother by letter and phone ever since. Over the
years she has prayed daily that her mother would be able to join her in
Portland, and she viewed it as an answered prayer when Seconda Apollo's name
appeared on the volunteer agency list in May.

But she was in for yet another disappointment.

Seconda Apollo had no money to get to Kampala for her interview. Her daughter
had sent her $50, but it did not arrive in time. Apollo borrowed money from her
cousin, but by the time she arrived in Kampala it was too late. Officials had
opened a file for her, but they were closing up shop the next day and moving on;
there was no time to process her paperwork.

Apollo had to return to Kiryandongo.

Helen Abwoch still hopes that her mother will come to the United States soon.
Immigration authorities initially said the earliest she could arrive is December
or January, but with the complications of the conflict in Afghanistan, it's
anyone's guess.

President Bush's planned signing of the refugee authorization act was delayed
because of the terrorist attacks, and the INS curtailed all nonessential travel
by its employees. The INS circuit riders who travel to refugee camps and other
out-of-the-way places to conduct refugee interviews are temporarily out of
commission.

"If the president signs (the authorization), we expect to see some people moving
on in, but not a whole lot," said Lavinia Limon, executive director of the U.S.
Committtee for Refugees in Washington, D.C. "And the longer INS is not
interviewing in any areas, then the less the numbers are later on down the
road."

When Seconda Apollo does arrive, she'll be meeting her grandchildren for the
first time. Linda, the daughter born to Helen Abwoch just before she fled Sudan,
is 9 years old and a fourth-grader at Riverton School.

"If my mom lets us, we can give her a welcome party," Linda said, shyly
clutching a stuffed animal. "We can show her around the house and show her all
the different things we've been learning in school.

"I would ask her if the war in Sudan is still going," she said.

Lina Alonyo had not seen her cousin Ben Kanga since he was a student and came
home to their village on school vacation. When Pajok was attacked in 1989, it
seemed as if she might never see him again.

Leaving everything behind, she and her family walked 50 miles to the Ugandan
border and settled in a small village.

Ugandan rebels kidnapped her husband, Ochilo Adong, and forced him into labor -
cooking, and carrying their gear to the front lines.

Lina Alonyo was left to take care of seven young children.

"Life was so unbearable because I was only a woman who was not used to doing
things that men are supposed to do," she said. "My kids were still young. They
could not even do anything, so we go and cultivate land, even with the young
ones."

Ochilo Adong was held captive for a year, until one day he crossed a river and
made a daring escape.

The family landed in Kiryandongo, where they were given small plots of land to
grow maize, cassava, sorghum and sweet potatoes. But infertile soils and drought
made farming there difficult.

Meanwhile, the couple's older daughter, Betty, had found her way to the United
States. And when Betty learned that her parents were living in Kiryandongo, she
immediately wrote them a letter to try to find out if they were OK.

"When we got that letter we were so happy because we know at least one person
has managed to go to a better place," said Alonyo. Until that moment, she had
had no idea what had happened to Betty or that she was living in Arlington, Va.

In the days after reconnecting with her parents, Betty and her husband, Charles,
had many phone conversations with Ben Kanga, who told them about the safety of
Portland. They decided to move to Portland in August 2000.

Betty's parents soon followed and arrived from Africa just a month later. They
could not bring their two oldest sons, Ben and Charles, because they were both
over 21. As adults, they were not eligible for sponsorship by their sister.

The brothers went with their family to the Entebbe airport the day they left for
Maine.

"They told them to leave, and everybody was crying," Ben Omal said. "They
thought that maybe we were remaining forever."

When Lina Alonyo and Ochilo Adong arrived in Portland in September 2000,
Catholic Charities helped them find an apartment on Merrill Street, just down
the street from where Ben Kanga lived when he first came to the United States.
They got jobs at Goodwill Industries of Northern New England, and regularly sent
part of their paychecks to their sons in Uganda. When they could, they talked to
their sons on the phone.

"They tell me they miss me very much," Alonyo said last spring. "I feel so bad
that I left them behind. Sometimes when I think about it a lot, it comes as a
pain to me."

Early in the summer, the brothers passed their medical exams. They sat through
cultural orientation classes that taught them what life is like in America.

"Do not bribe police," Ben Omal recalled being told in his class. "When you are
driving a car, you have to tie your belt."

On Sept. 12, Ben and his brother showed up with meager belongings, ready to fly,
unaware that terrorists had attacked the World Trade Center.

"We were innocent about it," he said.

Told to keep checking back, Ben and Charles worried that the terrorist attacks
meant they might never be able to rejoin their family. Finally, on the 24th,
they took their first plane ride and left Africa and their old life behind.

The brothers weren't the only ones whose lives were disrupted by the events of
Sept. 11. Some refugees never got off the ground; others found themselves
diverted to Canada. All the refugees who were destined for Portland during
September - the busiest month for refugee arrivals - did eventually make it
here, but many arrived without their luggage.

"I would say almost everybody who arrived in September arrived without the few
belongings that are emotionally very important to them," said Matt Ward of
Catholic Charities.

Ben and Charles landed at the Portland Jetport around 11 p.m. on the 26th.

Normally, refugee arrivals are warm, welcoming affairs, with both family members
and a Catholic Charities caseworker showing up at the airport. But in the
confusion following the terrorist attacks, no one showed up to greet Ben and
Charles. The brothers did not even have enough money to call their parents from
Africa to let them know they were coming.

They went to the police at the Jetport, and an officer phoned Charles Otim,
their brother-in-law, to come pick them up.

Until they can get their Social Security cards and find their own apartment and
jobs, they are staying in their parents' four-bedroom apartment, bringing the
number of people living there to nine.

It's a difficult adjustment going from working as hard as you can just to stay
alive to living in an American apartment with nothing to do.

"When we remain alone like this, we can feel bad," Ben Omal said. "We remain
sleeping sometimes."

While their parents are at work, the two brothers hang out at home, watching
cartoons and news coverage of the war in Afghanistan on a television equipped
with closed captioning. Sometimes they walk down to East End Beach, but they
can't stay long because they aren't used to the cold.

Ben said he is surprised by the lack of gardens in Portland - "Here, people
cannot even dig" - and he is looking forward to seeing the cold winters his
family has told him about.

"I have never seen what they call snow," he said.

Ben still remembers the exact date his family fled Sudan: March 3, 1989.

He recalls searching through piles of dead bodies for his father after hearing a
rumor that he had been killed. He says he will never go back to Sudan.

"I cannot go," he said. "I will not go back."

His parents do want to return someday, but not now.

"Even if the peace comes, I know that peace will not be real peace, not
immediately at least," Lina Alonyo said. "We have seen a lot of suffering with
our children, and we don't want to go through it again. We just want to stay
here and make it our home."

Staff Writer Meredith Goad can be contacted at 791-6332 or at:

mgoad@pressherald.com

                                   USA TODAY

                   October 17, 2001, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Afghans can't eat dollars

BYLINE: Jack Leslie

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15A

LENGTH: 646 words

President Bush has asked each of America's children to donate a dollar to help
Afghan refugee families, a commendable action. But money by itself is not
enough.

If hundreds of thousands of lives are to be saved in and around Afghanistan, the
United States needs to build a coalition of governments, foundations and
corporations to provide Afghanistan with humanitarian aid and supplies -- and to
exert pressure to ensure that international relief workers are able to help
those in need.

Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf joined the alliance against terrorism after
the United States made it clear that it was time for him to choose sides in this
new war. He did so at considerable political risk, as did others in the Muslim
world who knew that would prompt violent anti-American protests and governments
would have to respond quickly and forcefully to maintain stability.


We have meticulously sought cooperation on the use of airspace and territory for
waging war. But we are falling short -- woefully short -- on seeking
international cooperation in waging a campaign to assist millions of refugees in
and around Afghanistan.

Right now, we do not even fully understand the magnitude of the refugee crisis,
because the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), which
oversees relief efforts, cannot get its personnel into the most affected areas.
Both Pakistan and Iran have sealed their borders to refugees. In Pakistan, U.N.
personnel are confined to their offices because of security concerns. Most U.N.
workers left Afghanistan several weeks ago, following the Taliban's decree that
they do so, and angry mobs burned a UNICEF office on the border of Pakistan.
Only a few have been able to return, and those who have face new dangers from
the Taliban.

Lives slip away

Earlier this month, the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Ruud Lubbers,
publicly expressed his frustration, saying this battle to save lives is being
lost. Relief agencies can now get very little food, water and medical care to
where it is most desperately needed. While the well-publicized U.S. airdrops are
laudable, they are woefully inadequate, especially as the harsh Afghan winter
approaches.

In the past, Pakistan and Iran have been generous in cooperating with
international relief agencies. Since the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979,
both countries opened their borders and hosted millions of refugees. Before
Sept. 11, more than 2 million Afghan refugees were already living in camps in
Pakistan. But Pakistan now is balking at allowing UNHCR to set up refugee camps
in areas where they can be adequately supplied.

Uneasy truce dissolves

I have visited the refugee camps in Pakistan, and I traveled through the Khyber
Pass to Kabul to meet with the Taliban just before the 1998 bombings of U.S.
embassies in Africa. At the time, there at least was an uneasy peace between the
Taliban, the Pakistan government and international relief organizations.
Although we could hear the shelling on the front line with the Northern Alliance
outside Kabul, supplies were getting through. But that no longer happens.

We have heard many times in the past month that this war is different from all
others we have fought. One element of it remains the same, however: It will
result in millions of refugees caught in the crossfire. Most of these victims of
war are barely subsisting, and many are dying in lands far from here.

The international community must make the same effort to join together for
humanitarian relief as it has for waging war on terrorism. Financial support is
not enough if political support does not exist.

Jack Leslie is chairman of the board of the United States Association for the
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, a private, Washington-based
charity that supports the UNHCR.

                            The Independent (London)

                          September 29, 2001, Saturday

HAIDER: KEEP OVERSEAS REFUGEES OUT OF EUROPE AUSTRIA'S HAIDER SLAMMED FOR ANTI-
REFUGEE TALK

BYLINE: Stephen Castle In Brussels Haider: Stop refugee flow

SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 515 words


AUSTRIA'S NOTORIOUS far-right populist, Jorg Haider, reasserted his well
-documented hostility to foreigners yesterday, with demands that non-Europeans
should be banned from seeking asylum in his country.

In comments that brought swift condemnation from human rights organisations, Mr
Haider argued that refugees from other continents should no longer be granted
residence in Europe while their requests were being processed. They should wait
in "safe third states" in Asia or Africa, he said.

Mr Haider, former leader of the far-right Freedom Party, has a long track record
of similar views and it will surprise few that he has sought to take advantage
of the aftermath of the attacks on America. He remains governor of the southern
Carinthia province, but handed the leadership of the Freedom Party to Susanne
Riess -Passer in May last year. Peter Westenthaler, who leads the Freedom Party
faction in parliament, said Mr Haider's demands reflected those of the party
leadership.

Human rights organisations reacted quickly. Heinz Patzelt, a spokesman for the
Austrian chapter of Amnesty International, described the proposal as "totally
contrary to human rights, existing (national) law and international law".

He accused Mr Haider of abusing current fears caused by the terrorist attacks in
the United States "to derive political advantage under the title of a 'fight
against terrorism'."

Beat Schuller, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
in Austria, also rejected Mr Haider's plan, saying: "Clearly, we are shocked."
Mr Haider had put into question "the whole catalogue of human rights", he added.

European MPs also reacted with outrage. Simon Murphy, Labour leader in the
European Parliament, said: "This flies in the face of the fundamental values
underlying the EU. We are a community based on shared values of tolerance,
democracy and respect for human rights."

Mr Haider's past praise of aspects of the Nazi regime and his xenophobic and
anti-EU statements prompted temporary diplomatic sanctions against Austria last
year, when the Freedom Party was added to the coalition government.

The government's biggest party distanced itself from Mr Haider's views
yesterday. The interior Minister, Ernst Strasser, a member of Chancellor
Wolfgang Schossel's Austrian People's Party, argued: "Here in Austria, we adhere
to the constitution."

Andrea Kuntzl of the opposition Social Democratic Party, said Mr Haider and Mr
Westenthaler were abusing the "terrible terrorist attacks in the United States
for xenophobic sentiments and an anti-foreigner campaign at the lowest level."
Theresia Stojsits, a champion of foreigners' rights in the opposition Green
Party, said Mr Haider's comments were sickening.

Austria, now regarded as a country tough on asylum-seekers, has a postwar
history of accommodating refugees. It fed and sheltered about 90,000 from
Bosnia, who fled the war in the Balkans in the 1990s, and accepted thousands
from Latin America, Africa, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iraq and other developing
countries.

                        Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)

                    September 16, 2001 Sunday Final EDITION

U.S. justifiably worried about Canada's immigration policy

BYLINE: Diane Francis

SOURCE: The Financial Post

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. E5

LENGTH: 1226 words

DATELINE: TORONTO


America's pledge to punish as accessories countries where terrorists reside
should start with its naive neighbour, Canada.

Canada must get its act together when it comes to immigration and refugee
policies. Now it's apparent our policies and malpractices constitute a national
security threat to the United States.

For instance, on Sept. 23, 1997, I published a column in the Financial Post,
citing Interpol sources, that dozens of Algerian terrorists were living in
Montreal, posing as refugees.

Nothing happened.

Then 27 months later, in December 1999, one of these terrorists -- Ahmed Ressam
-- was caught on his way to Los Angeles to blow up its international airport on
New Year's Eve.

This week's catastrophe in the United States, and an investigation into whether
terrorists entered the U.S. from Canada, prove that Ottawa must completely
recant its immigration and refugee policies. Immigration Minister Elinor Caplan
-- who describes any critic as a "racist" or "bigot" -- should be
unceremoniously dumped.

If Ottawa does not change dramatically, the Americans will take action. Likely,
they will "Mexico," or seal, their border permanently with us, making travel and
trade onerous and expensive. And if facing inaction by Ottawa, they will be
totally justified to do so.

The U.S. ambassador this week talked about matching immigration policies, but
said the border would not be shut down because of the importance of the
$1-billion-a-day bilateral trade relationship.

But I don't believe that for a New York minute.

Our government has allowed in terrorists from Asia, the Middle East and North
Africa by the hundreds, if not thousands, as bogus refugees or immigrants.
Montreal has turned into a hotbed of francophone Arab terrorism, thanks to
Ottawa granting Quebec a great deal of control over immigration. The
secessionists, who control that province, have made francophone immigration a
priority. But they have not done their homework.

Canada is also currently accepting, without any demographic or economic
justification, four times as many immigrants and refugees per capita as the
Americans without the manpower, or political will, to properly police the
system. The presence of an excessive number of uneducated immigrants, with
unemployable family members, has imposed the biggest single strain on our
health-care, welfare, housing and education systems as well as on our judicial
and police systems.

Sadly, the result is Montreal has now become a staging ground for Arab
terrorism. Vancouver and Toronto have also become centres of Sikh and Tamil
terrorism as well as meccas for Mafiosi from Russia, China, Vietnam and Korea.

Until this country has a decent followup capability we should severely curb the
numbers of immigrants and refugees we have been accepting. Until this country
has a proper procedure to detain, then immediately deport, bogus refugees, it
should not accept any unless liberated from bona fide refugee camps.

Nowhere is the problem more noticeable than in the fact we let anyone declare
they are a refugee and then support them for years. Recent cases include the
acceptance of a ring of Peruvian pickpockets who were allowed to claim refugee
status even though their country is a democracy. Likewise, we accepted hundreds
of Honduran drug dealers as refugees. On top of all that, Quebec continues to
rubber stamp anyone with two legs just because they speak French.

As for immigrants, we accept tens of thousands of "entrepreneurial investors" as
immigrants without followup to make sure they keep their promises to create
jobs. A report in 1999 showed that 80,000 allowed in did not keep that promise.
We let people into Canada as sponsored immigrants then don't force their
sponsors to support them or pay their medical costs if they decide to renege.

Ottawa's immigration and refugee track record has been a joke. But now it's not
funny. It's downright dangerous to our neighbours and ourselves. Canadians, too
cowed to bring up the subject for fear of being labelled a racist or bigot, must
finally rise up and protest. Failing that, the Americans will take action and it
won't be pretty. But they will be right to do so.

Diane Francis is with The Financial Post.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                           September 16, 2001, Sunday

THE LOST BOYS

BYLINE: TAMARA LUSH

SECTION: PASCO TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 380 words

DATELINE: NEW PORT RICHEY



A few days after 21 Sudanese refugees arrived in Pasco County, a question spread
through the group.

Where, they wanted to know, was David Gray?

He was the man who brought them to the United States, a fatherlike figure from
the international aid group World Relief. Gray's name and address had appeared
in the corner of a brown envelope sent months earlier to their mud-and-grass
huts at the Kakuma refugee camp in Kenya.

The Sudanese had been curious about David Gray ever since they received the
letters that detailed their journey to America.

During an orientation meeting in a church hall with the Sudanese, another World
Relief worker acknowledged that he had heard the many questions about Gray. The
worker pointed to a man sitting in the back of the room.

It was David Gray.

The Sudanese clapped and grinned as he welcomed them to Pasco County.

During a 1987 civil war in Sudan, many children fled their villages and
eventually settled in refugee camps. Workers dubbed these children the Lost
Boys, after characters in the novel Peter Pan.

Gray acknowledged the transition from an African refugee camp to suburban
Florida would be rocky.

"You have an advantage that most Americans don't have," he told the group. "You
have your feet in two different cultures. Your heart is in Africa and the rest
of your body is here."

Gray is well aware of the culture shock felt by refugees when the first arrive
in West Pasco. During the past 10 years, Gray and his wife, Nancy, have helped
resettle 2,500 people from other countries, about 1,000 of them in west Pasco.

As the directors of the local chapter of World Relief, they have resettled
people from Bosnia, Cuba, Korea, Vietnam and now Sudan. By the end of this year,
they will have resettled 50 Sudanese men.

They have helped bring diversity to west Pasco: with the arrival 50 Sudanese,
World Relief has increased the black population in the greater Port Richey-New
Port Richey area by 15 percent.

Nancy Gray acknowledged that over the years, some people haven't been happy with
the county's newest residents.

"It bothers me when I hear people say, why are you bringing these people over
here?" she said. "Look at what our country was built on before you ask that
question. We're built on diversity."

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                     July 11, 2001 Wednesday, Home Edition

WORLD IN BRIEF

SOURCE: From staff and wire reports

SECTION: News; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 522 words


Fighting erupts amid Gaza demolition

Israeli army bulldozers rumbled into a Palestinian refugee camp in the Gaza
Strip early Tuesday and leveled houses and shops, leaving scores of people
homeless and igniting a fierce gunbattle.

The army said the structures razed at the camp in Rafah, on the Gaza Strip's
border with Egypt, had been used by Palestinian gunmen as cover for attacks on
Israeli troops.

On Monday, the Israelis tore down 14 Palestinian homes in a refugee camp in East
Jerusalem, saying they had been built without permits.

The United States called such demolitions provocative, and the European Union
said the demolitions would "complicate further the efforts of the international
community and the parties themselves to seek a solution to end the crisis."

AFRICA: African leaders meet on Libya's union plan

African leaders met in Lusaka, Zambia, to fine-tune a plan to transform the
Organization of African Unity, formed in 1963, into a European-style union. The
leaders selected Amara Essy of Ivory Coast to lead the 53-member group in its
transition to become the African Union, the brainchild of the Libyan leader
Moammar Gadhafi, who attended the summit meeting.

THE AMERICAS: Argentina indicts former junta leader

Former Argentinian junta leader Jorge Videla was indicted on charges he
conspired with other South American military dictatorships in the 1970s to
eliminate political opponents.

EUROPE: Motorists to face fee for driving in London

Drivers will have to pay $7 a day to take their cars into congested central
London as part of a plan aimed at reducing weekday traffic by 15 percent. The
fees go into effect in January 2003.

Sinn Fein head decries focus on IRA guns

Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican
Army, said talks aimed at achieving IRA disarmament would fail if they continued
"making all other issues secondary to the issue of IRA arms." Adams spoke as the
negotiations by British Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart,
Bertie Ahern, entered their second night. The Northern Ireland peace accord has
been in crisis since Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble resigned as first
minister last week.

Mrs. Schindler wants Israel to give up lists

Speaking at a modern history museum in Bonn, Oskar Schindler's widow, Emilie
Schindler, said that Israel should return to Germany his documents, including a
list of 1,200 Jewish prisoners he is credited with saving from the Nazis. Oskar
Schindler saved Jews by drawing up lists with fictitious jobs in his factory in
occupied Poland to convince the Nazi SS the workers were vital to the war
effort. His efforts were chronicled in the movie "Schindler's List."

ASIA: Heavy rains in India force 500,000 to flee

Monsoon rains have forced 500,000 people to flee their homes in the Indian state
of Orissa. --- From news services

a year will be switched off Saturday until early 2003, when the Paris landmark
will sparkle again with a new system.

                                Guardian Weekly

                                 March 7, 2001

UN tackles tragedy of 'hidden refugees'

BYLINE: Victoria Brittain

SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 486 words

HIGHLIGHT: Campaign aims to give hope to 25m people displaced within their own
countries


The United Nations is launching a campaign to confront the hidden problem of the
25m people displaced by conflict in their own countries.  There are twice as
many of these people as there are refugees, but the displaced -- mainly women
and children -- receive only a fraction of the assistance given to refugees.

"The level of human suffering and loss of hope for millions of displaced people
should be unacceptable in this age of prosperity," said the UN's special
coordinator for the displaced, Dennis McNamara.  "If we do not get a major
increase in resources very quickly, more people will simply die unnecessarily
from lack of shelter, health or basic nutrition in many countries."

He warned that the problem of displaced people was a big obstacle to stability
and development, particularly in Central Africa, and in parts of Asia, Latin
America and the Balkans.

Richard Holbrooke, the former United States envoy to the UN, was stunned by the
conditions he saw a year ago in the Angolan capital, Luanda, where desperate
street children live side by side with the conspicuous consumption of the
political elite.  His visit sparked an urgency among UN officials to tackle the
problem of the internally displaced.  They set up a network of agencies to
coordinate aid.  However, the UN immediately found itself facing problems of
sovereignty, lack of access and official indifference.

The network began a review last year of a first group of seriously affected
countries.  In Ethiopia, Eritea, Burundi, Colombia, Angola and Indonesia it
found that the most acute common problems were HIV/Aids, sexual violence, lack
of basic nutrition, health and sanitation, inadequate shelter, and death and
maiming by landmines.

The next countries to be studied will be Sudan, Afghanistan, the Democratic
Republic of Congo and Sri Lanka.

All these countries are deep in civil wars that have lasted for years -- or even
decades.  In many of the worst-affected states, such as Sudan and Congo, rival
armies not only routinely abuse displaced civilians, but have made vast areas
no-go zones for aid agencies.

Most displaced people are unprotected from military or official abuse, sexual
violence and abduction for forced military service.

The global programme for the displaced is hard to quantify, but by combining the
budgets spent by various UN agencies it amounts to several hundred million
dollars a year.

"What is clear is that this must be doubled or even more in many situations,"
said Mr McNamara.  "For example, Burundi got less than one-quarter of what it
needed in 2000, Afghanistan less than half.

"Unless there is a serious and renewed effort by all governments -- starting
with those whose citizens are the victims, and supported by those able to
provide political and economic support to them -- the displaced millions will
produce new generations with no place to call home."

                             The Guardian (London)

                               February 21, 2001

UN shaken by refugees' extortion allegations

BYLINE: Adrian Blomfield

SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages, Pg. 19

LENGTH: 372 words


The United Nations is investigating allegations that some of its employees were
members of an organised crime network in Africa which took bribes to resettle
refugees in the west.

Paul Stromberg, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for
Refugees (UNHCR), confirmed reports that at least four people who had worked out
of the Nairobi office were being investigated. One of the four is understood to
be a European.

Mr Stromberg said a number of refugees had alleged that they were asked to pay
between Dollars 2,000 and Dollars 5,000 (pounds 1,400-pounds 3,500) to be
resettled in North America, Europe and Australia.

"(The investigation) may involve more than four people. How many people will be
investigated, how many people may have charges brought against them we will only
know when the UN watchdog agency gives its final report."

The investigation is understood to be looking beyond resettlement cases to
reports that guards charged refugees for entry into UNHCR compounds, and that UN
workers demanded payment for appointments and for basic services, he said.

UN staff who allegedly extorted money from refugees should be "harshly" punished
if proved guilty, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday.

"I think it is abominable that refugees who are already suffering should be
exploited in this manner," he said.

Many refugees said they believed paying a fee to UNHCR officials increased their
chances of asylum.

"The refugees who have money do not have the problems that everyone else has,"
one refugee, Celestin Kangambo, said outside the UNHCR office in Nairobi.

Mr Annan said it was important that the problem was discovered quite early and
that the UN's Office of Internal Oversight, based in New York, had now taken
over the inquiry.

There appears to have been links to organised crime groups, with four UNHCR
staff having to be moved from Kenya after receiving death threats.

"Human trafficking is something which involves in many countries very highly
organised and very violent criminal groups," Mr Stromberg said. "They made very
serious threats against our staff."

Investigations are expected to be complete within the next few months.

                               The New York Times

                            February 19, 2001 Monday
                              Late Edition - Final

Refugees in Kenya Tell of Shakedown by U.N. Agency

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1167 words

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 14


Dahir is too afraid to give his full name, and for good reason: he is a refugee.
So far, at least three people with far more standing -- Western workers at the
United Nations here -- have received death threats. For their safety, they were
flown out of Kenya. No one will do that for Dahir.

But they all reportedly know about the same thing: unfolding allegations that
refugees like Dahir, most of them poor and fleeing war, were turned into a
business by the very people who were supposed to protect them.

United Nations investigators are quietly sifting through evidence that corrupt
workers with the United Nations high commissioner for refugees in Kenya -- a
country where corruption is the norm -- extorted fees for the agency's essential
services, which are supposed to be free. The fees are rumored to range from a
few dollars for an appointment or to fill out a form, to up to $5,000 for a new
life in the United States, Canada or Australia.

Dahir, 27, an Ethiopian who fled his country in 1993, said he paid $3,400, sent
mostly by friends abroad, to two United Nations workers at a hotel in Kenya's
capital, Nairobi, last July. He said he paid out of frustration that his
application to move to the West had stalled for four years, while friends
waiting far less time had left as asylum seekers to the United States.

"They said, 'We paid, we got the flight,' " said Dahir, who says he left
Ethiopia in the 1990's because he was tortured. "They said, 'Don't wait. There
is no right of refugees in this place. Your right is your money. Just use your
pocket.' "

Last year, 9,383 refugees from countries like Sudan, Somalia and Ethiopia were
approved to move to outside countries through the United Nations refugee
agency's branch office in Nairobi, where the allegations are centered.

Most eligible refugees have been persecuted or cannot return home for other
reasons. Ten countries accept such asylum seekers from East Africa, but the
allegations of corruption focus on refugees going to the United States, which
accepts most of the asylum seekers, Canada and Australia.

Daniel Tshitungi, head of the Kenya office, said it was impossible to know how
widespread the corruption was -- how many refugees paid to be resettled, over
what period, and whether any unqualified people simply paid to get asylum --
before an investigation by senior United Nations officials was completed.

Mr. Tshitungi acknowledged, however, that the investigation centered on at least
four employees, responsible for processing and vetting the applications of
thousands of refugees, and that the corruption appeared to date at least to
December 1999.

"It's being handled in a very efficient way, but we don't want to make noise
about it," Mr. Tshitungi said.

Several people with knowledge of the investigation say the allegations of
corruption extend beyond the United Nations office to at least one private
agency, and even to workers inside foreign embassies who handle asylum requests.

Peter Claussen, a spokesman for the American Embassy in Nairobi, acknowledged
that an American investigator with the Immigration and Naturalization Service
had been to Kenya recently to decide whether to initiate a separate probe. He
said, however, that no American Embassy workers were suspects.

Officials with the many organizations that assist refugees in Kenya -- where
each day's newspapers carry articles about one corruption scandal or another --
are unusually afraid to speak out publicly about the allegations. Much of that
fear stems from death threats to at least three United Nations employees, one
American and two Europeans, who reportedly found out about the scheme. The
threats were considered so serious that all three were evacuated from Kenya late
last year.

Three of the suspects are Kenyan, Mr. Tshitungi said. They still have their jobs
-- which people familiar with the investigation said put them in the powerful
position of deciding which applications to forward to higher-ups -- though with
what Mr. Tshitungi called severely curtailed responsibilities.

The remaining suspect, an Italian who worked at the Nairobi office for about two
years, did not have his contract renewed as a result of the allegations, Mr.
Tshitungi said.

Refugees, as well as people who work with them here in Nairobi, said everything
had a price in the Kenya branch of the refugee agency: Guards at the door had to
be tipped, they said. One current employee recalled asking about 35 refugees in
the Kakuma refugee camp in northern Kenya, where roughly 100,000 refugees live,
how many had paid bribes to guards on the way into the refugee agency's offices
there. Nearly everyone stood up, the employee said.

"I said, 'Why do you pay?' They said, 'Ah, well, life is sometimes hard.' " The
most expensive service was the one refugees wanted most: resettlement in the
West.

According to refugees, the corrupt workers were able to deliver what they sold
-- suggesting to some United Nations officials that corruption is not limited to
a handful of relatively junior employees.

Business relied on an elaborate system of people known as "brokers," who would
scout out refugees, negotiate prices and help the chosen through bureaucratic
obstacles.

One Somali refugee, Ahmed, said he was approached several times during the last
two years by brokers who promised him passage west for as much as $5,000. He
recalled a specific meeting in a Nairobi cafe where "that person told me: 'Pay
$3,000 and I'll arrange your case. If you know other people who will pay, we
will give you a discount. I will hold your hand into the office.' "

Ahmed said he turned down all offers.

Dahir and two other refugees, another Ethiopian and a Somali, described how the
heads of 30 families met last summer in a hotel in downtown Nairobi. Each
person, including Dahir representing his family, went with an envelope stuffed
with $3,400 for resettlement in the United States.

At the meeting, they said, were two Kenyan United Nations workers, who filled
out forms and collected photographs. Also present were two Europeans who did not
work for the United Nations, one apparently the owner of the hotel, and a Somali
who acted as broker.

But this deal was not completed -- because of the investigation, the refugees
suspect.

Mr. Tshitungi said he first requested an investigation, after refugees began
complaining to him about corruption, in December 1999. That inquiry, run out of
United Nations headquarters in Nairobi, ended inconclusively last June, he said.

He said he then requested a second probe, which began in November. That month,
Mr. Tshitungi also placed advertisements in The Nation, a Kenyan daily,
reminding refugees that the services were free.

Dahir and the other refugees who paid the $3,400 said they had gone back
repeatedly to one of the United Nations workers and the Somali broker. At least
one of the refugees has been beaten up as a result of the inquiries, they said,
adding that they now seem to have lost both their money and the chance to
emigrate.

                               The New York Times

                December 31, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

The World;
The Century of Refugees Ends. And Continues.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1257 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS


YOU don't see them run, because they aren't on the nightly news shows. But in
the last few weeks, tens of thousands of hungry Afghans have been moving toward
Herat, near the border of Iran, driven by civil war, bad government, winter and
the worst drought in decades.

They aren't alone. A continent away, renewed fighting in the Congo has people on
the run again, this time into Zambia, where Angolans are also seeking shelter.
In West Africa, the small nation of Guinea, with three million people, is being
overwhelmed by hundreds of thousands of people fleeing a cruel government in
Liberia and a civil war in Sierra Leone.

They 20th century may have taught the world to deal systematically with vast
refugee flows, too many to count precisely, but the 21st century may have to
invent new ways of coping with them, as the nature and definition of refugee
crises changes. The Afghans, the Africans, the East Timorese still in West Timor
more than a year after their compatriots gained independence from Indonesia --
these people, too, are often running from war and genocide, but the refugee
phenomenon has evolved in some important ways in the last half-century.

"The character of refugee flows has changed a lot," said Lionel Rosenblatt,
president of Refugees International, an independent aid and advocacy group in
Washington. After World War II, he said, "there was some focus and a fairly
quick international response -- at least to keep these people alive."

"One of the problems we face now is that this kind of displacement and suffering
is occurring in very remote places," Mr. Rosenblatt said. Citing Guinea as an
example, he said: "There's no reaction from the world. There's no focus, and
it's going to get worse. Bad men and bad leaders abound." That pattern, he said,
is "cropping up everywhere, really stretching both the attention of the world
and its capacity to respond."

Mr. Rosenblatt has written an open letter to the incoming Bush administration
asking it to consider backing an international rapid-reaction force composed of
troops from nations that are not permanent members of the United Nations
Security Council.

"Many experts agree," Mr. Rosenblatt wrote, "that a force of just 5,000
peacemakers could have saved hundreds of thousands of lives in Rwanda in 1994."
He also advocates the appointment of an official on the National Security
Council who would be responsible for directing America's emergency response to
crises.

The explosion in refugee crises has made the old definitions and rules obsolete.
Is someone who is abused, terrorized or hungry a refugee only if he or she
crosses an international border? At the moment, the United Nations says yes. But
that distinction looks absurd amid the brutality of recent civil wars. In
response, Richard C. Holbrooke, the American ambassador to the United Nations,
and major refugee organizations, have begun a vocal campaign to give so-called
"internally displaced people" the same assistance given to refugees.

What is asylum nowadays?

The cold war era definitions are crumbling before what amount to class-action
petitions: Chinese migrants who say they are hurt by the one-child policy, women
claiming domestic abuse or the fear of traditional genital mutilation. Down the
road is an even bigger test: a drive for the free movement of labor from poor
nations by workers demanding a right to relief from economic disadvantage.
President Vicente Fox Quesada has moved in this direction with calls for the
right of Mexicans to emigrate to the United States in search of work.

And what happens when abusive governments wanting to convince the world that
everything is under control ask international agencies to distribute aid inside
a troubled territory, not outside its borders, so that those who have fled, but
are living in despairing deprivation will be lured back to homes that are not
safe -- if those homes are even left standing? The United Nations faces this
dilemma in Chechnya.

Arthur C. Helton, a specialist in asylum and immigration law who directs a
refugee program at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, said, "The 20th
century created the refugee framework." Millions were displaced by World War I,
leading to a major exodus toward the United States. "But it was really only
after the Second World War that refugees became a question of high politics," he
said.

Organized programs of resettlement became the answer, which continued under the
auspices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees -- the U.N.H.C.R
-- created in 1950.

"With the Hungarian crisis later in the 50's, and the vast displacement of
people into Austria, the U.N.H.C.R. became a key player," Mr. Helton said. "It
was very much an adjunct of the cold war at that point." The cold war produced
other refugee crises, in Indochina, Central America and Afghanistan.

By the late 1980's, with the cold war waning, resettlement began to give way to
a demand that refugees be repatriated. The forcible return of Haitian boat
people was on display for all Americans to see.

"Cubans were still welcomed because the emigre community of refugees in Miami
had become a significant domestic political force," Mr. Helton said. "Haitians,
who never made it very high on the foreign policy screen, were treated as
unwelcome guests from the very outset. Generally in the developed world now, the
welcome is no longer out for refugees."

Also with the end of the cold war, the United Nations refugee commissioner
(Sadako Ogata of Japan, who stepped down this month after 10 years, to be
succeeded by Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands) had to deal with new problems in
the former Soviet Union, as Russians from the "near abroad" tried to return and
those displaced during Stalin-era ethnic resettlements, tried to go back to
ancestral homes.

A migration conference for the Commonwealth of Independent States was held in
1996, but progress on resolving the problems has been slow.

THE 1990's also introduced the concept of preemptive intervention to refugee
politics. That could mean forceful action inside countries where problems are
developing, a policy Secretary General Kofi Annan has endorsed as a last resort.

In barely a decade, the United Nations and private agencies have faced
unexpected new tasks: preparing a safe haven for Kurds in northern Iraq and
scrambling to find solutions for people caught in the implosion of Yugoslavia.
The United Nations has also found itself taking on a new kind of trusteeship,
administering first Cambodia, then East Timor and now Kosovo.

For Mr. Rosenblatt at Refugees International, the foray into "nation building"
has to start in the refugee camps, where people need to be trained for
productive lives when they can go home. Education to break down ethnic,
religious and other prejudices can also be introduced, along with counseling.

At the Social Sciences Research Council in New York, Beverlee Bruce, the program
director and an anthropologist, is also studying education for refugee
populations, with a focus on Africa, as well as projects involving women.

"We want to know, especially in cases of forced migration," she said, "what
really does happen when women go back."

"Ambitions and expectations have risen," said Mr. Helton. "The new
administration in the U.S. will have to come to terms with these new realities,
and will find itself pushed and pulled as this complicated set of new
humanitarian challenges force a new kind of statecraft and a new kind of
diplomacy."

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                 November 24, 2000 Friday MORNING FINAL EDITION

CENTER REACHES OUT TO REFUGEES FROM AFRICA ON THANKSGIVING HOSTS SHARE AMERICAN
CUSTOM TO MAKE NEW COUNTRY SEEM LESS STRANGE

BYLINE: SARA NEUFELD, Mercury News

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 575 words


Now that he's been here for three years, Musa Kamara knows a thing or two about
America.

For example, on the fourth Thursday in November, Americans fly all over the
country to have dinner with their families.

It's things like that, Kamara said, that every African refugee should know. So
on Thursday, Kamara held a Thanksgiving Day feast for African refugees
throughout the Bay Area. His aim was to teach the refugees American tradition,
and preserve a bit of their own.

"If all Americans are flying out of state and going all over the place to have
dinner with their parents, why can't we meet and have dinner together and say
thanks to the Almighty God and America?" asked Kamara, 30, a refugee from Sierra
Leone who spent four years in a camp before coming to Arizona in 1997.

Kamara now lives in San Jose with his wife and baby daughter. He works for the
refugee resettlement team at San Jose's Catholic Charities and recently founded
African Refugee Community Services.

About 80 refugees from countries all over Africa came to Thursday's feast at
Saratoga's Ascension Church. Most were dressed in colorful robes and hats from
their native countries. They ate some food they knew, like peanut butter soup
and sweet potato leaves. And they ate some food they didn't know, like turkey.

Before the feast, the refugees stood in a circle, holding hands, and prayed in
English and Arabic. Sister Marilyn Lacey, Kamara's boss at Catholic Charities,
thanked God for bringing them together and granting them freedom.

For many refugees, memories of their war-ravaged countries and the families they
left behind are still too painful to discuss. Kamara and the other 11 members of
African Refugee Community Services understand what they're feeling. So they're
trying to create a new extended family in the Bay Area so that no refugee will
have to spend holidays alone.

They have only $500 in their bank account, but they're coming together somehow.
Kamara spent much of Thursday driving around in a van, picking up refugees who
don't yet have American driver's licenses or cars.

"When you don't have any relatives, you don't have anywhere to go; it's kind of
depressing," said African Refugee Community Services member Dan Tadesse of
Mountain View, who spent his first Thanksgiving in the United States alone 33
years ago after coming from Ethiopia. "Whenever there's any occasion, we make
them feel they belong here."

Kamara said he uses the occasions to teach his fellow refugees as much as he can
about American customs so the country will seem less foreign.

"Today," Kamara told Thursday's crowd, "is a very special day in America." With
a cell phone in the pocket of his khaki pants, he showed one newcomer how to use
a digital camera to take pictures of everyone eating.

Twenty-year-old David Kabanda, who came to San Jose three months ago from the
Democratic Republic of the Congo, said he didn't think the American people had
much faith in anything, until he learned about Thanksgiving.

"This is very important because it shows the unity and the love of America
toward other human beings," Kabanda said through a translator. "It is as ifthey
have open arms to receive the world."

Angelo Wut was still trying to grasp the concept of Thanksgiving, but he, his
wife and four children were grateful for the company.

"I've been here one month," said Wut, 41, a native of Sudan. "I hope, in two
months, I know more."

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                     October 9, 2000, Monday, Home Edition

Refugees lean on each other to assimilate;
 GLOBAL ATLANTA: Every Monday, a look at our changing communities

BYLINE: Maurice Tamman, Staff

SOURCE: CONSTITUTION

SECTION: Metro News; Pg. 3E

LENGTH: 818 words

Agbo Medeousso raised his hand, waving at a passing red subcompact. The driver
veered right and pulled up outside a Crescent Hill apartment building.

Rolling down the car window, Peter Uchala greeted his friend. He spoke English
that approached the Queen's tongue, learned, in part, as a student in Sudan's
capital, Khartoum in East Africa.

Medeousso, a native of Togo in West Africa, replied in broken English he had
picked up since February, when he relocated to the United States.

English is a thin thread binding the two, who, though from the same continent,
have little in common culturally. But their greatest bond is that both are
refugees, thrown together in an Atlanta apartment complex by the vagaries of war
and politics.

Though the concept of America as a melting pot has fallen out of favor as people
place greater value on their ethnicity, in isolated refugee communities
throughout metro Atlanta, recent arrivals like Uchala and Medeousso are coming
together. It's often members of the refugee subculture who offer each other
solutions to problems such as schooling, health care, even transportation, not
the agencies set up to aid them.

That is especially true at Crescent Hill, where refugees have received little
support from Catholic Social Services, the charity that was supposed to help
them settle in the United States. The Catholic agency started moving some
refugees out of the complex last week after stories in The Atlanta
Journal-Constitution documented questionable practices by the agency and the
poor conditions at the Cleveland Avenue complex.

"We have Sudanese, like me, Burundians, Togolese, Taiwanese, Bosnians, Kenyans.
. . Next to me we even have Iranians," Uchala said.  "We are all here and we
have to help each other."

Given the lack of official support from Catholic Social Services, it is hardly
surprising that different groups of refugees in the complex have reached out to
one another, said Caitlin Killian, an Emory University graduate student who
teaches an immigration course at the school.

She said immigrants and particularly refugees often change whom they will
associate with when forced into confusing situations.

Bob Souvorin has worked as a volunteer helping refugees in Atlanta for about two
years. "In my experience, the Somalis prefer to associate with Somalis,
Ethiopians with Ethiopians, etc. But there is a good reason for that: They don't
speak English."

They do, however, see themselves belonging to the larger refugee community, he
said.

On Thursday, for example, he met with a Somali man who told him that his wife's
van pool had fallen apart, leaving seven women without a ride to work. A Bosnian
refugee in the same apartment complex found out about their problem, bought a
van and started his own van pool.

"Certainly, he has nothing in common with someone from the Horn of Africa,"
Souvorin said. "I don't know if they are close friends, but it is a very
practical, workable solution."

Uchala, 39, considers himself lucky.  He spoke English before moving here in
September 1999 and had learned to deal with other cultures while living in Syria
and Saudi Arabia.

As a result, others at the Crescent Hill complex have turned to him when they
need help and he, in turn, looks for newcomers who seem lost.

He even has a ritual when he sees new faces around the complex. If they are
black, he assumes they may be African. If they are, he strikes up a
conversation, offering practical advice on getting jobs and medical care.

Perhaps just as importantly, he offers a friendly face.

"First, we just greeted each other," Uchala said of the first time he met
Medeousso. "Then he came over to my house with his wife, we had dinner. Now we
are friends."

For others, Uchala's assistance has been more tangible.

He helped a sick woman get to the hospital because her family had no idea what
to do. He got his brother-in-law a job as a porter at Hartsfield International
Airport, where he also works as a porter.

He has also helped others find their way through the confusion of being moved
from the Crescent Hill apartments into hotel rooms or new apartments during the
current crisis. (Uchala and his extended family moved into a Clarkston apartment
late last week.)

"I have tried, for certain things, to help who I can," he said. "I did my best,
according to my abilities."

Medeousso said he will miss his friend, but believes mixing with other, more
experienced, refugees has made his transition easier.

Uchala said he leaves the complex with fond memories, despite the nightmare
conditions.

"It's really a great experience. . . When I was in Saudi Arabia and Syria, I met
Indians and Pakistanis. . . When I first came here it was mainly Cubans and
South Americans. It's all a superb experience. You really learn things."

WELCOME TO AMERICA: CATHOLIC SOCIAL SERVICES REFUGEE RESETTLEMENT;
 In Their Own Words: The refugees' lives;
 Congo: Pierre Butera, 64

BYLINE: Carrie Teegardin, Staff

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Reader; Pg. 3C

LENGTH: 390 words

ARRIVED: July 20
FAMILY: 10 children. With him here are Oremus, 36, Boniface, 24, Michel, 22,
Jonas, 20, and Frederic, 14.

A native of Rwanda, Butera moved to Congo in 1960. He and his wife, who died a
decade ago, were devout Catholics who raised a large family largely in peace
until Laurent Kabila seized power in 1997 and targeted Butera's ethnic group,
the Tutsis, for persecution.

(Butera was interviewed through an interpreter.)
On his homeland: Soldiers came to my house and they arrested me because I looked
like a Tutsi. . . . We were taken to a prison and we spent about a week locked
in with no food, nothing, and we couldn't see outside. The women were outside,
so the women saw most of it. They would call someone out of the small room we
were locked in and take him outside and shoot him right there. .  . .

What really saved our lives was when the Red Cross personnel came in to check
the conditions of the prisoners. When the Red Cross came in, they took a count
of every prisoner and gave an ID to the prisoners, and that's when the soldiers
could not kill us because they could know what happened. . . . I can't go back
to Congo or Rwanda because always they are fighting.

On coming to America: When we found out we were coming to America it was such a
great joy, going from fear of dying right there. Going to the United States, I
cannot describe the feeling except that it is like someone telling you you are
going to heaven. . . . Before we came here, the picture we saw as to housing
possibilities and community where we would be living, it was good compared to
what we came to on Cleveland Avenue. It was nothing at all like what we felt we
would be seeing and living. . . . It's not a good place to stay with the
children --- it's not clean, it's not safe. But we have no choice. . . .
Compared to the situation of facing death, I wasn't depressed. The most
important thing was to save our lives. It was not the best conditions, but what
can I do?

On moving out of Crescent Hills: At this point in time, I have concerns for my
future and my family. This (new apartment complex) is clean, but that is not the
only thing. We need jobs, education for the children; these are the most
important things. We need to start our lives all over again. I don't really know
what is going to happen.

WELCOME TO AMERICA: CATHOLIC SOCIAL SERVICES REFUGEE SETTLEMENT;
 In Their Own Words: The refugees' lives;
 Sudan: Tetus Ello, 34

BYLINE: Carrie Teegardin, Staff

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Reader; Pg. 2C

LENGTH: 340 words

ARRIVED: June 1999
FAMILY: Wife, Tubia, and children Gideon, 14, Isaac, 12, Fojiya, 7, Sunday, 4,
and Isiah, 1.

As a result of Sudan's civil war, Ello's family was threatened by the forces
from Sudan's north, who burned his house and chased his family away. His family
was in a refugee camp in Ethiopia for three years.

(Ello was interviewed through an interpreter.)
On coming to America: We came here from Ethiopia, where we were in a refugee
camp for three years. When I know I will be coming to America, I was very happy.
. . . When I was in Sudan, we work for ourselves as a farmer, and here we make
money from other people. As soon as we came here, it was confusing because there
is a lot of things in America. We've seen a lot of things in the market. With
food, we don't know what we should do. We don't know what to try; we don't know
what to try or what is good.

On Crescent Hills: The life as you see it here, how dirty the house is. We ask
them to put in good carpet, but they don't listen. . . . The air conditioning is
broken. Nothing works in this house and I ask them to fix it, but they do not
care. There are bugs also. I went to the office and informed them there are a
lot of insects. They never say yes or no.

On making ends meet: When we came, these people gave us very little financial
assistance. They tried to look for a job for us and took me to the Hilton where
I work right now. Since we came, the big problem we have is we don't have enough
money to pay the house rent, to pay for food (or) to pay electricity. The money
I get from the job is not enough. I'm not able to buy a car to take children to
see a doctor or go to work. Whenever I try to buy something special or food for
children like ice cream, we cannot make it. I want to get a better-paying job,
but I do not know how.

On the future: I do have children and these children are in school and if I'm
not here (in America) they might not be in school. The future of my children is
much brighter than if I am in Africa.

WELCOME TO AMERICA: CATHOLIC SOCIAL SERVICES REFUGEE SETTLEMENT;
 In Their Own Words: The refugees' lives;
 Congo: Andre Kayisabe, 31

BYLINE: Carrie Teegardin, Staff

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Reader; Pg. 2C

LENGTH: 330 words

ARRIVED: March 24
FAMILY: Single. A sister lives in Canada, but he believes his parents and three
other siblings were killed in civil war.

Kayisabe was a graduate student in education when civil war broke out. As a
Tutsi, he was targeted. He spent eight months in a refugee camp in Benin. Now he
works overnight security at a downtown hotel and lives in southwest Atlanta
after leaving Crescent Hills with the help of Catholic Social Services.

On coming to America: To the African community, the United States of America is
a dream. . . . My dream being here was to study. I would like to do something
like computer science or business administration, but I don't know how to get a
scholarship or even how to find a good institution. There is no advice provided
by the agency that brought us there for starting on the scholarships or how to
apply.

On Crescent Hills: Living on Cleveland Avenue was like hell for us. It was too
dirty. And we were living in a community of refugees, so we didn't have contact
with Americans, so it was difficult for us to integrate into American society.
We were living in a world which was apart from the United States. It was like
another country. . . . (When we arrived) they gave us two plates, two forks. I
had a mattress and one sheet. They gave us $ 30 for food and it was for 10 days.
We were surprised and some of us said it's even worse than at a refugee camp in
Africa. It was filthy and it was unsafe too. We saw people drinking too much,
shooting. Almost every night we were afraid.

On Catholic Social Services: We have to make a distinction between Catholic
Social Services as an institution and the people working for it. I mean that
there is bad management of (money) they receive from the government . . . (but)
our caseworker, Grace, understands our problems better than anyone else.  She is
a good woman. She has a maternal heart. . . . She is doing exactly what you
would expect a caseworker to do.
