                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  May 7, 1999, Friday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

ETHNIC ALBANIAN REFUGEES WILL RELOCATE ACROSS THE U.S.

BYLINE: Deb Riechmann; The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A13

LENGTH: 625 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


From Kosovo to Kansas. Tented camps in Macedonia to high-rises in Manhattan. Up
to 20,000 ethnic Albanians expelled from Serbia are coming to the United States
- and to the Americans getting ready to take them in.

In Gardner, Kan., Kurt Hoffman, who gets teary-eyed when he sees the refugees'
plight on television, is straightening up his finished basement to house a
family from Kosovo.

With her youngest son away at college, Rita Huebner and her husband have two
empty bedrooms at their small house in Sherwood, Ohio. "I thought if they would
only come to America, I could help them," says Huebner. Over the years they have
been host for 14 foreign exchange students. "I asked my husband and he said, 'No
problem.'"

New York restaurant owner Dine Rraci doesn't know when - or even if - his
65-year-old mother and six other relatives from Kosovo will come to America, but
he's got apartments and jobs waiting.

"My mother doesn't want to leave at all," Rraci said, adding that his other
relatives are eager to get out of the refugee camps but probably would return to
Kosovo if peace was restored.

After weeks of trying to reach his relatives in refugee camps, Rraci finally
spoke on the phone with his mother. "Are you Momma?" he asked, quizzing her
about family details. Then he ended the call when relatives told him how
Yugoslav forces raped and stabbed a woman he knew.

"I had to hang up the phone. I can't take it. I don't want to hear these
things," Rraci said.

On Wednesday, 453 refugees arrived at Fort Dix, N.J. Another was born Thursday,
a boy, the first child for Lebibe Karaliju, 21, and her husband, Naim Karaliju,
28. The father is thinking of naming the baby "America."

An additional 400 are expected today and 800 more are scheduled to arrive early
next week. On Saturday, 100 to 200 refugees, who are being sponsored by
relatives in the United States, are scheduled to land in New York.

The U.S. government is giving the ethnic Albanians from Kosovo refugee status,
which allows them to work and gain access to some social services. They can stay
in America and eventually apply for U.S. citizenship, or return to Kosovo.

"They're coming rather quickly from trauma to resettlement," says Richard
Parkins, who is with Episcopal Migration Ministries, one of 10 U.S. refugee
resettlement agencies helping the people from Kosovo. "I think we're going to
get people who are very distraught - in a state of shock."

The refugees will be placed with relatives, host families, or in houses and
apartments arranged by the agencies.

Some will live in Albanian communities in New York, New Jersey and
Connecticut."This can be temporary, or it could be permanent," says Ron Lambert,
46, of Des Moines, Iowa, who has volunteered in the past to help refugees from
Southeast Asia, Africa and Bosnia.

"Paper or plastic?"

Some refugees eventually go home. Others like life in Des Moines and stay,
Lambert said, recalling how he helped two Bosnian teens get their first jobs
bagging groceries. He says one of the first English phrases they learned was:
"Paper or plastic?"

Anna Crosslin, director of the International Institute in St. Louis, said it was
her understanding that the refugees initially would be placed only with U.S.
relatives and not with volunteer hosts. After that, she said, the traditional
route of resettling refugees in small mutual-support clusters would be followed,
as was done for Bosnian Muslim refugees in cities such as St. Louis where no
Bosnian community previously existed.

Crosslin said it would be two to three weeks before the Institute would be
notifified if any refugees might come to St. Louis.

St. Louis has a small Albanian community of up to 500 families.

refugees relaxed after their 13-hour flight from Macedonia on Wednesday.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           November 10, 1998 Tuesday

Top UN official assails Canada's refugee policy  Humanitarian tradition losing
out to economics

BYLINE: PAUL KNOX The Globe and Mail

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A19

LENGTH: 712 words


Self-interest is winning out over humanitarian tradition when Canada selects
refugees for resettlement from abroad, the top refugee official for the United
Nations says.

Sadako Ogata says Canada is giving less weight to refugees' need for protection
and more to how much they are likely to cost taxpayers once they arrive in
Canada.

Mrs. Ogata, now in her eighth year as UN High Commissioner for Refugees, said
Canada is becoming reluctant to accept refugees from overseas camps unless they
meet traditional immigration criteria such as education, skills or ability to
speak English or French.

"Those who really need resettlement because of persecution should be given much
greater consideration," she said. "I think that's a legitimate request."

Mrs. Ogata made her comments after spending two days in Ottawa discussing
Canada's support for her office, whose mandate is to deal with more than 20
million refugees and displaced people around the world.

A federal government official rejected Mrs. Ogata's claim, saying that Ottawa is
actually doing more to help refugees who have slim prospects of quick
integration.

"We are helping more of the people who have greater settlement problems than we
have in the past," said Gerry Van Kessel, director-general of the Immigration
Department's refugees branch.

The UNHCR seeks to help refugees return to their country of origin or settle
where they have fled. But, every year, thousands are resettled in third
countries such as Canada, the United States, Australia or Scandinavian nations.

A total of 7,710 were resettled in Canada under federal government sponsorship
last year after fleeing wars or persecution. The 1998 target for this category
is 7,300.

Thousands more apply for refugee status after getting to Canada on their own.
Over the past three years, refugees from the former Yugoslavia, Sri Lanka, Iran,
Iraq and Afghanistan accounted for the greatest share of all refugees arriving
in Canada.

Mr. Van Kessel confirmed that Canada considers the ability of potential refugees
to find jobs and integrate into Canadian society when considering who to accept
from overseas camps.

To choose candidates solely on the basis of need would increase the cost to
Canadian taxpayers, he said, because they would need more government support.
"If we stop looking at resettlement criteria and it costs more, we'll end up
taking fewer refugees."

He said a Canadian program under which single mothers and women at risk of
persecution are accepted has taken 231 women so far this year against fewer than
200 last year.

Ms. Ogata, 71, became high commissioner in 1991 and will serve until the end of
2000.

She took office as an unprecedented wave of refugee crises was swamping the
world. Ethnic wars in the former Yugoslavia displaced about four million people,
adding to huge refugee populations in central Asia, Africa and Latin America.

At the same time, the governments that support her office were cutting back
foreign-aid budgets. She has made deep staff cuts at the agency but acknowledged
that there is still work to do in tightening up management procedures.

A draft audit leaked to the London-based Financial Times newspaper last summer
harshly criticized the UNHCR for failing to impose adequate controls on money
paid to other agencies working with refugees. The agency hotly denied the
allegations and Ms. Ogata was reconfirmed as high commissioner in September.

UNHCR was criticized for failing to push Western nations harder to intervene in
the former Yugoslavia or accept refugees fleeing ethnic cleansing. Ms. Ogata
acknowledged that in some cases the agency actually appeared to be sanctioning
ethnic cleansing by helping refugees flee it.

Millions were given so-called "temporary protection" by Germany and other
European countries, which were theoretically obliged to grant them permanent
asylum. Ms. Ogata said it was impossible for UNHCR to screen all victims to see
whether they qualified as refugees.

A Japanese-born former international-relations professor, Ms. Ogata laughed when
asked why she wants to continue in the job. "I'm stuck," she said, then
explained that "women usually start working rather late [in life], after you're
freer and more independent from household duties. . . . I think I can handle
another year or two."

                              Journal of Commerce

                           November 5, 1998, Thursday

Clinton closing door on refugees

BYLINE: BY BRONWYN LANCE

SECTION: EDITORIAL/OPINION; Pg. 7A

LENGTH: 885 words


President Clinton seems to enjoy his global reputation as a humanitarian.
Indeed, his intentions are probably genuine, and his attempts to bring peace to
the Middle East and to end the troubles in Northern Ireland are laudable
actions. However, while he has actively pursued a high-profile-handshake
altruism, Mr. Clinton has neglected lower-profile humanitarianism in his own
backyard by reducing the number of refugees into the United States to the lowest
figure in a decade. In a recent memo, the president set the number of refugees
admitted to America at a ceiling of 78,000 for 1999, down from 83, 000 in 1998.
Overall refugee admissions have plummeted from a Bush- administration high of
142,000 in 1992 to 70,000 in 1997. This is a 58 percent drop in refugee
admissions to the United States during the Clinton presidency. Remember, these
are refugees who have already proven that if they return to their home countries
they will be persecuted or killed because of their religion, race, national
origin, membership in a social group or political opinion. Yet not once on
President Clinton's watch has the overall ceiling for refugee admissions been
met, despite such horrors as the Rwandan genocide. Refugee admissions are based
on allocation by global region. The Clinton administration deserves much praise
for raising the previously paltry number of 7,000 refugees allowed to enter
America from the entire continent of Africa to 12,000 for next year. However,
this will be an empty gesture with no way to fill those numbers until Mr.
Clinton decides to improve the Byzantine way in which refugees are processed in
Africa. Simultaneously, the administration reduced the number of European and
former Soviet refugees to be given shelter in the United States by 3,000. This
odd move comes at a time when Bosnia is still a mess, 270,000 persons have fled
ethnic violence in Kosovo, and several former Soviet republics teeter on the
brink of civil war. If the situation is bad enough for Mr. Clinton to be
considering air strikes in Kosovo, now is not the time to shut the door on
refugees. It seems that an idea has taken root in Foggy Bottom that since the
Cold War has ended, there are no more refugees. However, human misery and fear
are felt equally, whether the oppressors are communists, fascists, or religious
fundamentalists.  The Clinton administration reduced the number of refugees
allowed from East Asia by 5,000 due to the winding down of the Vietnamese
program. However, last year saw 20,000 Burmese and 70,000 Cambodians fleeing to
Thailand. Many of these souls will never be able to return to their homelands
because they subscribed to American ideals of democracy, free speech and free
press to try to bring change to their own repressive governments. As large
caseloads, such as the Vietnamese, have begun to dwindle, the State Department
has seen no reason to use those numbers to allow shelter for other groups of
persecuted peoples. There has been a general unwillingness to help groups that
may be widely-scattered or may have fled to countries that are more difficult to
reach. Yet times have changed. The Cold War is a memory, and the administration
would do well to show creativity and look at opportunities to make a new
foreign-policy statement by offering the shelter of the United States to the
enemies of our enemies. It would speak volumes to those who denounce America and
decry our policies if we welcomed discrete and deserving groups such as
pro-democracy Burmese, religiously-persecuted Bahaists from Iran, anti-Saddam
Hussein Iraqis, and even Algerian journalists and small groups of Afghani women
now living in Pakistan. How many refugees can we afford to take? Ironically,
while our motive in accepting refugees may be generous, receptivity also serves
the national interest. Other nations look to us to be the leader on human rights
and global matters, as well as in protecting those fleeing persecution. As
America was founded by those fleeing religious, political and other forms of
oppression, we have a moral commitment as a nation to continue in that
tradition. No one is suggesting that the United States bear all the burden. In
fact, "regional burden sharing' has become an international catch-phrase. Over
half the countries in Africa either host or produce refugees, with many doing
both at the same time.  However, the stress of such an obligation can send
countries with low incomes and struggling political systems reeling into chaos.
It is, sadly, Mr.  Clinton's own presidency that has overseen one of the
sharpest reductions in America's acceptance of refugees in our history. Earlier
this year, the president said, ""I believe immigrants are good for America.
..They are renewing our values. And they are reminding all of us what it truly
means to be an American.'' However, in a classic flip-flop, President Clinton's
recently disbanded, anti-immigration immigration commission struck a tone far
from Franklin Roosevelt's recollection that ""We are all immigrants and
revolutionists,'' or John F. Kennedy's unabashed Melting Pot populism. America
is a nation of character that should abide by its moral commitment to help those
fleeing oppression. If Mr. Clinton is truly a humanitarian, he will rethink U.S.
refugee-admission policy.

LOAD-DATE: November 5, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                           October 27, 1998, Tuesday,

Most refugees white, European, while others are widely excluded;
 A recent article didn't quite get the racial mix right

SECTION: EDITORIAL, Pg. 9A, MAINE VOICES

LENGTH: 690 words


I read with interest the article in the Oct. 10 Press Herald regarding
complaints of neglect of refugees recently arrived in Portland. I am a Maine
native who just returned to Portland in September from Boston, where I practiced
immigration law.

I feel compelled to make two comments in response to your article. First, your
writer's statement that the United States admits annually "80,000 refugees, most
of them from war-ravaged countries in Africa or eastern Europe," is misleading.

Annual refugee admissions have little to do with war and other humanitarian
emergencies, and more to do with foreign policy concerns.

MOREOVER, there is no disguising the fact that U.S. refugee admissions are
shamefully race-based and have historically excluded legitimate refugees from
African nations, while favoring whites.

The institutionalized racism can be easily discerned from the fact that during
the last several decades, the African nations of Algeria, Angola, Burundi, Chad,
Ethiopia, Eritrea, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Democratic
Republic of Congo (Zaire) and Zimbabwe, to name just a few, have experienced
wars, turning literally millions of persons into refugees.

Yet historically, the number of refugees allowed in annually from the entire
African continent has been less than 10,000.

In fact, for fiscal years 1993-1998, African refugee annual admissions were
capped at 7,000 persons, while in the same period, annual admissions from Europe
and the former Soviet Union ranged from 45,000 to 64,000, the vast majority
being from the former Soviet Union.

The lack of any correlation to war, and the foreign policy aspects of refugee
admissions, are further exemplified in INS statistics regarding refugee
admissions from the Latin American/Caribbean region.

During the 1980s while U.S.-funded civil wars raged in El Salvador and
Guatemala, nearly the entire annual refugee quota of approximately 3,000 was
filled by Cubans, whose country which was not at war, but whose government this
nation opposed.

IT DOES NOT enhance the debate around refugee issues in Portland to perpetuate a
myth that because war exists in Somalia or in any other African country, the
U.S. government will permit Africans to comprise "most" of the refugee pool.

In fact, in fiscal 1999, of the 78,000 refugees to be admitted, only 12,000 will
come from Africa, (a significant increase from the norm, actually), while 48,000
will come from Europe, with 40,000 of those slated to arrive from Bosnia.

Second, I would like to underscore the difficulties of resettling refugees in an
area with a tight rental market. In Boston, resettlement agencies' case workers
are constantly under tremendous stress, and often work nearly around the clock
trying to locate housing for arriving refugees.

What rental units they are able to find, at a rent which can actually be
afforded on the meager federal refugee resettlement welfare allotment (which
will last only for a maximum of eight months) are often places in which most of
us would despair of living.

Imagine, for example, trying to find a de-leaded apartment with at least two
bedrooms for a refugee family of seven, for under $ 500 per month.  In Boston,
this is nearly impossible. From what I have seen, after having recently
completed my own search for a place to live in Portland, the situation would not
be much better here.

I HAVE NO knowledge of the events complained of in your article, but I hope that
the complainants and any other interested parties will take into account that
refugee resettlement agencies are given only a limited amount of funding from
the federal government with which to resettle refugees, and that amount does not
vary in response to changes in the local housing market or other local factors.

Unfortunately, refugee resettlement agencies can influence neither whom the
United States chooses to admit as refugees, nor the amount of funding which is
granted to assist refugees in adjusting to their new country.

I hope those who evaluate the situation complained of in your article will
consider these realities.


LOAD-DATE: February 9, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES:  --- Special to the Press Herald Beth Stickney is a former directing
attorney of the Legal Department at the International Institute of Boston. She
now teaches an immigration law seminar at the University of Maine School of Law.

                October 1, 1998, Thursday, 3 Early Tampa Edition

Boats work to clean up mysterious oil spill

SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires

SECTION: NATIONAL; IN BRIEF; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 587 words

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO; WASHINGTON; ATLANTA; MANASSAS, Va.



Dead and dying birds were found coated with oil in coastal waters Wednesday  as
skimmer boats worked to contain a 2,300-gallon spill.

"I expect the number of dead birds to keep going up," said Dana Michaels,
spokeswoman for the California Department of Fish and Game. "It's just this
nasty, crusty gunk, big globs. And the sheen spreads over the surface of the
area for miles."

Twenty-six dead birds were collected and 30 oil-covered birds were found  alive
by Wednesday, two days after the thick, heavy oil was spotted 10 miles  from San
Francisco.

Skimmer boats were sucking up what oil they could, and samples of the oil  were
sent to Federal Oil Pollution Clean-Up Fund laboratories for comparison  with
oil taken from ships that had recently traveled through the waters.

Clinton cuts number of slots for legal refugees

   WASHINGTON - President Clinton on Wednesday lowered the number of refugees
to be allowed legal entry into the United States, granting more entries to
refugees from Africa but fewer to those from Europe, Latin America and the
Caribbean.

In a memo to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, Clinton authorized  entry of
up to 78,000 refugees during fiscal 1999, down from 83,000 the year  before.
That restored the number to its fiscal 1997 level, the lowest figure  in a
decade.

Under the new authorization, 48,000 refugees would be allowed in from  Europe,
9,000 from East Asia, 12,000 from Africa, 3,000 from Latin America and  the
Caribbean and 4,000 from Near East/South Asia. An additional 2,000 slots  were
not allocated.

Americans' eating habits improve, study shows

  ATLANTA - A study says Americans are eating almost 20 percent more  vegetables
than they did a quarter-century ago, but many of the veggies aren't  green or
leafy - they're deep-fried.

Twenty-five percent of the vegetables consumed by Americans are french  fries,
according to Dr. Susan M. Krebs-Smith, author of a study in today's  edition of
the journal Cancer.

The study said Americans have improved their diets since the early 1970s  but
need to eat even better to help reduce their cancer risk.

Krebs-Smith, a research nutritionist with the National Cancer Institute,  said
the explosion of fast-food joints makes potatoes - especially in the form  of
french fries - the vegetable people eat most. Half of all servings of
vegetables Americans eat are potatoes, and half of those are french fries.

Family plans to remove man's feeding tube

   MANASSAS, Va. - Virginia's top health official made a last-minute appeal
Wednesday night to the family of a comatose man not to remove the feeding tube
that has kept him alive for 3 1/2 years.

The grieving family of Hugh Finn planned to remove the tube after a court
appeals deadline expired at midnight Wednesday.

But state Secretary of Health and Human Resources Claude Allen tried to
persuade the family to change its mind, even as state attorneys pondered ways
to keep the tube in place without the family's blessing.

Hugh Finn, a former Louisville, Ky., television news anchor, was injured in  a
traffic accident in March 1995.

His wife's decision in June to remove the feeding tube divided the family  and
led to a court battle over guardianship.

A judge ruled Aug. 31 that Michele Finn would remain as her husband's  guardian
and had the right to remove the tube. The family dropped plans to  appeal,
leaving her free to remove the feeding tube.

NATION

BYLINE: From News Services

Oil spill drifts south along California coast

A 2,300-gallon oil spill that had threatened one of the largest West Coast
breeding sites for marine life outside Alaska was moving south along the coast
Wednesday. The Coast Guard resumed the cleanup effort after about 200 gallons of
the oil slick had been sucked up Tuesday at the site 10 miles off San Francisco,
said Dana Michaels, a spokeswoman for the California Department of Fish and
Game. The spill, reported Monday by a passing ship, was initially between San
Francisco and the Farallon Islands, a collection of barren rocks 27 miles off
the coast that are home to thousands of birds and sea lions. But by Wednesday,
the oil had drifted about 20 miles south, off the coast of Half Moon Bay. The
spill occurred at the end of the breeding season when hundreds of thousands of
birds gather in large flocks to teach newborns how to feed themselves.

Federal worker linked to radicals enters guilty plea

A U.S. Fish and Wildlife officer who provided paramilitary training to Islamic
radicals linked to the World Trade Center bombing and other terrorist plots has
pleaded guilty to federal charges. Kelvin E. Smith, 43, entered a conditional
guilty plea Tuesday in Scranton, Pa., to lying to the FBI and hiding evidence by
dumping semiautomatic rifles in the Delaware River. The guns have never been
found. Defense attorney Joshua Lock said Smith entered the plea on the condition
that he could appeal a judge's ruling that prevented Smith from arguing that he
lied out of fear of retribution from the terrorists. The judge said Smith could
have gotten fellow enforcement officers to protect him and his family. Under
federal guidelines, Smith probably faces less than two years in prison at
sentencing Jan. 18. FBI investigators were led to Smith's farm while tracing the
movements of more than a half-dozen would-be terrorists who trained at the farm
and its firing range in 1993.

President lowers number of entry slots for refugees

President Bill Clinton lowered the number of refugees to be allowed legal entry
into the United States, granting more entries to refugees from Africa but fewer
to those from Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean. In a memo Wednesday to
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, Clinton authorized entry of up to 78,000
refugees during the fiscal year that begins today, down from 83,000 the year
before. That restored the number to the level of the fiscal year that ended
Sept. 30, 1997 - the lowest figure in a decade. Admissions are based on
country-by-country allocations made each year by the State Department.
Applicants must prove a "well-founded fear of persecution based on race,
religion, membership in a particular social group or political opinion" to be
admitted. This year, Clinton reduced the entry levels for European refugees by
3,000 and for Latin American refugees by 1,000. His order allowed 5,000 more
entries from Africa.

Jeb Bush leads Florida gubernatorial race, poll says

Republican candidate Jeb Bush maintains a comfortable lead over his Democratic
opponent in the Florida gubernatorial race, according to a poll published
Wednesday. Bush, the son of former President George Bush, led Democratic Lt.
Gov. Buddy MacKay by 52 percent to 37 percent in the latest poll by Mason-Dixon
Political/Media Research Inc. The general election is Nov. 3. The margin was
almost identical to Bush's 51 percent to 35 percent lead over MacKay in a late
August Mason-Dixon poll. Eleven percent of the respondents were undecided. The
telephone poll of 815 registered voters was conducted Sept. 22-24 and had an
error margin of 3.5 percentage points. The same survey showed Sen. Bob Graham
also maintaining his firm lead over Republican challenger Charlie Crist, a
former state senator from St. Petersburg. Graham, a former Democratic governor
seeking his third Senate term, was favored by 59 percent of the respondents,
versus 30 percent for Crist. Eleven percent were undecided.

Clinton earmarks money for bombing suspects' trial

President Bill Clinton set aside nearly $ 8 million Wednesday to support the
establishment of a court in the Netherlands to try two Libyan suspects in the
1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. Clinton directed Secretary of State Madeleine
Albright to transfer $ 7.9 million under the authority of the Foreign Assistance
Act. Libya has accepted a proposal from the United States and Britain to try the
suspects in the Netherlands by Scottish judges under Scottish law but is arguing
about specifics. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi wants details of the proceedings
and the treatment the suspects would receive once they are in Dutch custody, as
well as assurances that the suspects will have the right of appeal. Britain and
the United States have rejected the Libyan demands for guarantees before the
suspects are turned over.

2 teen-agers plead guilty in Michigan sex scandal

Two more young men accused of having sex with underage girls in a scandal in the
wealthy Detroit suburb of Grosse Pointe Woods pleaded guilty to lesser charges
Wednesday. Daniel Raymond, 19, and his cousin, James Raymond, 19, pleaded guilty
to contributing to the delinquency of a minor. Three 14-year-old girls told
authorities that the Raymonds and two other teen-agers gave them alcohol and had
sex with them last winter. All four young men were charged with statutory rape,
punishable by 15 years in prison. The girls came forward after the Grosse Pointe
North High School yearbook was published with a picture of 18-year-old Daniel
Granger apparently exposing himself. Granger, the Class of 1998 president,
pleaded guilty two weeks ago to the same charge. He and the Raymonds could get
up to six months in jail. The fourth defendant, Daniel Cooper, 18, will accept
the same deal next week, his lawyer said.

11 charged after mob threatens mixed-race couple

Eleven members of a mob in York, Neb., that marched with baseball bats to the
home of a mixed-race couple were charged Wednesday with disorderly conduct.
Prosecutors filed criminal mischief charges against three others. Shouting
racial slurs, about 30 young white men with bats and carrying a Confederate flag
broke car windows and attacked the home of a white woman and a black man on
Sept. 17. Police dispersed the mob. Police said the attack took place after the
woman said that a man who had been a guest had stolen money from the home. Jason
Negley, 18, was charged with taking $ 60 to $ 80 in cash and video games.

U.S. assails Cuba's treatment of four dissidents

The State Department sharply criticized Cuba's decision to charge four of the
country's best-known dissidents with sedition. According to attorneys in Havana,
the government is seeking a a six-year prison sentence for Vladimiro Roca and
five-year terms for Rene Gomez Manzano, Felix Bonne and Marta Beatriz Roque.
They were arrested in July 1997 and were formally charged Thursday. State
Department spokesman James Foley said Wednesday the only crime of the four "was
to speak the truth about the repression of freedom in Cuba, to criticize the
government's failed economic policies and to call for peaceful, democratic
change." Foley said the four have been held in cells with common criminals and
have been denied adequate medical care. The four criticized the Communist Party
for not presenting solutions to the country's severe economic problems.

                                The Toronto Star

                    September 4, 1998, Friday, METRO EDITION

Canada seeking border harmony Axworthy presses for North American co-operation

BYLINE: By Allan Thompson TORONTO STAR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 463 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA - Canada, the United States and Mexico are discussing greater
integration on border controls and other cross-border issues, Foreign Affairs
Minister Lloyd Axworthy says.

"Sometimes the best way to deal with the elephant is to get them to share the
same cage," he told reporters this week.

Axworthy said he raised the subject of greater North American co-operation with
U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright when she visited Ottawa in March.

She agreed to discuss a variety of border issues and how to address them with "a
North American view," he said.

Axworthy said a summit on the subject with Albright and Mexican Foreign Minister
Rosario Green was to have been held last month in Santa Fe, N.M., but was
postponed because of the U.S. embassy bombings in Africa.

"One of the things that has not been developed as much as it should have been is
this notion of working within the North American framework . . . to see what we
have in common that requires it," he said.

"There's a whole series of things just happening across this border and how do
we deal with it?

"We can either ad-hoc it, deal with each one as a conflict and a resolution, or
we can try to put a new framework around it that recognizes that this
integration is taking place and . . . try to manage it and plan for it as
opposed to simply respond to it."

Axworthy said Americans' attempts to tighten their border controls are just a
symptom of the problems caused by the lack of a North American approach.

"If you simply build up your fence between Canada and the United States, you're
also going to keep out a lot of other things that you want to have happen, so
why don't we look at this in a North American context?"

Asked if that would require a fundamental overhaul of Canada's immigration and
refugee laws, Axworthy said changes are being considered.

Changes to immigration and refugee policy "should be looked at in concert, as
opposed to simply in a unilateral way," he added.

Canada's immigration department has been trying for years to negotiate an
asylum-sharing agreement with the U.S., but those negotiations fell by the
wayside earlier this year. Such a harmonization of refugee policy would allow
Canada to deny entry to migrants who come here by way of the U.S., where they
could have filed a refugee claim.

Axworthy said the kind of harmonization he is talking about goes beyond refugee
and border policy.

"My argument there is we should be doing this in a North American context,
addressing the terrorist problem, the crime problem or the drug problem, but not
with a series of isolated regulations of our own," he said.

"This is a North American problem. We'd better sort of work together and find
some cohesion on this thing."

Refugees here back U.S. action

BYLINE: Elizabeth Kurylo

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 04A; Pg. 04A

LENGTH: 538 words


The U.S. missile strike on a pharmaceutical factory in Sudan was appropriate and
should be followed by more U.S. attacks on terrorist training camps in the East
African country, a group of local Sudanese refugees said Monday.

"One strike is not enough," said Khalifa Abdelraham, 49, a Sudanese refugee who
lives in Decatur. "There are plenty of terrorist camps in Sudan where they train
all those Islamic fundamentalists. America should continue with air strikes."

An estimated 200 Sudanese refugees live quietly in metro Atlanta, primarily in
Clarkston, Decatur and other parts of DeKalb County.  On Monday, 10 of them met
in Clarkston to discuss their reaction to last week's U.S. military action in
Sudan, where a plant believed to be making components for chemical weapons was
hit, and in Afghanistan. They gathered at the headquarters of World Relief, a
nonprofit agency that helps refugees start new lives in America.

The men are Christians from southern Sudan who fled their homeland because of
religious and political persecution. Many still have family members in Sudan,
where a 15-year civil war and famine have killed more than 1.5 million people.
Sudan's government is run by Muslims who took power in a 1989 coup and sought to
convert the country to Islam.

Before fleeing to the United States, several members of the group fought
alongside rebels trying to overthrow the current government. All spent years in
African refugee camps waiting for the chance to come to America. And that was
after they had walked for days, sometimes nearly a month, across Sudan to a
neighboring country such as Kenya or Ethiopia for refuge.

Luka Hol, 31, escaped Sudan in 1984 when he was in high school. He said students
were forced to learn the Koran and study the Islamic way of life. When they went
on strike to protest, the government sent in police, then soldiers, who started
shooting students. "We had to run away," he said.

He and 100 students walked for 30 days to Sudan's border with Ethiopia, he said.
Only 50 students survived the trek. He has lived in metro Atlanta for 3 years.
His mother, three sisters and two brothers still live in Sudan.

"We are not happy with the government in Sudan," he said. "They are training
people to become terrorists."

He is upset that most Americans don't know what is going on in his home country.
He and the rest of the group urged the United States to support Sudanese rebels
who are trying to overthrow the current government.

"This is a war against Christians," Hol said. "When Sudan became Islamic, the
military government did not want us to practice our beliefs. They started
teaching us Arabic instead of English. They closed schools if you didn't want to
learn their religion. They brought in female circumcision, which we think is a
complete violation of human rights. They brought in Islamic law, which says that
if you steal, they will cut your hand off."

Peter Woko, 44, who was a member of parliament before the 1989 coup, said
pressure from the U.S. government and the American people can change Sudan's
oppressive government.

"The bombing . . . was very, very useful. We need more of this. We would really
like for the Americans to help us."

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                             June 16, 1998 Tuesday

LACK OF MONEY TO CLOSE U'S REFUGEE STUDIES CENTER

BYLINE: FROM STAFF REPORTS

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 272 words


The University of Minnesota's Refugee Studies Center has run out of money and
will close at the end of June.

The center, which was created in response to the large influx of Southeast Asian
immigrants to Minnesota, has failed to develop a strong research program that
generates the money to continue, said Michael Metcalf, who oversees the center
as director of the Institute of International Studies and Programs.

"We (the institute) took it on as an at-risk project with the understanding that
it would seek outside funding; the center has been unsuccessful in doing that,"
he said.

In the meantime, university officials are trying to find another place to house
the center's research collection on refugees.

Immigrant advocacy groups have mounted a letter-writing campaign to try to save
the center.

"When I first heard it was closing, I was shocked," said Hean Her, executive
director of the Council on Asian-Pacific Minnesotans. "The center over the years
has worked to build a relationship with the refugee community, and it has given
voice to the needs of the community."

Since its beginning in 1980, the center has grown to encompass the study of
refugees from Africa, Central America, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and other
refugees from Asia.

"In the mind of the Hmong, this is the only place in the state of Minnesota
where they can come and find materials to trace their history and culture," said
Masami Suga, a program associate at the center. "It is especially significant
for Hmong people who came here very young, or who were born here, and may not
know much about their history in Laos."

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                           December 29, 1997, Monday,

ETHNIC GROUPS STRESS SOCIAL TIES;
 AMERICANS' INDIVIDUALISM IS AT ODDS WITH SUCH COMMUNITY-ORIENTED CULTURES AS
CAMBODIAN, BOSNIAN AND SOMALIAN.

BYLINE: Steven G. Vegh Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 556 words


When a Cambodian refugee like Tong SaVaun wants to open a store or buy a car, he
doesn't call local banks or credit unions. He calls a tightknit circle of family
and friends, and they collect among themselves the needed sum.

The practice has a practical side; most Cambodians don't have the credit history
or collateral required for a bank loan. But the larger reason is that
Cambodians, like many immigrant groups, think and act as a community far more
than is common among Americans.

''This is what make the Cambodian community. We have family and beyond that we
build up friendship. We look out for each other,'' said SaVaun, a leader in the
Maine Khmer Council.

There are at least two dozen nationalities represented among foreign-born
immigrants in Maine. Many came as refugees, resettled here by the Refugee
Resettlement Program of Catholic Charities Maine during the past 20 years.

Like other immigrants throughout America's history, the newcomers have sought
out their fellow countrymen because of shared language, history and cultural
tastes.

But the Cambodians, Bosnians and Somalians are among nationalities whose
cultures are also community-oriented by nature. These cultures emphasize
membership in the ethnic group as the way their people identify and think of
themselves.

The contrast between other cultures and American individualism is striking, even
for Doris Hohman, who immigrated from Germany. She has worked in refugee relief
in Africa and is now executive director of the Refugee Resettlement Program.

''My observation coming here as an immigrant is that I don't think there are
many places where there is as little community'' as in America, she said. ''This
emphasis on the individual over the community, that is unique.''

But because they are in the land of rugged individualism, it is groups like
Portland's Cambodian community whose communal attitude seems unique. Among
Cambodians, community is composed of the family and friends with whom trust runs
so deep that the link is as close as a blood relationship.

''This is 'mitphak,' the special kind of friend,'' SaVaun said. ''If you get
older and pass away, your family will be taken care of by this person. It's not
a contract; it's based on trust.''

Ljubica Forkapic, a teacher's aide at Portland High School, said that in her
homeland of Bosnia, community was a cultural norm expressed in regular visiting
and gathering with friends.

''I used to have friends living next door to our apartment, and I'd have coffee
with them every day, talk for an hour, and then go see another family,'' said
Forkapic, who lived with her family in Sarajevo. In the countryside, rural
families welcomed each other to share meals spontaneously.

Forkapic said this face-to-face socializing is, for her, the most important
aspect of what makes life enjoyable. When she and her family came to Portland
three years ago, Forkapic was shocked to see American's didn't devote much time
to gathering regularly with friends.

''Americans spend their life in automobiles by themselves. We aren't going to do
that. That's not a life,'' said Forkapic, who gets together often with others in
Portland's 150-member Bosnian community. To talk, eat and spend time with people
''is the most important thing for me and the people I represent,'' she said.

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 1997

day with friends. Such interaction, she says, ''is the most important thing for
me.''

                      June 13, 1997, Friday, Final Edition

Rwanda Replies

SECTION: OP-ED; Pg. A28; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

LENGTH: 442 words


The government of Rwanda has been accused of having sent troops to the eastern
parts of the Democratic Republic of Congo to kill innocent Hutu refugees.

The government of Rwanda would like to state the following:

(1) Since 1994 more than 3 million Rwandese refugees, both "old" and "new" have
been repatriated. More than 1.4 million of these have come home in the past six
months alone. The internal population of Rwanda is now estimated to be 8
million.

The government and people of Rwanda are struggling with the tasks of national
reconciliation, justice, resettlement, social and economic development, peace
and stability inside the country as well as in the Great Lakes region.

(2) The international community, having spent more than $ 3 billion in
maintaining camps in which perpetrators of genocide trained and armed refugees,
has done little or nothing to help Rwandese returnees resettle.

(3) It is time to establish the whole truth, not parts of it, of what has
happened in the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1994.
Only this would stand a chance of being impartial and credible. Therefore, any
such investigation should have a broad mandate to include the following:

* The consequences of the French "Operation Torquoise" in 1994.

* The role of nongovernmental organizations, international agencies (including
the United Nations), human rights organizations and governments (mainly in
Africa, Europe and America).

* The massacres that took place in the eastern areas of the Democratic Republic
of Congo, involving mainly the people of Masisi and the Banyamulenge.

* The role of the perpetrators of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

* The recent reports of massacres in the refugee camps.

(4) The above investigation should not be a pretext for the international
community to run away from the responsibility to bring to justice those who were
responsible for genocide in Rwanda. The exceedingly poor performance of the
International Tribunal for Rwanda is a stain on the conscience of the
international community.

(5) Those who are agitating for linking assistance to Rwanda to its admission of
guilt had rather revise their facts. The track record of the government of
Rwanda since 1994 is clear, and there is significant reason to be proud of it.

The government of Rwanda challenges this constituency to make public their
balance sheet of performance. Above all, the government of Rwanda owes its
existence to the people of Rwanda, and as such the talk of pressuring the
country into submission is misplaced.

THEOGENE N. RUDASINGWA

Ambassador

Embassy of Rwanda

Washington

                              Journal of Commerce

                            May 28, 1997, Wednesday

US miserly refugee policy

BYLINE: BY PHILIP PETERS

SECTION: EDITORIAL/OPINION; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 741 words


The issue of American global leadership usually arises in discussions of war,
finance or trade. But it is also an important factor in issues that involve
neither high politics nor high finance, but still affect millions of lives.
Refugee policy is a case in point.

The world produces far more refugees than any single country is willing to
accept. The key to securing humane treatment for the maximum number of refugees
often lies in international community. In the 1970s, the United States'
acceptance of Indochinese refugees provided such a demonstration to the
international community, and helped save the lives of thousands of boat people
who would have succumbed to pirates or other hazards at sea.

Without American leadership - which brought the eventual resettlement of more
than 1.2 million Indochinese in the United States - countries such as Australia
and New Zealand may not have accepted boat people for resettlement, and
countries such as Malaysia and the Philippines might not have established camps
that provided temporary safe haven.

Today's global refugee situation is more severe and more diffuse than during the
last years of the Cold War. More people are being driven from their homes, and
they are fleeing for reasons that are no longer principally tied to communism or
East-West conflict.

Even without the Cold War foreign policy context, refugee flows remain a
pressing international concern. They are both a symptom of instability and a
potential cause of further instability. That, apart from the humanitarian motive
or the economic benefits refugees bring, is the root of America's practical
interest in leading shared international efforts to care for and resettle
refugees.

The Clinton administration has steadily reduced the annual ceiling for refugee
admissions. Its proposed ceiling of 78,000 admissions for 1998, the same level
as 1997, marks the end of five consecutive years of decline. It represents a 39
percent cut from the 1990-1995 average ceiling of 127,000.

Administration officials contend that the cuts are appropriate in light of the
winding down of Vietnam War-related refugee admissions, and reductions in the
number of applicants from the former Soviet Union who seek admission on the
basis of religious persecution.

But current global conditions call more than ever for American leadership on
refugees - leadership that is undermined by the administration's cuts.

The Clinton administration's reduced ceilings may allow enough room for groups
that have long been of interest to the United States - Iraqi Kurds, Indochinese,
victims of religious persecution in the former Soviet Union. But they will
reduce overall U.S. admissions, and they will likely impede America's ability to
enlist greater international cooperation in other crises.  Two examples:

* Africa. Nearly 1 million refugees and displaced persons are in Central
Africa's Great Lakes region alone. Some Rwandan refugees have been able to
return home, but the former Zaire's civil war is causing new refugee flows. The
region's political instability and extensive ethnic violence block the
possibility of return for many refugees. Nonetheless, the administration has set
a ceiling of 7,000 refugee admissions for all of Africa in both 1997 and 1998.

* Bosnia. More than 1 million refugees from the former Yugoslavia are scattered
across Europe, over 300,000 of these in Germany. However, German state
governments have begun to return small numbers of Bosnians against their will,
and have recently sent deportation notices to 60,000 Bosnians.

In January, the Clinton administration announced that the United States would
admit up to 18,000 Bosnian refugees for resettlement in 1997. More than 32,000
have already resettled here since 1992. This is a positive step, but America's
ability to do more for those who have little hope of a safe return home - mixed
marriage families, Bosnians from towns ""cleansed'' by Serbs, victims of
violence - is limited by the low refugee ceiling.

Refugee policy involves a combination of moral, humanitarian and foreign policy
interests, and refugees have accounted in part for the benefits that legal
immigration has brought to the American economy. In the upcoming consultations
on 1998 refugee policy, Congress will have an opportunity to question whether
those interests are best served by the Clinton administration's proposed low
level of refugee admissions.

INTERNATIONAL ATLANTA;
World experts meet at Emory to discuss Zaire

BYLINE: J. Randal Ashley

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. 08A

LENGTH: 421 words


The 31-year president has life-threatening cancer, the prime minister was
apparently ousted Tuesday, there's no constitutional line of succession,
refugees are starving in jungles, and "rebel forces" backed by several
neighboring states have captured one-third of a nation that would be rich if not
for political corruption.

This describes Zaire, a huge country in the center of Africa. American forces
might have to intervene this week - even if only to rescue other Americans from
the growing chaos.

Three of the world's leading experts on Zaire, the genocidal wars in Rwanda and
Burundi, and the plight of thousands of refugees will discuss these issues
tonight at Emory University's White Hall at 7 p.m.

Ambassador Richard Bogosian has been the point man for the State Department in
the region. Soren Jessen-Peterson is in charge for the U.N. High Commissioner
for Refugees. Marge Tsitouris leads efforts by the CARE Emergency Group, one of
the main providers of humanitarian aid in the region.

Elections in China

Bob Pastor was jetlagged but exhilarated Tuesday after observing elections -
yes, elections - in China. A seven-member team organized by the Carter Center
returned Sunday after monitoring village elections in Fujian and Hebei
provinces. Pastor, who has done a lot of such work previously in Latin America,
was invited by China to bring the international Carter Center team to observe
and comment on the voting in a few of the local elections that affect 900
million Chinese villagers. The delegation found that the voting was not a ploy
by the Communist Party, but an election with "the basic norms of a democratic
process - secret ballot, direct election, multiple candidates, transparent
count, 3- year fixed terms" of office. Incumbents are regularly voted out,
Pastor said, and 40 percent of the village chairmen are not Communist Party
members. The delegation offered 14 suggestions on ways to improve the process.

assembly, Alexander Yakovlev, is a visiting professor at Emory Law School this
spring.

NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C.: KIDNAPPER RECEIVES 10-YEAR SENTENCE

MANITOBA

WINNIPEG: EXILED IRAQIS COMING TO CANADA

The biggest stream of refugees into Manitoba this year will be exiled Iraqis
currently living in a wretched Saudi camp, says a Winnipeg refugee placement
agency.

About 12,000 Iraqis have been languishing for years in the Rafgaa refugee camp
since fleeing duty in Saddam Hussein's army, said Tom Denton, executive director
of the International Centre.

The United Nations has made them a top priority, he said.

"It's a terrible camp. They are Iraqis who cannot go back to Saddam Hussein's
Iraq because they would be killed."

Citizenship and Immigration Canada has advised the International Centre to
expect 490 government-assisted refugees this year -- 215 from the Middle East,
165 from Europe, 100 from Africa, and 10 from Latin America.

In 1996, the International Centre settled 366 Europeans, all from the former
Yugoslavia, 61 refugees from the Middle East, 48 Africans and 11 Latin
Americans.

Resettlement is the UN's last resort, and among the 10 countries which will
settle refugees, only Canada, the U.S. and Australia take significant numbers,
Denton said.

QUEBEC

MONTREAL: POLICE ADMIT BREACH OF ETHICS

Four Montreal police officers found guilty of assaulting a cabbie who died of
his injuries pleaded no contest yesterday to charges they broke the police code
of ethics.

Quebec's police-ethics committee said Louis Samson, Andre Lapointe, Pierre
Bergeron and Michel Vadeboncoeur used greater force than was necessary during
the arrest and detention of taxi driver Richard Barnabe on Dec. 14, 1993.

They also violated their code of ethics with an abusive search and by ignoring
Barnabe's condition when they took the injured man to police cells rather than
to hospital.

Barnabe died last May after spending 29 months in a vegetative state. He never
recovered from the coma he fell into during his detention.

The ethics committee is studying a recommendation that the officers be suspended
between 150 and 200 days without pay.

The four were convicted in June 1995 of assault causing bodily harm and are
appealing the verdict.

They were given relatively light sentences that were widely criticized. Two were
given 90 days in prison, another drew a 60-day term and the fourth was to
perform 180 hours of community work.

NOVA SCOTIA

Canadian taxpayers have spent at least $200,000 so far on an extradition hearing
which they don't legally have to pay for, in a high seas murder case they can't
prosecute.

last spring before the ship arrived in Halifax.

for a trial, and the federal government will decide whether the accused men will
be tried in Romania.

Under international treaties, Canada can force Romania to foot the bill. But a
top official with the federal Justice Department says Canada won't likely make
the demand.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            December 27, 1996 Friday

Zairian mission decided without first-hand facts  ANALYSIS / Canada shouldn't
have to depend on other countries' intelligence services when considering
sending military on foreign operations.

BYLINE: BY JEFF SALLOT Parliamentary Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 1161 words

DATELINE: Ottawa


WHEN Prime Minister Jean Chrétien launched his rescue mission for Rwandan
refugees on Nov. 12, he did so without the benefit of reliable Canadian
intelligence about the numbers and conditions of refugees in eastern Zaire.

He committed Canada to a military expedition to Central Africa -- a venture the
government estimated might cost as much as $100-million -- before a single
Canadian military officer or intelligence operative could conduct a
reconnaissance patrol to assess the refugee situation on the ground.

Ultimately, the operation was called off before it really began because more
than half-a-million refugees in eastern Zaire managed to walk back to Rwanda
without the assistance of an outside military force.

Operation Assurance, as it is code named, is winding down. It wraps up
officially at the end of this month with the return to Canada of the last of the
air crews and transport planes sent to Africa and staging areas in Britain and
Crete in mid-November.

At its peak in late last month, the operation involved more than 430 Canadian
Forces personnel deployed to eight countries. Most of them never got within 400
kilometres of a refugee.

Unlike Britain, the United States and many of the other allied countries that
later agreed to join the mission -- and privately questioned the need for it --
Canada does not have a foreign intelligence service.

A discreet foreign intelligence-gathering agency, able to send assessment teams
into the field in eastern Zaire early last month, might have provided Mr.
Chrétien with reliable first-hand information about:
   The numbers of refugees and their location;
   Their state of health;
   Their supplies of food and fresh water;
   The physical terrain on which the Canadian-led military force might need to
operate;
   The position and relative strength of Tutsi rebels and Zairian army units and
their proximity to the refugees;
   The refugees' intentions.

Instead, what was available to Mr. Chrétien on Nov. 12 were the estimates from
international aid agencies about the conditions in the refugee camps. But aid
workers had abandoned those camps more than a week earlier because of fighting
between Tutsi rebels and the Zairian army.

Mr. Chrétien also was relying heavily on the political reports of Raymond
Chrétien, his nephew and the ambassador to Washington, who was serving as the
United Nations special envoy to Central Africa to deal with the plight of the
refugees.

Raymond Chrétien had been in the region only seven days. Most of his time was
spent shuttling back and forth between African capitals for meetings with
leaders. It was valuable political intelligence, but it was not first-hand
information about conditions on the ground.

The Prime Minister also had available estimates of the numbers of refugees and
their position based on U.S. spy-satellite monitoring. Aid agencies said the
U.S. estimates were far too low. Some of the agencies suggested the United
States was minimizing the numbers because Washington was anything but
enthusiastic about sending troops to Central Africa to protect refugees. Ottawa
did not have its own aerial-surveillance capability until a week later, when
Canadian military aircraft first arrived in the region. In any event, the
satellite sensors and aerial photos could not pick up intelligence about the
state of health of the refugees -- something an intelligence-assessment team on
the ground could have provided.

In other circumstances, Canadian diplomats might have gone into the field to
look around. But the embassy in Kigali, the Rwandan capital, is a small post and
its diplomats were busy providing logistical support for Raymond Chrétien.

The first Canadian intelligence gathering on the ground in eastern Zaire did not
take place until Nov. 28, two weeks after the Prime Minister's announcement of
the mission and almost a week after hundreds of thousands of refugees already
had crossed the border back into Rwanda. That's when Lieutenant-General Maurice
Baril, commander of the Canadian force, first travelled to eastern Zaire for a
five-hour reconnaissance trip and a meeting with rebel leaders whose soldiers
controlled the area.

It took days of negotiations with Rwandan authorities and the rebels to arrange
even that escorted trip. He saw only what the rebels and their backers in the
Rwandan government wanted him to see.

The first Canadian troops on the ground in Africa arrived in Kigali -- a
three-hour drive from the Zairian border -- after refugees started their return.
The small Kigali detachment -- never more than 40 -- was supposed to be the eyes
and ears for Gen. Baril's headquarters in Entebbe, Uganda, on the far northern
shore of Lake Victoria.

But the Kigali forward detachment was not in a position to provide much
intelligence. The detachment did not have a short-wave radio to monitor the
on-the-spot reports being broadcast by British, French and German reporters in
the field. Much of the information that this detachment received about the
conditions of refugees came the next day in faxes from Ottawa of newspaper
reports from journalists travelling outside Kigali and into eastern Zaire.

The Rwandan government believed an outside military intervention force was
unnecessary. Thus the Canadian soldiers in Kigali were treated as unwelcome
guests and were forced to keep a low profile. They spent almost all their time
in their quarters. It was almost a form of house arrest. The Rwandan government
and the Canadian embassy spent days trying to negotiate a status-of-forces
agreement to cover the soldiers and provide freedom of movement, but they did
not succeed.

Foreign intelligence services do not worry about such things. But Canada has no
foreign intelligence service and, according to Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd
Axworthy, it does not need one because more than enough information is available
from open sources.

Another country with a foreign intelligence service, and facing the same
situation as Canada in early November, might have sent a team into the field in
Africa without thinking twice. (Diplomatic sources in Rwanda suggest that the
United States did just that, but that the intelligence was not fully shared with
other countries.)

A discreet team in civilian clothes simply might have disappeared into the bush
for a couple of days to avoid roadblocks and military checkpoints and to make
direct contact with refugees. With portable satellite phones they could have
reported back directly to government decision makers half a world away with
real-time intelligence gathered on the spot.

An intelligence service of one's own -- even a small one dispatched abroad for
specific covert assignments -- would enable one to test the credibility of the
claims made by other countries or aid agencies as to the numbers, state of
health and food supplies of refugees.

Decision makers should not depend on secondhand sources when they're considering
sending the Canadian military on foreign missions.

ZAIRE REBELS TO CO-OPERATE WITH RELIEF OPERATION

SOURCE: QNP

BYLINE: TOMLINSON C

LENGTH: 565 words

Zaire rebels to

co-operate with

relief operation

By CHRIS TOMLINSON in Goma ZAIREAN rebel leader Laurent Kabila said

yesterday an international relief effort for Rwandan refugees is now

unnecessary and the people roaming eastern Zaire are mostly Zaireans

displaced by fighting.

Kabila said he would nevertheless co-operate with the Canadian-led

military mission to central Africa, approved

by 14 countries at a meeting in Ottawa on Friday.

Kabila said most of the Rwandan refugees who fled to eastern Zaire

in 1994 had gone home, and the people spotted by foreign reconnaissance

planes in the region

were actually Zaireans trying to escape warfare.

Western officials said at least 100,000 Rwandan refugees remained

in the mountains of eastern Zaire.

The Rwandan refugees, mostly Hutus, had lived in United Nations aid

camps in eastern Zaire until five weeks ago: when they vanished into

the countryside to escape clashes between the rebels and Zair

ean

soldiers. The refugees had fled Rwanda 2 1/2 years ago, fearing

retribution for the Hutu-led massacre of at least 500,000 Tutsis.

At Friday's meeting in Ottawa,

the 14 countries agreed to participate in an aid operation, a

scaled-down version of the multinational force proposed last month

before hundreds of thousands of refugees began leaving Zaire on their

own.

Diplomats agreed to establish a military headquarters in the

Ugandan capital of Entebbe

to run reconnaissance missions and possibly air

drops.

About 260 troops each from the United States and Canada are already

in Entebbe sharing makeshift headquarters in the airport terminal.

Military transport aircraft that could be used for airdrops are also in

Entebbe, about an hour's flying time from eastern Zaire.

On Saturday, a Canadian military cargo plane from Entebbe

carried cholera medicine to a refugee camp on Tanzania's border

with Zaire. The medicine would help prevent an outbreak among the

refugees, said Tom Kaptyn of Doctors Without Borders, who asked for the

airlift to Kigoma,

Tanzania.

""I'm more than just a little pleased," Dr Kaptyn said as his

cargo

was taken off the Hercules.

In all, about 20 countries, including the US, Britain, France,

South Africa, Spain, Senegal and Japan, were expected

to provide support to the force, Canadian officials said.

Britain and France have not said what their role in the mission

will be.

Spain plans to send three transport planes and between 30 and 40

people to help distribute food; and has offered 400 troops if needed.

Kabila is concerned that multi

national forces in eastern Zaire could be used to impede his

efforts to topple the government of President Mobutu Sese Seko, which

he says is corrupt and decadent.

""All this kind of intervention is purely politically motivated. We

think the problem of refugees is over in this area," said Kabila, who

met on Thursday with Canadian Lieutenant-General Maurice Baril, head of

the inter

national

mission.

Still, he said, the rebels ""have agreed to co-operate."

Rwanda, too, has repeatedly questioned the need for the force,

saying that the number of refugees in need in eastern Zaire has been

vastly overstated.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                               November 29, 1996

Canada puts final touches to aid mission for Zaire refugees

BYLINE: From Randall Palmer;

SECTION: Pg. 15

LENGTH: 611 words


Ottawa, Thursday

THE international humanitarian mission to central Africa will be approved
tomorrow at a meeting in Ottawa, Canada announced today.

"We have now achieved an agreement," said Canadian Foreign Minister Lloyd
Axworthy, adding that more than 20 nations had offered support for a mission.
Ambassadors from those countries will meet in Ottawa as a steering board to give
final confirmation.

The agreement is to establish a multi-national headquarters in Uganda, pursue
further reconnaissance, and put in place the capability to carry out air drops
of food into eastern Zaire if needed. The project is aimed at bringing food to
Rwandan Hutu refugees still in eastern Zaire.

There were an estimated 1.2 million refugees before fighting between the rebels,
Zairean troops, and Hutu extremists forced them from their camps.  Earlier this
month up to 600,000 went home to Tutsi-dominated Rwanda, which the refugees fled
in 1994 fearing reprisals for the genocide of up to one million Tutsis and
moderate Hutus.

The Canadian-led international coalition appeared determined to go ahead with
its plans despite opposition from the Zairean information minister to food drops
and scepticism from relief workers that this was the route to go.

Asked if the co-operation of neighbouring Rwanda was required for convoys,
Axworthy said: "That would be one of the questions. I'm hoping . . . from what
we've seen today that the Rwandan government is showing more co-operation."

He said Rwanda had agreed to allow the force commander, Canadian Lieutenant
-General Maurice Baril, to scout around eastern Zaire today and had agreed to
allow relief agencies to investigate what was needed there for 10 days.

Baril, who toured the western shore of Lake Kivu with Zairean rebels today,
reported that 40,000 Rwandan refugees were heading north along the lake towards
home.

He added that at least 100,000 other refugees were still in the mountains.

"(Some refugees) don't seem to be able to break away and come on down," Baril
said. "There are still vulnerable groups out there and we must find them."

Philipo Grandi, spokesman for the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in Goma,
said: "Humanitarian agencies are being given more access, but the problem is
that many refugees are still unreachable."

The UN Security Council authorised an international force on November 15, but no
mission has yet begun, partly because of confusion about the need after the
return of around 600,000 refugees to Rwanda, and partly because the Rwandan
Government has refused to allow the force to operate from its territory.

The United States, France, Belgium, South Africa, Malawi, Senegal, Denmark, and
Japan were among those that had offered support, Axworthy said - for example
with planes, reconnaissance, and staff for the headquarters.

Axworthy said Canada had devoted 600 troops to the mission, just under 300 of
whom are in the region, along with three Hercules transport planes that can be
used for food drops.

A figure for the total force was not available but Senegal was contributing a
battalion of 800, Canadian defence officials said. France was sending two
aircraft and 50 personnel and the United States was helping to set up the
headquarters at Entebbe in Uganda and would assist in planning airdrops.

However the United States has expressed reservations about the Canadian plan for
air drops of relief supplies to the Rwandan refugees in Zaire who have not yet
made it to the border. Americans fear the supplies would not reach malnourished
refugees, but would be taken instead by Hutu militants.  -Reuter/AP.

                              The Washington Post

                   November 28, 1996, Thursday, Final Edition

U.S. Near Approval of Mission To Aid Central Africa Refugees

Peter Baker, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A44

LENGTH: 649 words


The United States inched closer to a humanitarian mission to rescue ill and
hungry refugees in central Africa yesterday, endorsing a Canadian plan to
establish a multinational headquarters in the region and putting troops on alert
for possible airdrops of food and medicine into Zaire.

The operation envisioned by the Canadians would base operations out of Entebbe,
Uganda, and involve far fewer soldiers than originally projected just two weeks
ago. The Clinton administration said the 400 U.S. support troops already moved
to the region may be enough to handle the task, although an additional 200 could
be needed. In any case, officials stressed they are not planning to send U.S.
combat forces.

A statement by the White House supported the proposal to locate a headquarters
in the region. However, it added that more planning must be done over the next
few days before a final decision can be made on airdrops. "It's not a done deal,
but it is a statement of our intention," one high-ranking official said.

U.S. officials want to be assured cargo planes will not be fired upon by hostile
rebels on the ground and that supplies will be used for relief of refugees
rather than hijacked by armed militias. Also in the past, airdrops have injured
or killed some of the innocents they were intended to help by dropping pallets
on them and by creating out-of-control stampedes for the packages.

The United States and Canada do not want their efforts to halt the flow of
refugees returning from Zaire to Rwanda by creating a disincentive to go home,
as some United Nations officials fear.

"We are fundamentally committed to helping the refugees, but we want to do so in
a way that's effective," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said.

National security adviser Anthony Lake conceded yesterday that many problems
have to be worked out. "I hope they all have solutions," he said. "We just don't
know the solutions yet."

Lake also said he hopes African nations will participate in the mission, but the
reaction to the plan was cool in Rwanda, which objects to deploying an
international force within its borders.

One appeal of operating out of Entebbe is that Western allies could circumvent
any Rwandan objections while avoiding areas of Zaire not under government
control. Another advantage, officials said, is that the international force
could respond quickly to any change in the situation.

The nature of the problem and, therefore the solution, has changed drastically
since President Clinton announced earlier this month that he was willing to send
up to 5,000 members of the armed forces to the region, with 1,000 ground troops
in Zaire.

With the return home of about 600,000 mostly Rwandan Hutu refugees in recent
days, officials are debating how extensive the remaining problem is and how best
to complete the exodus from Zaire.

Although Rwanda insists the crisis has subsided, some estimates place several
hundred thousand refugees remaining in eastern Zaire.

Africa was not the only national security issue on Clinton's plate as he
returned to Washington yesterday from a 12-day Asian-Pacific vacation and trade
mission. Shortly after landing at the White House in the morning, he was hard at
work trying to assemble a new foreign policy team for his second term.

Chief of Staff-designate Erskine Bowles met him with a two-inch-thick binder of
transition recommendations covering possible Cabinet selections and potential
reactions to those choices by Congress and constituency groups.

Clinton then met with Bowles for three hours, joined at times by telephone by
Vice President Gore and outgoing Chief of Staff Leon E. Panetta.

Clinton and his family left last night for a Thanksgiving weekend at Camp David,
where he will review his briefing book and prepare for possible announcements
next week of new secretaries of state and defense.

                                The Toronto Star

              November 23, 1996, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

Baril briefs leaders on east Zaire Weekend meeting to decide mission of
multi-national military force

BYLINE: By Bill Schiller Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 651 words

DATELINE: STUTTGART, Germany


   STUTTGART, Germany - Canada's Lt.-Gen. Maurice Baril arrived here yesterday
from Central Africa, armed with the first western eyewitness account of more
than 100,000 Hutu refugees still on the run in eastern Zaire.

He met behind closed doors, with military representatives from 25 countries, to
press his case for speedy deployment of a multi-national force.

Having sized up the problem in a four-day mission, Baril told reporters
yesterday he hopes to have "a full slate of options" available for participating
countries to assess by the end of the weekend.

The man who will lead any multi-national force sent said military planners and
humanitarian aid groups first must agree on the scale of the task.

That could take the whole weekend, he said.

Estimates of refugees still on the move inside eastern Zaire range from 200,000
to 500,000.

"We have to determine how many refugees there are and where they are," said
Baril, who flew in from Entebbe, Uganda, at 3 a.m. yesterday.

"We're about to commit some pretty heavy resources to help those refugees," he
told a press conference. "Planning depends critically on getting a clear picture
of the situation on the ground.

"Before any country is going to commit their sons and daughters to go in . . .
they've got to be guaranteed that's it's a mission that's possible."

But, as time passed yesterday, some countries were having second thoughts,
either reducing original offers of support, like the United States or
threatening to drop out, like Ethiopia.

Out of eastern Zaire came a promise from Tutsi rebel leader Laurent Desire
Kabile that if western countries even consider a troop deployment there, they
would do it over the dead bodies of his fighters.

The rebels control a swathe of eastern Zaire and believe any humanitarian force
sent in would be aimed at retaking territory lost by the Zairean army.

Rwanda, too, has expressed disquiet over western deployment, saying the refugee
crisis is over.

But Baril said yesterday he had personal assurances from Rwandan Vice-President
Paul Kagame that a western humanitarian mission would be able to stage any
relief effort from Rwandan soil.

The general said he flew in a military craft at an altitude of about "1,000
feet" over a 60-kilometre corridor along the Zaire-Rwanda border this week and
observed more than 100,000 refugees on the move inside Zaire.

"These were Rwandan refugees," he said "and they had been tracked from Bukavu
and had moved (for) four or five days because of the fighting along the road."

To avoid gunfire, they had moved high up on to a hill. "When we flew over them
they were just breaking camp," he said.

Baril denied there was growing friction between military planners and
humanitarian officials over the numbers in need but agreed there was "a
difference of opinion" on the issue.

He believes as many as 250,000 refugees may be on the run. Aid groups suggest
twice that number.

The general stressed that military planners are relying on "definite sources" of
information and technical data, whereas the aid organizations have not had
contact with the refugees for several days.

But Baril and the aid agencies agree the Central Africans must be helped.

"If we have people starving in our range of our possible operation," he said, "I
really don't care whether he's a refugee or a 'displaced person.' We're going to
go and feed them."

The U.N. Security Council last week authorized deployment of up to 12,000 troops
to help get food to the refugees.

The United States promised about 1,000 logistics specialists and $172 million in
humanitarian aid. The European Union has pledged $244 million.

Canada has promised troops, the leadership of Baril and $15 million in
humanitarian aid with most of the funds going for food, medicine, blankets, crop
seeds, latrines and water in the countries involved.
