                               November 21, 1996

ZAIRE AID FORCE ON HOLD AS JETS SEEK REFUGEES

BYLINE: Ian Black Diplomatic Editor

SECTION: THE GUARDIAN FOREIGN PAGE; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 667 words


SCALED-DOWN plans for an international military mission to central Africa were
on hold yesterday, awaiting information from aerial reconnaissance on the
whereabouts of between 500,000 and 700,000 displaced Rwandans whom aid agencies
maintain are still stranded in eastern Zaire.

An RAF Canberra was flying over the region, seeking refugee encampments,
especially in the south Kivu region.

Military leaders from 14 countries, including Britain, France, the United
States, and Canada, delayed a meeting set for yesterday to discuss the size and
shape of a Canadian-led force to help refugees caught in the fighting in eastern
Zaire. They are expected to meet tomorrow in Stuttgart.

With the return to Rwanda in recent days of an estimated 500,000 refugees,
Germany's foreign minister, Klaus Kinkel, said several countries were having
second thoughts about joining the mission.

Michael Portillo, the Defence Secretary, said it was too early to say whether
the 10,000-12,000 strong force envisaged last week was still required. British
troops remain on standby.

France insisted it was still preparing to send soldiers and urged the US to do
the same. Washington has cancelled plans to send combat troops to Zaire and is
preparing instead for a relief operation involving fewer than 1,000 logistical
personnel.

Politicians meet in New York today to decide what help the refugees now need.
Canada will chair a meeting of donor countries in Geneva.

Britain's Overseas Development Administration announced a further pounds 10
million of assistance to the Great Lakes region, bringing to more than pounds 18
million the amount given this year.

Mr Portillo called for a radio information campaign to let Rwandan refugees know
it was safe to go back to their homeland.  "It is possible that there are still
people in deep distress who need our help, so we will go on planning the
mission," he said.

"I think a small number of troops will be necessary anyway on a multinational
basis to help Rwandans with taking the people across the border and to undertake
that information campaign. I really cannot say whether we are going to need the
full military mission."

                              The Washington Post

                   November 21, 1996, Thursday, Final Edition

Zaire Rebels Allow Search For Refugees; Rwandans Scattered Around Border Area

Lynne Duke, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A27

LENGTH: 927 words

DATELINE: BUKAVU, Zaire, Nov. 20


As governments and aid groups continued to dispute the number of Rwandan
refugees remaining in eastern Zaire, the rebels who control this border town
agreed tonight to allow relief officials to scour the surrounding area for
refugees and gauge the needs of any they might find.

Since 500,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees returned to their home country over the
weekend from camps around the Zairian border town of Goma, 80 miles north of
here, the fate of the other half-million Rwandans who have taken refuge in
eastern Zaire since 1994 has been hotly disputed. Aid groups maintain that
hundreds of thousands remain in Zaire -- many of them around Bukavu -- while the
Rwandan government proclaimed on Tuesday that all the refugees had returned home
or were on their way there and that the two-year-old refugee crisis was over.

Resolution of the dispute could determine whether foreign governments proceed
with plans to send a multinational military force to help with the feeding and
repatriation of any remaining refugees.

Tonight's move by the rebels, a largely Zairian Tutsi force that has driven the
Zairian army from much of the border region, broke a week-long impasse between
them and international aid workers and gave relief officials their first access
to the Bukavu region since the rebels seized this town on the southern shores of
Lake Kivu nearly three weeks ago.

The Rwandan refugees in Zaire were mostly Hutus who fled their country in 1994
in fear of reprisal killings when a Tutsi-led rebel force halted extremist
Hutus' massacre of Tutsis and moderate Hutus, which claimed an estimated
half-million lives. They settled in camps clustered mostly around Goma and
Bukavu, which were dominated by the perpetrators of the 1994 massacre, who
staged guerrilla raids into Rwanda and prevented the other refugees from
returning there.

The Hutu refugees were scattered from most of those camps in recent weeks by
fighting between the Zairian army and the Zairian rebels, who were backed by the
Rwandan government. At least 500,000 refugees gathered at one Goma-area camp,
Mugunga, and returned to Rwanda over the weekend; the rest are unaccounted for.

The United Nations says about 700,000 Rwandans are still in Zaire. Of those
refugees, aid workers say about 500,000 are scattered in the hills and forests
of Zaire's South Kivu Province, where Bukavu is located.

In Washington, U.S. officials said today that because it is the rainy season in
central Africa, clouds have impeded satellite surveillance attempts to track the
refugees. The United States has used low-flying C-12 and P-3 propeller planes --
one of which observed nearby antiaircraft fire today -- to try to find refugees
who are still unaccounted for. On Tuesday, these aircraft found two groups, each
with approximately 50,000 refugees, on either side of a volcano at the north end
of Lake Kivu. But by today the groups had disappeared, and U.S. officials said
they did not know where they had gone.

The overflights also found an estimated 200,000 people in one group in the
Mitumba Mountains, west of the lake. However, officials said many of those could
be Zairians displaced by fighting in the area. Senior U.S. officials said aerial
surveillance had found nothing south of Bukavu.

Relief officials in Kigali, the Rwandan capital, added to the uncertainty today
when they reported that tens of thousands of refugees from around Bukavu were
moving north toward Goma and could come through that border town into Rwanda
within the next few days.

Here on the the Rusizi River, which separates Bukavu and the Rwandan town of
Cyangugu, there was a small but steady flow of a few hundred refugees into
Rwanda today.

Aid officials contend that the masses of refugees still unaccounted for are in
dire need of food and medical care. The international military force, these
officials contend, remains critical to ensure that aid is delivered safely and
effectively, and they say the uncertainty about the numbers of refugees makes
discussion of canceling the mission premature.

"This is exactly the wrong time to step back from the worst refugee crisis in
modern times," Lionel A. Rosenblatt, president of the Washington-based Refugees
International, said as he stood at the Rwanda-Zaire border waiting for
permission to cross to Bukavu.

The fate of the proposed force will be discussed Friday in Stuttgart, Germany,
by representatives of nations that may participate in the mission.

Returning refugees who crossed from Bukavu to Cyangugu today told of continuing
ethnic conflict deep in the Kivu region, with members of the former Rwandan
militias continuing their anti-Tutsi campaign on Zairian soil.

"My coming here now is because of the instability in that place," Antoine
Kayiranga, 50, said of the camp at Katana, about 25 miles north of here, where
he lived until early this month. He was separated from his wife and children
during the fighting in the region and does not know where they are.

Unlike most of the refugees who have poured back into Rwanda in recent days,
Kayiranga is a Tutsi who fled Rwanda in 1959 when Hutus came to power shortly
before Rwanda gained independence from Belgium. Despite having deep roots in
Zaire after so many years of living here, Kayiranga said he had to leave because
the Hutu extremists who have lived among the Rwandan refugees "have exported
their genocide ideology to that region."

Correspondent Stephen Buckley in Kigali and staff writer Thomas W. Lippman in
Washington contributed to this report.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                          November 20, 1996 Wednesday

Caution on the road to Kigali

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A18

LENGTH: 596 words


'WE have already won an early battle against moral blindness and self-interest
by galvanizing the world community," Jean Chrétien says of Canada's leadership
in the mission to Central Africa. "Let us now do what is required to complete
the work."

Here are two thoughts begging examination, in light of changing circumstances.
The first suggests that Canada has succeeded in bringing this calamity to the
world's attention. For the most part, this is true. It was Mr. Chrétien who
telephoned world leaders and won commitments from them to join the force. By
week's end he had recruited a dozen nations -- including the United States,
France and Britain -- for a multinational force, eventually authorized by the UN
Security Council.

Whether Mr. Chrétien was motivated by frustration, morality or opportunism,
whether he wanted to revive Pearsonian diplomacy or restore honour to the
tarnished armed forces, he acted creatively. As the leader of a middle power
with a tradition of humanitarian intervention, he was able to mobilize Canada's
resources, influence and good will. Moreover, he was able to win the confidence
of the Africans and of the Americans.

The mandate of the mission was largely (though not wholly) defined when Canadian
soldiers departed for Zaire on Friday. The purpose was to provide food, water
and medicine to the refugees in the camps of Zaire and secure safe passage for
them to return to Rwanda. It was not to disarm the rebels or prop up the
government. The mission was to stay four months and carry weapons, with strict
rules of engagement.

That was last week. Now things have changed. On the weekend, the refugees
unexpectedly began leaving the camps for Rwanda. Today these camps are largely
empty. The apparent need is not to provide them protection to leave Zaire, but
to feed and house them in Rwanda.

All of which brings us to the second part of Mr. Chrétien's statement: "Let us
now do what is required to complete the work." The question, of course, is
knowing what is required in Central Africa today, which isn't necessarily what
was required last week. The Prime Minister says the situation is "fluid" but
maintains the mission is still necessary.

But are 12,000 soldiers still necessary? Maybe, we could say, if there are
indeed 500,000 weak and hungry refugees remaining in the bush, as aid agencies
maintain. The trouble is that this assessment is contested, and it has
introduced two new constraints. First, the government of Rwanda says it doesn't
want foreign soldiers on its soil, which is why it refuses to let any more
Canadians land in Kigali. Second, the United States has rescinded its offer of
soldiers, agreeing only to provide logistical support.

The situation is changing. If the Rwandans refuse to welcome the multinational
force, it will have to operate out of Zaire, which will be harder. And if the
Americans refuse to join it, it will be considerably weaker.

Members of the government have allowed that the mission may well be changed,
which will be discussed in New York today and Germany tomorrow. It may be too
early to say how, but it could be reduced dramatically, or even cancelled.

The challenge for Canada is to manage the mission's momentum. That we have
organized the mission is not reason to send it -- unless its necessity is
reaffirmed by new information. At the moment, the mission should be rethought
and recalibrated. In light of changed circumstances, should more of our
resources be devoted to sending food rather than troops? The worst course would
be to do something solely for the sake of doing it.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                               November 20, 1996

America will send Zaire food instead of troops

BYLINE: Patrick Brogan

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 537 words


THE Clinton administration has decided with great relief that it need not send
any troops to Zaire, to help Rwandan refugees return. Just four days after Mr
Clinton announced that 5000 troops were going, the Secretary of Defence, William
Perry, said today that 300 would be quite enough - and in Rwanda, not Zaire
itself.

These will be Air Force personnel and they will help air traffic control at
Kigali airport. Others will deploy to airports at Entebbe in Uganda and Mombasa
in Kenya. In all, there will be fewer than 1000 Americans, all employed in
logistics.

The change in the situation on the ground began on Friday, just as Mr Clinton
announced his decision. Half a million Rwandan refugees have already returned
home and it is hoped that the rest will follow in the next few days. What they
need now is humanitarian relief, and the Americans are already despatching
planeloads of food and medicine.

They announced yesterday that the United States would provide $ 140m (£85m) for
relief operations, aimed chiefly at helping children.

The head of the US Agency for International Development (AID) said today that
there were still more than 100,000 refugees in Zaire. They have been spotted
from the air: the US has been flying reconnaissance flights over the region for
the past week.

The American decision to scale back its efforts before they began could be
reversed again, if the need arose. Mr Perry made the point today that the
situation remains very fluid. The future of the international operation will be
discussed on Thursday at a meeting in Frankfurt under the chairmanship of the
Canadians.

Meanwhile, for many Hutus the suffering continued in the homeland they fled in
1994 after their kinsmen committed genocide against minority Tutsis and pro
-opposition Hutus.

Tens of thousands of returning refugees demanding food today blocked the streets
of Nkamira, 13 miles northeast of Gisenyi at the border with Zaire.

French President Jacques Chirac, speaking in Tokyo, backed the force despite the
mass migration. He said one French objective was security in eastern Zaire - a
new mission for the force given a narrow mandate by the Security Council.

Britain also refused to bury the force, dogged by delays and confusion for the
past fortnight before it is even deployed.

Rwanda wants the resources originally set aside for the force to be diverted to
resettle the returnees instead.

The peace force's future also appeared complicated by President Nelson Mandela,
who said South Africa would contribute troops only if they were led by an
officer from the region.

"I am not prepared to put my troops under any other commander except a commander
from the Great Lakes," Mandela told reporters.

Two soldiers stood on guard outside the UN transit centre at Nkamira, stopping
refugees from entering to have a rest, sleep and receive food as planned by the
UNHCR.

The Rwandan authorities insist the refugees, exhausted by days of marching and
sleeping rough, keep trudging onwards to their home villages.

The few who have made it back to their villages said there had been no animosity
from their former Tutsi neighbours.

                                The Toronto Star

                  November 20, 1996, Wednesday, METRO EDITION

Africa force in doubt Canada may give aid - not troops, Chretien says

BYLINE: by Tim Harper Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 794 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA - Prime Minister Jean Chretien said yesterday the refugee crisis in
Central Africa may not require a military intervention.

The United States yesterday decided to reduce its troop commitment for the
region from 5,000 to fewer than 1,000 - none of them combat units - after the
peaceful return since Friday of about 500,000 refugees from Zaire to Rwanda.

Ottawa appeared ready to follow suit a week after pledging to lead an
international force of as many as 12,000 soldiers.

"It might be, in the next three or four days, we might be in a situation where
the armed forces will not be needed any more," Chretien told the House of
Commons yesterday.

He said Rwanda has promised it would facilitate the smooth movement of relief
workers and open its southern border to a further influx of refugees from Zaire.

"This would not necessarily have to be done by soldiers," Chretien said.

Three meetings this week are expected to make clear the relief force's final
shape:

* At the United Nations today in New York, the mission partners mobilized by
Chretien will examine what help the refugees require.

* In Stuttgart, Germany, tomorrow or Friday, Canada, America and other troop
contributors will plan the role - if any - of the military.

* In Geneva Saturday, Canada's International Co-operation Minister Don Boudria
will convene a meeting - possibly the most important of the three - of donor
nations to examine what aid each country or international agency can bring.

In Kigali yesterday, Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana said Rwanda would only
accept military units coming to help with projects such as distributing water
and building emergency housing.

"We want the secretary-general to make a report to the (U.N.) Security Council
that the mission is not now necessary," Gasana told reporters.

But the mission's Canadian commander insisted yesterday a role remains for the
multinational force in central Africa, The Star's Allan Thompson reports.

"The aim of my mission in here was to see what could be done for the refugees -
wherever they are," Lt.-Gen. Maurice Baril said in Kigali.

"We are evaluating what we can do and readjusting any planning that was going
on."

Baril was to meet Rwandan officials in the capital Kinshasa before continuing to
Stuttgart.

The Prime Minister said if things unfold efficiently, there would be no need for
military intervention once the refugees return home to Rwanda.

"The problem would become strictly humanitarian," Chretien said.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has appealed for $66.9 million
for its emergency operation for refugees displaced by the fighting in eastern
Zaire.

Canada has pledged $15 million.

"We have taken on the leadership for the whole intervention. It seems totally
logical that the leadership be also taken for the humanitarian intervention,"
Boudria said.

"Remember, the only reason there is a military intervention to start with is to
offer the humanitarian aid."

In other developments yesterday:

* A disagreement arose over where aid is required.

Gasana said "hardly any" of the 500,000 Rwandan refugees remain in eastern
Zaire.

But the U.N. refugee agency contradicted him, saying the Zairean camps held more
than 1.2 million refugees.

U.N. envoy Raymond Chretien said in Kigali: "There are still approximately
between 300,000 and 500,000 (unaccounted refugees) according to our best
estimates and we have to know a bit more about what is happening to them."

* U.S. Defence Secretary William Perry said the United States still planned to
join the Canadian-led force in its mission to help the refugees and encourage
voluntary repatriation.

But he said the mass return justified a smaller force "and these will be support
logistics troops rather than combat troops." Washington had planned to commit
about 1,000 ground forces and about 4,000 other military personnel for massive
support operations such as transport.

* The peace force's future appeared complicated by President Nelson Mandela, who
said South Africa would contribute troops only if they were led by an officer
from the region.

"I am not prepared to put my troops under any other commander except a commander
from the Great Lakes (region of Africa)," Mandela told reporters. Initial plans
called for South African troops to remain in the region after the international
force completed its four- to six-month mission.

* The British government ordered a probe into arms export controls after the
discovery of documents indicating a British firm supplied $5.53 million in
military equipment to the Rwandan Defence Ministry during the massacre of
thousands of Tutsis.

With files from Reuters.

                                The Toronto Star

                   November 19, 1996, Tuesday, METRO EDITION

Zaire mission to proceed: PM But task shifting, Chretien says

BYLINE: By Tim Harper TORONTO STAR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 425 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA - Prime Minister Jean Chretien says the Canadian-led humanitarian
mission to Zaire will proceed, although the nature of the job is shifting,
buffeted by changes in the region.

"We have already won an early battle against moral blindness and self-interest,
by galvanizing the world community into action," Chretien told the House of
Commons yesterday.

"Let us now do what is required to complete the task."

As he spoke in a parliamentary debate, Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy
shored up support for the multinational force which is gathering to aid hundreds
of thousands of refugees in Central Africa.

But Washington has hesitated in its support of the force and African nations are
calling for aid rather than arms.

The need for intervention was cast into doubt by the mass exodus of refugees
into Rwanda following the collapse of Hutu militias that had been holding them
virtually hostage in camps along the border in Zaire.

Defence Minister Doug Young suggested yesterday to reporters that the military
component of the initiative could be called off and turned into a strictly
humanitarian effort.

"Canadians deserve to know what we are getting into and what we can reasonably
expect," the Prime Minister told the Commons.

The return of some 500,000 refugees from Zaire to Rwanda is "all very good
news," he said.

"But let's not forget that fighting continues in the region and the situation is
very fluid.

"We know the changes on the ground will affect the mission."

In response to those changes, Chretien said, Canada pumped $15 million in
humanitarian aid into the region and has organized a meeting of major donor
nations.

That meeting could take place perhaps as early as Saturday, according to
International Co-Operation Minister Don Boudria.

In addition, Christine Stewart, secretary of state for Latin America and Africa,
has been dispatched to Africa to meet with leaders believed to be resisting the
international effort, and force leader Lt.-Gen. Maurice Baril was to arrive
overnight in the region to be briefed by the special United Nations envoy,
Canada's Raymond Chretien.

The shape of the effort is likely to be decided at a meeting of
troop-contributing nations set for Thursday in Stuttgart, Germany.

The opposition Bloc Quebecois lent its support to Chretien during Commons
debate, but the Reform party would only "grudgingly" back the mission, according
to its foreign affairs critic Bob Mills (Red Deer).

                              The Washington Post

                   November 19, 1996, Tuesday, Final Edition

Families Fall Apart On Road to Rwanda; Thousands of Children Find Themselves
Alone After Walk That Was Supposed to Lead Home

Stephen Buckley, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A15

LENGTH: 995 words

DATELINE: GISENYI, Rwanda, Nov. 18


As they hustled to escape the world's largest refugee camp last week, thousands
of Rwandans left behind some of their most important possessions: their
children.

Some youngsters got separated from loved ones during the weeks when as many as
500,000 Rwandan refugees were crushed into Mugunga camp in eastern Zaire,
roughly 10 miles west of this border town. Others vanished on Friday when the
refugees, tired of two years in exile and two weeks caught between warring
militias, began walking to the Rwandan border.

"We left Mugunga during the evening, after the fighting," Immaculae Hatungakana,
46. "We were walking together, and then I turned around and he was gone. Since
then, I have been calling his name over and over on the road."

The boy, 7, has not answered. He may be among the nearly 2,000 children who have
passed through the transit center for unaccompanied youngsters and infants at
the border. Or he may not.

Aid workers said that figure was lower than expected for such an exodus, but
they stressed that they believe thousands more children are still on the Zairian
side of the border. No one knows precisely how many children were in the refugee
camps in eastern Zaire that for two years held about 1.1 million refugees.

Most of the refugees were members of Rwanda's Hutu ethnic majority who fled in
1994 when a Tutsi-led rebel force took power from a militant Hutu government
that had slaughtered at least 500,000 Tutsis in a matter of weeks.

About 750,000 Hutus settled in camps around this town, but fighting between
Zairian troops and a Zairian rebel force -- led by Tutsis and backed by Rwanda's
Tutsi-led government -- cleared all of the camps except one, Mugunga. The
half-million refugees there were under the sway of former government and
military leaders who intimidated anyone seeking to return to Rwanda -- until
Friday, when continued fighting drove the Hutu militants deeper into Zaire and
the refugees headed the other way.

Relief officials said some children returned to Rwanda alone after losing their
parents when fighting broke out in other camps before refugees began crowding
into Mugunga. The children made it to Mugunga, then came into Rwanda with the
rest of the refugees this past weekend.

Claver Ntuyenabo, 45, said he became separated from his three daughters and two
sons while they were hiding in a forest after fighting broke out in their
refugee camp three weeks ago.

Ntuyenabo, who crossed into Rwanda alone on Saturday, said his family had left
him in the forest because "I was very weak, and I was sick. I told them to wait
for me at a particular point. I never saw them. I continued alone to Mugunga.
Then I came to Rwanda."

Relief workers said such accounts are not uncommon among the unaccompanied
children they have seen since Friday. But most frequently, they said, children
got separated from their parents during the trip from Mugunga.

During their trek to Rwanda, the refugees packed the road to the border. Fathers
hefted children onto their shoulders. Mothers strapped babies to their backs,
and youngsters clung to their skirts, half-running with awkward, choppy strides.

But many children, jugs of water or small sacks on their heads, could not keep
up with their families. At times the crush of moving people became especially
chaotic. The air was thick with sweat. Couples argued. Children bawled.

"Children, hold on to your parents!" aid workers shouted continually through
megaphones as refugees passed the border. "Parents, hold on to your children!"

Many tried but could not.

"It was easy to lose two or three children," said Mike McDonagh, emergency
coordinator for the Concern relief group. "I walked in the middle of those
refugees, and it was dark and confusing."

The lost children who are now in the care of aid workers appear stunned. Many
are exhausted, having walked for as long as three weeks with little food or
water. They do not move. They do not speak.

Infants and toddlers, meanwhile, often appear oblivious to their plight. In a
room at the transit center for unaccompanied children, they screamed, sucked
their fingers, eyed strangers with curiosity and slept.

A girl, about a year old, eagerly took porridge from a relief worker, who gently
wiped the child's lips after every spoonful. The girl's mother died on Sunday.

Aid workers say that cases involving such small children are especially tough
because the youngsters cannot provide information that could help relief
agencies reunite them with parents or relatives.

"They can't tell you their parents' names or which commune they're from," said
Charlie Main, an emergency officer with UNICEF.

Relief groups can do little more than take pictures of the youngest children and
distribute them. Older ones do provide crucial information, which aid groups --
primarily Save the Children, the International Committee of the Red Cross and
Concern -- then distribute in the child's home community, hoping that someone
who knows the boy or girl will see it.

Some unaccompanied children are intentionally left behind. Many youngsters who
were separated from their parents as long ago as the 1994 exodus to eastern
Zaire were taken in by strangers. Upon returning to Rwanda, those strangers
sometimes "no longer see the child as a priority," said Mary Dunne, a Concern
nurse.

Among all the trauma that marked the trek into Rwanda, some stories had happy
endings. Today, Ndwi Mukanya, 22, sat by the road several hundred yards after
crossing into Rwanda with her 3-day-old baby.

The baby, late afternoon sun glistening off its black curls, reared its head
back and howled, repeatedly clenching its tiny, wrinkly fingers. Mukanya said
she had walked several miles into her homeland after giving birth to the girl,
who does not yet have a name.

Mukanya, who said her ordeal left her with an aching back, pressed out a weak
smile. "In all of this trouble," she said, "I am happy."

                                Guardian Weekly

                               November 17, 1996

Canada prepared to lead Zaire force

BYLINE: Chris McGreal in Goma and agencies

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 405 words


CANADA offered this week to lead a multinational force to help end the crisis in
eastern Zaire and bring vital relief to more than a million Hutu refugees
displaced by four weeks of fighting, United Nations sources said in New York.

Canada's intervention came as Laurent Kabila, the leader of the Rwandan-backed
rebels who have seized parts of eastern Zaire, threatened a renewed attack on a
large refugee camp unless the international community sends troops to neutralise
Hutu extremists.

South Africa would also be prepared to send troops as part of an international
force, President Nelson Mandela said in a television interview on Monday. He
said he would send a delegation to the region to gather information.

Meanwhile the United States, a crucial player in any UN decision to send troops
to Central Africa, denied it was blocking the creation of an international force
but said it had still not seen a coherent plan for assembling one.

In Goma, the provincial capital seized by rebels earlier this month, Mr Kabila
appeared to be laying the groundwork for breaking his own ceasefire in order to
launch a new onslaught against Hutu militias using Rwandan refugees as a shield.

Speaking as the first humanitarian aid dribbled into rebel-held areas on Monday,
Mr Kabila, who heads the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of
Congo-Zaire, warned that the war was about to escalate because Hutu extremists
in the Mugunga refugee camp were continuing to shell Goma.

He said he would accept an international force only from countries he deemed
neutral. Nations such as Sweden would be acceptable but he would prefer troops
from African countries such as Mall, Zimbabwe or Ethiopia. French soldiers would
be presumed hostile because of Paris's support for Zaire's president, Mobutu
Sese Seiko.

In Goma, there are mixed emotions about the surly young men wandering the
streets with Kalashnikovs over their shoulders. Some say they welcome the rebels
as less abusive than the Zairean forces that fled. Goma was always an ugly town,
but suspicions run deep among the people: "We are glad to see the Zairean army
gone," said Theoneste, a young moneychanger. "They were always drunk. That is
why they did not fight. But these rebels are all Rwandans. We can hear it from
the way they talk. So what do they want here? We are not Tutsis. We are not like
them."

Martin Woollacott, page 14

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           November 16, 1996 Saturday

UN authorizes Zaire rescue force  Security Council sets March 31 deadline for
Canada-led humanitarian mission to end its work

BYLINE: BY PAUL KNOX The Globe and Mail

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1024 words


The United Nations Security Council unanimously gave its blessing last night to
a Canadian-led multinational force in eastern Zaire, authorizing it to use "all
necessary means" to rescue hundreds of thousands of refugees cut off from aid by
fighting.

The 15-member council set a deadline of March 31 for the force to finish
delivering food and medicine to the refugees and help their "voluntary, orderly
repatriation" to neighbouring Rwanda.

Council members ignored Rwanda's plea to hold off approval while seeking more
information about the mass return of refugees that began yesterday from one zone
in the vast, troubled region.

They heeded the call of Robert Fowler, Canadian ambassador to the UN, who said
the 1994 slaughter of Tutsis and moderate Hutus in Rwanda approached the horrors
of the Holocaust and must not be repeated.

"We are absolutely convinced that there is no alternative but to act," Mr.
Fowler told the council. "When we said, 'Never again,' we meant it."

Even with the beginning of yesterday's refugee exodus from Zaire to Rwanda, Mr.
Fowler said, there are still "close to a million" Rwandans and displaced
Zairians who need food, shelter and medical help. "People will continue to die
in eastern Zaire in appalling numbers."

The decision means 10,000 troops from 20 countries will be sent to Central
Africa as soon as they can be airlifted there. U.S. and Canadian reconnaissance
teams already are in the area.

Most of the force will be made up of soldiers from the United States, France,
Britain and Canada, Mr. Fowler said, adding that firm offers of troops have been
received from other European countries, Latin America and Africa.

He pleaded with other countries to contribute to a UN fund set up to pay the
expenses of African countries providing troops. So far, Senegal, Ethiopia and
Malawi have offered battalions, he said.

The force will be limited to helping relief agencies return to eastern Zaire and
distribute supplies among refugees and Zairian civilians, as well as allowing
those who want to return home to do so.

Mr. Fowler rejected the idea of broadening the mandate to include disarming Hutu
militias and former members of the Rwandan army who have been active among the
refugees in Zaire.

That would imply a declaration of war, he said. "Such a war would bring enormous
and immediate harm to those we are seeking to save."

Relief agencies say it will be difficult to get food and medicine to many of
those who need it without disarming the militiamen who still control some groups
of refugees.

Rwanda's UN ambassador, Gideon Kayinamura, told the council that the proposed
force was "no longer relevant, at least as far as rescuing refugees in eastern
Zaire is concerned."

He said the mission should be smaller, be able to disarm the militias and last
only two or three months. Other countries should provide Rwanda with resources
to help resettle returning refugees, he added.

Mr. Kayinamura traded verbal shots with Zaire's UN ambassador, Lukabu Khabouji
N'Zaji, who accused Rwanda of staging yesterday's refugee exodus as a
"diversionary tactic" to slow the momentum for a rescue force.

"We are not responsible for the misery Zaire is going through," Mr. Kayinamura
retorted.

Earlier, U.S. President Bill Clinton said news of the refugees' return was
encouraging, but the mission should still go ahead with U.S. participation. "The
world's most powerful nation must not turn its back on so many desperate people
and so many innocent children," he told reporters at the White House.

Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy, claiming partial credit for the return
to Rwanda of refugees, told reporters in Ottawa that it would be wrong to cut
the size of the planned rescue mission.

"The initiative that was taken this week, beginning last weekend with the Prime
Minister, is already, I think, beginning to pay its own dividends in terms of
having a breakthrough."

U.S. officials prevailed in arm-wrestling with Canada over the maximum length of
the mission. The Canadians had argued for a six-month term.

Mr. Fowler also said plans will be drawn up for a follow-up mission headed by
the UN that would focus on human rights, reconciliation and strengthening
democratic institutions in Rwanda.

Rwandan Hutu refugees swarmed into eastern Zaire in 1994 after members of the
Tutsi ethnic group seized power. The Hutus, who included Rwandan army troops and
militia members, feared reprisals for massacres of Tutsis and moderate Hutus
carried out by Hutu extremists.

Militias took effective control of some UN-supervised camps, warning the
refugees that they would be killed if they returned home.

The latest crisis erupted when anti-government rebels, many of them Tutsis with
links to Rwanda, began an offensive in the border region, routing Zairian troops
and seizing three towns. Refugees fled the camps to avoid getting caught in the
fighting.

Controversy swirled around the dramatic return of thousands of refugees
yesterday. The giant Mugunga camp emptied, apparently after the Hutu militias
that controlled it were routed in an onslaught by the Tutsi rebels.

Mr. Fowler's estimate of nearly a million people in need of aid in Zaire was at
odds with that of Ray Wilkinson, an official of the UN High Commissioner for
Refugees in Goma, the key refugee centre. He said 700,000 refugees in the Goma
area were heading to Rwanda.

Two days ago, the UN's humanitarian affairs department said 200,000 refugees
from Katale, the northernmost camp in the region, were dispersed in thick forest
about 70 kilometres northwest of Goma.

Another 250,000 fled camps near the southern town of Uvira, the first to be
captured by the rebels more than two weeks ago. And about 200,000 had been
housed in camps near Bukavu, which is between Uvira and Goma.

Before yesterday, only small groups of a few thousand each had reached Tanzania,
Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda after fleeing the rebel onslaught.

Relief agency staff said the Mugunga refugees were likely to be stronger and
healthier than those roaming the bush. They are reportedly surviving by eating
grass, roots and rotting sweet potatoes from abandoned hill farms.

OVERVIEW: NOVEMBER 9 - 15

SECTION: THE GUARDIAN FOREIGN PAGE; Pg. 18

United States

'I get so much money to fight, man, how can I not continue?' asked a battered
Mike Tyson after being beaten into submission against all the bookies' odds in
the eleventh round in Las Vegas by Evander Holyfield. A reasonable enough
question, given that the controversial heavyweight and former rape convict
picked up A18 million for one night's violent drubbing in front of 16,000
hysterical fans. Holyfield (A8 million) modestly attributed his victory to god.

No sooner was Tyson led off in his blood-stained white towelling than his
promoter, the eccentric despot Don King, was talking up a rematch he claimed
could break box-office records. This week's spectacle drew the biggest
pay-per-view audience in boxing's television history 1.6 million people.

French Guiana

The European Space Agency's launch-pad for its Ariane rockets (right) a place
otherwise known as French Guiana, South America's only non-independent state was
shaken by days of rioting in the capital, Cayenne. Paris flew 200 paramilitary
riot police reinforcements into the territory when protests by school students
over poor conditions turned into a looting free-for-all.

Zaire

After the better part of a month of studious hesitation over whether to send
troops to help more than a million refugees in eastern Zaire, the United States
decided to commit ground forces to central Africa, but hand the chalice of
potential disaster to Canadian command of the multinational operation. Britain
came on board, as did France, which had with Spain led calls for intervention.

But force contributors insisted their focus was an aid mission, and not to
complete the unfinished business from the 1994 genocide in Rwanda - the source
of the present Zaire conflict. This would mean disarming Rwandan Hutu refugee
fighters in eastern Zaire, and probably also clipping the wings of their rivals,
Zairean factions backed by the Rwandan army.

The oddly named Operation Phoenix Tusk, under a United Nations mandate, is
expected to last at maximum six months. Then a mainly African force would
replace it.

But confusion over the size and task of the mission deepened when thousands of
refugees began to head back towards the Rwandan border as their interahamwe
tormentors retreated westwards.

Belgium

The European Union's independent Court of Auditors reported that fraud and
bureaucratic error around the EU cost an estimated A3.2 billion last year.
Fiddles by farmers and olive oil producers, and the erroneous waiving of customs
duties, were among the errors of omission or commission found. But, it added, 80
per cent of the money gone astray was the responsibility of member states; 20
per cent was down to Brussels.

Greece

The nation with the biggest budget deficit in the European Union had a brilliant
new idea. It unveiled a military spending programme to pump more than A11
billion into overhauling its armed forces by 2007. The insistence of the prime
minister, Costas Simitis, that this would not affect Athens' targets for meeting
European Monetary Union criteria left some wondering whether he had been reading
too many Greek myths.

Caspian Sea

The week of the United Nations Food Summit in Rome, not to mention the refugee
crisis in Zaire, seemed less than an ideal moment for the World Wildlife Fund to
dish up troubling news for the rich: Planet Earth is on the brink of running out
of caviar due to rampant sturgeon-poaching centred in the Caspian Sea.

And that wasn't all: South African ostrich meat, beloved of trendies shunning
beef, was banned by the European Union due to reports it carries a potentially
fatal disease.

Bosnia

Hoping to relegate one of the most embarrassing figures from the Bosnia war to
non-person status, Bosnian Serb politicos issued an ultimatum to their military
commander, General Ratko Mladic: step down, or else.

Or else what? was the attitude of the indicted war criminal's troops as they set
up roadblocks around Mladic headquarters and invited some visiting Bosnian Serb
luminaries including the defence minister to stay for dinner. Indefinitely.

Meanwhile, word at a Paris conference was that a 30,000-strong international
force would remain in Bosnia for one or two years the high figure reflecting
pessimism that the 'peace' would last if the republic were left to its own
devices.

Hong Kong

The Hong Kong Governor, Chris Patten, flew to London to seek firmer guarantees
of residence rights in Britain after 1997 for up to 5,000 ethnic-minority
residents of the colony. Despite backing from the Queen, his mission bore no
immediate fruit. Nor did the government, which is rebasing 750 Gurhka troops
(right) to Britain, relent on its refusal to let the soldiers' families, who
live with them in Hong Kong, go along.

India

Two fiery rows blew up over the world's worst mid-air crash when a Kazakh cargo
plane collided with a Saudi jumbo jet near New Delhi's airport, killing 349
people (below).

Russian officialdom, defending the Kazakh pilot, said outmoded control equipment
at the airport was to blame. The Indians blamed a misunderstanding by the Kazakh
pilot, or equipment failure on his allegedly poorly maintained plane.

While that verbal war went on, funerals began for the victims, conducted by
Muslim, Hindu and Christian clergy. But Muslims (the majority of the Indian dead
from the Saudi plane) bury their dead, and Hindus cremate them. Thus a tragedy
looked like being compounded by a religious dispute.

Guide to the Zaire crisis: Which military units will be going in to help; The
forces

BYLINE: Christopher Bellamy Defence Correspondent

SECTION: INTERNATIONAL; Page  10

LENGTH: 288 words


Reconnaissance teams from the Western nations leading the international
intervention in eastern Zaire have begun arriving in central Africa. The first
United States teams arrived on Thursday and the first British reconnaissance
team, 43-strong, was due to arrive in Nairobi at 6.30 last night, having flown
from Brize Norton in Oxfordshire.

The intervention force is deploying under Chapter Seven of the United Nations
Charter, in an "enforcement" rather than a peace-keeping role.  The troops will
concentrate on guaranteeing the delivery of humanitarian aid and helping
refugees return home, but will fire back if they or those they are guarding are
threatened.

Of the 75 nations represented at the UN meeting in New York, as yet only Canada,
the US, Britain, France, Spain and six African countries appear committed to
providing troops

The headquarters of operation "Phoenix Tusk" will be Goma, the main airfield and
centre of refugee movement. Yesterday, 10,000 refugees from the five camps
around Goma were reported to be moving back through the town and south-east into
Rwanda, the first of an estimated 300,000-400,000. The operation will be
commanded by the 1st Canadian Division, under General Maurice Baril. Canada is
sending a force of 1,500 in all.

US troops will also head for Goma. About 1,000 US troops are expected to be
deployed on the ground; another 2,000 to 3,000 are expected to be based in
Uganda and Kenya.

Britain and France are likely to secure the airport at Buk-avu. Britain plans to
send head- quarters of 5 Airborne Brigade, troops from 1st Battalion Parachute
regiment and 45 Commando, Royal Marines. MoD sources said yesterday the British
force could reach 3,000.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                   November 15, 1996, Friday, JOURNAL EDITION

President Clinton right to move slowly on Zaire

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 22A

LENGTH: 540 words


THE UNITED STATES has taken some heat for its reluctance to send troops into the
maelstrom of fighting, killing and starving that has enveloped the Zaire-Rwanda
border. Now President Clinton has announced plans to contribute some 4,000
soldiers to a multinational force that will try to restore the flow of food,
water and medicine to hundreds of thousands of refugees.

The decision may quiet some of the international criticism, but the fact is that
the administration was correct to move very carefully on this issue, and to
insist that certain security safeguards be guaranteed before any troops are
dispatched. Both in the short term and in the long run, this is a crisis that
has no easy answers and few hard ones, and any intervention holds grave risks
for everyone concerned ---foreign troops, aid workers and refugees alike.

Remember that the humanitarian tragedy of the refugees is taking place in the
middle of two civil wars: the bloody tribal conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in
Rwanda, and the effort by rebels to overthrow the government of Zaire. Many of
the refugees themselves are direct participants, not innocent bystanders.

In this fiercely hazardous environment, it's far more likely that things will go
wrong than right. So we believe the president was wise to go slow and to demand
several conditions: agreement by all parties to allow the international force to
operate, tough rules of engagement that will allow the troops to use whatever
force necessary to protect themselves, and a fixed time limit on the operation.

In the long run, we don't see why the United States has any higher obligation
than any other nation to bring order to the chaos of the region. No specific
American political interest is at stake, and when it comes to humanitarian
concerns, every country bears an exactly equal obligation. There's no reason
Washington should be expected to take the lead in every crisis, especially when
other nations are as well-equipped to contribute.

The conflict in Rwanda and Zaire is precisely the sort of thing that ought to be
addressed by countries closest to the action, and thus most directly affected.
At the United Nations, America has already proposed an African Crisis Response
Force (ACRF), that would include military forces from nations like South Africa,
Nigeria, Ethiopia, Senegal and others. A bipartisan commitment in Congress got $
20 million in the federal budget to help create such a force.

In a post-Cold War world of ethnic and nationalist outbreaks, that is a far more
sensible approach ---in any region, not just Africa ---than the automatic
assumption that the United States must lead, and carry the heaviest burden, in
every crisis around the globe.

We don't suggest that America shrink from defending its genuine interests, or
from carrying its fair share of the burden. We do believe that it's time for new
structures, new processes, and new ways of calculating responsibilities, so that
future international endeavors will be not just fair, but maybe even more
effective.

Editorials represent the position of The Atlanta Journal and are written by its
editiorial board, whose members are Jim Wooten, Jeff Dickerson, Martha Ezzard
and Richard Matthews.

Govt considering personnel contribution to Zaire effort

BYLINE: Yomiuri

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 201 words


The government has begun studying the specific personnel and financial
contributions it can make to the international effort to aid refugees in Zaire,
senior government officials said Thursday.

"We have started to look into the possibility of contributing personnel," Chief
Cabinet Secretary Seiroku Kajiyama told reporters.

Japan will not participate in the multinational force to be made up of troops
from the United States, Canada, Britain, France and other European and African
nations because this body will be permitted to use arms. Participation in such
force would violate the Constitution, which bans the dispatch of troops to
settle international disputes.

"A request for a financial contribution has already been made by Canada," said a
high-ranking Foreign Ministry official.

However, he said, "Japan wants to consider conspicuous way of providing support
in addition to money."

The government is studying ways to help refugees, possibly in cooperation with
the Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees or non-government
organizations, he said.

In the autumn of 1994, Self-Defense Forces members were sent to Zaire to help
Rwandan refugees fleeing an internal war.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                 NOVEMBER 15, 1996 Friday MORNING FINAL EDITION

WHAT'S AHEAD FOR U.S. FORCES IN ZAIRE

BYLINE: Mercury News Washington Bureau

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 26A

LENGTH: 374 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


President Clinton is expected to announce today that the United States will send
military forces to take part in the humanitarian effort to aid refugees in
Zaire. Here is a look at the problem, what the United States might do to help,
and the conditions that must be met for the U.S. to become involved:

The problem: More than 1 million Rwandan refugees, mostly members of the Hutu
ethnic group, are trapped in eastern Zaire. They recently were cut off from
food, clean water, health care and other assistance during an outbreak of
fighting among the Zairean army, Rwandan Hutu guerrillas, and other military
factions.

What's expected: The Americans and other U.N. military forces would help secure
an airport at Goma, near the refugees, to permit international relief
organizations to fly in food and set the stage for other assistance. About 1,000
U.S. infantry soldiers - spearheaded by Army paratroopers based in Vicenza,
Italy - and about 400 Canadians would help secure a three-mile-long corridor
between Goma airport and Rwanda through which refugees could return home safely.
About 4,000 American soldiers are expected to participate in airlift and
security operations over about four months.

Potential dangers: American forces would face conditions as dangerous and
chaotic as those three years ago in Somalia, where 18 U.S. service personnel
died in a firefight. There are tens of thousands of armed Rwandan Hutu militia
members and 40,000 former Rwandan soldiers mixed in among the civilians who fled
their country in 1994. Any relief and repatriation would have to deal with the
presence of these guerrillas and soldiers as well as with the murderous anger
between Rwandan Hutus and the now-dominant Rwandan Tutsis.

American conditions: While President Clinton called American participation in
the relief effort "vital," he set a series of stringent conditions that must be
met before American troops would participate, including:

Local governments and forces now fighting must agree to the peaceful entry of
United Nations troops.

The U.S. forces will not attempt to disarm militias or other fighting forces and
will be prepared to respond violently in the event of attack under "very robust
rules of engagement."

                             The Guardian (London)

                               November 14, 1996

MISSION TO SAVE MILLION LIVES;
Clinton agrees to send US troops into Zaire as part of multinational force.
Britain may send 3,500 soldiers to join relief drive

BYLINE: Martin Walker In Washington Ian Black In London And John Palmer In
Brussels

SECTION: THE GUARDIAN HOME PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1627 words


PRESIDENT Bill Clinton yesterday agreed, under intense international pressure,
to send United States troops to Zaire as part of a multinational force under
overall Canadian command, with neither its precise objectives nor rules of
engagement clearly defined.

Britain followed suit by saying it was ready to contribute "constructively" to
the international effort, "providing a satisfactory plan can be worked out" for
dealing with an unprecedented humanitarian relief mission to more than a million
refugees caught up in fighting by Tutsi rebels in Zaire.

John Major said later: "We will contribute, we will definitely send troops." But
he said their number, the scope of the mission and its "exit strategy" were yet
to be decided.

The Foreign Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, said: "The United Kingdom is prepared to
play its part, including a military contribution, to help deal with the
humanitarian aid, to get food, medical aid and shelter to the refugees."

If crucial issues can be resolved at a meeting of potential contributors at the
United Nations in New York today, thousands of troops from north America, Europe
and African countries could be heading for the Great Lakes region of central
Africa by the end of this week.

The rapid deterioration of conditions in Zaire has led to chaotic military
planning.  As the standby orders went out last night from the Pentagon, which is
to send up to 5,000 troops - 1,000 into Zaire and the rest in logistical and
support roles - commanders were still uncertain of their brief.  The defence
department said the mission would not exceed four months.

The Defence Secretary, William Perry, said: "Our mission will be to secure Goma
airport (in eastern Zaire), and then open and secure a (three-mile) land
corridor to the main refugee area, to bring food and medical relief to this
terrible humanitarian tragedy."

The White House spokesman, Mike McCurry, insisted yesterday: "The mission is not
to disarm militants, nor to conduct any forced entry into the area, nor to
police refugee camps."

But commanders wondered whether they would have to impose a local ceasefire and
establish and police a humanitarian zone.  Some basic aims of the mission are
not yet agreed, such as whether the troops will shepherd refugees back into
Rwanda, or deeper into Zaire.

Rwanda's president, Pasteur Bizimungu, warned yesterday that intervention would
get "messy" unless rebels in control of eastern Zaire were consulted.

US ambivalence about the UN and multinational operations means Mr Clinton's
decision carries huge political risks. It could end the post-election honeymoon
with the Republican Congress.  Haunted by the humanitarian mission to Somalia,
which veered out of control in his first months in office, Mr Clinton was talked
into the mission by Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien.

After a long night of negotiations in the Pentagon, General Maurice Baril, the
commander of Canadian ground forces, secured a rare agreement by Washington
early yesterday to put its forces under Canadian operational command. They will
remain under US tactical command.

But the US insisted on "robust" rules of engagement. They will be allowed not
only to defend themselves, but to patrol aggressively to ensure they are not
attacked.

The logistical challenge of flying in troops and equipment, and food and
medicine for a million refugees, into an area with few roads and dilapidated
airfields - where cholera vies with Aids as a health hazard for the troops -
"will make Somalia look like a tea party", one Pentagon officer told the
Guardian yesterday. "We are looking at literally hundreds of C-5 (carg o plane)
airlifts," he added.

"Every second counts," Emma Bonino, the European Union's humanitarian aid
commissioner, told the European Parliament yesterday. "If it (the mission)
arrives in three weeks, it will have a lot of work burying corpses, but not much
else."

The mission is to be tripartite. There will be a north American contingent of
some 1,500 Canadian troops and two US logistics and communications battalions,
protected by US paratroops.

The European contingent is expected to have British, French and Spanish troops,
with the Netherlands and Belgium providing logistical support. Although no
British units have yet been placed on standby, the most likely option is a light
brigade of about 3,500 troops, drawn primarily from 45 Commando Royal Marines
and the 1st Battalion The Parachute Regiment.

France said yesterday it was prepared to send 600 paratroopers to Zaire within
24 hours of UN approval of the mission, and 600 more a day later. It is also
making available its bases in west and central Africa.

The WEU, still embryonic as the eventual European pillar of Nato, will undergo
its first big test when officials meet in Belgium on Monday to co-ordinate.

European countries are expected to foot the bulk of the bill and provide
equipment and training for the African contingent, whose participation is seen
as essential politically. The main local contingent will be South African, with
token units expected from Mali, Ethiopia, Cameroon, Senegal, Eritrea and Congo.

The UN Security Council was planning a special session last night to give a
formal mandate to the effort, not as a Nato mission, but as an unprecedented
"multinational force under Canadian command".

US officials told the Guardian they expected their part of the mission to be
"very limited in time, to establish the conditions in which the African
countries will be able to take over on the ground and create the space for a
longer-term political settlement".

                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

                          November 14, 1996, Thursday

Refugees, go home Zaire leader changes tack, says Rwandans must leave

LENGTH: 441 words


PRESIDENT Mobutu Sese Seko has thrown his weight behind moves to send home more
than a million Hutu refugees caught at the centre of warfare in east Zaire.

Canada stepped forward yesterday to lead a planned multinational force to secure
food aid and passage for the refugees scattered by three weeks of violence in
eastern Zaire.

But judging by the firm statement by Mobutu, until now the protector of ethnic
Hutu refugees who fear revenge at home for a massacre of the rival Tutsis, the
intervention force's main task will be providing safe conduct back to Rwanda for
the refugees.

"The refugees are the source of many problems," Mobutu told a television
interviewer in France where he is convalescing after cancer surgery. So everyone
should go home and each government take the responsibility of looking after its
citizens." Most of the Hutus are Rwandans who fled after the 1994 massacre of up
to a million Tutsis or their sympathisers. Some are Hutus from Burundi who fled
massacres in their own homeland.

The governments of Rwanda and Burundi, both led by Tutsis, as well as the Zaire
authorities, want the Hutus back in their countries. So do ethnic Tutsi rebels
who have seized Zaire's two eastern provinces where refugee camps were located.

Many of the refugees also say they want to go home but that they are being
prevented by armed Hutu hardliners, most of them former Rwandan soldiers who led
the 1994 genocide of the Tutsis.

Hardline Hutus, apparently using refugees as human shields, are battling ethnic
Tutsis around Mugunga camp near Goma. The situation in the camp has been unclear
since the Tutsis defeated the Zaire army in recent fighting.

Most of 1.2 million camp refugees and hundreds of thousands of Zairean villagers
fled into the jungle where aid workers say thousands could die of hunger or
disease.

Canada said yesterday it had agreed to lead a multinational military force to
take aid to the refugees but details of the operation were still being worked
out.

Canada told officials at the United Nations it needs more than 10,000 troops for
the operation, which it expects to last four to six months, UN spokeswoman
Sylvana Foa said. After that time any mission, if needed, would be under a UN
flag.

Among the countries that have expressed a willingness to join the force are
France, Spain, Italy, South Africa, Ethiopia and Mali. Still key to the
operation are anticipated responses from the United States and Britain before
the UN Security Council formally approves the operation.

UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros Ghali said that he expected more than 12
countries to participate.

                             The Guardian (London)

                               November 13, 1996

US STALLS ACTION TO HELP REFUGEES;
International force for Zaire

BYLINE: Martin Walker In Washington

SECTION: THE GUARDIAN FOREIGN PAGE; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1160 words


THE United States, distracted by cabinet reshuffles and its attempt to unseat
the United Nations secretary-general, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, was being dragged
slowly and unwillingly yesterday into giving token logistical support to a
Canadian-led international force for the refugee disaster in Zaire.

American foot-dragging threatened to prevent swift and serious action, as it did
two years ago. US officials were stalling on the grounds that there was no clear
military goal: was the force intended to safeguard humanitarian convoys, push
refugees back into Rwanda, or send them back into their old camps in Zaire?

Canada's agreement to lead a multinational force, and the reluctant acceptance
by the Rwandan government of a modest French component, has made some kind of
intervention likely.

But the basics of the operation - such as the number of troops, the kind of
mandate needed, and how to finance it - are uncertain, victim of the confusion
which surrounds all such UN ventures while America remains so deeply ambivalent
about them.

"There is no coherent plan, rather four or five proposals running together," the
state department spokesman Nicholas Burns said.

The US says the refugees should be encouraged to return to Rwanda rather than be
herded back to the overstrained camps in Zaire.

But Mr Burns was careful not to rule out some American involvement in tackling
"this terrible humanitarian tragedy".

Canada was taking the lead in planning the intervention yesterday, consulting
Britain, France, the US and other interested powers.

But no meeting was scheduled at the UN in New York, where Mr Boutros-Ghali was
hoping that a successful international effort could strengthen his case for
staying in office for a second term, despite US threats of a veto to exclude
him.

Canadian officials hoped that a "firm decision to proceed" could be reached this
week. They have offered a specially-trained force of 1,200 lightly armed troops
with its own logistic, medical and communications facilities as the keystone of
the effort.

Earlier offers from France and Spain to provide troops were stalled by Rwanda's
initial refusal to accept French forces, seen as partial to Zaire.

UN rules require the interventions' formal approval by the governments of Rwanda
and Zaire, even though Zaire's authority has broken down in the eastern region.

Britain, which was discussing the intervention with Canada yesterday, says it
will contribute, but no decision has been taken whether this will comprise
troops, logistic support, or emergency finance.

Ironically, the Zaire crisis seems tailor-made for the proposals floated last
month by the US secretary of state, Warren Christopher, for an "African Crisis
Response Force" with troops from African countries and financial assistance from
richer countries, including the US.

But it may have come too soon for such an effort, which provoked criticism from
the Republican-run Congress as a dangerously open-ended financial commitment
which might draw the US into other unwise interventions, as in Somalia.

The US, increasingly unpopular at the UN, was voted off an important budgetary
committee this week.

Senator Jesse Helms, just re-elected to resume his chairmanship of the foreign
relations committee, described it as "an outrage against the country which foots
the bills".

* Hundreds of Zairean soldiers who deserted when rebels drove them out of Goma
have been arrested near Kinshasa after an odyssey on hijacked barges down the
River Zaire.

A Zairean military officer said that most of the deserters, who numbered more
than 600, had been held since Friday in Maluku, which merges with the capital's
outer suburbs. They would appear before a military tribunal.

                              The Washington Post

                  November 13, 1996, Wednesday, Final Edition

U.S. Sends Team to Central Africa; International Force to Aid Rwandan Refugees
Being Considered

Thomas W. Lippman, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 1037 words


The Pentagon dispatched a 40-member team to Central Africa yesterday to assess
supply and security needs as Clinton administration officials said the United
States is likely to participate in an international military rescue mission to
aid Rwandan refugees in Zaire.

Senior officials said, however, that no U.S. forces would be committed to such
an effort until crucial questions have been answered about how a force would be
organized, who would lead it and what its objectives would be.

Under growing pressure from France, Canada and the United Nations to make a
commitment to a mission to aid an estimated 1.1 million Rwandans in need of food
and shelter, U.S. officials said they are not going to be stampeded into an
operation that could blow up in their faces.

Nevertheless, U.S. officials stepped up planning for possible U.S. participation
in a relief effort. A team from the U.S. Agency for International Development is
attempting to cross into Zaire from Rwanda, the State Department said.

The Defense Department's announcement that an assessment team will be flown to
Central Africa from Italy today said that "this deployment will enhance the
military's ability to respond but does not represent a commitment by the U.S. to
deploy other forces."

U.S. officials made little effort to disguise their irritation with France,
which made a plea for an international force last week. In the American view,
Paris did so without providing a credible deployment plan in a transparent
effort to ingratiate itself with Africa at U.S. expense.

Canada, which has offered to lead a humanitarian mission and provide troops for
it, sent a senior-level delegation here yesterday to discuss the proposed
intervention with White House national security adviser Anthony Lake and other
senior U.S. officials.

The United States agrees that such a mission is probably necessary, U.S.
officials said, adding that if it takes place America should participate. The
international community has a humanitarian obligation to help in such a dire
situation, and the United States has the kind of transport planes, generators,
water purifying units and other necessary equipment, officials said.

But one official who was briefed on the talks said Washington is taking the
position that "we are not prepared to go to Congress and the American people
with a plan that is not fully thought out, without agreement on rules of
engagement or force capability. We will not haphazardly throw U.S. troops into
such a volatile situation."

As they have throughout the past week, U.S. officials stressed the complexity of
the situation in eastern Zaire. It is true that hundreds of thousands of people
probably need help, U.S. officials said, but at the same time the circumstances
on the ground make it difficult to provide that aid without risking an armed
conflict with Rwandan militias.

"You can't simply, you know, air drop C-rations or MREs [meals ready to eat], as
they're called, in there and hope it all gets solved," State Department
spokesman Glyn Davies said. "We can't simply go in there without a plan for
dealing with repatriation" of the Rwandan refugees to their home country.

Most of the refugees in Zaire are Hutus who fled Rwanda after the genocidal
conflict there in 1994. Rwanda now is controlled by the rival Tutsi tribal
group, which drove out the Hutus after suffering hundreds of thousands of deaths
in the 1994 fighting. The refugees recently fled their camps along the
Zaire-Rwanda border when a Zairian Tutsi group, facing expulsion from Zaire,
began attacking the Zairian army units in the area.

The U.S. position, shared by the Rwandan government, is that any plan to aid the
refugees must include their return to Rwanda.

According to several U.S. officials, the biggest obstacle to deploying a relief
mission is that the refugees remain largely under the control of former Rwandan
officials and Hutu militia leaders who perpetrated the mass killings in 1994.
Those Rwandans do not wish to return home because they fear reprisal or
prosecution, and they have persuaded or intimidated the refugees, who have been
their meal ticket for the past two years, to stay with them.

Rwandan Ambassador Theogene Rudasingwa said here yesterday that his country,
like the United States, opposes any rescue mission that simply returns the
refugees to their former camps, which the Hutu militias had used as bases to
harass Rwanda.

"An international neutral force of intervention should have a clear mandate for
neutralizing these [Hutu] forces," he said at a forum at the Center for
Strategic and International Studies. Otherwise, he said, "the government of
Rwanda is willing and ready to undertake to liberate Rwandese refugees from
these [Hutu] criminals."

In light of the possibility of further violence, U.S. officials said, Washington
wants to know exactly what an international force would be expected to do and
where, what its exit strategy would be, how the legitimate refugees would be
separated from their militia bosses, and who would pay for the African military
units envisioned in the Canadian plan.

Estimates of how long it would take to resolve these issues firmly enough to
take the matter to President Clinton ranged from 24 hours to several days. With
a decision pending on extending the U.S. peacekeeping commitment in Bosnia,
officials said, the administration does not want to embark on a mission in
Africa that would evoke memories of the 1993 Somalia debacle.

Canada's offer to lead a relief mission came after Prime Minister Jean Chretien
spent the weekend telephoning leaders in Europe, Africa and the United States to
gauge support.

He said the country has received commitments from 10 nations to participate, and
from that should be able to assemble the up to 10,000 troops needed for a
strictly "humanitarian" effort.

Canada itself would commit up to 1,500 troops, including a newly formed Disaster
Assistance Response Team that could deliver military physicians, engineers and
communications experts to Africa within 48 hours.

Correspondent Howard Schneider in Toronto and staff writer Peter Baker in
Washington contributed to this report.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           November 12, 1996 Tuesday

Canada offers to lead aid force  South Africa also willing to commit troops for
humanitarian relief mission

BYLINE: BY JEFF SALLOT The Globe and Mail

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 639 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


Canada is offering to lead an international military force to help deliver food
and other humanitarian assistance to hundreds of thousands of starving refugees
in Central Africa, aides to Prime Minister Jean Chrétien said last night.

The United Nations Security Council is to meet today to consider the Canadian
offer and also that of South African President Nelson Mandela to provide
additional troops for the mission.

The United States, a key player because of its ability to provide military air
transport and other logistical support for such a mission, has yet to make a
decision on committing U.S. troops. General John Shalikashvili, chairman of the
Joint Chiefs of Staff, told CNN, "Obviously, before you commit troops you have
to understand very clearly what their tasks should be, whether they are really
the right solution."

France, which has been spearheading efforts to create a multinational force,
says it is ready to contribute 1,000 troops, but insists the force of about
5,000 men must be made up of U.S. and African troops as well as European
contingents. Rwanda has objected to French intervention.

Canada has pledged to send a special 180-member Canadian Forces team as the
vanguard unit for a larger UN force.

Known as the Disaster Assistance Response Team, the lightly armed mobile unit
would include officers experienced in UN peacekeeping missions, communications
officers, a field hospital capable of treating 500 people a day and a complete
water-purification system that could be set up in the jungles of Central Africa.

Mr. Chrétien has been on the phone to about 15 other world leaders over the
Remembrance Day weekend trying to muster support for a multilateral humanitarian
relief mission for the refugees caught in the crossfire between rival military
forces near the Zaire-Rwanda border.

"The Prime Minister has been concerned about this situation for about 10 days,
and when it appeared that nobody was going to do anything about it, he started
making phone calls," an aide to Mr. Chrétien said.

Canada offered the DART team or "whatever else we can to get this thing moving,"
the aide said.

The Prime Minister's nephew, Raymond Chrétien, the Canadian ambassador to
Washington, is on a special mission to Central Africa for UN Secretary-General
Boutros Boutros-Ghali to see whether the world body can secure safe transit of
food and medicine to the refugees who have been wandering the jungles of eastern
Zaire.

Relief agencies, frustrated by their inability to get food and medicine into
eastern Zaire, say thousands of refugees are days away from starvation and there
is great risk of a deadly cholera epidemic because of poor sanitation.

A UN force could secure corridors across the border so that relief supplies
could move by road west into Zaire and so that Hutu refugees could return to
their homeland in Rwanda.

Thousands of Rwandans fled their country after the 1994 slaughter of more than
half a million people in one of Africa's worst ethnic clashes.

DART teams are prepared to move within 48 hours of a go-ahead order. They were
established after the Rwandan crisis when a small UN contingent led by Canadian
Major-General Roméo Dallaire was unable to get tons of food and medicine to
civilians caught in the crossfire.

DART teams generally are not combat forces -- they carry only sidearms for
personal protection -- and are intended to deal with a variety of disasters,
including floods and hurricanes. They are highly mobile and can be deployed
anywhere in Canada or around the world.

They come equipped with enough food and water to sustain themselves in the field
for 10 days and to remain in the field for another 30 days with fresh supplies
flown in by giant C-130 transport planes. The government has allocated enough
money from the defence budget to mount three DART missions a year.
