                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                          September 9, 1992, Wednesday

The march of refugees

BYLINE: By Jonathan Powerinternational; immigration; aid; war; opinion

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Section A; Page 13

LENGTH: 817 words


Dusseldorf, Germany - Three years ago refugees flooding from east to west were
instrumental in bringing down the Berlin Wall, the single most sinister symbol
of the Cold War. Now anti-refugee riots flaring up in ex- East Germany have
become the ugliest reminder of what was worst in the former communist
dictatorship, a propensity to vitriolic intolerance.

Yet, here in the prosperous, educated, former West Germany, there are
significant numbers of Germans who are taking Yugoslav refugees into their
homes. Germans today make more effort than most to lend a hand to the underdog
and dispossessed.

Last year, Germany took in 40 percent of all the refugees admitted to the West,
a quarter-million of them. The Germans are now struggling with a constitution
that ties them to the open door. The Germans cannot cope. But can anyone else?
In 1951, there were only 1.5 million refugees. By 1980, there were 8.2 million.
Today there are 18 million.

Contrary to myth, it is not the United States that has the widest door of
welcome. It is not Europe either, even though it takes in six times as many as
America. It is the Third World. The great majority of refugees seek - and are
given - shelter in the world's poorer countries. Among the 20 African countries
most critically affected by famine, 13 are hosting - for the most part
voluntarily - a substantial number of refugees.

Contrary to myth, aid to refugees has not always been humanitarian and benign.
The United States consciously used its "refugee aid" to underpin the Afghani
refugee/guerrillas based in Pakistan, and U.N. relief and food agencies were
pressed by the big western nations to support the Khmer Rouge camps in Thailand,
even though they were transparently used as military training centers. The
crisis today in the Horn of Africa is very much rooted in the geo-political
competition between Moscow and Washington in the 1970s and '80s that used
international relief programs to support one refugee warrior group against

The reduction of tension between the old superpowers, and their disengagement
from many of the regional and internal conflicts that generated so many refugees
in the past, does make it easier, in a number of cases, to both wind down the
fighting and send the refugees home. (The United Nations High Commission for
Refugees is attempting to raise funds to sustain 20 such repatriation programs.)
Nevertheless, what is apparent in Yugoslavia and the upheavals in the former
Soviet Union is that the end of the rival meddling of the United States and the
U.S.S.R. is of little significance to a number of deep-rooted nationalistic and
ethnic conflicts.

At one time, outsiders could afford to detach themselves from much of the
consequences of their actions - or others' actions. These days, television takes
us into the abyss of every crisis, and cheap, fast transport brings the fleeing
bodies to the nearest open door.

But asylum policies are universally incoherent and ineffective. The total cost
in Europe of processing asylum applications and feeding, clothing and housing
refugees while they await a decision on their admittance is an extraordinary $ 7
billion a year. This is 10 times the annual worldwide expenditure of the U.N.
High Commission for Refugees.

The relatively recent spate of unwanted migrations, Kurds from Iraq, Vietnamese
to Hong Kong, Haitians to the United States, Bhutans to Nepal and Yugoslavs to
Germany, raises the question of whether the world can go on tolerating internal
actions and policies, once considered a country's own business - "the sovereign
right to be brutal," as one cynic aptly described it - when they have such a
profound impact on a neighbor's well- being, security and stability.

For the first time ever, when Saddam Hussein attacked Iraq's Kurdish population
and refugees poured over the mountains into Turkey and Iran, the world said no.
U.N. Security Council Resolution 688 was a marker for our times. It was the
first time a Security Council resolution explicitly stated that the
international community had a right to intervene with humanitarian aid to
protect a people, even if its state did not agree.

Perhaps we have to prepare ourselves for more of this kind of action in the
future, though clearly in Yugoslavia the conflict is so far gone and so
complicated that simple military action a la Kurds is not realistic or
practical. Notwithstanding, there are many situations in which a far-sighted
step before a situation spins out of control could stem a refugee crisis in the
making. This is why the peacekeepers should have gone into Yugoslavia at the
beginning of the crisis. And why the peacekeepers arriving in Somalia are a year
too late.

Preemptive peacekeeping to staunch further refugees is a topic the world
community needs to start to debate in a hurry.

Jonathan Powers is a columnist for the International Herald Tribune.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              July 24, 1992 Friday

Immigration falling short of target   Advocates challenge Canada's commitment to
refugees

BYLINE: ESTANISLAO OZIEWICZ; GAM

LENGTH: 696 words


BY ESTANISLAO OZIEWICZ
Immigration Reporter
Canada likely will fall well short of its target of 250,000 immigrants for
this year, based on "landing" levels for the first three months, a senior
Immigration Department official confirms.

The anticipated shortfall this year follows on the heels of one last
year, when Canada had an overall immigrant target of 220,000 but admitted
205,650.

According to recent Immigration Department statistics, Canada landed
53,543 immigrants for the first three months of this year. ("Landing"
means permission to come into Canada to establish permanent residence.)
   If that trend continues, said Meyer Burstein, the department's director
of strategic planning, the department will undershoot the 250,000 target
set by Parliament in the second year of the Conservative government's
five-year immigration plan.

The levels in the plan were determined after nation-wide consultations.
Immigration Department officials say the size and mix of immigrant
categories are designed to meet the country's economic, social and
humanitarian objectives. For example, judging by numbers alone, the
family-class category (with a target of 100,000 of the 250,000 total this
year) is the most important component.

"The shortfalls are likely to be in refugee categories," Mr. Burstein
said.

Nancy Worsfold, executive director of the Montreal-based Canadian
Council for Refugees, said yesterday that the figures show a weakening
commitment by Canada to the humanitarian ideals it espouses on refugees.

For many refugee advocates it is ironic that at a time of burgeoning
refugee populations worldwide, Canada would not meet its refugee targets.
(The targets do not include those admitted to Canada after passing through
the refugee-determination system for those in the backlog prior to Jan. 1,
1989. Last year, 24,080 in the backlog were landed as permanent residents)
   "I think it is true that for the majority of the world's refugees,
resettlement is the wrong answer," James Hathaway, a refugee specialist at
Osgoode Hall Law School, said in an interview yesterday. "But on the other
hand, the target is low and they (immigration officials) don't do a very
good job of filling it."

Mr. Burstein also said there has been an increase in the number of
people not using the visas issued to them, a situation the department
calls "visa wastage," and an increase in the length of time that potential
immigrants take before using their visas to enter Canada. Immigrant visas
are generally valid for up to one year from the time of medical clearance.

Department officials are concerned about the anticipated immigrant
shortfall for various reasons. If the deficit ends up including skilled
workers, for example, that could jeopardize Canada's future economic
prosperity.

"We try to manage to attain the targets and it's something we look at
on a regular basis," said Mr. Burstein.

For the first quarter of this year, the department is getting fewer
immigrants from Africa and the Middle East, Europe and Britain, but more
from the Asia-Pacific region, Central and South America, and the United
States.

The top 10 source countries were Hong Kong, Sri Lanka, Poland, India,
the Philippines, China, Lebanon, Iran, the United States and Taiwan.

Carter Hoppe, chairman of the immigration section of the Canadian Bar
Association (Ontario), said yesterday the shortfall indicates that the
retroactivity measures in the new immigration legislation before
Parliament are not needed.

"One of the most controversial aspects of the new immigration
legislation introduced last month, Bill C-86, is a provision to allow the
government to retroactively disqualify immigrants' applicants in process,"
he said.

"One of the reasons given by the government for the need for this
drastic power was the supposed fact that Canada had a tremendous backlog
of applications in process around the world. And the retroactivity power
would be necessary to bring the numbers down into more manageable
quantities.

"Obviously, the government has been misled by their experience in the
latter part of the eighties. If, in fact, Canada will be lucky to come
within 80 per cent of its global target, we certainly don't need a
retroactive disqualification power."

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            June 24, 1992 Wednesday

It is easy to exercise power against those who have none   REFUGEES"Moral
bankruptcy is at the root of Canada's   proposed treatment of those who come
here seeking protection

BYLINE: EDWARD HYLAND; GAM

LENGTH: 950 words


BY EDWARD HYLAND
  O NE day, I was speaking with a Tamil who recounted how the Sri Lankan
army had, on separate occasions, "disappeared" his son and burned his
crops. "Why did they do this to me? What harm could I cause them?" he
asked. Weakly, I mumbled something about the soldiers being afraid that
his son might join the guerrillas or that he might give food to them.

With great weariness and sadness he simply shook his head. "No," he
said, "they did this because they had guns and uniforms and power. And I
am a poor and powerless man. They took my son and destroyed my food
because it's easy to exercise power against those who have none. It's like
that everywhere in the world."

Immigration Minister Bernard Valcourt and his army of policy advisers
have given us an example of what my friend from Sri Lanka meant. Designed
to keep more refugee claimants out of Canada, the recently proposed
changes to the Immigration Act reveal how easy it is for the power of the
Canadian government to come down hard on those who have no power, like
refugee claimants.

The government's justification is familiar: the number of claimants is
getting out of control; the refugee system is riddled with abusers trying
to get around our regular immigration channels; there are criminals posing
as refugees trying to come to Canada; we can't let every refugee in the
world come here.

Curiously, Mr. Valcourt and his officials never talk in terms of hard
figures. Yes, it is true that in the past decade the number of refugee
claimants has increased significantly. What the government conveniently
neglects to point out is that the total refugee population worldwide has
also increased in that time - from seven million in 1983 to 17 million in
1991. As a proportion of the total refugee population, the number of
claimants who came to Canada last year represented just 0.18 per cent. The
vast majority (96 per cent) of the world's refugees are in developing
countries in Africa, Asia, the Middle East and Latin America.

Abusers? Again, one wonders what Mr. Valcourt is talking about when
Canadian officials judge that more than 95 per cent of all claims have
some degree of credible basis, requiring a closer examination. It is
simply untrue to say that refugee claims in Canada are abusive or
manifestly unfounded.

Refugees flee for their lives and often they have to use false
documents to escape because their government won't give them a passport or
an exit visa. Sometimes it's hard for us in Canada to understand this.

So what do the proposed amendments to the act hold in store for
refugees? Well, immigration officers at the border will be able, on their
own, to determine whether a person can even make a refugee claim. With the
current system immigration officers are supposed to ask people if they
want to make a refugee claim, but this will no longer be the case. With
greater power in their hands, immigration officers will be able to turn
away more people. The government's target is a 40 per cent reduction in
claims.

The minister will have authority to enter into agreements with other
countries, such as the United States or the European countries, to send
claimants to those countries when they could have made a refugee claim
there. So, for example, Guatemalans passing through the United States on
their way to Canada to make a claim would be turned back to the United
States and be forced to make their claim there. The problem is that in the
absence of standards of protection in these third countries we will have
failed in our obligation to protect those who come seeking refuge with us.

Other measures to keep refugees from making it to Canada include
tougher fines against airlines that bring refugees who do not have proper
documentation; fingerprinting and photographing refugee claimants to see
whether a person has made a claim in another country and if so sending him
or her back to the country where the claim was made; designation by
Cabinet of countries deemed safe, where people can make claims if they
pass through them before arriving in Canada; directing people who arrive
through the United States back there.

A claimant who manages to make it past the stricter immigration screens
will find a refugee-determination system that is streamlined, with the
elimination of the credible-basis stage. However, if someone's claim is
rejected, the appeal remedies available are even weaker than now, as the
person will only be able to go before a single judge of the trial division
of the Federal Court of Canada, as opposed to a three-judge panel of the
Federal Court of Appeal.

Moreover, the person still will not be able to introduce new
information or have the court examine the merits of the claim, but simply
appeal on points of law. And while awaiting the court's decision the
person can be removed from Canada.

Canada has legitimate concerns in managing its immigration program
well. However, the government continues to fail to understand the
difference between immigration concerns rooted in the national interest
and the obligation under international law to protect the right of people
fleeing persecution and violence to seek asylum. The changes recently
announced undermine that right and weaken Canada's commitment to protect
refugees.

Recently, a senior immigration official protested that his job wasn't
to deal with refugees but to make policy about them. Such moral bankruptcy
is at the root of the new amendments and Canada's proposed treatment of
those who come here seeking protection. It is also why, as my Sri Lankan
friend said, it is easy to exercise power against those who have none.
  Edward Hyland is director of the Jesuit Centre for Social Faith and
Justice in Toronto and a member of the board of the Inter-Church Committee
for Refugees.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                                  June 1, 1992

Haiti's boat people show downside of sanctions

BYLINE: Patrick Brogan

SECTION: Pg. 7

LENGTH: 581 words


Washington, Sunday

THE United States Coast Guard is returning hundreds of Haitians to their
miserable homeland every day, a reminder of the doubtful effects of economic
sanctions.

An economic blockade of Haiti was imposed after the coup in September last year.
Only medicine and humanitarian aid is allowed in.

These are the same conditions that have applied to Iraq since August 1990, and
that have just been imposed upon Serbia.

Haiti was already the poorest country in the western hemisphere. Now most of its
six million people are on the edge of starvation and desperate peasants are
cutting down the last trees for fuel: all oil imports are banned. Soon Haiti
will be an over-populated desert.

Thousands take to the seas, buying places on crowded boats in which they try to
reach America. The Coast Guard intercepts them. About 12,000 people, plucked
from the sea, many of them saved from drowning, are now being kept in tents in
the American base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba.

Now the Americans simply stop the refugee boats, take everyone on board, and
ship them straight back to Haiti. This draconian rule, imposed last week, has
yet to stem the flow.

The American contention is that these are not political refugees, who would be
entitled to sanctuary in the United States. They are economic refugees and the
US wants none of them.

The torrent of immigrants pouring into the United States from Mexico, the
Caribbean, and Asia has changed the demography of Florida and the south-west.

In Los Angeles 40% of the people were born abroad, in Latin America, or in Asia,
particularly Korea, and the conflicts arising from the presence of this immense
mass of foreigners were among the causes of the riots.

Haitians and their champions claim that they are turned back because they are
black, poor, and illiterate. They note that Cubans who manage to escape Fidel
Castro's communist paradise are all welcomed.

Miami is now a Cuban city, and there is constant tension between American blacks
and Hispanic immigrants, also between Hispanics and Haitians.

A year ago, the State Department was highly critical of Britain for proposing to
send home Vietnamese refugees from Hong Kong. The American papers have been full
of the European backlash against immigrants from North Africa, the Middle East,
and Eastern Europe.

What is happening to the Haitians is demonstration enough that the North-South
problem is world-wide.

It is also proof that sanctions work slowly, if at all. No-one has much doubt
that Serb leader Slobodan Milosevic will do as well as Saddam Hussein, despite
UN sanctions, and Colonel Muammar Gaddafi is merely inconvenienced by the
sanctions imposed on Libya.

The difference between these three cases and Haiti is that the fascist
governments of Iraq and Serbia will manage to feed their people, but the
Haitians will starve.

Soon President Bush will be faced with the choice of lifting the sanctions or
invading Haiti. The world cannot allow the imminent disaster in Haiti, however
worthy the cause of restoring President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

It is hard to see Mr Bush sending the Marines into Haiti unless there is some
further act of extreme violence there or a direct provocation. Americans are not
in the mood to police the Third World, nor even the Caribbean, and this is an
election year.

So perhaps sanctions against Haiti will be abandoned, just as they are being
imposed on Serbia.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             May 16, 1992 Saturday

REFUGEES   WHERE THERE ARE NO HAPPY ENDINGS   Land of Dreams is full of
emotional intensity and   uncompromising in its political bitterness. That said,
every frame is worth watching. TVO, Wednesday, 9 p.m.

BYLINE: SHIRLEY KNOTT; GAM

LENGTH: 656 words


BY SHIRLEY KNOTT
Let's start with a promising idea for a TV movie. The subject is political
refugees. There are as many possible dramatic plots as there are refugees
pouring into countries across Europe and North America every day. Their
numbers are overwhelming and so are their stories. The question is this:
what kind of stories do Canadian and British audiences see on their TV
screens?

In a recent Canadian attempt, we got a widow, three waifs and a hero in
a white coat battling injustice with his stethescope. It all started with
a family who had escaped the Death Squads in Central America. Along the
way, the husband is caught by American officials and sent back to his
death. The widow ends up in Toronto working illegally in a sweatshop while
her three kids hide out in a squalid flat.

As if all this weren't enough to wring tears from a troll, her baby
dies. That's when the crusading doctor comes to the rescue - battling
immigration officials, hospital bureaucrats and the heartless system of
the law. This was the story seen a few months back in the CBC's Wojeck:
Out of the Fire.

In the British movie Land of Dreams, this week on TVO, a black South
African gets off a plane in London with a forged passport and a story
about being a teacher with no political ties. That's not quite the truth.
The fact is that he's wanted in South Africa for the necklacing murder of
a policeman. He's been in and out of prison for demanding better education
for blacks, and now if he's sent back, he faces a rigged trial. There is
not much his cynical lawyer in London or his squiffy neighbour can do to
help him.

Land of Dreams couldn't have been made here in Canada. The main
character is too black, too foreign-sounding and too fond of quoting
poetry. As well, the story is too bleak, too claustrophobic in its
emotional intensity, too uncompromising in its political bitterness, and
there is no happy ending.

Land of Dreams is Joseph Mnwans's story. When he leaves South Africa,
he isn't looking for any happy endings, only a chance to go on living.
Back in South Africa, he faces a cell on Death Row. In England, he faces a
life in dingy bed-sits feeding coins into an electric heater to fend off
the damp misery of the English weather and English indifference. As a
teacher and community leader in his homeland, he was a respected man. Here
in England, his lawyer tells him, "You're just another poor nigger."

As a refugee, Joseph has lost everything - his home, family, job and
the passion of his cause. Being a refugee means being utterly
dispossessed. It also means weeks and months of answering questions,
filling out forms, filing applications, launching appeals and waiting.

For Joseph, there are alternatives. He could marry the breezy, boozy
girl next door who offers herself as his ticket to freedom. He could even
go back, as his lawyer suggests, to be a hero and martyr to the cause.
Joseph believes he can choose his own way and then discovers that being a
refugee means having no real choices at all.

For all its blunt and gritty honesty, there are moments of simple fun
in Land of Dreams. "My mother once set my hair fire," says Rudi Davies as
the next door neighbour with a whiskey-twinkle in her eye. "But she was
drunk, so it must have been an accident." As Joseph, Patrick Shai manages
to overcome some of the obvious sentimentality of the script and fill the
screen with a visceral sense of desperate confusion, fear and frustration.
Through it all, the music score jumps, jingles and soars with the voices
and rhythms of Africa.

But to get back to the comparison between the Canadian and British TV
versions of the refugee story, it has to be said that both movies aim at a
kind of realism. The question is how real? How many refugees can actually
thank a crusading doctor for helping them get a stamp on their immigration
papers? On the other hand, how many refugees have spent weeks and months
waiting for the final notice of rejection and the one-way ticket back?

                               The Daily Yomiuri

                            April 23, 1992, Thursday

U.N. Official: Refugees Get Chance To Go Home

BYLINE: Virginia Van Natta; Daily Yomiuri Staff Writer

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 477 words


More than half of the estimated 17 million refugees in the world have a chance
at repatriation, rather than resettlement in a new country, U.N. High
Commissioner for Refugees Sadako Ogata said in Tokyo Wednesday night.

Ogata, who was elected to a three-year post by the U.N. General Assembly in
1991, said 28 million refugees have been helped since the Commission was founded
41 years ago.

She said that until recently most refugees were resettled in new countries,
particularly the United States, Canada, Australia and the Nordic countries. But
now, more refugees are able to return to their homelands.

"The trend is changing and resettlement as an option is slowly drying up," Ogata
said in a press conference at Tokyo's Imperial Hotel.

She cited the sheer number of refugees, an increase in the number of countries
less willing to accept immigrants and an improvement in the chance for
repatriation as cause for the reversal.

Although 8 million refugees will have to wait for "a peace settlement of some
sort" before being allowed to return home, political changes in 20 countries,
mainly in Africa and the former Soviet Union, are opening up other possibilities
for solving refugee problems.

"Whenever a ceasefire is agreed upon and peace is restored in a country, the
voluntary repatriation of refugees becomes a reality," Ogata said.

"The most recent returns involve South Africa where political exiles have begun
to return home," she said.

Angola is expecting 300,000 repatriated refugees and in Mozambique, where the
government and opposition groups are talking peace after a lengthy civil war,
more than 1 million refugees are expected to return home, she said.

Last month, 350,000 Cambodians began a mass influx back to their homeland after
12 years in exile in camps along the Thai border.

"Prolonged civil war has left the country a virtual minefield," according to
Ogata.

"On March 30, the first group of 526 persons returned from Thailand to
Cambodia," she said, and 2,754 refugees have returned in six convoys to
Cambodia, 713 of whom returned to their villages.

The cost of repatriating millions of refugees is staggering and, according to
Ogata, Japan has become increasingly generous. In 1991, Japan's donation to the
commission was over $100 million, compared to $10 million in 1978.

"The contribution from the Japanese private sector in 1991 was the largest,
accounting for over 70 percent of all the private sector contributions" received
by the commission, Ogata said.

Japan and the United States provide more than one-third of the resources for the
commission, she said.

Ogata said Japan's geographic position keeps it from being a destination for
refugees. "Japan is not a frontline state ... The number of asylum-seekers
coming to Japan will not be as large as that coming to Europe," she said.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           February 4, 1992, Tuesday

Victims of Cold War? Critics blame left-over anti-Communist policies,
election-year jitters for closed door to fleeing Haitians.

BYLINE: By Deborah Scroggins STAFF WRITERunited/states; immigration; policy;
haiti; international; statistics

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 1

LENGTH: 678 words


U.S. refugee policies that are a relic of the Cold War and election- year
worries are driving the Bush administration's forced return of thousands of
Haitian boat people, administration critics charged Monday.

The Coast Guard shipped the first 381 Haitians back to the economic and
political chaos of their country Monday, after the Supreme Court lifted an
injunction barring their forced return over the weekend.

The government is expected to repatriate more than 6,000 others encamped at the
U.S. Naval Station at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, who say they fear political
persecution at the hands of Haiti's military dictatorship.

The Bush administration has said only 3,609 of the about 11,000 Haitians at
Guantanamo Bay qualify to apply for political asylum in the United States. But
politicians and refugee advocates claim the administration is judging the
Haitians by different standards than Soviet or Vietnamese refugees because the
Haitians are poor, black and persecuted by the wrong people.

Also, almost all Cubans fleeing the Communist regime of Fidel Castro are granted
political asylum in the United States.

"Unfortunately, the question of who gets asylum is largely based on political
considerations," said Hiram Ruiz, a policy analyst at the U.S. Committee for
Refugees, a non-profit group in Washington, D.C.

"In the case of Haiti, the political consideration is not whether these
individuals have a legitimate fear of political persecution, but what impact the
arrival of a large number of poor, rural, not very well- educated people will
have on this country."

State Department officials contend the Haitians are seeking economic
opportunities in the United States, and they point out that only a handful have
fled to the neighboring Dominican Republic. But some privately admit that
refugee policies left over from the Cold War still make it difficult for people
fleeing non-Communist dictatorships to receive refugee status.

Each year the State Department and Congress jointly work out a system of
regional refugee quotas, and each year all but a tiny number of spots go to
people fleeing Communist countries.

Of the 1,203,609 refugees admitted to the United States since 1981, 94 percent
have come from Communist countries.

Despite the end of the Cold War, refugee policies remain focused on the former
Soviet empire, partly out of inertia and partly because of strong lobbying
interests. Refugees from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will make up 43
percent of the refugees resettled in the United States this year,
notwithstanding the election of democratic governments in their homelands.

American Jewish organizations have lobbied fiercely to reserve a high quota for
Soviet Jews, for example, and in recent years 80 percent of the Soviet newcomers
have been Jewish.

"It would be naive not to admit that the existence of a strong American
constituency makes a difference," said a State Department official who insisted
on anonymity. "If a group has the ear of Congress, the ear of the
administration, it can't hurt."

Vietnamese refugees will make up another 35 percent of those resettled this
year.

Though soldiers overthrew Haiti's first democratically elected president,
Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in September, no places were reserved for Haitian
refugees.

Democrats say President Bush has pressed so hard to repatriate the Haitians
because he wants to ward off political attacks by Pat Buchanan. Mr. Buchanan, a
conservative challenger for the Republican presidential nomination, has
criticized Third World immigration.

Perhaps remembering the effect of the Mariel boatlift on President Jimmy
Carter's re-election campaign, however, the Democrats have been slow to act.
Several bills giving the Haitians temporary protected status in the United
States remained stuck in House and Senate committees Monday.

In a speech before Atlanta's Concerned Black Clergy, Nebraska Sen. Bob Kerrey
called the forced return of the Haitians "a terrible mistake." But the
presidential candidate said he did not know what to do about it.

                                   USA TODAY

                   January 23, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

High court chills hopes of asylum

BYLINE: Tony Mauro; Sandra Sanchez

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 279 words


Refugees from strife-torn nations can be denied asylum in the U.S. under a
Supreme Court ruling Wednesday.

The 6-3 decision gives immigration officials broad discretion to deny refugee
status - even to applicants who fled their countries to escape service in
guerrilla forces.

Nearly 100,000 refugee applications may be pending, most from Central America.

Loser in the case: Jairo Jonathan Elias Zacarias, who left his native Guatemala
in 1987 at age 18 after masked gunmen tried to recruit him.

The court said Zacarias' story didn't fit the legal requirement that he show
persecution for ''political opinion.''

A refugee applicant must produce ''evidence so compelling that no reasonable
factfinder could fail to find the requisite fear of persecution,'' Justice
Antonin Scalia wrote.

That high standard is ''fundamentally anti-humanitarian,'' said Arthur Helton of
the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. ''It will affect ... thousands of people
from countries with civil strife - El Salvador, South Africa, Guatemala,
Afghanistan, Haiti.''

Washington, D.C., immigration lawyer Michael Maggio said that under the court's
standard, ''If you were being forcibly recruited into the Nazi party of Germany
before they took power and you refused to attack Jews, you would be refused
political asylum.''

The fate of more than 6,000 Haitian refugees detained at a U.S. military base in
Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, also was hanging in the balance Wednesday.

Justice Department official Kenneth Starr Wednesday argued before a federal
appeals court panel in Atlanta that they ''have no enforceable rights'' to
asylum, in part because they never reached the U.S. border.

                      Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)

                  November 18, 1991 Monday Burlington Edition

Mercy flights to Africa teach stark lesson on good life

SOURCE: THE SPECTATOR

BYLINE: By STEVE ARNOLD

SECTION: TODAY; Pg. T6

LENGTH: 519 words


STARVATION AND desperate poverty may be routine for many Africans, but for
former Burlington resident Simon Round they were a pointed reminder of just how
good life in Canada can be.

For two weeks in September, the Canadian Armed Forces officer was part of a team
assigned to the United Nations for an emergency food convoy into strife-torn
Ethiopia.

Flying as the navigator of a Hercules transport plane, and landing on runways
marked by bomb craters, he made nearly 50 trips during that period.

"Ninety per cent of the airports we flew into were just strips in the middle of
the desert, and some of them were just barely bulldozed strips at that," said
the captain in an interview from his Oshawa home.

Capt. Round was part of one of several Canadian flight crews assigned to the
United Nations for the airlift into Ethiopia.

Working from bases in nearby Djibouti, they each carried up to 20 tonnes of
grain and soya meal donated by European countries and the United States.

Once unloaded in Ethiopia, the food supplies were turned over to the Red Cross
to be trucked to refugee camps -- some holding as many as 100,000 people.

"As soon as we landed, people who looked like frail little old men would start
to unload the airplane," he said.

"It took 40 minutes to get loaded in Djibouti and only 20 minutes for them to
unload the food. I guess that's the difference between being starving and having
plenty of food," said Capt. Round.

Among the UN agencies working to alleviate the desperate poverty of Africa is
UNICEF, represented in Burlington by Capt. Round's mother Jean, a pastoral lay
worker for St. Luke's Anglican Church.

According to information she supplied, years of civil war, drought and famine
have crippled Ethiopia. One in four children dies before reaching the age of
five, compared to eight deaths per thousand in Canada. The mortality rate for
women in childbirth is 40 times that of the industrialized world.

One-third of the children are seriously underweight and Ethiopia has the world's
highest illiteracy rate.

While a first visit to a Third World country can be a shock for many servicemen,
Capt. Round has made five other journey's to Africa, as well as South America
and Eastern Europe.

He is also a veteran of Operation Desert Storm.

"I'm proud to have been in the Gulf War, but this was a more enjoyable feeling,"
he said.

"The war was right and good, but here you know you are doing good things for
people and they appreciate it."

Although he didn't visit any of the refugee camps, Capt. Round said the sights
and smells of poverty are never far from the mind during any visit to Africa,
even in the heart of major cities.

"There are always beggars in the streets, men sitting on a little piece of
cardboard that they put over themselves at night," he said. "The more I travel,
the more I realize just how good life can be here."

The work of agencies such as UNICEF is supported by the sale of Christmas cards,
stationery, books toys and gift items. In Burlington, that merchandise is
available at Burlington Mall and Mapleview Centre until Nov. 23.

U.N. learns about refugees

BYLINE: Lee Michael Katz; Wendy Benedetto

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 249 words


The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, says she
learned a lot about how to deal with refugee problems from the Persian Gulf war.

Ogata, who met with President Bush last week to discuss the status of Iraqi
civilians, says the commission will use this newfound knowledge to tackle other
refugee problems around the world.

''We are the ones who experienced it. We know where the weaknesses are and where
to go for assistance. If we build up fast, we can manage (the Iraqi situation
.''

Ogata says the commission's 1991 budget is $ 800 million. These volunteered
funds go toward handling refugee problems around the world.

Ogata says the commission must raise all of the $ 800 million to be able to
manage its agenda. So far, about $ 550 million has been donated, which is almost
as much as last year's budget, she says. Iraq's refugee problem alone will cost
about $ 267 million this year.

According to the commission, the refugee problem isn't unique to the Middle East
but is a growing problem around the world.

- Asia: 6.7 million (China, 280,500; Thailand, 99,900; Hong Kong, 49,500)

- Africa: 4.6 million (Malawi, 822,500; Sudan, 767,700; Ethiopia, 710,200)

- North America: 1.4 million (USA, 1 million; Canada, 447,200)

- Latin America: 1.2 million (Mexico, 356,400; Costa Rica, 278,600; Honduras,
237,100; Guatemala, 223,100)

- Europe: 828,487 (France, 194,900; Federal Rep. of Germany, 150,700; Sweden,
139,800; United Kingdom, 100,000)

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  April 25, 1991, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

AN INVISIBLE FAMINE

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 2C

LENGTH: 341 words


International efforts to aid starving Kurdish refugees are welcome, although
refugees and others elsewhere are facing similar or worse problems with scant
attention from the West. The Bush administration initially ignored the Kurds but
has since adopted them as America's latest humanitarian cause. The shift
probably is due partly to television footage that brought the aftermath of the
Persian Gulf War into U.S. homes.  The belated response is better than none.
Aside from the Kurdish problem, however, the international spotlight needs to
focus on what is fast becoming what one relief official calls second-rate
famine. In Ethiopia, for instance, an estimated 2 million people in the Eritrea
province and another 2.4 million in the Tigre area are severely affected by
famine. Another 1.9 million in Angola are facing starvation, and the U.N. is
appealing for $136 million in aid to assist 3.9 million famine victims in
Mozambique. Starvation also has become commonplace in the African nations of
Liberia, Somalia, Chad and Rwanda.  To be sure, these African nations, unlike
the landless Kurds, have been assisted by private international relief agencies.
It also should be noted that a good part of the starvation in Africa is due to
leaders who favor guns over butter. Roughly $12 billion is spent annually on
weapons and armed forces in African countries, many of which lack en ough food
to feed their people.  In addition, the hunger and starvation in these nations
stem only partly from drought and bad harvests. A big factor is civil war, which
has created large refugee populations whose suffering is every bit as tragic as
that of the Kurds. The international community cannot give this suffering a low
priority even if its attention is focused mainly on the gulf crisis.  It took
television footage of starving children, dehydrated infants and slaughtered
adults to convince the Bush administration to respond to the plight of the
Kurds. What will it take to focus more attention on starvation and slaughter
elsewhere?

                              The Washington Post

                    November 26, 1990, Monday, Final Edition

Horror in Liberia;
African Hospitality, American Indifference

BYLINE: Lionel Rosenblatt

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A11

LENGTH: 952 words


As a veteran observer of refugees in Southeast Asia, I was prepared to see more
suffering when I went to West Africa to assess conditions for Liberian refugees.
Like almost all refugees, the Liberians brought little with them except tales of
horror -- the kind of atrocities I had not encountered since listening to
accounts of Cambodian refugees who fled the murderous Khmer Rouge regime more
than a decade ago.

Sometimes the terror in Liberia is random: villages burned, inhabitants
massacred. Sometimes the terror is dreadfully focused, as in the instance of a
young woman who told us how her brother had pleaded for her life, saying to take
his instead; his captors obliged, killed him before her eyes and then let her go
on to a lifetime of nightmares.

I found two things astonishing about the Liberian situation and its refugees --
the hospitality of neighboring countries and the apparent willingness of the
United States and the international community to tolerate continued violence in
Liberia, which indiscriminately generates more dead, more wounded and more
displaced.

The problem is large and growing -- more than half a million Liberians have fled
to the neighboring countries of Sierra Leone, Guinea and the Ivory Coast.
Counting those displaced inside Liberia, half of the country is homeless, which
may be the current world record for displacement.

Yet there are no refugee camps. Hospitality for those who manage to flee across
the border is given by villagers in neighboring countries. To see this personal
generosity is deeply moving -- an extraordinary willingness of those who have
little to share with those who bring nothing. In effect, the villagers were the
sole international donors to Liberian refugees until the slow-moving relief
machinery began to respond months after the first refugees fled.

The advantages of living in a village environment instead of confinement in a
refugee camp are great. Village life permits dignity and freedom of movement,
not possible in the confinement of a camp and at a much lower cost. The refugees
may be poorer than those in Southeast Asia, but their daily existence is
immeasurably better. It is now past time for the international community to
reimburse the front-line village hosts. Yet the rice and other food now finally
being distributed in these villages goes to refugees only.

An international appeal for aid to some 200,000 villagers in Guinea to replenish
their food supplies has received only scant international support. One hopes
that the United States will lead the way in generating the overdue response to
this appeal.

If it is time to recompense the villagers of the neighboring countries. It is
also time to encourage an end to the fighting in Liberia. Even before the Gulf
crisis the United States apparently decided to sit on the sidelines rather than
seek a settlement in the Liberian civil war.

There is bitterness among the Liberian refugees toward all factions, but there
especially is grief that the United States -- long a special patron of Liberia's
since freed slaves returned there from America -- has failed to play a strong
role to end hostilities. Officials in Guinea and the Ivory Coast, as well as
U.S. diplomats in the two countries, believe that active U.S. intervention
months ago could have saved hundreds, perhaps thousands of lives.

It is now time to put other solutions in place. Though the cease-fire engineered
by Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen in late September lasted only days,
this peacemaking attempt does show the potential for constructive U.S.
involvement.

What is needed from the United States is a presidential push for a settlement in
Liberia, starting with a new cease-fire. Perhaps a U.N. peacekeeping component
could be added. U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar should appoint a
high level representative immediately. But with the African group at the United
Nations split, the secretary general can only move ahead with support from major
powers like the United States.

Where are the voices in and out of government for a more responsive approach to
Liberia? Those in Congress who follow Africa -- including the Black Caucus --
have been generally passive. Meanwhile, the media continue to allow the Gulf to
dominate their radar screens.

While pressing for a more effective U.S. approach to the Liberian civil war, we
should encourage recent, belated U.S. actions to get food to Liberia. Starvation
is looming. As helpless as the Liberian refugees are, they never forget to
remind a visitor of the need to get food to their brethren back home and the
imperative to stop the fighting. Obstacles to increased food delivery need to be
addressed: maritime carriers must be insured, the interdiction of food must be
ended and the facilitation of distribution on the ground improved. These
problems are soluble and the world should be doing more than watching Liberia
starve.

One last problem: Why is it so difficult for those Liberians with relatives and
other close ties to the United States to get non-immigrant visas? Thousands of
Liberians have been granted the right to remain indefinitely in the United
States until conditions improve at home. This should be extended to those close
family members who arrived after July, and the State Department should instruct
our embassies to interpret the visa law flexibly and humanely.

It is unconscionable that the United States and the international community are
not acting more effectively on Liberia across-the-board -- inside the country,
along its borders and at ours.

The writer, executive director of Refugees International, recently visited
Liberian refugees in Guinea and the Ivory Coast.

Agreement may be near on child-care bill

SECTION: NATIONAL; WASHINGTON DIGEST; Pg.  4A

LENGTH: 633 words



Senate leaders say they are near an agreement with the White House on a $
13-billion child-care bill that would provide matching money to states seeking
to set up training programs and to subsidize state-regulated child-care centers.
After years of efforts, it appears that Congress has finally devised the vehicle
to provide federal money to modernize the nation's child-care system. Lawmakers
involved in negotiations said the two sides are close to concluding an agreement
under which participating states could either give families vouchers for day
care or grant direct subsidies to centers.  The negotiations seek to avert a
threatened White House veto on grounds that Senate and House versions of the
bill establish a new and unnecessary federal child-care bureaucracy. By Monday
evening, congressional aides said the main issue unresolved was how much federal
money to distribute to the states.
 Bush allows more refugees
 President Bush said Monday he was raising to 131,000 from 125,000 the number of
refugees that can be admitted to the United States this year for humanitarian
reasons. Bush raised to 50,000 the number of refugees permitted from the Soviet
Union. Last year's ceiling on refugees from the Soviet Union was 42,000. Refugee
limits for other regions are 52,000 from East Asia, 6,000 from the Near East and
South Asia, 5,000 from Eastern Europe, 4,900 from Africa and 3,100 from Latin
America and the Caribbean.

occurred in  February at Michel's house.
 Negotiators move forward on clean air bill
 House negotiators reportedly agreed Monday to give the steel industry more time
to comply with tougher new toxic air pollution requirements. The action moved a
House-Senate conference committee one step closer to overall agreement on the
first reorganization of the nation's federal clean air laws in 13 years. The
development appeared to set the stage for a settlement with the Senate over new
controls on toxic chemical emissions from the industry as a whole. The
Associated Press reported that House negotiators decided to give steel companies
an additional 20 years, until the year 2020, to bring coke ovens in line with
the rest of industry. The Senate proposal already has such a provision. The
section on toxic emissions and another section on acid rain are the two major
unsettled issues before the conference committee.

                    October 16, 1990, Tuesday, Final Edition

Bush Approves Modest Rise In Immigration

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A14

LENGTH: 126 words


President Bush yesterday authorized the admission to the United States of up to
131,000 refugees in the next 12 months, an increase of 6,000 over last year.

The government will pay the travel costs for all but 10,000 of the refugees,
defined as fleeing persecution on religious, ethnic or other human rights
grounds. Private sources fund the rest. Most would be from the Soviet Union,
with an allocation of 50,000 people, and Southeast Asia, whose allocation is
52,000.

The total from Eastern Europe was down about 1,500, to 5,000, administration
officials said, because democratic reforms have reduced the number seeking to
emigrate. Other allocations were 6,000 for the Middle East and South Asia; 3,100
for Latin America and 4,900 for Africa.

                             The Guardian (London)

                                October 4, 1990

Rwanda calls for aid to halt rebels

BYLINE: By PETER BILES in Nairobi

LENGTH: 514 words


THE tiny central African state of Rwanda has asked its former colonial ruler,
Belgium, for military assistance to help quell an invasion by rebels trying to
overthrow President Juvenal Habyarimana.

The rebels, estimated to number around 1,500, crossed into north-eastern Rwanda
from neighbouring Uganda on Sunday. Yesterday they were within 45 miles of the
capital, Kigali, the Belgian foreign ministry said.


A ministry spokeswoman said rebels were fighting government troops near the
towns of Gatsibo and Gabiro, north of Kigali. 'It's not difficult for the rebels
to move to there. It's all savannah,' she said.

The Rwandan government sent reinforcements to the area yesterday, and the
Rwandan Interior Minister, Jean-Marie Vianney, said the army was engaged in
heavy fighting about 90 miles from Kigali. A dusk to dawn curfew was imposed on
Tuesday.

Belgium has not yet replied to the appeal for help, and unconfirmed reports from
Kigali said a similar request had been made to France.

The rebels, most of whom are Rwandan refugees who had been serving in the
Ugandan army, are being led by Major-General Fred Rwigyema, a former deputy
commander of Uganda's National Resistance Army (NRA), and a deputy defence
minister until last December. Gen Rwigyema is a member of Rwanda's minority
Tutsi tribe, which was ousted from power by the majority Hutu in 1959.

The Ugandan President, Yoweri Museveni, has told President Habyarimana that the
attack took Uganda by surprise. 'We have been taken aback by the scale and
rapidity of the desertions,' Mr Museveni told Uganda's New Vision newspaper.
Both leaders have been attending the United Nations summit on children in New
York, but are now returning home.

The Rwandan army is understood to have sent all its operational units
3,000-4,000 men to the north-east, amid fears that more rebels are gathering on
the Ugandan side of the border.

The Ugandan government has been seriously embarrassed by the affair. Yesterday,
an official statement said the border would be sealed and all returning NRA
soldiers would be tried for desertion.

'If President Museveni succeeds in closing the border, the invasion force inside
Rwanda, will die out,' said a Western diplomat in Kigali. 'It was counting on
local support, and that appears not to have materialised.'

In the Ugandan capital, Kampala, a spokesman for the Rwandan Patriotic Front
stressed that although his organisation contained many Tutsi refugees, the
rebels were not invading Rwanda primarily on their behalf. The first objective
was to overthrow the 'corrupt' government of President Habyarimana.

The United Nations High Commission for Refugees reported that there were 75,000
registered Rwandan refugees in south-western Uganda at the beginning of this
year. Thousands more live in other neighbouring countries Tanzania, Burundi and
Zaire.

Rwanda, Africa's most densely-populated country, has consistently said it cannot
allow the return of large numbers of refugees, as the country would be unable to
cope with such an influx.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     July 14, 1990, Saturday, City Edition

U.S. often rejects refugees

BYLINE: REENA SHAH

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 981 words



It wasn't anything out of the ordinary. It was just another flimsy boat on the
choppy seas, crammed with 108 Haitians seeking a better life. And, like most
such sailors, they were being sent back home. Forty-eight of them drowned
Tuesday as their boat was being towed by a Bahamian patrol ship.

    A brief report in the Miami Herald said it was tragic the Bahamas refused to
be a sanctuary for the Haitians but allowed one of its islands to serve as a
cemetery for these dead refugees. The St.  Petersburg Times gave the Haitian
deaths a few sentences on Page 12A on Friday. But mostly, the deaths went
unremarked.

    Nobody knew who the refugees were or why they fled. And it wasn't clear how
they had drowned. One radio report said the refugees panicked and ran toward one
end of the boat, making it capsize. The dead Haitians were piled on a fishing
boat and buried nearby. The surviving Haitians were taken for questioning.

    Although international agreements on refugees promise that people who face
persecution won't be sent back against their will, many nations do so. Refugees
from poor nations are often thought to be fleeing poverty rather than political
persecution, and they are returned forcibly.

    "There is danger of refugees being killed or persecuted when they are sent
back to their countries, but countries still do it," said Hiram Ruiz, a policy
analyst at the U.S. Committee for Refugees, a non-profit group that monitors
refugee policies around the world.

    The United States, the world's largest asylum-giver, is a major offender;
last year, more than 5,000 Haitians, 4,000 Guatemalans and 4,700 Salvadorans
were forcibly returned, according to the U.S.  Committee for Refugees.

    Immigration officials say they don't deport refugees. They only send away
people who don't fit their definition of a refugee.  "Anybody can make the claim
that they are persecuted," said Verne Jervis, a spokesman of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service (INS) in Washington, D.C. "They have to show whether this
fear is real, or whether they're coming to get away from poverty, to get a
better job. The burden is on them to make their case credible."

    The United States gives refugee status to people who prove they can be
threatened because of their race, religion, ethnicity or political opinions if
they return to their home country, Jervis said.

    Haitians make up the largest number of refuge-seekers who are
 rejected because they're the largest number caught. Most Central Americans
cross land borders and seek asylum after they've crossed into the United States.


    But most Haitians set out in small boats and are turned back by the Coast
Guard before they arrive within U.S. boundaries.  Haitians who make it to the
United States can file for asylum and are detained in camps while they wait to
see if they can stay permanently. If they are rejected, they are deported.

    As part of a special $ 30-million program to prevent an influx of Haitians,
the Coast Guard monitors international waters to spot refugee-filled boats.
Immigration officials on board question their motives. "They ask each of them
why they've left Haiti, if they have any fear of returning to Haiti," Jervis
said.

    "Most of them are very honest. They say they're coming to the United States
to find work, so they can live better."

    And, rejected as refugees, they are taken back to Haiti on Coast Guard ships
because their own boats are too flimsy. The Coast Guard sinks the Haitian skiffs
"so they won't be a danger to other vessels."

    About 20,000 Haitians have been returned since the program began nine years
ago. Thousands of others are deported out of D Miami and other centers because
they aren't considered refugees.

    Of the 350 boats intercepted by the Coast Guard, less than two dozen
Haitians have been accepted as refugees, Jervis said. In comparison, America
accepted 29,000 refugees from the Soviet Union last year.

    Refugee groups say those who flee poor nations are unfairly suspected of
being economic gain-seekers, but refugees from the Soviet Union and Eastern
Europe are easily accepted as their persecution is assumed.

     It's hard to distinguish between economic and political suffering, said
Ruiz, the Committee for Refugees analyst. "The people who were leaving East
Germany said they were looking for freedom and a better life. The political
dimension was there, but there was an  economic difference, too."

    And in a country like Vietnam or Haiti, political persecution can take an
economic form, when jobs are denied and property is seized by officials.

    Other nations also have been known to turn back asylum-seekers.  Mexico, the
source of many economic migrants to the United States, last year turned away at
least 46,000 refugees from neighboring nations like Guatemala and Salvador.

    Malaysia has in the last year towed away more than 6,500 Vietnamese boat
people and left them on the high seas. About 950 refugees voluntarily went back
to Vietnam from Hong Kong, where 56,000 refugees wait in camps to be accepted by
America and Europe. Many of the refugees were declared economic migrants, and
impatient with their slow return, Hong Kong has speeded the process by forcibly
airlifting some of them.

    South Africa turned away 34,000 Mozambicans fleeing the war in their
country, while its burdened neighbor Malawi has given asylum to so many that one
in 10 of its people today is a refugee.

    An international conference on refugees was scheduled to be held this year
in Geneva but was postponed because of disagreements between governments.

                   November 8, 1989, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Canada pledges aid for refugees in Africa

BYLINE: By Paul Watson Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A24

LENGTH: 308 words


   Canada has promised an extra $2 million to the cash-starved United Nations
refugee agency to help it handle a growing crisis in Africa.

The federal government's Canadian International Development Agency confirmed
yesterday that it pledged at least that much cash to the refugee commission's
43-nation executive committee in Geneva last month.

The final pledge won't be announced until a donors conference in New York later
this month and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees is lobbying hard
for more money.

"The situation requires that we have more from everybody," commission
spokesperson Angela Gibbs said from Ottawa.

A massive budget shortfall has forced the commission to carry over a $40 million
(U.S.) deficit into next year, but it has to find another $60 million (U.S.) in
the next two months, Gibbs said.

"No refugee will die (due to the deficit) this year, although life will be
difficult. But next year will be the problem."

Ottawa won't say whether it has any more money to give until the New York
meeting, said development agency spokesperson Jean-Marc Emery.

"We know what the situation is, but we know our constraints also," he said.

Once the refugee commission's ninth largest donor, Canada has dropped to twelfth
place despite steady increases in its donations, Gibbs said.

Half of Canada's $2 million increase will help feed and give shelter to almost
750,000 Mozambicans driven into neighboring Malawi by a vicious civil war that
has caused Africa's worst refugee problem.

Ottawa has already given $300,000 for refugees in Malawi, one of the world's
poorest countries, which has a refugee burden that is one-tenth its own
population.

The rest will be split between Ethiopia and Sudan, which have a total of at
least 1.4 million refugees living in border camps.

                        October 25, 1989, Wednesday, ME2

Canada, Britain in clash on refugees

BYLINE: Special-Staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 644 words

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR


   KUALA LUMPUR (Special-Staff) - Canada has told Britain it views with concern
a possible plan to forcibly repatriate Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong.

"Let me just say that we should all hope that it doesn't come to that and that
suggestions like that would not find much favor in Canada," Prime Minister Brian
Mulroney said yesterday at the end of the Commonwealth Conference in Malaysia.

External Affairs Minister Joe Clark disclosed that he raised the issue last
month in London, during a meeting with British Foreign Secretary John Major.

"It's a difficult question and everyone is watching it, but the British are
aware of our position," said Clark.

Clark's remarks followed a statement by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher
during her final press conference.

Undesirable refugees

She said Britain is entitled to expel and return refugees to Viet Nam, if it
deems them undesirables.

United Nations officials, the U.S. government and several western countries have
made it clear to Britain they consider the mandatory return of Vietnamese as
inhumane, in light of possible persecution.

On the contentious issue of sanctions against South Africa, Mulroney and
Thatcher exchanged bitter parting shots as the Commonwealth summit ended.

Thatcher, who opposes sanctions as a strategy to end apartheid, said a future
South Africa "will inherit a strong economy and they will have (Britain) to
thank for that."

Mulroney, who told a news conference he was "blindsided" by the British on
sanctions, said South Africa will remember who her friends are.

Thatcher was unrepentant about her lone stand against increased sanctions.

"If it is one against 48," she said, "I am very sorry for the 48."

Mulroney, asked what message the summit sent to South Africa, said Pretoria had
"congratulated one member and castigated all the others."

"The message is pretty clear," he said.

Angry Mugabe

President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, quoted by Canadian Press, said Thatcher was
characteristically "the only dissenting voice" at this year's summit.

"I don't know whether that is British politics, but I think it is despicable,
unacceptable," he told a news conference.

The refuge question came up yesterday as tempers still seethed from the
sanctions debate.

In the past year, more than 30,000 refugees have sailed into tiny Hong Kong,
stretching its resources to the limit. Demonstrations and riots have broken out
several times.

Thatcher yesterday drew a distinction between such people and so-called economic
refugees from Viet Nam.

"Most countries in the world send back illegal immigrants," she said. "The
United States sends them back, including to Mexico, and repatriates them to
Haiti, for example."

Of 55,000 boat people Thatcher said are now in Hong Kong (other estimates run
well above 60,000), about 13,000 so far have been assessed "genuine refugees,"
meaning they fit the standard United Nations definition of people fleeing
oppression. More than 25,000 have arrived since January.

'Great difficulty'

The Philippines has offered to set up a "staging post" to hold such people in
transit pending resettlement elsewhere.

"This leaves Hong Kong in a great difficulty," said Thatcher.

"Hong Kong has never pushed away boat people for very obvious reasons," she
said.

"Hong Kong cannot go on steadily accepting more.

"If I might respectfully say so, those countries who criticize Hong Kong, or us
about this same matter, would be very much more helpful if instead of just
criticizing (said) 'right, we will take a certain number,' " Thatcher argued.

One such country is the United States. Thatcher did not say whether she was also
referring to Canada.

About half of all refugees and immigrants from Hong Kong who left in 1988 went
to Canada. Britain took less than 2 per cent of them.

              October 21, 1989, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

Opera night will 'water' Africa

SECTION: RELIGION; Pg. M30

LENGTH: 928 words


   OPERA lovers can enjoy an outstanding musical event in Toronto next month and
help the Consolata Missionaries "Water For Africa" campaign.

Metropolitan Opera baritone Louis Quilico and his pianist wife, Lina, will be
among the stars of a concert at 4.30 p.m. on Nov. 19 at Roy Thomson Hall.

Others appearing include soprano Maria Spacagna, tenor Vladimir Popov,
mezzo-soprano Catherine Stolz, and St. Michael's Choir School.

The orchestra will be conducted by Daniel Lipton, artistic director of Opera
Hamilton and San Antonia Texas Festival.

Because this is the International Year of Illiteracy, proceeds from the concert
will mostly go to provide water for the missionaries' schools in Kenya, Ethiopia
and Mozambique, organizers say.

Tickets are $35, $25 and $20 (tax included), available at Roy Thomson Hall and
Massey Hall box offices: 593-4828, and at the Consolata Missionaries: 749-8907.

Refugee law

The Canadian Council of Churches has raised about $175,000 to pay for its legal
challenge of Canada's new refugee law, says the Mennonite Reporter. The total
cost is estimated at $350,000.

Most donations have come from individual church members and congregations, Mary
Sanderson, co-ordinator of the fundraising effort, told the paper. Money-making
projects include the sale of refugee T-shirts, Christmas cards, and tapes by a
Winnipeg group, The Common Cup.

A federal court ruled this spring that the council had the right to fight the
refugee law, but no date has been set for the next step.

Thje council argues that the law does not protect refugees according to the
Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

Cocaine dilemma

Church members can be affected as drug producers as well as victims or
caregivers in North America's drug war .

A Christianity Today article points out that growing coca enables Christian
farmers in Bolivia to provide for their families, while they also know it is
used to make cocaine.

Although none of the major denominations has officially condemned coca
producation, local pastors often preach against it. The Pentecostal church does
not allow coca growers to hold leadership positions. World Vision, a relief and
development agency, is looking for ways to provide incentives to Christian
farmers not to grow coca.

Meanwhile the United Church Observer quotes the ironic comment of a physician
with the American Association for World Health that more Colombians die from
diseases caused by tobacco products imported from the U.S. than do Americans
from Colombian cocaine.
