                              The Washington Post

                     October 6, 1989, Friday, Final Edition

Europe's Migrants Swell Refugee Wave;
Millions Across World Are Seeking Asylum

BYLINE: Don Podesta, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A41

LENGTH: 2102 words


While the thousands of East Germans who have fled to the West have had to leave
behind homes, jobs, cars and loved ones to pursue their desperate bid for a new
life in the West, they can be considered fortunate among the world's millions of
refugees: They are wanted.

They will automatically be received into West German society as citizens and
will be aided in finding homes and work. But in refugee camps from Sudan to Hong
Kong, a different drama is playing itself out.

This should have been the year some of the world's millions upon millions of
displaced people could begin thinking about going home.

Wars in Angola, Afghanistan, Cambodia, Nicaragua and the Persian Gulf either
wound down significantly or ended. Vietnamese, Soviet and Cuban troops involved
in three of these conflicts were withdrawn. U.S. military support for Nicaraguan
rebels came to an end.

Yet there are more refugees seeking asylum than ever: By some counts there are
more than 15 million people languishing in camps from Central America and the
Horn of Africa to Pakistan and Thailand -- and now, also in the courtyards of
West German embassies in Eastern European capitals, adding up to one of the
greatest migrations of people in the world's history.

"We in the refugee field haven't seen the benefits of the end of regional
conflicts," said Roger Winter, director of the U.S. Committee for Refugees, a
nonprofit organization headquartered in Washington.

One exception is Namibia, where in June the first of more than 41,000 political
exiles began returning home as a result of a U.S.-brokered regional peace
agreement, the biggest refugee airlift ever conducted by the United Nations.

In the last decade, the world may have become inured to Third World refugees.
But this year's wave of European emigres -- 100,000 Soviets, 45,000 East
Germans, 300,000 Bulgarian Turks, 230,000 Poles, 20,000 Romanians -- form
something that has not been seen since the great European migrations at the end
of World War II.

In many ways, the sudden outpouring of East Europeans heading West serves to
partly explain why reduced conflict has not led to relief for the world's
refugees. If anything, the reduction of East-West tensions, which contributed to
many of the regional conflicts, and the accompanying birth of more open
political systems in formerly rigid dictatorships such as Poland, Hungary and
the Soviet Union, have contributed to the mass movement of people as barriers to
emigration have come down.

Where a few years ago the word "refugee" evoked images of an emaciated Ethiopian
child seeking relief from drought and famine in a dusty desert camp, today's
refugee is as likely to be seeking better economic opportunities or political
liberty as fleeing war or natural disaster.

Indochina offers a particularly graphic example of how the nature of refugees
and the world's response to them has changed in the past decade.

Since Communist victories in Vietnam and Cambodia in 1975, Southeast Asia has
been flooded with refugees -- Cambodians fleeing the horrors of the Khmer Rouge
regime and later the Vietnamese invasion, and Vietnamese "boat people."

Soon after the wave began, the countries in the region, in consultation with
Western nations, adopted a "first-asylum" policy, under which no refugees
fleeing communism would be turned away. The West, for its part, agreed to a
massive program to resettle the refugees in other countries. Thailand, as the
closest point of escape for most Indochinese refugees, bore the brunt of the
first-asylum policy but also benefited from large infusions of U.N. aid and
other humanitarian assistance.

About two years ago, things began to change. Western countries had taken most of
the refugees they wanted to resettle -- former employees of the U.S. or South
Vietnamese government, ethnic Chinese entrepreneurs, skilled professionals
fleeing communism -- and they reduced their intake.

At the same time, the nature of the refugees themselves began to change. Now
from Vietnam, there are fishermen and farmers who were not necessarily escaping
political persecution but looking for a better life economically. An increasing
number of boat people are now coming from northern Vietnam.

The Southeast Asian nations coined a term for the new reluctance by the West to
continue accepting refugees: "compassion fatigue."

Faced with this change of attitude by the West, Southeast Asian nations have
decided that their policy of granting first asylum has become untenable. The
refugees kept coming, with a new wave beginning in 1987, but fewer and fewer
were being resettled elsewhere. In the spring of 1987, Thailand became the first
country to challenge the first-asylum agreement by adopting a policy to push
boats laden with refugees back out to sea. Indonesia followed suit, and there
are reports that Malaysia is quietly doing the same.

One result of Thailand's rolling up the welcome mat has been a marked shift in
the patterns of refugee movements, with increasing numbers of boat people
arriving in the British crown colony of Hong Kong and in Japan.

Britain and Vietnam have held talks on the issue of sending refugees back to
Vietnam. Hanoi has refused to take back any refugee who does not volunteer to
return, a position that the U.S. government has supported.

British and Thai officials have accused the United States of hypocrisy, pointing
to U.S. interdiction of Haitian boat people and deportation of illegal
immigrants from Mexico and Central America.

"We couldn't take the moral high ground because our own skirts were dirty," said
Winter, of the U.S. Committee for Refugees.

Among Japanese, unaccustomed to immigration, the surge in refugees has stirred
fears that the country will be overrun. It has caused the government for the
first time to adopt a screening process under which refugees with only economic
motives will be repatriated.

And it has caused conflict between Vietnamese-speaking boat people and young
Chinese laborers who have boarded Vietnamese boats in hopes of finding work in
prosperous Japan. The two groups have clashed in overcrowded refugee centers,
and Japanese officials have segregated them.

According to officials in the Japanese Foreign Ministry and the prime minister's
office, 34 boatloads carrying 3,181 people reached Japan as of the end of
September. Only 219 boat people came in all of 1988.

For the Vietnamese, the trip is an arduous, 2,000-mile journey risking pirates
and storms on the open sea. About 80 percent of the arrivals have come to Japan
on their own, with the others picked up by ships on the way.

Japan, which has accepted fewer than 7,000 Indochinese refugees since the end of
the Vietnam war, has said that it will allow the total to rise to 10,000,
providing the new immigrants are genuine refugees under U.N. definitions. But
its processing centers, intended to offer six months of instruction in Japanese
language, are suddenly woefully understaffed and crowded.

Japan is not alone in its reluctance to admit refugees from alien ethnic groups.

In the United States, "East Europeans and Soviets are on the front burner now
and there is a great deal of interest in accepting them," Winter said. "But who
cares about Somalis who have gone to Ethiopia?"

West Germany greets all immigrant ethnic Germans -- whether East Germans or
people of German ancestry from Poland or the Soviet Union -- with up to $ 125
each in "welcome money" and low-cost loans of up to $ 5,000 per family to get
started. All are eligible for normal unemployment or welfare and state-supported
health insurance benefits.

If they are retired, they receive the same pension as if they had worked in West
Germany all their lives; thus a Polish ethnic German who retired after working
35 years as a machinist in Poland receives the same pension as if he had worked
all those years at the same job in West Germany.

But non-German asylum-seekers -- mostly Poles, Yugoslavs, Turks and Iranians --
don't enjoy those benefits. Many of them must work in black market jobs while
waiting -- typically for several years -- for a decision on whether they are to
be granted political asylum. Only about 9 percent ever receive asylum; the rest
are classified as people merely trying to improve their economic status and
technically are supposed to be expelled from the country, although in practice
this does not happen often.

When international laws covering refugees were written in 1951, most of those
heading for Western Europe or America were Europeans. But with modern
transportation and regional wars in many parts of the Third World, refugees are
traveling to the West from farther away and most of them are not white. This, in
Winter's view, helps account for the West's increasing reluctance to continue
accepting refugees.

"You start to get a decreasing receptivity to refugees," Winter said.
"Governments are backing away from the system they created."

As a result, contributions to organizations that care for refugees, such as the
International Red Cross and the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), are
down, in relative terms, just when the need is greater than ever.

The U.N. deputy high commissioner for refugees, Eugene Dewey, said budgetary
pressures have forced the agency to cut back on all but "survival items" for
refugees. The number of exiles cared for by the agency has risen 40 percent over
the past three years with victims up 700,000 in the last year alone.

But contributions are up only 17 percent since 1986, Dewey said, adding that
UNHCR may face a $ 40 million deficit by the end of the year.

"We've had to retrench. We've had to cut out almost everything except survival
items, care and maintenance," Dewey said. "This is tragic because it has cost us
our investment programs in education and training, which have some chance of
getting refugees out of this dependency syndrome."

But despite the increase in migration for economic reasons, the bulk of the
world's refugees are fleeing their native lands not to search for better jobs or
more money or even political freedom. Most of the 4 million refugees in Africa,
the 5 million Afghans encamped in Pakistan and Iran and the hundreds of
thousands of displaced Central Americans have fled for a much simpler reason: to
stay alive.

Often, that is all they achieve; conditions in many camps around the world are
hellish.

Camps in Malawi, South Africa and Zambia for 1 million Mozambicans fleeing the
14-year-old civil war in their country offer nightmarish scenes: children with
bloated bellies and pencil-thin arms crawling through the dust in search of
shade or beetles to eat, and adults wearing bark peeled from trees, clamoring
around a relief plane's whirring propellers for sacks of grain tossed out the
door.

Afghan refugees, who represent fully a third of their country's population, also
are a third of the world's refugees. Many of them have been in camps in Pakistan
and Iran for all of the 1980s.

Sanitary conditions in the camps are poor even by South Asian standards;
diseases associated with malnutrition are chronic, and morale is generally low.
More than 75 percent of the refugees are women and children, most of whom have
not been home since leaving Afghanistan. A third of the children have been born
and raised in the camps, according to the United Nations.

"The situation of the women has been particularly difficult due to the fact that
Afghan culture and traditions strictly discourage contact between women and
outsiders," a recent U.N. report said. "Most women have been confined . . . in
their shelters with very little social contact. In many cases this has resulted
in psychological depression and despair."

But the irony is that 10 years of war and international administration of the
camps has led to another kind of distortion of the Afghan experience: Refugees
now receive more and better services in the squalid Pakistani camps -- health,
education, and food -- than they would in most areas of Afghanistan, where the
war-torn countryside is generally devoid of civil administration.

Aid officials worry that they are a long way from being able to promise the
refugees a better life if and when they go home.

And for many of the world's refugees, there is no guarantee that they will ever
go home. Palestinian refugees now number nearly 2 million in Lebanon, Jordan and
the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank, and many of these have been in
camps for more than 40 years with no end to their displacement in sight.

Washington Post correspondents abroad contributed to this report.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                   USA TODAY

                    October 3, 1989, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

U.S. denies Israel refugee funds

BYLINE: Johanna Neuman

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 513 words


Congressional calls for more aid to Poland already are stretching the U.S.
budget, Baker added.

In the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, the United States limits the number of
Soviet refugees, many of them Jews, coming to the USA to 50,000.

Consequently, a number of them - like Lev Gelfand, a 33-year-old engineer - have
chosen Israel instead.

''When my visa application to the U.S. was refused, I didn't reapply as I could
have,'' said Gelfand, who's studying Hebrew in a Tel Aviv suburb.

''It made me think that if America doesn't want me, why should I be fighting to
go there? I'm lucky I made that decision,'' said Gelfand, who arrived in
Jerusalem a little more than three months ago with his wife and two children.

Gelfand is one of 350 Soviet Jews who have arrived in Israel since the beginning
of the year from Italian transit camps after being refused U.S. visas.

While the number isn't yet large, Israeli officials see it as the forerunner of
a heavy tide of Soviet Jews who'll be turning to Israel as the United States
becomes more selective about who is let in.

''What is significant about these 350 is that they all planned to go somewhere
else and changed their minds,'' says Ephraim Bluth, an immigration official.
''Last year none came from the Italian camps.''

Israel has sent emissaries to the camps to try to persuade the Russian emigrants
to change direction.

''The picture we had of Israel in Russia was that it was a very dangerous place
where there was no work and where the religious parties dominated,'' says Dr.
Arkady Levitan, 50, who arrived in Jerusalem from Italy last month. ''It was
painted as a desert.''

After waiting for five months in vain for a U.S. visa at the Ladispoli transit
camp outside Rome, Levitan and his wife, Galina, a biochemist, decided to opt
for Israel.

''We spoke to an Israeli emissary,'' says Galina Levitan. ''He told us it was no
paradise but that it was a place where our 13-year-old son could grow feeling
that he belonged. We found a beautiful country.''

Valerie Mishiyev, 36, a teacher of English, reached Ladispoli, but before even
applying for a U.S. visa, he decided to come to Israel.

''I figured that America doesn't need Russian English teachers,'' he said. He
too was surprised to find a modern country with well-stocked stores. Some 7,000
Jews are now leaving the Soviet Union each month.

''Last year we had 2,000 Russian emigrants,'' said Bluth. ''This year we expect
about 8,000. Next year we hope to get 20,000 and some optimists even say
50,000.''

Contributing: Abe Rabinovich in Jerusalem

                              The Washington Post

                   September 12, 1989, Tuesday, Final Edition

U.S. Eyes 50,000 Limit On Soviet Emigres in '90;
Up to 150,000 Are Expected to Seek Entry

BYLINE: John M. Goshko, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A1

LENGTH: 668 words


The Bush administration plans to propose to Congress that the United States
accept 50,000 refugees from the Soviet Union during the coming year -- far fewer
than the 100,000 to 150,000 Soviet Jews, evangelical Christians and other Soviet
citizens expected to seek admission to this country in 1990.

The 50,000 slots proposed for Soviet emigres, most of them Jews, would make them
the biggest single subgroup of the 125,000 refugees that the administration will
recommend admitting during fiscal 1990, which begins Oct. 1. Still, it would
mean that the United States, after waging a two-decade struggle to induce Moscow
to ease its restrictions on emigration, will be in the embarrassing position of
turning away thousands who had hoped to resettle here.

The figures are contained in a confidential memorandum prepared by Jewel S.
LaFontant, the State Department's coordinator for refugee affairs. Informed
sources said yesterday it has been approved tentatively by the White House and
will be proposed to Congress by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and other U.S.
officials in testimony this week.

In addition to the Soviet quota, LaFontant's memo proposes fiscal 1990 refugee
allotments of 3,000 for Africa, 25,000 for "first entry" refugees from East
Asia, 26,500 spaces primarily for Amerasians and their families, 6,500 for
Eastern Europe exclusive of the Soviet Union, 3,500 for Latin America and the
Caribbean, 6,500 for the Middle East and South Asia, and 4,000 for others coming
under various private-sector programs.

Refugee status quotas are fixed by the administration in consultation with
Congress. The federal government pays refugees' transportation and resettlement
costs, and the rising numbers of people seeking such status from troubled areas
of the world have put a greater strain on the budgetary resources than the
austerity-minded administration is willing to commit.

The 50,000 figure for Soviet immigrants to the United States would apply only to
those receiving expenses-paid refugee status. Those denied that status could
apply for admission under the attorney general's parole authority, with a
reasonable expectation of success. But they would not get U.S. government
financial help. Much of the problem stems from President Mikhail Gorbachev's
easing of Soviet immigration policies after departures had been sharply
curtailed for several years.

An estimated 2 million Jews live in the Soviet Union, and about 50,000 are
expected to relocate in the United States this year. State Department officials
have told Congress that they expect up to 150,000 refugee applicants next year.

That has led to an informal consensus between the administration and influential
groups in the American Jewish community that the number is too large for the
United States to absorb. There is an expectation that most of those denied entry
will be redirected to Israel, but considerable disagreement still exists about
how many should be admitted to this country.

Since September 1988, the Justice Department has tightened its standards for
granting them refugee status, turning down what U.S. Jewish groups estimate is
about 20 percent of the applicants. Processing backlogs have also left about
14,000 Jews stranded in Italy and thousands more backed up in the Soviet Union
waiting for their applications to be considered.

That has led to drives in Congress for legislation to establish a presumption
that Soviet Jews and evangelical Christians are subject to persecution in their
homeland and thus make it easier for them to get refugee status.

Rep. Bruce A. Morrison (D-Conn.), sponsor of the legislation in the House, said
last night the 50,000-space quota for the Soviet Union is "reasonable." But he
added that those already in the pipeline because they had been led to expect
they would gain admittance to this country should be judged on a presumptive
basis, and he warned that the administration is likely to face a major fight
with Congress if it does not go along.

                                The Toronto Star

                      July 7, 1989, Friday, FINAL EDITION

Re-shaping a distorted global map

BYLINE: by Bruce McLeod

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A19

LENGTH: 548 words


   THERE IS a map of the world on the immigration manager's wall, near Pearson
airport. He supervises adversarial screenings where arriving refugees must prove
their right to appear before Canada's new refugee board.

Slightly above the map's center, Canada is vivid in empire-red. Southern
countries, from which refugees come, seem small and insignificant. Alaska
appears bigger than Mexico, which is actually three times its size. Greenland
looms larger than South America or Africa.

The manager's map is drawn on the 400-year-old Mercator projection. A tiny note
in the corner explains that, despite appearances, South America is actually nine
times larger than Greenland. But pictures speak louder than words.

German cartographer Mercator was not trying to downgrade the Third World; he had
never heard of it. No flat-page map ever conveys the Earth's spherical character
without distortion. Mercator's purpose was to help navigators plot diagonal
courses that weren't simply north-south or east-west. To achieve that, area-size
accuracy was sacrificed. Lines of latitude distant from the equator were
stretched apart; the equator itself was lowered. Southern countries, in
Mercator's day hardly known to Europeans, shrank; northern countries grew.

Generations of schoolchildren, some now immigration officers, were raised on
Mercator's map; it formed their view of the world. Other maps, based on
projections which correct Mercator's distortions (exchanging them for others)
have long been available. But they often appear in atlases which give detailed,
large-scale treatment to northern countries, while Africa and South America are
in small scale only.

CUT TO SIZE

In the recent Philips Atlas, for instance, the scale for England and Wales is
four times that of Madagascar which, on quick glance, seems smaller; instead of
larger, which it is. Says Terry Hardaker, Oxford cartographer, it's like
"peering at Europe and North America through a magnifying glass, and then
surveying the rest of the world through the wrong end of a telescope."

In 1973, German historian Arno Peters, outraged at uncritical use of biased
world pictures, developed an area-accurate map. Shape distortion appears in
countries along the equator; but relative area is true. Africa is central, and
enormous; Canada and Greenland are cut to size.

This year, Longman has published the Peters World Atlas. Each same-scale
double-page map, hand-drawn to computerized satellite projections, represents
one-sixtieth of the Earth's surface. In addition, 246 color-coded thematic maps
give detailed information on world distribution of everything from donkeys,
bees, and fish catches to calorie consumption, education expenditures and the
status of women.

No map is perfect. But some, given prevailing attitudes, are more imperfect than
others. Peters says, "if the view of the world that underpinned (the age of
colonialism) is to come to an end, we need a new geography - one that is based
on the equal status of all peoples." Maps that, intentionally or not, convey
another message should be removed from schoolrooms, and from the walls of
immigration officials who greet refugees from other parts of the world.

* Bruce McLeod is a minister at Toronto's Bellefair United Church.

                                 The Advertiser

                              June 23, 1989 Friday

The millions who flee for a better life

BYLINE: HEDLEY THOMAS

LENGTH: 1204 words


National Refugee Week this week sees a continuation of the worsening plight of
the world's asylum-seekers. Hedley Thomas in London reports on the grim future
ahead for the 14 million living in limbo after fleeing their homelands.

THEY number some 14 million worldwide. They are people frightened, uprooted,
dispossessed and unwanted, having fled their own miserable homeland for want of
a better one.

They are effectively voiceless and completely bereft of what the more fortunate
among us call human rights. They are the world's refugees.

The vast majority are living fourth-world lives in third-world countries. With
limited resources, those countries struggle to support the burden imposed by so
many destitute new arrivals from Africa, Asia and Latin America.

Authorities estimate only about 10 per cent have been allowed to settle in such
places as western Europe, the United States, Canada and Australia.

The United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights states that everyone
has the right to seek and to enjoy in other countries asylum from persecution.

But, for the 14 million asylum-seekers, this declaration means little because
the crisis is worsening.

In January this year there were almost a million more refugees than the January
before. As situations in strife-torn countries change constantly so, too, does
the number of people displaced.

Many survive at virtual starvation level in overcrowded camps, locked up and
with little chance of returning to their country of origin or moving on to their
country of choice.

Thousands carrying injuries or affected by disease are dying. Boat people are
dying at sea. Some might have lived but were ignored by passing ships.

According to some estimates, one in three of the people who leave Vietnam by sea
never makes it safely to land. The prospects for many refugees who do live
rarely improve a great deal.

Most are victims of wars. From Afghanistan alone, more than five million have
fled since 1980. Despite its peace agreement with Pakistan and the Soviet
Union's withdrawal of troops, observers concede there is much work to be done
until Afghanistan will be safe and secure for all refugees.

In few countries has the situation improved enough for a notable percentage of
the people to be willing to return. Recent exceptions have included Chad,
Ethiopia, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Sri Lanka and, most lately, Namibia.

According to the 1951 United Nations Convention, a genuine refugee is "a person
who, owing to a well-founded fear of persecution, for reasons of race, religion,
nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is
outside the country of origin and is unable or, owing to such fears, unwilling
to return to it".

Yet, gaining the status of "genuine refugee" is harder than ever before.
Throughout Europe and North America, governments are adopting more sophisticated
measures aimed at reducing the number of asylum-seekers arriving.

Stricter visa requirements are being imposed and sanctions, such as fines
against airlines bringing asylum-seekers without proper papers, are being
strengthened.

Compare the spirit behind these measures with the spirit behind a resolution
resolved by the Council of Europe in 1967: "That governments should act in a
particularly liberal and humanitarian spirit in relation to persons who seek
asylum in their territory."

For those seeking asylum in Western countries, their attempts have been
punctuated with bitterness and frustration as delays, rejection and deportations
become increasingly common.

According to a recent report by the Council of World Churches in Geneva:
"Governments faced with new refugee arrivals turned to each other in trying to
formulate common policies to relieve the situation - policies which were too
often based on a desire to keep people out."

The director of the British Refugee Council, Mr Alf Dubs, said: "Western
countries are basically closing their doors.

"They are telling the refugees that they are economic migrants who are moving to
better themselves economically.

"In the process of closing the doors, governments are not giving refugees a fair
chance to answer to whether they are in fear of persecution or not.

"They are not being allowed in or are being sent back to the countries they came
from. The future doesn't look too good. In fact, it's pretty gloomy."

The "orbiters" - a floating population of refugees in the sky, touching down,
taking off, touching down again - tell another side of the story. These
unfortunates are asylum-seekers who find themselves either airborne or held by
immigration authorities at airports that become detention centres for days,
weeks, sometimes even months at a time.

W ILLIAM Hamid, in his early 20s and from the northern lowlands of Ethiopia,
began his life as an orbiting refugee when he bought a Somalian passport and a
plane ticket to Canada to start a new life.

His plane journey took him via Cairo and Switzerland. When he landed in Geneva
to wait for his onward flight, Swiss immigration authorities studied his
passport, found it was about to expire and refused to let him board the Canadian
flight. They also refused to allow him to stay.

Hamid was dispatched back to Cairo, his last port of call. But the Egyptians
would not keep him either and, after 10 days in the departure lounge, Hamid was
put on a plane to Cyprus.

The Cypriots sent him back to Egypt; the Egyptians returned him to Cyprus.
Eventually he was sent to the country of his now long-expired passport - Somalia
- where he is now believed to be.

According to latest United Nations statistics, Pakistan has the largest single
refugee population in the world.

Estimates range between three million and four million, largely as a result of
the influx of Afghan refugees since 1978. It is hoped improving conditions in
their home areas will encourage their complete return.

Iran is host to almost three million refugees, comprising about 2.3 million
Afghans and some 600,000 refugees of other origin. A few live in camps - the
rest have been absorbed into the local economy - but their presence puts a great
strain on health services, food supplies and water. Since 1975, more than two
million Indo-Chinese are estimated to have left their countries. More than half
have been either kept in camps or resettled in China, Hong Kong, Indonesia,
Japan, Cambodia, Laos, Macau, Malaysia, the Philippines, Republic of Korea,
Singapore and Thailand.

More than 45,000 boat people are in limbo in Hong Kong. They are treated as
illegal immigrants and questioned to determine whether they are genuine refugees
fleeing from persecution or economic migrants seeking a better life in the
booming economy.

At a time when Hong Kong's citizens themselves are eager to secure places abroad
before the Chinese takeover in 1997, Britain and the colony have begun talks
with Vietnam which could lead to the repatriation of the thousands of Vietnamese
boat people in Hong Kong, whatever the boat people's will.

The facts and figures from dozens of other regions in Africa, Latin America and
elsewhere relate the pathetic future for refugees caught up in this global
crisis.

              January 14, 1989, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

Court blocks man's deportation after refugee claim turned down

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 193 words


   The Ontario Supreme Court has blocked the deportation of an Ethiopian man
whose refugee claim was turned down this week.

A two-member immigration panel rejected 18-year-old Hussein Mohamoud's claim in
Niagara Falls on Jan. 10 and he could have been sent back to Ethiopia as early
as last night, immigration lawyer Maureen Silcoff said.

But Madame Justice Louise Arbour ordered immigration authorities to keep
Mohamoud in Canada until the court decides whether the new refugee system
violates the Charter of Rights, Silcoff said.

Mohamoud is an ethnic Somali from the Odagen region of Ethiopia in the Horn of
Africa, Silcoff said.

Ethiopia and Somalia have contested the territory for decades and went to war
over it in 1977.

Mohamoud has heard from friends in the United States that his mother was
recently killed by the Ethiopian army, Silcoff said.

Mohamoud's father was arrested by the Ethiopian army last February and hasn't
been heard from since, a group supporting Mohamoud's refugee claim said in a
news release.

His sister is also dead and his brother was tortured before fleeing to a refugee
camp in neighboring Somalia.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   January 9, 1989, MONDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

EVENTS FOCUS ON REFUGEES' PLIGHT

BYLINE: Bill Smith Of the Post-Dispatch Staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1094 words


Varinta Khounphannavong said he fled from Laos last month to escape service
inthe communist military.  Boris Iouioukine defected from the Soviet Union in
September, leaving behind his wife, two children and a country that he both
loved and hated.  And Jacob Masisi, a Moscow-educated chemist from South Africa,
said his choice was simple: Begin a new life in America or remain in Africa and
expose himself and his family to the possibility of execution at the hands of a
South African ''murder squad.'' The three men were among about 100 refugees who
took part Sunday in a Migration Week Mass at St. Joseph Shrine, 1220 North 11th
Street.  They are among 226 people who came to the United States last year under
the sponsorship of the Catholic Charities of St. Louis Refugee Center, according
to Richard Hayde, associate director for refugee services for the center.
''These are people who cannot return to their country for fear of persecution,
for religious or political reasons,'' Hayde said.  The Mass on Sunday and other
Migration Week events, Hayde said, are part of an effort to make area residents
more sensitive to the plights of refugees.  Masisi, 41, a native of South
Africa, said he had lived for the past few years in the tiny kingdom of Lesotho,
which is surrounded by South Africa. He said he had lectured there against South
Africa's policy of apartheid and had felt increasingly threatened by the
possibility of South African reprisal. Masisi said his name was included on a
list of people that the South African government had asked Lesotho officials to
expel from their country.  Friends and neighbors were killed by what he says are
government-sponsored ''murder squads.'' He said he was so worried that he had
spent the last months of his life in Lesotho moving from the home of one friend
to another, in an effort to make himself a more elusive target.  ''I felt very
soon they would be catching up with me,'' he said.  Even though he still has
been unable to find work in the St. Louis area, Masisi called the United States
''a country that abounds in opportunities.'' ''My life hasn't really come
together; I am still struggling,'' he said.  ''When you don't have a job, life
becomes difficult.'' Hayde, with Catholic Charities, said Sunday that his group
helps the refugees find affordable housing - usually in areas of south St. Louis
- gets basic furnishings and other household items for them and assists them in
finding employment.  The group has served more than 1,600 refugees since 1981,
he said.  Iouioukine, 37, also remains unemployed, although he can speak seven
languages.  A former interpreter for the Soviet petrochemical industry in
Ethiopia, Iouioukine said his run-ins with Soviet officials had begun early.
While working in Ethiopia, he said, he was reprimanded for associating with
Ethiopians and Indians. At one point, he said, he was seriously injured in an
automobile accident in Ethiopia while running an errand as part of his job.
Soviet officials were more concerned about the food and jewelry they had sent
him to buy than they were about his health, he said.  Eventually, he said, he
was returned to the Soviet Union, but he then sought asylum at the American
embassy in a trip to Greece.  ''I didn't want to leave my country,'' he said.
''But things were very bad there. I didn't desert my family; I'm going to bring
them here.'' Iouioukine, who comes from the Russian city of Krasnodar near the
Black Sea, said he had nothing but praise for the United States and its people.
''So many people took part in helping me settle here,'' he said. ''I didn't
expect so much.  ''We are told that people are very business-minded here, that
there is much crime and unemployment,'' he said. ''I never expected people to be
so humane, so kind.'' Khounphannavong sat in a basement hall of St. Joseph's
Sunday afternoon with three fellow Laotians, all of whom had left their country
to avoid being pressed into military service.  His father, a soldier, had fought
against the communists and was killed by communists in 1977, Khounphannavong
said.  ' 'I didn't want to be a soldier - not for the communists,'' he said
softly in broken English.  Nhan Thi Nguyen, 53, a Vietnamese refugee, said she
had been in St. Louis and the United States only one month. Her English, too, is
rough, but her message is clear.  ''No freedom in Vietnam,'' she said. ''I go to
America for freedom.''

                                The Toronto Star

              December 31, 1988, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

Refugees pour in from danger zones

BYLINE: By Paul Watson Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 475 words


   History gives Osman Isse and his family from Somalia at least even odds at
winning their refugee claim.

Canadian officials accepted about 55 per cent of 455 Somali citizens whose
refugee cases were decided in 1986 and 1987.

That means members of the defunct Refugee Status Advisory Board believed the
successful Somali claimants had a well-founded fear of persecution because of
their political beliefs, nationality, race or religion.

But refugee claimants from some countries weren't so fortunate, according to
Immigration Canada statistics.

In a list of 14 major countries where Canada's refugee claimants come from, the
success rate ranges from zero for Portuguese and Jamaicans to about 74 per cent
for Ethiopians.

And for the most part, Immigration Canada's list of the countries where the
majority of our refugees come from reads like a guide to the world's hot spots.

Millions killed

Somalia and Ethiopia are neighboring countries in the Horn of Africa, where
civil war, drought and famine have killed millions of people in the last 14
years.

Only 218 Ethiopians, whose impoverished country is ruled by a Soviet-backed
regime, asked for asylum in Canada last year.

But several thousand Somalis have asked for refugee status here since 1986 when
the pro-Western dictatorship there stepped up a bloody campaign to crush a
northern guerrilla movement.

More than 1,500 Somalis have made refugee claims in Canada this year.

Refugee claimants from India, which Sikhs and others have fled for Canada, had
one of the lowest success rates. Just one out of 496 Indian citizens got refugee
status here in the 1986 and 1987.

About 60 per cent, or 406 of 671 Chileans, convinced federal officials in 1986
and 1987 not to send them back to their South American country ruled by
right-wing dictator Augusto Pinochet.

But Nicaragua topped the list of the 10 countries that send the most refugee
claimants to our borders.

More 3,564 Nicaraguans have told immigration officials they can't risk returning
to their homeland, where guerrillas supported by the United States have fought
an eight-year war against the government.

The now-defunct Refugee Status Advisory Committee couldn't provide figures for
the success rate of Nicaraguan claimants.

Iran is second on the list with 3,275 refugee claimants. Sri Lanka is third on
the list with 3,229 claims.

The collapse of Canada's refugee screening system started to make headlines
after 155 Sri Lankan Tamils were plucked from a crowded lifeboat off the coast
of Newfoundland on Aug. 11, 1986.

The Tamils said they were fleeing a civil war sparked by demands for a separate
state on their island homeland off the southern tip of India.

Trinidad, a Caribbean country with comparatively few political problems, placed
fourth on the top 10 list with 2,894 claims.

                                The Toronto Star

              December 31, 1988, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

The fear of refugees in waiting

BYLINE: By Paul Watson Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1337 words

DATELINE: LACKAWANNA, N.Y.


   LACKAWANNA, N.Y. - Osman Isse has seen the room a thousand times in his mind
and listened to the echo of questions that will decide his future.

And he lies awake each night waiting for the immigration official to answer.

"I think about it every hour - no, every minute," said Isse, one of several
hundred refugee claimants waiting in the U.S. for hearings in Canada. "I'm
scared for myself and my family."

The 36-year-old Somali said he can't return to his homeland in the Horn of
Africa because he supported a northern rebel group trying to overthrow the
government.

Isse, his wife Sahra, 20, and their 5-month-old son Abdulaziz were caught up in
the scramble of both bogus and genuine refugees trying to enter Canada before
tighter rules take effect tomorrow.

Canada ranks second only to the United States in the list of developed countries
that have given a permanent home to refugees.

From 1975 through 1987, Canada gave landed immigrant status to 223,637 refugees,
according to the U.S. Committee for Refugees in Washington, D.C.

During that same period, the U.S. allowed 1,166,191 refugees to stay there.
France was third with 169,452 and Australia

ranked fourth at 150,859.

Isse and his family would have had a 65 per cent chance of staying in Canada if
their refugee claims had been decided last year.

That's the success rate for 403 Somali refugee claimants in 1987, according to
Immigration Canada figures.

Last year, about 27 per cent of refugee claimants from Africa, the Middle East
and West Asia won their cases. It was just under 1 per cent for Europeans, about
23 per cent for people from the Western Hemisphere and 19 percent for Asians.

But Isse made the mistake of trying to come to Canada by land, at U.S. border
points like the Peace Bridge.

While the debate raged over the growing backlog, the federal government
announced in early 1987 that refugee claimants coming from the U.S. would have
to wait there for hearings.

Several hundred people are still living in churches, homes and other emergency
shelters in the Buffalo area, in towns on the Quebec border and as far away as
Erie, Pennsylvania.

Thousands of others who arrived at air and sea ports across Canada were allowed
to stay until their claims are heard.

Some came because immigration scam operators told them Canada was an easy mark,
but others showed up because our reputation as a safe haven for genuine refugees
has spread around the globe.

Isse arrived at the Canadian border with his family after a 28-hour bus trip
from from Washington, D.C. on Nov. 8, and Immigration Canada officials told him
to wait four months in the U.S. for a hearing.

But he had no place to live and only $200 in his pocket.

So an immigration officer passed him a piece of paper with the address of La
Casa - The House.

More than 150 refugee claimants knock on the door of the rundown, two-storey
house in this town near Buffalo, N.Y., that is slowly choking as its steel mill
dies.

The former convent has welcomed about 3,000 refugee claimants turned away from
the Canadian border since February, 1987, and found shelter for any they
couldn't offer a bed or couch.

Thirty-five people are living in the 10-room house where the beds are packed in
so close that there's barely enough room to take two steps in any direction.

It costs up to $3,000 a month to provide food, medicine and transportation for
La Casa's residents, said Sister Bette DiCesare, who helps run the shelter for a
refugee group called Vive.

"We used to just automatically give out the name of the church and the address,"
DiCesare said between interviews with the latest refugee claimants turned back
from the Canadian border.

Being selective

"Now we're trying to make sure it's just those who need us most because we're
just stretched to our limits. We've had as many as 50 or 60 people here at a
time when we can't find housing for them in other churches."

People live at La Casa for as long as five months. They can't work in the United
States, so they do house chores like laundry and cooking. Local Catholic schools
have agreed to let some of the children attend classes.

But there's still a lot of time to sit around and watch TV, or worry about what
will happen when the waiting is over.

Some inevitably break down under the pressure, like a Somali government official
who asked for asylum at the Canadian border while he was supposed to be at a
conference in the U.S.

"Within about a week, he found out that as soon as the Somali government found
out he hadn't attended the conference and had actually defected, his whole
family was taken into custody," DiCesare said.

"The man was absolutely distraught. He sat in that chair and pleaded for us to
help change his hearing date before January because he knew the new rules were
coming into effect."

Getting tough

Former immigration minister Benoit Bouchard put out the word that Canada is
getting tough with bogus refugees with two bills in May and August of 1987.

Bill C-55 was drafted to make it quicker for immigration officials to separate
genuine refugees from so-called queue jumpers, or economic refugees in search of
better jobs.

Bill C-84 was aimed at people who smuggle refugee claimants into Canada and help
them concoct phony stories to support their claims.

The protests were quick and fierce.

A battalion of groups as diverse as the Autoworkers Union Movement, the Canadian
Council of Churches and the Canadian Bar Association attacked the proposed
crackdown as cold-hearted and unconstitutional.

The government got praise for finally moving to fix a system that was overloaded
and has left thousands of people hanging in limbo for up to eight years.

But critics say the new system would send genuine refugees home, possibly to
their deaths, in the bureaucratic rush to clear out false claims.

Immigration Minister Barbara McDougall announced this week she is setting up a
separate, $100 million system to clear the backlog of 85,000 refugee claims.

Anyone who made a refugee claim before Jan. 1 will appear in front of special
two-member panels.

If either the immigration department adjudicator or an independent refugee board
member believes the refugee claimant's story, he qualifies for permanent
residence in Canada.

Under pressure

McDougall was under pressure to quickly clear the backlog by letting any refugee
claimants who were working and had family in Canada stay.

But she said a so-called limited amnesty, or administrative review, would
destroy the integrity of the country's refugee screening policy.

The refugee pipeline to Canada is so clogged at the front end that relatively
few people have managed to make it through and get landed immigrant status in
recent months.

The government estimates that 70 per cent of the 85,000 claims waiting to be
decided don't fit the internationally accepted definition of a refugee.

By this fall, only 540 bogus refugees had been deported from Canada in 1988,
said Immigration Canada spokesman Gerry Maffre.

Isse and his family will get a home in Canada if they convince one of two
immigration officials that they are genuine refugees on Feb. 10.

He left Somalia to work in Saudi Arabia as a customer service agent in a Riyadh
telecommunications company 10 years ago.

When his contract was up and Isse was supposed to return to Somalia, he said he
couldn't because he belonged to the Somali National Movement.

The group is fighting the government of Mohammed Siad Barre, which the respected
monitoring group Amnesty International has accused of gross human rights
violations.

"The evidence reveals a consistent pattern of torture, lengthy and often
arbitrary detention of suspected political opponents of the government and
unfair trials of political defendants," Amnesty International said in a recent
report.

But Isse has to prove he is personally at risk if he is deported to Somalia and
sent home at Canadian taxpayers' expense.

Canadian Press
  ST. STEPHEN, N.B.

A dash across the United States to the Canadian border ended

Seven members of the group began driving non-stop from Florida on

legislation comes into effect next month.

their (immigration) inquiries,' said Max Wolfe, a Fredericton-area  lawyer who

African, all in their 20s, will stay in Saint John until their hearings in
late January.

                                     Herald

                            November 11, 1988 Friday

English classes are child's play

BYLINE: LESTER L

LENGTH: 475 words


The long list of names on a wall at the Enterprise child-care centre in
Springvale starts: Oliver, Poland; Beatriz, Chile; Vet Souphanh, Laos; Jose, El
Salvador.

There are few other child-care centres like Enterprise, where the children have
such diverse backgrounds but such a common reason for being there. Their parents
are all attempting to learn English.

The centre, funded by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic
Affairs, was set up to give migrant families access to English classes.

It is one of the services which, according to the World Council of Churches'
Refugee Services, makes Australia stand out for its treatment of newly-arrived
migrants. The child-care centre is run in conjunction with the Adult Migrant
Education Service, also on site at the Enterprise Migrant Centre. It has a
bilingual staff, trained to provide a multicultural program.

According to the centre's acting co-ordinator, Mrs Joan Meredith, staff
recognise the differences and the similarities in the children.

"They are aware of the different cultures so they don't do anything offensive
and can respect the cultural days," she said. "We are also aware that for many
migrant families, this is their first experience of child-care services. If they
don't have a good experience here, they could go out into the community and
never again trust anyone with their children."

According to Dr Elizabeth Ferris, of the Geneva-based World Council of Churches'
Refugee Services, Australia's reception and language services for refugees are
well ahead of other settler countries.

She said the concept of a refugee reception centre and associated services, such
as those at Enterprise, were unique to Australia.

"In these terms, Australia's range of services are wonderful," she said. "For
example, in the United States refugees go straight to their sponsors, who in
some cases provide great personal service, in others, very bad." However, Dr
Ferris said there were some major gaps in Australia's services for refugees - in
particular, for refugee women.

Dr Ferris also said that although Australia took an adequate number of refugees
in terms of its population, it could take many more if its resources and
multicultural policies were considered.

Of the 143,000 migrants who arrived in Australia in 1987-88, 11,076 were
refugees.

Almost 6000 came from Asia; 2300 from Europe; 1800 from South and Central
America; 906 from the Middle East; and 137 from Africa. In 1988-89, 12,000
refugees will be accepted by Australia.

Dr Ferris was also critical of Australia's selection procedure."Australia needs
to not only look at how well a refugee will be able to adapt to Australian life,
but how much the refugee needs to be resettled," she said.

                              The Washington Post

                   September 13, 1988, Tuesday, Final Edition

U.N. Refugee Aid Chief Faulted on Management;
Report Alleges 'Climate of Helplessness'

BYLINE: Ed Vulliamy, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A22

LENGTH: 938 words


A veteran relief expert who heads the U.N. High Commission for Refugees has been
sharply criticized by an internal U.N. panel, which charges that he is
responsible for poor management practices at a time when the commission faces
severe challenges in providing aid to more than 12 million refugees around the
world.

The report criticizing Jean-Pierre Hocke, the high commissioner, surfaces as
Hocke's three-year term draws to a close -- he is seeking reappointment in
November. Challengers include Norwegian Foreign Minister Thorwald Stoltenberg
and Finnish diplomat Martti Ahtassari, currently a U.N. undersecretary and
special representative to Namibia.

The restricted report, by the U.N. Panel on Discrimination and Other Grievances,
which is independent of the refugee agency, alleges "a general climate of
helplessness" at the commission that has led to the resignations of "highly
qualified senior staff . . . . " The Geneva-based panel, which submitted its
report in March, found that the "current management style at [the commission]
demonstrates the personalization and centralization of authority" around Hocke.

The Washington Post obtained the report, as well as a June 30 statement by
Robert van Leeuwen, chairman of the commission staff council, to representatives
of the 43 nations on the commission executive. The statement asserts that
despite the commission's "abiding commitment" to aid refugees, the working
"climate is marked by a lack of confidence [and] disaffection . . . . The
frustration of this commitment, due to continuing management problems . . .
seriously hampers our ability to serve refugees . . . . "

There are many millions more refugees in the world than the 12 million under the
umbrella of the commission, which, for historical reasons, is not responsible
for the Palestinians.  Among the refugees are about 5 million Afghans in Iran
and Pakistan; more than 1 million across the Horn of Africa; a million in
southern Africa, and several hundred thousand in Southeast Asia and Central
America.

The commission will spend about $ 500 million in aid funds this year. It has a
staff of 2,300 officers, 800 at headquarters in Geneva, and the rest in the
field as specialists, medical and supply personnel. The United States, Japan,
and West Germany, in that order, are the agency's biggest contributors.

Hocke, a Swiss, was named high commissioner in 1985 with U.S. support. The State
Department divisions concerned with the work of the commission, the Bureau of
International Organization Affairs and the Bureau for Refugee Programs, have
both reaffirmed full support for Hocke's reappointment. An official at the
Refugee Programs offices said: "We support him entirely. He has done a great
deal for the Horn, and in planning the repatriation of Afghans and in responding
to emergencies."

The grievance panel began its inquiry after two High Commission staffers, Yilma
Makonnen of Ethiopia and Nicolas Bwakira of Burundi, complained that they had
been denied new positions. The panel found that the two men were much better
qualified for the posts than the men eventually appointed by Hocke.

But the panel added, "It is becoming common practice to disregard the
qualifications, competence and seniority of staff . . . , " and called it "a
deplorable waste . . . . "

Other staff members said they had warned Hocke of what they called a
"frightening pattern" of resignations.

The panel also criticized what it said was Hocke's policy of hiring outside
consultants "reportedly at exorbitant cost, to do tasks . . . which could have
been accomplished more efficiently by [commission] staff."

Hocke, a veteran of the International Red Cross, arrived at the commission at a
time when some important member states were cool to the principle of asylum and
the number of refugees was growing. He was lauded by some sources for a
combative, effective management style.

But Roger Winter, director of the U.S. Committee on Refugees, a major U.S.
refugee organization, blamed Hocke for what he called a High Commission "retreat
. . . from its only statutory duty, that of protecting refugees in the fullest
legal and moral sense."

Hocke drew some criticism from within the State Department after he opened a
bureau in Kabul and went to Moscow for talks on the Afghan refugee problem; the
International Organizations office faulted this as "legitimizing the illegal
Afghan regime."

The Organization of African Unity last May complained that the commission had
made no allocation for South African refugees under the care of the African
National Congress (ANC). Brig. Gen. Hashim Mbita, executive secretary of the
OAU's Liberation Committee, berated Hocke for what he called "a steady and
substantial reduction" of assistance to refugees in the front-line states,
particularly Namibia.

Earlier this year, Hocke attracted attention after he ordered the burning of all
130,000 copies of an edition of the commission's monthly magazine Refugee before
distribution. The magazine contained a 14-page article critical of West Germany
for what the authors said was a declining commitment to refugee asylum. Hocke
was accused by some refugee experts of repressing it to appease the West
Germans, who contribute 10 percent of commission funds. Hocke has said that the
article was out of date and needed revision.

Hocke declined to discuss with a reporter any of the matters in this article. A
spokeswoman said he regarded the grievance panel report as "part of an appeal
procedure in which the high commissioner has participated and provided
documentation. The procedure is still going on."

                          August 29, 1988, Monday, ONT

Burundi killing forces Rwanda to request aid

BYLINE: (REUTER)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A9

LENGTH: 284 words

DATELINE: KIGALI, Rwanda


   KIGALI, Rwanda (Reuter) - Rwanda is asking for urgent international aid to
help cope with the flood of refugees and corpses flowing over its borders from
the violent tribal conflict in neighboring Burundi.

A Reuter correspondent in Kigali, Rwanda's capital, reported that dozens of
corpses are still being pulled out every day from the Nyabarongo River, which
forms the border between the two tiny central African nations.

The bodies are tied together in bundles, or arrive individually with their hands
bound. There have even been dead mothers with the corpses of their children
strapped to their backs.

Over 50,000 refugees have also poured in during the two-week conflict but a
Canadian diplomat in Kigali said yesterday the arrival rate has slowed.

Very poor nation

The Burundian refugees are mostly from the Hutu tribe, the majority in the
country but subservient to the minority Tutsi tribe. Burundi says about 5,000
people have been killed since fighting between the tribes broke out two weeks
ago but villagers have put the toll at tens of thousands.

Rwanda, one of the world's poorest nations, said Saturday it cannot afford
economically or physically to handle the refugees without aid. It noted it had
donated $200,000 to refugee relief funds and it also thanked eight countries -
Canada, Belgium, China, the United States, France, West Germany, Switzerland and
Zaire - for pledging aid.

Other aid has been promised by the European Community and the United Nations.

Rwanda has also said the refugees can't stay. The small state is already so
overcrowded that it refuses to take back thousands of its own refugees who have
fled because of tribal conflict.

Canada gives refugee aid

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 233 words

DATELINE: Oslo NORWAY


Reuter OSLO
   The United Nations said yesterday it will cost $600-million (U.S.) to
help refugees in southern Africa and only their high death rate keeps the
cost from climbing.

Canada pledged $4.2-million (U.S.) and the United States $10.5-million
in emergency aid on the second day of a three-day international conference
discussing the plight of about one million refugees and five million
displaced people in southern Africa.

The scale of the problem was highlighted by a paper prepared by the UN
development agency and distributed to the 500 conference delegates
representing 81 countries.

'Though the cost of rehabilitating around one million families  (representing
six million people) will be high - probably around $600-  million excluding
short-term food aid - it is far less than the cost of  continuing relief
assistance into the future,' the paper said.

It estimated the cost of supporting each refugee family at about $1,000
a year for a yearly total of $1-billion.

'To the extent that less resources are available for support, a  natural
equilibrium is achieved through increased morbidity,' the paper  said.

The pledges of emergency aid came in speeches from the Canadian and
U.S. delegation chiefs.

The conference chairman, Norwegian Foreign Minister Thorvald
Stoltenberg, has said the aim of the conference is not to collect funds
but to draw up an overall plan to deal with the crisis.

The pledge, along with one of about $12.9 million ($10.5 million U.S.) by the

discuss the plight of the refugees.

But the conference was told it would take about $738 million (about $600 million

that figure from rising.

The scale of the problem was highlighted by a paper prepared by the U.N.
development agency and distributed to the 500 conference delegates representing
81 countries.

people) will be high - probably around $600 million (U.S.) excluding short-term
food aid - it is far less than the cost of continuing relief assistance into the
future," the paper said.

Serious damage

giving a yearly total of $1 billion U.S.

"To the extent that less resources are available for support, a natural
equilibrium is achieved through increased morbidity," the paper said.

behalf of External Relations and International Development Minister Monique
Landry.

"Canada remains firm in its commitment to the South African region and continues
to provide humanitarian assistance to those in need," McLean said.

                              The Washington Post

                     July 23, 1988, Saturday, Final Edition

Canada Tightens Laws on Refugee Claims

BYLINE: Herbert H. Denton, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A24

LENGTH: 312 words

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 22, 1988


Tough immigration bills designed to give the Canadian government more power to
deny entry to bogus refugee claimants were approved yesterday after an
11-month-long, acrimonious battle in parliament.

Two new laws give the government authority to turn back ships carrying illegal
aliens and raise the penalties against persons helping illegal immigrants enter
Canada to fines of up to $ 10,000 and jail terms of up to 10 years.

Prime Minister Brian Mulroney had called the House of Commons into an emergency
session last August to pass the bills, but objections raised by church groups
and refugee aid organizations delayed approval.

Mulroney acted after a public outcry about abuse of Canada's immigration system
that followed the landing of 174 Sikhs off the coast of Nova Scotia. There had
been an uproar the previous summer after a boatload of Tamils fleeing refugee
camps in West Germany and elsewhere in Europe, where aliens are often prohibited
from working, had arrived in Canada off the coast of Newfoundland.

The new laws require that refugees seek asylum to escape political persecution
rather than to seek economic gain.

Under old Canadian laws, authorities were forced to give the benefit of the
doubt and allow entry to any alien who sought asylum, no matter how flimsy the
claim.

Often it would take years to hold a hearing on the claim. By then, many with
unfounded refugee claims had married Canadian citizens or taken other steps to
legalize their status. There is currently a backlog of about 50,000 such cases.

Illegal aliens flocked to Canada from Asia, South America, southern Europe and
Africa. Authorities said there even was a handful of Americans who claimed
political persecution in the United States.

In the new system, authorities will be able to send refugees back to "safe"
countries while their claims are being considered.

                               The Times (London)

                           February 27 1988, Saturday

Books: Touching the essence of bravery - Review of 'My Happy Days in Hell' by
George Faludy

BYLINE: MARK LE FANU

SECTION: Issue 63014.

LENGTH: 528 words


The autobiography of Hungary's foremost 20th century poet - self-exiled, since
1957, in Canada - was first published, to acclaim, 25 years ago and has just
been re-issued by Corgi.

Many prison-and-exile memoirs have been published in the interim; the genre now
constitutes one of the recognizable sub-divisions of modern literature. At its
highest level - at the level of a Solzhenitsyn, say, or a Nadezhda Mandelstam or
a Galina Von Meck - such memoirs seem almost to have ousted the novel from its
pinnacle in modern letters: the place where society finds its finest, gravest
self-reflection. One is so bowled over at the biographical truth of what human
beings can go through, and have gone through, that invented fiction is
henceforth a frivolity.


Only a third of Faludy's book deals with the specific experience of imprisonment
and torture in the forced labour camps of Stalinist Hungary. The first
two-thirds of the memoir are taken with a richly evocative account of Faludy's
early life, his initial exile in Paris during the 1930s (refugee from Horthy's
fascism which he had lampooned in his verses); war-time wanderings in Northern
Africa; finally an agreeable period in the United States from which, however, he
chose to return in 1945, ostensibly to help rebuild his stricken country, but
actually into the waiting jaws of fate.

The character of the man that emerges from these Preliminaries is intriguing.
For at the same time as it is apparent that he is one of those rare spirits who
knows the tragic weight of things, it becomes, as the story goes on, no less
clear that he is an optimist, a fabulist, or perhaps in the end I mean merely a
poet.

Take the interlude in Morocco where he wound up in 1940 as a refugee from Vichy.
The episode contains some of the book's most richly detailed passages. Yet
'realistic' as the scenes are in terms of dates, names, conversations, the
episode resembles, elsewhere, a baroque dream lifted out of the Arabian Knights.
Faludy's intense erudition (he is as wittily learned vas Thomas Mann or
Marguerite Yourcenar) can't refrain from converting the dross of contemporary
experience into mythical or historical ore. Is 'reality' distorted in the
process? We can't tell. The author, at any event, comes across as a hedonist, a
connoisseur, a self-taught master of the 'art of life'; and this gives a special
flavour to the final third of the book that describes in detail the encroachment
of the Communist nightmare.

The battle that follows from this for our hero's body and soul is thrilling.
Faludy survived the ordeal, survived torture and starvation to set it all down,
like Solzhenitsyn, in the minutest detail. Heading this beautifully-written
testimony is to be put in touch, at times, with the pure essence of energy and
bravery. One closes the book with awe, sustained by the reflection - we hope not
illusory - that there are no misfortunes that the human spirit can't rise above.
The book's title is perhaps only sardonic on the surface. Happiness (by which
Faludy means boundless wonder and curiosity in front of the universe) seems to
be each man's ineradicable birthright.

                              The Washington Post

                    January 19, 1988, Tuesday, Final Edition

Sen. Inouye's School (Cont'd.)

SECTION: EDITORIAL; PAGE A14; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

LENGTH: 346 words


Irene Novak's letter ["Sen. Inouye's School in France," Jan. 7] is yet another
example of the ignorance of the U.S. taxpayer as to who is a refugee and who is
funding the refugees in the Arab-Israeli conflict.

For the past 40 years, we have heard only about the Arab refugees. Little is
known of the 856,000 Jews who lived in Arab countries before 1948, indeed, long
before the dawn of Islam. Of these, 830,000 were forced to leave their countries
of birth and find refuge in Israel, Europe and the Americas. These Jews left
behind incalculable assets in property and cultural and religious patrimony
accumulated from more than 2,000 years of living in these countries.

Most of these Jews arrived destitute to their new homes. Unlike their Arab
counterpart, Jews did not benefit from funds of the U.N. Relief and Works
Agency. Yet these Jews are the other side of the coin of the Middle East refugee
problem. Between 1949 and 1974, the United States and Israel contributed $
582,339,802 to UNRWA's budget, which was allocated to provide relief assistance
for all refugees of the Near East. This should have included Jews from Arab
countries as well. Instead, more than $ 1 billion to date has gone to the
rehabilitation of Palestinian refugees alone, who were refused resettlement by
their Arab brethren in the vast land of the Arab nation extending from the
Persian Gulf to the Atlantic Ocean.

Therefore, Irene Novak and others should not feel distraught by the allocation
of a meager $ 8 million for children of Jewish refugees from North Africa, which
has been allocated for learning and not for political or military ends.

Perhaps the time has arrived for Congress, the White House and the American
public to recognize the other refugee problem that has been neglected over the
past 40 years. In acknowledging their plight as well, we will discover the
missing part of the solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict.

MAURICE M. ROUMANI

College Park

The writer is a professor of political science and Middle Eastern studies at the
University of Maryland.

                                The Toronto Star

                   August 12, 1987, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Legislation endangers refugees, politicians, rights groups say

BYLINE: By Olivia Ward Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 551 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   By Olivia Ward Toronto Star

OTTAWA - Refugee legislation reintroduced in Parliament this week is unworkable
and endangers the lives of refugees, say politicians, and human rights and
public policy groups.

Bill C-55 puts emphasis on sending refugees back to "safe third countries" they
have passed through, returning them to countries that once granted them asylum,
or sending them home.

But the United States and other potential "third" countries are closing their
doors.

Of the almost 200,000 asylum-seekers in Europe last year, it's estimated that
fewer than 9,000 will be granted permanent residency.

Most will be forcibly returned to their own countries. And some, like the Tamils
and Sikhs who landed in Canada, will pay large sums to smugglers who promise
them a new homeland.

An immigration department spokesman said Monday that although other Western
countries have made "no firm commitment" to accept claimants Canada rejects,
negotiations are in progress.

But, say refugee advocates, the number of countries that will take refugees back
is becoming limited. Even countries of first asylum - those bordering areas from
which refugees are fleeing - are becoming nervous about the numbers of newcomers
entering their territory.

"The majority of Western countries now feel they've done their bit, and are
concentrating on family reunification cases rather than new refugees," says a
spokesman for the United Nations High Commission for Refugees in Geneva.

Canada 'deluded'

Bill Frelick, a policy analyst with the Washington-based U.S. Committee for
Refugees, says Canada is "deluded" if it thinks the U.S. will take back Central
Americans or others who have passed through the country heading north.

"Canada may want to get rid of them, but I can see no indication that the
immigration service would accept them," he said in a phone interview. "Their
view has always been that once someone is over the border, they are no longer
our problem."

Frelick says the new Canadian legislation would create more "orbit refugees" - a
term for homeless asylum-seekers forced to move from country to country.

The West's reluctance to accept refugees is having an effect on countries of
first asylum, refugee monitoring groups say. And they are using tough tactics,
ranging from tightened legal requirements to violence, to reduce their own
numbers of refugee claimants.

Panic reactions

"Turkey is a very worrisome case just now," says Frelick. "It has recently made
a rule that only East Europeans can be classed as refugees, which means that
Iranians fleeing the country are being turned back."

Max Brem of the North South Institute, an Ottawa-based public policy group, says
that the focus on the "panicked reaction" of Western countries has covered up
the fact that Third World nations on the front lines are often more fragile and
ill-equipped to deal with large numbers of new residents.

In Africa, about 3.5 million people are displaced because of catastrophic
drought and warfare. And although refugees are generally accepted, the receiving
countries are too poor to support the new burden.

"Africans don't want to leave the continent as refugees," says Stephen Lewis,
Canada's ambassador to the United Nations and head of a UN task force on Africa.

                                The Toronto Star

                      July 17, 1987, Friday, FINAL EDITION

Thousands of other 'refugees' enter Canada at normal ports

BYLINE: By Jim Emmerson Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 735 words


   While Canada agonizes over its latest boatload of claimants to "refugee"
status, it's scarcely noticed that thousands of others have made similar claims
recently from normal ports of entry.

The largest number, by far, have come to Ontario entry points - Fort Erie,
Windsor and Niagara Falls - by foot, by automobile, bus and train.

Others have come from abroad by plane.

Many are turned back immediately but most are allowed into the country to begin
the long, laborious process of establishing their claim. If court appeals are
involved, it could take two years.

Ron Bull, immigration representative in Toronto, said 1,058 refugee claim cases
are being examined in Ontario, while another 203 applicants have been turned
back to the United States to await further inquiry.

And, Bull added, this covers only the period from Feb. 20 to July 10 this year.

In February, Ottawa clamped down on the growing tide of "refugees," removing
many countries from the list of those whose citizens enjoyed automatic
categorization as refugees.

2,000 a month

Visa requirements were imposed on most foreign nationals.

A church official working with refugee claimants already in Metro Toronto
estimates that about 2,000 "refugee" applicants a month were entering Ontario.

Mark Persaud, co-ordinator of the Toronto United Church Emergency Refugee
Relief, said "there are a number of reasons" why 174 people would be smuggled in
by boat off the Nova Scotia coast, as happened Sunday, if people can walk up to
the border, claim refugee status and be granted temporary admission.

"It is difficult to get to Canada by plane," Persaud said in an interview. "A
lot of people have to get false documents to get here. If they used proper
identification it would be difficult for them to come by normal means in seeking
political asylum.

"Some of these people - and a lot of them are Iranians - go to Turkey or
Pakistan and get false papers. This is not held against them. It is recognized
that when you flee from persecution you use whatever means you can to get to a
safe place."

'Action in Ontario'

Bull told The Star: "Most of the action, now, is in Ontario. There are a lot of
Latin American claimants. They are looking to Canada now that their hopes of
settlement in the United States have been dimmed."

But Canada has also toughened up its stance toward "refugee" claimants -
applicants many Canadians view as line-jumpers in the normal immigration
process.

To try to weed out people seeking economic advantage in Canada, Ottawa requires
visas of visitors from most Asian and Iron Curtain countries, Bull said. Brazil
was recently added to the list of countries where people must obtain visas
before leaving for Canada.

Those who get to the border seeking refugee status are subjected to thorough
checks, Bull said.

As a signator to the Geneva Convention on refugees, Canada is obligated to grant
asylum where there is genuine fear of persecution because of race, nationality,
religious belief or political affiliation, Persaud said.

Runs Tucker House

Persaud, who runs Tucker House on Avoca Ave., said he has about six would-be
refugees at a time on the premises.

Since Tucker House opened in 1985, about 400 applicants have been given
temporary shelter, he said, and of those "a significant number" met the refugee
criteria. He didn't have an exact figure at hand.

Most of the refugees have come from Chile, Guatemala, El Salvador, Eritrea,
Ethiopia and some from South Africa, he explained.

He said Sikhs are rare at his centre because the Sikhs, like the Tamils, are
absorbed by their own communities.

Dr. Tom Clark, co-ordinator of the Inter Church Committe For Refugees (supported
by nine churches), said he thought the latest furor over refugees smuggled
ashore in Nova Scotia is "a tempest in a teapot.

Claim rejected

"There are 18,000 claimaints to refugee status and if the (Canadian) system
worked properly half of those would be accepted," he added. "And here we are
suddenly asking a lot of questions about 174."

Clark rejected Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard's claim that the Opposition
has held up the bill, which would make it easier to deal with the refugee
question.

"Some of his own caucus members spoke against the bill in the House and it's now
recognized as unfair and unworkable," Clark said.
