                          July 14, 1987, Tuesday, ONT

Unwelcome refugees desperate for help

BYLINE: By Thomas Netter Special to The Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 573 words

DATELINE: GENEVA, Switzerland


   GENEVA - Unwelcome in Europe and the United States, many refugees from Sri
Lanka, South Asia, Africa and Latin America are becoming desperate, aid workers
here say.

In their desperation, more are turning to countries such as Canada for
sanctuary.

Refugee workers fear incidents such as the arrival Sunday of 174 illegal
immigrants in Nova Scotia and last summer's boatload of Tamils off Newfoundland
may become more frequent.

According to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees in Geneva, the
number of refugees requesting political asylum in the 12-nation European
Community increased by 50 per cent between 1985 and 1986 to about 165,000.
Provisional estimates put the total number by mid-1987 at about 180,000.

Rickety boats

Over the past decade, some 50,000 Tamils fleeing civil strife and economic
uncertainty in Sri Lanka have arrived in Europe via air links through East
Berlin or virtually any other means of transport from rickety boats to freight
trains.

But there is little to welcome the refugees in Europe:

* In West Germany Tamils are restricted in their movements, facing heavy fines
if they re-locate, forbidden to work and denied German language courses.
Legislators are studying measures that would tighten refugee laws;

* Denmark has begun planning a ban on all refugees lasting for one year to clear
asylum seekers from overflowing camps;

* Belgium has begun turning refugees back at its national borders;

* Switzerland, long proud of its status as a home for exiles, last year proposed
the deportation of some 1,000 Tamils, or about 10 per cent of the estimated
total in the country.

The proposal created a major political conflict even though the majority of the
Swiss appear to favor sending the Tamils home, and even voted in favor of more
restrictive refugee laws several months ago. The outcry by Liberal politicians
and refugee assistance groups has blocked the government's plans;

* In France the ultra-right has won continuing support by pleading with the
government to further restrict the arrival of new refugees.

Official and bureaucratic restrictions are often compounded by outright racism,
refugees claim.

France, for example, has been wracked by racist incidents involving verbal and
even physical attacks on mostly Third World, Arab or dark-skinned refugees.

In other European nations, Tamils and other refugees, primarily those from the
Third World, are facing similar and growing hurdles in their bids to find a new
home.

Steady deterioration

In short, the prospects for those seeking to flee their homeland appear bleak,
the aid officials say.

"The corollary to this is that external ramparts are being considerably
strengthened," a European Community spokesman said in a recent interview.

"There has been a steady deterioration in the legal and social position of those
seeking asylum in the European Community," said a report published by the
European Parliament earlier this year. Swiss activists fighting the government's
plans have made similar comments.

Switzerland, though not a community member, has been regarded as a prime country
of asylum and currently has a post-World War II high of 21,000 pending asylum
cases.

The more restrictive attitude of authorities in the community as well as
Switzerland appears to be based primarily on high unemployment and a rising tide
of xenophobia, community and Swiss officials say.

Unwelcome refugees growing more desperate for help

BYLINE: By Thomas Netter Special to The Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 503 words

DATELINE: GENEVA, Switzerland

are accepted into the country and only if they can establish that their lives
would be endangered if sent back to their homeland.

                                The Toronto Star

                     June 18, 1987, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Letters to the Editor: Refugee bill nothing to be proud of

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A24

LENGTH: 360 words


   The harsh attitude heralded by the new refugee bill is already having its
psychological toll.

At the Canadian Centre for the Investigation and Prevention of Torture in
Toronto, torture victims from Asia, Africa and Latin America are extremely
worried, according to centre staff.

Unlike Canadians, they don't assume that any civilized government is sympathetic
to their plight and will ensure they are not sent back to the torture chambers.
In the new refugee bill and public suspicion about refugees, these people see
only danger. Alone in a strange city, separated from friends and family, some
are talking about suicide; anything is better than going back.

One hopes their fears are unfounded, but the new bill leaves lots of room for
doubt.

The chief danger is that most refugees arriving in Canada may soon be sent back
to so-called safe countries, if they passed through such countries on their way
here. The problem is, there is no guarantee they would be allowed to stay in
those countries.

For example, there is little doubt that the United States will be on the list of
safe countries; it would be politically unwise to exclude it. Yet for refugees
from Central America, the U.S. is anything but safe - Washington sends back more
than 95 per cent of refugees from El Salvador and Guatemala, despite those
countries' horrendous human rights records.

Many Canadians say they are sympathetic to genuine refugees but fear a tidal
wave of claims, both legitimate and false. This fear is unfounded; and the fact
it is promoted by the government shows a terrible unconcern for the true
situation of most refugees.

After the 1956 uprising in Hungary, Canada accepted 37,000 Hungarian refugees,
no questions asked. We took in more than 70,000 Vietnamese boat people in
1979-'80.

But in 1986, with a grand total of just 18,000 refugee claims, we were said to
be facing a tidal wave. And so now we propose to shut the door on virtually all
refugees, who are largely fleeing brutal regimes in places like Chile, El
Salvador, Guatemala and Iran.

It will be a sad day for Canada if the bill is passed.

TED WAKEFIELD

Toronto

                                The Toronto Star

                           May 17, 1987, Sunday, Su2

Austria's forgotten refugees

BYLINE: By Arch MacKenzie Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. H5

LENGTH: 525 words

DATELINE: TRAISKIRCHEN, AUSTRIA


   TRAISKIRCHEN, Austria - The envelope pinned to the bulletin board outside the
headquarters of this sprawling refugee camp is addressed to Maria Varga, Grande
Prairie, Alta. It has been returned "address unknown."

Maria Varga, wherever she is in Canada, may have lost touch with Traiskirchen
camp but she is presumably a successful graduate of the Austrian refugee system.

Since the end of World War II, the system has handled more than 2 million
uprooted people, products of the upheaval of the war itself and the subsequent
fallout from political and social change in Central and Eastern Europe.

In Canadian terms, Austria gets the daily equivalent of the 155 Tamil refugees
from Sri Lanka who last August materialized via West Germany off Newfoundland
and changed the pattern of Canada's refugee-screening program.

Legislation tabled in the House of Commons May 5 perpetuates an emergency
crackdown imposed Feb. 20 to block landed status for refugee claimants.

The Canadian government has blamed a surge of claims from Portugal, Turkey and
now Central America for forcing a crackdown on applicants it says should be in
the lineup for immigration status.

But every day is refugee day in Austria, flanked by Czechoslovakia, Hungary and
Yugoslavia and within easy reach of Romania, Albania and Poland.

This nation of 7 million people is host to about 1,800 each of Czechoslovakians
and Hungarians, 1,300 Romanians, 500 Yugoslavs, 300 Poles and small groups from
Albania, Iran, Viet Nam and other points in Asia, Africa and the Middle East -
about 6,500 in all.

Dusted off

This day in Traiskirchen, built by the doomed Hapsburg empire as an artillery
cadet school and later used as a riding academy and wartime German military
camp, the refugees total 1,550, including 70 single females, 800-odd single
males and the rest family units.

Canadian officials, who supervise the annual migration to Canada of about 1,200
Austria refugees, say it is a rare refugee who is turned away.

Austria harbored 1.5 million displaced people when World War II ended in 1945.

At the time of the Hungarian revolt in 1956, there were still 114,000 refugees
here, and Traiskirchen was dusted off and thrown into the breach when another
150,000 Hungarians flooded in.

They were joined by 10,000 Yugoslavians.

The Czechoslovakian crisis of 1968 provided another 96,000 refugees directly and
66,000 via Yugoslavia, although many were simply pausing to weigh the risks of
returning home.

In the Polish upheaval of 1980-82, Austria took more than 33,000 refugees but
has since tightened entry requirements for Poles so that claimants now must find
personal sponsors here.

Austria has been a leading conduit for the movement of Soviet Jews, recording as
few as 251 in 1968 up to 3l,000 in the early 1970s, 50,202 in 1979 and 1,126 in
1985.

Canadian officials fret about the fact that only a few Austrian refugees reach
Canada with private sponsorship. Only about 85 of the 1,200 arrivals last year
received that kind of support.

Canada ranks second after the United States, which takes about 1,800 Austrian
refugees annually.

                              April 6, 1987 Monday

Refugees, immigrants object to new policy

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 282 words


The Globe and Mail
  About 300 refugees and immigrants from Afghanistan, Africa, Vietnam,
Guatemala and other countries braved cold winds and freezing rain on the
weekend to protest against Canada's immigration policies.
   'There are refugees on the U.S. side of the border waiting to come to
Canada to live a life without war,' Sister Bonny Butler, a relief worker
with Central American refugees waiting in Buffalo to come to Canada, told
the rally at Toronto's Nathan Phillips Square on Saturday.
   'These people are desperately afraid. They don't want to come to
Canada because of the climate. They come here seeking peace.'
   In February, the federal Government announced tough measures aimed at
stopping or diverting a stream of people from entering Canada to claim
refugee status.

Under the new policy, all refugee claimants coming from the United
States are sent back to that country until an immigration hearing can be
held in Canada. In addition, all claimants must go through the refugee
determination policy.

Michael Schelew, a spokesman on refugee affairs for the Canadian
section of Amnesty International, said Canadians and the federal
Government must be made aware that if refugees are deported to countries
with poor human rights records, the refugees could be killed.

'Refugees are being turned away at the door to go back to an uncertain  fate,'
he said.

Dr. Joyce Kabalya-Senyonjo, who came to Canada as a refugee almost
three years ago, said it was difficult for her get to this country because
there are so few foreign missions.

'There are only four Canadian foreign missions in Uganda,' she said.  'It is
almost impossible to reach a Canadian foreign mission to get to  Canada.'

                                The Toronto Star

                  March 8, 1987, Sunday, SUNDAY SECOND EDITION

'Superpower game' spawns millions of stateless citizens

BYLINE: By Olivia Ward Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 1220 words


   There are about 5 million people in refugee camps throughout the world,
living in conditions that range from poverty to squalor. Some - as in Lebanon -
are targets for political violence. Others, like Kampucheans in Thailand, are
turned out and moved away. Still others, like Indonesians in Papua New Guinea,
are forcibly returned to countries that persecute them.

There have been successful attempts to settle refugees from camps. But in the
main the camps are becoming permanent fixtures where children are born and grow
up.

And outside of them, another 15 million displaced people try to survive in
villages, slums or on the run. Some are forced to move within their own
countries. Many are trying to escape continuing conflicts that push them back
and forth like pawns on a chess board.

"Part of the problem is the superpower game," says York University political
scientist Reg Whitaker, author of a forthcoming book on Canadian immigration
policy. By supporting Third World conflicts, he says, Russia and the United
States cynically create stateless citizens for whom they will not take
responsibility.

"In El Salvador the Americans are sponsoring bombing campaigns to move people
out of what they feel are power bases. They're driving people into refugee
camps, but won't accept them in the U.S."

Local wars, civil wars and guerrilla conflicts are responsible for mass
migrations in Africa and Asia. And ongoing religious wars in the Near and Middle
East (sometimes abetted by superpowers) have created permanent refugees.

The following is a list of the most critical refugee areas, with latest
estimates for 1986 from the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR).

AFRICA

SUDAN - One of the world's leading refugee countries, with 1.2 million displaced
people, most of them from Ethiopia, Uganda and Chad. New arrivals have
diminished slightly with civil strife on the East Bank.

SOMALIA - Refugee agencies now count about 700,000 refugees, most of them women
and children living in 36 centres throughout the country.

BURUNDI - The large refugee population of almost 268,000 is growing due to
unchecked fertility. Most refugees are Rwandese or Rwandese-born Ungandans whom
Burundi government hopes to repatriate.

TANZANIA - More than 207,000 refugees have arrived, most fleeing the military
government of Burundi. The majority have formed self-sustaining communities
along Lake Tanganyika.

ETHIOPIA - The entire southeastern part of the country is a vast refugee camp,
home to 180,000 refugees, most of them from Sudan.

UGANDA - The political upheavals of 1985 displaced more than 150,000 people
within the country. Most have fled to the western part of the country, forming
eight transitional communities.

ZAMBIA - More than 100,000 refugees have poured in from Mozambique and Anglola.
Downturn in economy and currency devaluation have made their survival more
difficult.

Asia

PAKISTAN - World's largest receiver of refugees, the vast majority from
Afghanistan. About 2.7 million people, mostly women and children, live in camps
that have been turned into makeshift villages by foreign aid. Population has
increased by 7 per cent in past year.

CHINA - Hong Kong has about 200,000 refugees, most from mainland China

THAILAND - More than 130,000 people live in refugee camps, most of them Laotian
and Kampuchean. Numbers have increased for the first time since 1979, but the
Thai government is moving aggressively to forcibly repatriate them.

PAPUA NEW GUINEA - About 10,000 Indonesian refugees are scattered through
isolated camps where malnutrition is major problem. Government has tried to
forcibly repatriate those suspected of belonging to a political independence
movement.

Near and Middle East

IRAN - About 2 million Afghan refugees have been resettled in Iran, dispersed
through 12 provinces. Government integrates refugees quickly.

ISRAEL - Occupied territories contain 1.5 million stateless Palestinians settled
on West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem.

CYPRUS - About 200,000 people were displaced when Turkey invaded Greek Cypriot
territory in 1974. UNHCR still funds assistance projects for refugees.

LEBANON - More than 100,000 citizens are displaced within the country by
continuing wars. About 140,000 Palestinians are in refugee camps near Beirut,
and 271,000 Palestinian refugees live outside the camps. Attacks and blockades
of the camps have made them among the most dangerous territories in the world.

Latin America

MEXICO - Most of Mexico's 175,000 refugees are Salvadorans, the remainder
Guatemalans. Refugee camps are set up in southern states, where there are border
raids. Those who leave are having increased difficulty in finding work in
cities, or obtaining work documents as Mexican economy worsens.

HONDURAS - More than 60,000 refugees, many of them Miskito Indians from
Nicaragua, have settled in rural areas. Most are self-supporting.

COSTA RICA - Small, politically tranquil country attracts refugees fleeing civil
wars. Has about 27,000 refugees from Nicaragua and El Salvador, but cannot
absorb more into its 2.5 million population.

NICARAGUA - About 17,000 Salvadorans have fled and been integrated into the
country. Sandinista government offers assistance, technical and agricultural
training.

ARGENTINA - With economy in crisis, Argentina has accepted 14,000 refugees from
Chile, Uruguay and Indo-China. Numbers have been rising as political tensions in
region increase, in spite of return of some Uruguayans following change of
government.

Europe

FRANCE - Now records 174,000 non-naturalized refugees, many Africans and Asians.
Government funds refugee integration programs, but new applications are severely
restricted.

BRITAIN - Has 135,000 refugees, including large number from Hong Kong. After
1985 new status determination procedure reduced numbers significantly. Present
intake is less than 1,000.

WEST GERMANY - Government's open policy has brought total to 134,000, including
Tamils from Sri Lanka. Refugees live in "collective accommodation centres," some
of them closed because of squalid conditions. New centres are opening, and some
refugees are put in private apartments.

BELGIUM - Has taken 36,000 refugees, but now restricts entry because government
says receiving facilities are inadequate.

SWITZERLAND - Current total of registered refugees is 30,000, but government
doesn't favor open policy. It now favors "voluntary repatriation."

AUSTRIA - About 20,000 refugees have been admitted, many of them East Europeans.
In spite of resettlement attempts, numbers of people living in refugee centres
hasn't diminished very much.

Pacific

AUSTRALIA - Refugees now total 89,000. Government tries to naturalize them
routinely. Refugees include Europeans, Middle Eastern people, Asians.

NEW ZEALAND - Has taken 4,500 refugees, including recent Vietnamese refugees.

North America

UNITED STATES - Has taken about 1 million refugees since 1950s, but has cut back
yearly admission quotas in past two years to 63,000.

CANADA - Has taken about 360,000 refugees since 1950s, with yearly quotas of
about 12,000. Last year admitted 12,146 government-sponsored refugees and 5,067
privately-sponsored. Quota for 1987 is 12,000 government-sponsored, 4,000
private.

                                The Toronto Star

                February 22, 1987, Sunday, SUNDAY SECOND EDITION

Small border towns said refugees' best way in

BYLINE: By Walter Stefaniuk Toronto Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2

LENGTH: 553 words


   The quickest way into Canada now for Latin American and other refugees is
through out-of-the-way border towns, off the beaten path to sanctuary.

"At some of the smaller points of entry, it's conceivable that people would be
allowed in because (immigration officials) can schedule inquiries within 48
hours to get the refugee claims going," said Canada Immigration spokesman Gerry
Maffre in Ottawa last night.

"That's the hook - if they can schedule hearings within 48 hours, then they'll
let the person in."

Scores of refugee claimants trying to cross into Canada via the United States
have been turned back at major entry points in Ontario and Quebec since
Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard imposed tighter controls on the flow
Friday.

They must now wait at the border - unless they face deportation to their
homeland by the U.S. government - until their status is established by the
hearing.

Points of entry

Maffre said that at major points of entry, "the numbers are just beyond what the
officers can handle along with the other immigration work they have to do."

Precise figures of those admitted and those turned back won't be available until
a tally is made by managers Monday. So far, no claimants have shown up at places
such as Sault Ste. Marie or Fort Francis in Northern Ontario. Immigration
officers at popular entry points for refugees in southern Ontario said they were
not authorized to comment on the numbers knocking at the door.

But two bus loads of Latin American refugee claimants, about 33 in all, have
been turned back at the Blackpool crossing in Lacolle, Que., about 60 kilometres
(36 miles) south of Montreal, until hearings into their status can be arranged.
Another six were turned back after trying to enter at Phillipsburg, Que.

Quebec, because of its proximity to New York city with its high numbers of Latin
American refugees, is by far the most used doorway to Canada.

The government measures ordered Friday came after the refugee flow via the
United States - which totalled 1,600 people for all of 1980 - began to rise in a
torrent since last fall, bringing 1986 totals to 18,282 people.

British Columbia

And 6,120 refugee claimants entered Canada just in the first six weeks of 1987.
A total of 3,989 came to Quebec, 1,672 to Ontario, 396 to British Columbia and
63 to the other provinces.

The largest groups originally came from strife-torn Latin American countries
such as El Salvador (2,294), Chile (1,010) and Guatemala (600). More than 400
each arrived from Sri Lanka and Iran, with most of the rest from other Middle
Eastern countries and Africa.

About 700 of those claimants crossed into Ontario on Fort Erie's Peace Bridge
which, along with Niagara Falls, Windsor and Sarnia, is in the London
immigration district, said Roger White, an immigration spokesman in Metro.

The controversial cancellation of the so-called B-1 list of 18 countries -
including El Salvador, Guatemala, Sri Lanka and Iran - to which Canada did not
deport people means claimants from those countries can be returned home if they
are not granted refugee status.

Previously, claimants from B-1 list countries had been automatically issued
special minister's visas which enabled them to enter Canada and work while
awaiting the results of their hearings.

                                The Toronto Star

                    January 20, 1987, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Tory MP wants visa requirement for people fleeing Central America

BYLINE: (CP)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. C10

LENGTH: 485 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA (CP) - The federal government should impose a visa requirement on
Central American citizens if they are abusing the refugee system to live in
Canada, a Progressive Conservative MP says.

Tory Ross Belsher (Fraser Valley East) also criticized the government's handling
of the refugee situation over the last few months.

Nearly 1,000 Central Americans seeking refugee status entered Canada in the
first two weeks of 1987, immigration officials confirmed last week. Many entered
Canada from the United States.

Most are from El Salvador and Guatemala, and came here because they feared being
deported by the U.S. government to their countries of origin despite the
possibility they would face political persecution. The United States does not
recognize all Salvadorans and Guatemalans as refugees despite the poor human
rights situations in both countries.

"If we're going to retain a fairly open refugee policy, then there's going to
have to be a number of countries from which we insist on a visa along with any
applications to visit our country - and not just grant wholesale visiting
rights," Belsher said outside the House of Commons yesterday.

Tighten doors

"There's no problem with American citizens or British citizens - but we're going
to have to tighten up our doors."

Anyone can apply for refugee status upon arrival in Canada. Some would-be
immigrants seeking better economic conditions do so because an application for
refugee status takes up to four years to process and they can settle here in the
meantime. Claims for immigrant status are processed more quickly.

Belsher noted that Tamil refugees were granted ministerial permits before the
government knew they had actually come via West Germany.

He also cited the recent influx of Turkish nationals who requested refugee
status in Montreal.

"We became aware in October that a number of Turks were starting to abuse the
system and we didn't impose a visa requirement until late December or early
January," Belsher said.

In the Commons, Belsher asked Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard about "a
possible influx of people of Central American extraction by way of the United
States," and what the government is doing to prevent the "possible influx and
abuse of Canadian policy."

Political refugees

Bouchard told the Commons the government will take action if necessary, but for
now it will continue to "watch the situation very closely."

Bouchard said last week the people from Central America can't be compared to
those who have abused the system because many are political refugees.

Belsher claimed the minister's response was "incomplete," and said he will raise
the matter again.

Canada recently imposed a visa requirement on Turkey and four African countries.
Citizens of those countries must now obtain a visa from Canadian officials there
before visiting or travelling through Canada.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            January 8, 1987 Thursday

Don't spurn refugees, Canada urged

BYLINE: CP

LENGTH: 762 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ONT


Canadian Press
  OTTAWA
   The federal Government must not turn its back on political refugees,
despite widespread concern that phony claimants are abusing the system,
the North-South Institute says.

The independent research institute, in its annual review of Canadian
foreign policy released yesterday, expressed concerns similar to those of
immigrant aid groups, who are worried that Ottawa may soon move to
restrict access to full hearings by refugee claimants and their rights of
appeal.

'This turning back on Canada's liberal humanitarian tradition is  vigorously
opposed by all groups concerned with refugee rights,' the  annual review says.
'Other approaches are needed to curb abuses of  Canada's refugee system.'     In
a series of observations on other issues, the institute:   . Congratulates the
Conservative Government on its leadership role in  Commonwealth sanctions
against South Africa, its efforts at the United  Nations to relieve African
famine, and its prominent role in La  Francophonie, the French- speaking
counterpart of the Commonwealth;   . Warns that free-trade negotiations with the
United States 'may have  been oversold' and urges a higher priority for
multilateral initiatives  through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade;
. Expresses satisfaction at Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's commitment to
getting UN finances in order, but takes a slap at Mr. Mulroney for his
appointment of former Montreal mayor Jean Drapeau to the sensitive post of
ambassador to UNESCO, the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural  Organization.
. Regrets the increasing tendency to tie foreign aid to the interests of
domestic Canadian industry, often providing a subsidy to the Canadian  supplier
while raising costs for the recipient;   . Calls on the Government to help
revive the stalled Contadora peace  process, which seeks a negotiated settlement
between leftist Nicaragua and  its Central American neighbors.

Roger Young, acting director of the institute, told a news conference
he has no easy solutions to the refugee issue and acknowledged it may be
necessary to impose visa requirements on visitors from some countries to
prevent abuses.

Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard has said he may require visas for
Turkish visitors in light of a recent flood of arrivals from that country
- some of whom have apparently been encouraged by brokers and other
middlemen to make spurious claims for refugee status.

Canada has come to be considered an 'easy mark' by some bogus
claimants, and visas or other deterrent measures may be needed in the
short term, Mr. Young said.

In the longer term, however, Canada must remain open to legitimate
refugees and should not take the regressive step of tightening access for
all just because there are abuses by some, he said.

Mr. Young said he hopes that Mr. Mulroney will use a visit to Africa
later this month to reaffirm Canada's battle against apartheid and to
offer financial aid to the black front-line states that could be hurt by
South African retaliation against Western sanctions.

The institute, in its written report, argues against any relaxation of
sanctions but also extends an olive branch to white South Africans by
reminding them that 'their own legitimate place in the country' can be
preserved if they enter serious negotiations to end apartheid.

Turning to free trade, the institute says talks with the United States
'likely will not be as comprehensive nor as easy as once thought,'
partly because of U.S. reluctance to exempt Canada or any other country
from existing U.S. trade laws.

The main value of the talks may turn out to be that they provide a
dress rehearsal for wider discussions within GATT that hold the
possibility of increasing Canadian markets in Asia, the Pacific and Latin
America.

Mr. Young said he was disappointed that a political appointee such as
Mr. Drapeau, rather than a career diplomat, was chosen as ambassador to
UNESCO. The troubled UN agency has been criticized by many Western nations
for extravagant spending and alleged anti-Western bias.

The aging Mr. Drapeau, with his recent history of illness, may 'not be
in a position' to handle the work load and the delicate task of balancing
various national interests, Mr. Young said.

The North-South Institute, established in 1976, describes itself as a
non-profit, non-partisan, independent organization providing research and
information to policy makers and the general public. Bernard Wood, head of
the institute, has served as a personal emissary of Mr. Mulroney in past
talks on South Africa with the heads of other Commonwealth governments.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                          December 31, 1986 Wednesday

Turkish delight?

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 512 words


Immigration Minister Gerald Weiner should therefore impose a visa
 requirement on Turkey immediately, if not sooner. But that will not end
 such abuses. Every time Canada imposes a visa on one country, it finds
 itself targeted by nationals of another. The Turks are only the latest to
 play "refugee roulette."

Last summer, Canada imposed a visa - very belatedly - on Portugal. In
 1985, it took aim at the Dominican Republic; in 1984, at Jamaica, Guyana,
 Peru and Guatemala; in 1983, at Sri Lanka and Bangladesh; in 1981, at
 India; in 1980, at Haiti; in 1979, at Chile; in 1978, at South Africa,
 Cuba, El Salvador, Ecuador, Ghana and Uganda. Some of these inflows were
 substantially composed of authentic refugees; most were not.

Canada now imposes visas on 93 countries. Yet the roulette wheel still
 turns. And with each go-round, a few thousand more phony claimants enter
 the refugee determination process alongside the sincere ones. Between May
 and the end of November, 5,400 claimants - mostly Portuguese, Turks and
 Chileans - moved into the line for an oral hearing before the refugee
 status advisory committee (RSAC).

Thanks to additions of manpower, claims can now clear RSAC in six
 months, but its rulings may be appealed to the Immigration Appeal Board
 and subsequently to the courts. These are vital protections for serious
 claimants, but the Portuguese and the Turks are manifestly unfounded
 claimants. And they will be joined by others unless Ottawa does more than
 serve as the croupier at the roulette wheel.

One possibility would be the imposition of a universal visa (with
 exemptions for the United States and a few West European countries). The
 United States and Australia have adopted such a system, but former
 immigration minister Lloyd Axworthy spurned the idea when it was proposed
 in the Robinson report on illegal immigration.

The idea merits a second look. While it seems a drastic step, it might
 only take us in one fell swoop toward a policy that we are now approaching
 one country at a time. It would cut down on a current practice whereby
 nationals from a country under visa acquire fake passports of visa-free
 countries in order to pass unhindered into Canada.

Another possibility would be to deny manifestly unfounded claimants the
 right to a full refugee determination process. Currently, Ottawa has moved
 to deny access to would-be applicants who have established refugee status
 elsewhere or who do not declare themselves refugees within six months of
 their arrival in Canada. Similar "access controls" could be applied to
 nationals whose homelands, in the designation of the immigration minister,
 do not produce refugees.

The churches oppose such designations as discrimination on the basis of
 nationality. Would they be a denial of equal protection before the law, as
 guaranteed by the Charter of Rights? Or might they be "reasonable limits .
 . . in a free and democratic society"? Mr. Weiner may be right to view
 these specific measures as Draconian and unconstitutional. But he cannot
 simply play the little Dutch boy who sticks his finger in the dike.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           December 13, 1986 Saturday

Canada proves a kind exception for refugees

BYLINE: SHELDON GORDON

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. D3

LENGTH: 621 words


But perhaps even more crucial has been Canada's maintenance of its
 postwar liberalism toward asylum-seekers at a time when the United States
 and Western Europe have retrenched. Despite the backlog of refugee
 claimants and the initial public dismay at the arrival of the Tamil boat-
 people in August, Canadians - led by the churches - have remained
 relatively compassionate.

In 1982 the UNHCR asked its members not to deport asylum-seekers whose
 homelands were convulsed by violence, even if the individuals did not meet
 the narrow criteria of the UN convention on refugees (a "well-founded fear
 of persecution" based on race, religion or nationality). This was a
 recognition that most of the world's 10 million refugees have fled war,
 not persecution.

In response, Ottawa has designated 18 countries to which it will not
 deport individuals. Exiles from these states are allowed to stay on
 minister's permits, perhaps later to be made landed immigrants on
 humanitarian grounds. Numerous Salvadoreans and Sri Lankans have followed
 this Canadian route. In contrast, the United States and Western Europe
 dismiss such exiles as economic migrants.

The overwhelming majority of Salvadorean asylum-seekers who reach the
 United States are deported; at least 52 of them later have been killed in
 their homeland. Opposing this harsh official stance, a network of 50,000
 U.S. church people has provided illegal sanctuary for the Salvadoreans.
 (Seven churchmen have been prosecuted for their efforts.)

In Western Europe, liberal societies such as France, West Germany, the
 Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark have tried to roll up the welcome mat.
 Streams of Iranians, Palestinians, Tamils and other exiles land on their
 doorsteps, only to be spurned as bogus refugees. Often they are shunted
 from one European country to another, winding up in refugee "orbit."

West Germany, overwhelmed with 600,000 asylum-seekers, prods them to
 move on by denying them the right to work during the first two years,
 refusing them language courses and sheltering them in overcrowded
 conditions, which the UNHCR has criticized as a calculated inducement to
 leave.

Even so, refugees who do not make it to the West may be even worse off.
 Many developing countries are not even signatories to the UN convention,
 so Asians, Africans and Latin Americans who seek refuge in neighboring
 states may end up in wretched holding camps where disease and external
 attacks are constant perils.

In Honduras, Nicaraguan refugees have been kidnapped by the contras,
 while Salvadorean refugees continue to be harassed by the Honduran
 military. In Thailand, refugees in the Laotian and Cambodian border areas
 are vulnerable to military onslaughts. In Lebanon, Palestinian refugees
 are exposed to artillery fire from Lebanese Shiites and to air attack by
 Israel. South African forces have raided refugee centres in Zambia,
 Zimbabwe and Botswana.

For refugees who are either in "orbit" or under fire, the UNHCR has
 become a beleaguered support group. It has increased its staff at refugee
 camps to try to improve protection, and it has initiated working groups
 with the West European nations to find a way to share the burden of Tamil
 and Iranian refugees.

But it is hampered by its "poor relative" status in the UN family. Its
 mandate, unlike those of other UN agencies, has to be renewed every five
 years, and the UNHCR lacks an assured level of financing from year to year
 - actual contributions last year fell $50-million short of the amounts
 pledged by its 34 donors. Even Canada, one of the most reliable donors,
 has allowed its funding to decline in real terms.

If the Nansen medalist rests on its laurels, what hope is there for the
 UNHCR to come between homelessness and hopelessness?

Visa rule allows special cases / New Home Office immigration guidelines issued

BYLINE: By DAVID HENCKE

LENGTH: 410 words


MPs are to retain the right to stop immigration officers sending back refugees
and students who arrive in Britain without visas, under guidelines released by
the Home Office yesterday.

But the new rules, announced by Mr Douglas Hurd, the Home Secretary, on Tuesday,
will abolish MPs' rights to stop the removal of newly-arrived visitors to
Britain from 71 countries. Refugees and students will be the main exemptions.


The Home Office said yesterday that MPs would also keep the right to halt the
sending back of visitors from all countries where visas were still not required
while their cases were considered.

This covers South Africa, the Caribbean, Hong Kong, the EEC, the United States,
Australia, New Zealand, Canada and many central and south American countries.

Last night Mr Gerald Kaufman, Labour's shadow home secretary, who strongly
attacked Mr Hurd's statement on Tuesday, said that the new guidelines still
looked a shambles.

He intended to lead a team of Labour MPs to see Mr Hurd next week after
Parliament had debated the changes in the guidelines.

In the Commons, the Junior Foreign Office Minister, Mr Tim Eggar disclosed that
it would cost more than pounds 120,000 a year to post an entry clearance control
officer to India.

In reply to a series of written questions tabled by Mr Greville Janner (Labour,
Leicester West), Mr Eggar said the cost of the new controls would be met from
visa fees.

He told Mr Janner: 'The maximum cost of posting an entry clearance officer to
India is pounds 126,000 per year based on 1986/87 prices. This relates to
Bombay, where costs are higher.

By Seamus Milne

An arson attack on the offices of the Joint Council for the Welfare of
Immigrants was yesterday being investigated by police.

The attack took place at the organisation's offices in Islington, North London,
late on Tuesday night, a police spokesman said. The arsonists broke in and set
light to furniture, but a passerby called the fire brigade and damage was
limited.

Ms Anne Owers, the council's general secretary, said yesterday that the attack
followed abusive phone-calls and letters which appeared to have been triggered
off by publicity surrounding the controversy over visas for African and Asian
visitors.

On Tuesday morning, Ms Owers received an unstamped racist letter at the office
from 'The English Brigade,' which threatened: 'We are keeping an eye on you and
will get you. '

                                The Toronto Star

                     October 3, 1986, Friday, FINAL EDITION

Why Americans should support the U.N.

BYLINE: By Stephen Thiermann

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A21

LENGTH: 730 words


   The relationship of the United States to the United Nations is at a turning
point. The question is whether the U.S. will abide by its treaty commitments and
continue its assessed contribution to that organization, or whether it will
unilaterally reduce that contribution, thereby weakening the U.N. at a time when
the world desperately needs it.

If Congress reduces U.S. funding, the losers will include refugees in the Middle
East, hungry people in Africa and other parts of the world, and the U.S. itself.

Staff workers with independent international development and emergency
assistance organizations know that, in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the
Middle East, the U.N. provides crucial humanitarian services in emergency
situations, aid to refugees, and programs that encourage self-reliance and
support a new status for women.

Private agencies can innovate, take risks and set examples; they cannot,
however, wipe out disease, feed the starving who are caught up in vast droughts,
relocate millions of refugees, or give a fresh start to whole regions in search
of development. They rely, as do their thousands of contributors, on the
multiple capacities of the U.N. and its agencies.

Furthermore, the U.N. provides a stabilizing international presence that allows
private agencies to reach out to victims caught up in political conflicts over
which they have no control. For humanitarian service organizations in the Middle
East, in Southeast Asia and in Central America, the U.N. plays an indispensable
role, enabling them to respond to the needs of those who would otherwise be
outside the reach of their compassion.

Although we frequently hear that the great powers do not need the U.N., in fact
the nuclear powers need the organization more than anyone else does. Unforeseen
events can draw us into a vortex, leaving our governments with few means of
getting out. When worse comes to worst, the U.N. Security Council or the Office
of the Secretary General provides an internationally acceptable setting in which
nations can move away from rigid positions and toward solutions. The Congo
crisis, the Cuban missile crisis, and the 1973 Middle East war are examples.

In another area, the U.N. has been able to play a unique role in focusing world
attention on critical needs of our day. Vitally important international
gatherings that have been held on the environment, on women, and on the debt of
African nations would be unimaginable without the U.N. So would the
internationally supported cleanup of the Mediterranean Sea - one of the few
projects on which Arab nations and Israel are co-operating.

The subject of current congressional debate is $210 million, the American share
of the general U.N. budget. While vital to the successful operation of the U.N.,
this amount is minor in comparison with the total U.S. budget. The Pentagon
spends in three months more than the whole world has spent on the U.N. in the
last 40 years.

Looked at another way, each U.S. citizen pays $1,254 yearly for the defence
department, but less than $1 for the work of the U.N.

The U.S. has achieved pre-eminent military power and a society of abundance. But
is this the only face the people of the U.S. want to put forward to the world?
Or do they wish also to be recognized as an enlightened nation in the service of
human dignity, human progress and international co-operation?

If this seems an irrelevant consideration, remember that by the time the youth
of today reach maturity, the U.S. population will represent just 3 per cent of
the world population. Future generations of Americans will want to be recognized
for carrying their fair share of international responsibility. U.S.
participation now in taking funds away from the U.N. would have the lasting
effect of isolating these future generations from much of the rest of the world.

Certainly the efficiency of the U.N. system can be improved. Yet it would be
tragic if, as a result of congressional concerns for these reforms, the U.S.
were to withdraw support and undermine the ability of the U.N. to fulfil its
essential mission for all of us.

* Stephen Thiermann is the former Quaker representative at the United Nations
and now serves as vice-chairman of the board of directors of the American
Friends Service Committee, an independent international aid organization.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              May 23, 1986 Friday

Xenophobia a threat, UN refugee chief says

BYLINE: VICTOR MALAREK; The Globe and Mail

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 495 words


Rising xenophobia and compassion that is wearing thin in Western Europe
 - feelings that at times seem to be gaining a foothold in Canada and the
 United States - pose serious threats to refugees, a United Nations
 official says.

Jean-Pierre Hocke, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, said
 yesterday that ''negative attitudes in public opinion are being translated
 by political parties and governments into negative policies, and this is
 of grave concern to us."

He said the general public has confused to an alarming degree the
 plight of genuine refugees with that of ''economic migrants."

His mandate is to deal with refugees, but he believes Western
 governments must come to grips with the larger issue of economically
 inspired migration.

''Since the movement of people will most probably last for quite some
 years to come, the sooner political authorities react and start accepting
 it as a problem . . . the sooner there might be different attitudes and
 hence, eventual solutions.

''Trying to be very practical and not philosophical, this is the reason
 I insist on this basic attitude of accepting the fact that the world is
 faced with a real problem, . . . that it has to do with root causes that
 are not of UNHCR responsibility but which have to do with the whole North-
 South issue of economics, trade, the debt, unemployment. . . ."

As long as these problems are not dealt with in concrete terms, Mr.
 Hocke said, ''the consequence will be the erratic movement of large
 numbers of people" looking for better prospects.

Mr. Hocke, who took over as head of the UNHCR in January, is in Ottawa
 for discussions with Government officials on Canada's role in refugee
 issues. Canada, like all Western democracies, has signed the United
 Nations convention and protocol on refugees but Mr. Hocke touched on what
 he believes is a flaw in the definition of a refugee.

The definition describes a refugee as a person fleeing a homeland
 because of political, religious, racial and ideological persecution.

A refugee is not someone fleeing war or internal conflicts, although
 Canada's policy has been not to send people back to countries where such
 conflicts rage.

Mr. Hocke said the Organization of African States expanded its
 definition of a refugee in 1969 to include what he described as ''violence
 criteria."

''No other country has recognized this formally or informally outside
 Africa, yet if you look at the world, the single most important factor for
 people fleeing their countries is violence.

''To forget about this violence factor, even though you could do it
 legally . . . is not right morally. You must recognize the very obvious -
 that hostilities are going on. There is fighting and people are fleeing."

Mr. Hocke said governments must not ignore these issues, because in
 some way - in the form of refugees and economic migrants - it will end up
 on their doorstep.

The answer, he said, lies in large part with Western governments'
 facing the problem and working to find solutions.

                             The Guardian (London)

                                January 10, 1986

Third World Review: Three peaks to climb / Problems facing Jean-Pierre Hocke,
the new Swiss head of UNHCR

BYLINE: By MARTIN BARBER

LENGTH: 889 words


This week the United Nations acquired a new High Commissioner for Refugees.
Jean-Pierre Hocke, the Swiss Director of Operations in the International
Committee of the Red Cross, comes with one important advantage over his
predecessors; he already knows the major refugee situations around the world in
great detail. The ICRC has taken him regularly to Indochina, the Horn of Africa,
Pakistan and Central America. He knows the people in the provinces as well as in
the capital cities.

But Mr Hocke faces an awesome challenge. If his tenure is to be counted a
success he will have to make progress on three fronts. First he must disentangle
UNHCR from the longstanding programmes, where UNHCR's bottomless assistance
funds have provided an excuse for not finding a solution. Ten years after the
change of governments 'boat people' are still leaving Vietnam, 'land people'
still escape from Laos and Cambodia. They have to be maintained in expensive
camps in Hong Kong, Malaysia, Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand. Even the US
government is seriously worried whether the people involved can any longer be
described as 'refugees.' UNHCR plans to spend some dollars 53.5 millions on
helping these people in 1986.


In Pakistan, 2.3 million Afghans will cost UNHCR dollars 51.5 millions next
year. Most of them have been in camps since 1980. Another 1.8 million Afghans in
Iran will cost dollars 11.3 millions, and 7,500 in India will cost dollars 3.5
millions. Nowhere is a political solution which would allow most of these
refugees to go home more urgent.

Mr Hocke's in-depth knowledge will be particularly welcome in countries like
Somalia where there are said to be 700,000 refugees from Ethiopia in camps. Yet
the Ethiopians say 300,000 have gone home. Others say that most of the people in
the camps is Somalia are now actually poor Somalis and that the UNHCR will be
paying dollars 23 million in 1986 for what is largely a relief operation for
Somalia's own drought victims.

So, these three programmes alone will cost dollars 143 million in 1986, 53 per
cent of a total budget of dollars 270 million for UNHCR's work in all countries
of the world.

A second major area for Mr Hocke to tackle, if he is to maintain the credibility
of his new office, is that of double standards. In 1984 the US paid dollars 112
million to UNHCR's budget, EEC countries dollars 99 million and Japan dollars 43
million. These governments are happy for UNHCR to turn a blind eye to the fact
that Afghan refugee camps in Pakistan make convenient bases for the families of
guerrillas fighting the Russian troops in their home country. But any suggestion
that the camps for 20,000 Salvadoreans in Honduras might be fulfilling a similar
function produces urgent pressure for the camps to be moved.

During 1985 UNHCR clearly told several European governments that they must not
force Tamil refugees back to Sri Lanka but made no protest at continuing US
expulsions of Salvadoreans and Haitians. Mr Hocke was the US candidate for his
new job. He will have to show the rest of the world quickly that he is not their
puppet, and he will have to remind Mr Reagan that UNHCR's mandate is worldwide.

European governments, throroughly miffed at the UN Secretary-General for
imposing Mr Hocke on them, will be mollified if the new man can make progress in
what for them is now UNHCR's major task: how to impose some order on the arrival
of refugees from Third World countries seeking asylum in Western Europe.
European governments believe they are being much more generous than their
critics give them credit for.

All this comes at a time when public opinion demands severe restrictions on the
rights even of their own citizens or permanent residents to bring their close
relatives from abroad to live with them. European governments are forced to
accept these new refugees because there is no effective help for them in their
own parts of the world.

Palestinian migrant workers are being laid off in several Middle East countries
as the oil boom winds down. They have no homeland to return to. There are no
programmes anywhere in Africa which cater for city dwellers from Ghana or Zaire
who find themselves out of favour with the present regimes in Accra or Kinshasa.

The UNHCR needs to recognise that European governments are not being
unreasonable in asking for concerted international action to provide help for
these refugees in the regions where they come from. This would allow Europe to
respond with greater humanity to those refugees who do indeed have established
links with European countries: students from Iran whom the Khomeini regime
believes have been polluted by decadent Western society; Tamils whose close
family members are established residents in Europe; Ugandan students at Europe's
universities whose home villages have been destroyed in the civil war.

Mr Hocke inherits an organisation which has no money and where staff morale is
low. Governments and his staff will give him the usual 100 days in which to work
miracles. He cannot possibly achieve anything substantive in that time. But if
he has demonstrated by then a willingness and ability to confront these three
major problems and to tackle them with imagination and enthusiasm, then the
money will flow in and the staff will warm to him.

                               The Times (London)

                            November 4 1985, Monday

Unending flow of boat people prompts protest by Jakarta / Indonesia protests
growing number of Vietnamese refugees

BYLINE: From PAUL ROUTLEDGE

SECTION: Issue 62286.

LENGTH: 533 words

DATELINE: JAKARTA


The largely forgotten boat people of Vietnam are still fleeing the 10-year-old
commun-ist regime at the rate of more than 1,000 a month.

Guided by the currents and an oil-platform flare in the South China Sea, many
are heading for Indonesia, and the influx is straining relations between Jakarta
and Hanoi.


As the monsoons abate, more and more boats are leaving Ho Chi Minh City,
formerly Saigon. Their uncertain and dangerous journey can cost dollars 2,000 (
pounds 1,000) a head.

Indonesia is to protest to Vietnam later this month, that the exodus has been
turned into a commercial migration business, and that Hanoi is not doing enough
to stem the flow.

The United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) which maintained a camp
for more than 9,000 boat people on Galang Island in the Riau archipelago, is
compelled to accept the newcomers even though it has suffered a 25 per cent cut
in budget because of the extra call on its funds for Africa.

The UN agency is also having trouble finding third countries to take the
refugees, particularly the elderly and disabled. About 5 per cent of the camp
inhabitants have been there for more than two years.

There is more than a suspicion on the Indonesian side that some lower-level
officials in Vietnam are collaborating with the traffickers in this human trade.

'These new boat people are not pure refugees', one government source said. 'The
question of repatriation is something we would like to take up with Vietnam.'

UNHCR takes a more generous view of the plight of the boat people, arguing that
life in their native country must be unpleasant, even dangerous.

However, the agency admits that it is getting harder to resettle the refugees in
the West, where most want to go. The United States, Australia and Canada have
taken 75 per cent of the 89,000 refugees processed through the Indonesian centre
since 1979.

Britain has taken only 83. Recent requests for more help was rebuffed on the
ground that resettling the thousands of boat people in Hong Kong is more
important.

The refugees' plight is likely to become more, rather than less, acute. Malaysia
has announced its intention to close the Bidong Island centre. Singapore takes
few, and only on the strictest understanding of resettlement. Indonesia already
takes about a third, and this proportion seems certain to grow while the
military-backed Government becomes more prone to 'compassion fatigue'.

The UNHCR sees the exodus as 'an unabated outflow' and fears that, unless it is
stopped at the root. President Suharto's Administration will start to show
exasperation. 'Compassion is wearing thin. It is now 10 years since the fall of
Saigon.'

While the problem gets bigger, the agency's budget has been substantially cut
because of the enormous cost of looking after famine refugees in Africa.

The boat people are being put on a cheaper diet, with eggs substituting for
fish. Only essential repairs are being carried out in the makeshift town on the
previously uninhabited Galang Island, which served as a processing centre for
the repatriation of Japanese soldiers from South-East Asia at the end of the
Second World War.

                              The Washington Post

                  September 18, 1985, Wednesday, Final Edition

Shultz Warns of Cuts In Refugee Admissions

BYLINE: By I. Rajeswary, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A4

LENGTH: 396 words


Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned Congress yesterday that the United
States would have to drastically reduce refugee admissions for the next fiscal
year if Congress sharply reduces the administration's $338 million budget
request.

Shultz also said he would establish a new panel to review refugee operations in
Southeast Asia. Department officials said they believed it was time for a fresh
look at the issue. Shultz is expected to announce details of the panel soon.

Testifying at the annual refugee consultation meeting before a Senate Judiciary
subcommittee, Shultz said the president proposes a ceiling of 70,000 refugee
admissions to the United States for the coming fiscal year, including a ceiling
of 3,000 for Latin America and the Caribbean "in the hope that Cuba will end its
suspension of the U.S.-Cuban Migration Agreement of last December."

He said there will be a separate ceiling for admissions under the United Nations
High Commission for Refugees Orderly Departure Program from Vietnam (ODP). The
purpose is to reassure ASEAN countries (members of the Association of Southeast
Asian Nations) that an expanding ODP will not mean a decrease in resettlement
from first asylum camps and to send a clear signal to Hanoi that the U.S. is
prepared "to make good on its offer to accept a large number of Amerasians and
reeducation camp prisoners."

Since 1975, the United States has taken 125,000 Cambodian refugees. Shultz said
this year the Vietnamese released almost 4,000 Amerasian children and family
members compared with 2,200 last year. "The Vietnamese failed to reach our goal
of 5,000 for the first year," he said.

Shultz said the United States will be meeting with Vietnamese representatives in
Geneva next month. "We will be seeking agreement by Vietnam to improvements in
the operation of the ODP which will enable more Amerasian children and other
persons of special humanitarian concern to the United States to leave Vietnam,
via this safe and humane route."

Robert Funseth, the department's senior deputy assistant secretary will once
again lead the U.S. delegation this year.

Responding to questions, Shultz said the Reagan administration definitely plans
to go ahead with a ban on the import of South Africa's krugerrand gold coins. He
said the U.S. was in the process of "notification and consultation" prior to the
ban.

                             The Guardian (London)

                                August 23, 1985

Victims of America's persecution complex / The US sanctuary movement for Central
American refugees

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WHITE

LENGTH: 1131 words


Seated in her cluttered office at the Peace Resource Centre on Milpas Street,
Shelly Sherman represents another face of Santa Barbara, quite distinct from the
beautiful California seaside resort which has become the Western retreat of the
President.

Sherman, 33, is an activist in the local Unitarian church and one of those
instrumental in getting the 800-strong congregation to vote itself into becoming
a 'sanctuary congregation' - one of 250 throughout the United States, including
five in this city - which are actively offering food and shelter to illegal
immigrants fleeing from political persecution and civil war in Central America.


Most come from El Salvador and, to a far lesser extent, from Guatemala -
anything between 300,000 and a half million of them, mostly concentrated in the
Southwest and especially in and around Los Angeles 100 miles to the south. Where
they have come from and why they have come is central to the history of the
sanctuary movement which has emerged as a loose coalition of churches, backed by
statements from 2,000 more, out of small beginnings at the Southside
Presbyterian Church in Tucson, Arizona in 1982.

The Reagan administration has refused to grant political asylum to all but a
handful of the refugees on the grounds that, as individuals, they do not have
the 'well-founded fear of persecution' necessary to qualify them under the 1980
Refugee Act United States supports the regimes in El Salvador and Guatemala. To
say that these regimes are not upholding human rights would be to admit that US
policy there is bankrupt.'

Not everyone in the sanctuary movement would go that far (the Unitarians are a
socially radical church), but the movement has gained support across the
political and religious spectrum, conservative Republicans and anti-abortion
campaigners, as well as Catholics, Jews, Episcopalians and left-wing Democrats,
are united in support of the proposition that the US is not playing fair to the
El Salvadorans.

The administration, in the shape of Assistant Secretary of State for Latin
America, Elliott Abrams, insist that most refugees, like the other millions from
Mexico and beyond who have swarmed towards the Rio Grande in recent years, are
economic immigrants looking for a better life. Muddling the issue with the
long-standing debate about how to control the border (the influx figures are
strongly disputed in some quarters), it says that to admit them would be to open
the floodgates. It has expelled 35,000 Salvadorans since 1980.

In response to renewed warnings from the sanctuary movement this week - that the
influx is political and increasing - the State Department said that the UN
Convention accepted that 'general conditions of civil unrest .. are not grounds
for granting asylum. Most Salvadorans in the US who file for asylum, by their
own admission, state that they've come to this country because they want to
work, because of social unrest and poverty. And therefore they have limited
opportunity to do these things in El Salvador.'

Official research - though not the American Civil Liberties Union - claims that
very few deportees have later been killed or kidnapped.

The figures tell a more complex story. The State Department says that 328
Salvadorans were admitted under the policy last year, but it does not say that
13,045 were denied asylum. More significantly, those fleeing from countries with
whom the US has poor relations - Cuba, Nicaragua, the Soviet bloc -did notably
better, 52,000 from Vietnam, 11,000 or 49 per cent of applicants from the Soviet
bloc, 5,200 from the Near East (Iran), even 2,700 from Africa. But only a few
hundred were admitted from the whole of Latin America, 2.5 per cent of
applicants in the case of El Salvador. Now that relations with Peking are good,
92 per cent of Chinese applicants are being rejected too - to the chagrin of
American anti-Communist lobbyists as well as the American Civil Liberties Union,
which complains of double standards.

It was this selective policy which sparked off the sanctuary movement, which
draws its religious inspiration from biblical teaching and its political one
from America's own traditions-the 'freedom road' network run by anti-slavery
activists before the Civil War to help runaway slaves escape from the South to
free states. More recent memories are of helping opponents of the Vietnam war
escape the draft by going to Canada.

Today the target of churches like the Unitarians, Quakers, Presbyterians, B'nai
Brith (the Jewish civil rights group) and others in cities like Santa Barbara is
either Canada - where refugee policy is more relaxed - or providing breathing
space food, shelter and sometimes publicity, for those refugees who feel they
have nothing to lose by going public with their case.

In practice, says Shelly Sherman, whose own job is with a legal firm dealing
with conventional immigration cases, this means housing families or individuals
for two or three weeks in Churches or in private houses. She has heard harrowing
stories of atrocity and murder in El Salvador's civil war.

Sanctuary workers acknowledge that only desperate or particularly vulnerable
refugees go public. Like the ordinary illegal immigrants, whose cheap labour
sustains California's prosperity, most prefer to slip into the anonymous safety
of Hispanic families and friends in Los Angeles county. Their role is largely
symbolic in making a stand and working to shift public opinion.

In 1980, Congress tried to regularise its asylum policy with the Refugee Act.
That allows for temporary refugee status, known as extended voluntary departure,
the more liberal use of which would please many activists. Congress has passed a
non-binding resolution to that effect which the administration has ignored. Next
month a stop-gap measure, the Moakley-Deconcini Bill, which would suspend
Salvadoran deportations for two years, reaches the Senate floor. The State
Department is already lobbying against it.

Such legislation runs into anxiety about the flood of Central Americans simply
seeking work here. Yet again, efforts are being made to curb the flood by
imposing penalties on US employers who hire illegal workers, an approach widely
regarded as ineffectual and arbitrary. At the ACLU, Carol Wolchok thinks control
would be more effectively achieved by removing the incentive to hire: the
enforcement of minimum wages and conditions, 'That would be a better use of the
energy and resources,' she says.

In the present climate it seems unlikely. Santa Barbara may have been founded by
the Spaniards in 1782 and be 25 per cent Spanish-American. But, as elsewhere in
California, its tourist hotels and restaurants thrive by the labour of cheap and
sometimes illegal workers.

                              The Washington Post

                    August 15, 1985, Thursday, Final Edition

Refugee Agency Faces Curb;
D.C. Agency Is Prohibited From Aiding Illegal Immigrants

BYLINE: By Laurel E. Miller, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: District Weekly; DC1

LENGTH: 888 words


The District's Office of Refugee Resettlement spends more than$2 million a year
in federal funds to help about 500 refugees, mostly from Indochina and Ethiopia,
find jobs, housing and health services.

The office is prohibited, however, from helping the thousands of illegal
immigrants who are streaming into the city each year from war-torn countries in
Central America, because the U.S. government does not consider them refugees.

"My office would not exist if it weren't for federal funds," said Wallace W.
Lumpkin, director of the Office of Refugee Resettlement. "I can have all the
sympathy as an individual, but I cannot use my funds here to help undocumented
refugees."

Lumpkin added: "We assist anyone who the federal government designates as a
refugee, or who has refugee status. If they come from El Salvador, chances are
they don't have that [refugee status] at all."

The federal government's definition of a refugee is one who flees his or her
homeland out of fear of persecution because of race, religion, nationality,
membership in a particular social group, or political opinion.

The government has set quotas on the number of refugees who may enter the U.S.
legally each year: about 50,000 from Indochina, 19,000 from Eastern European
countries and 3,500 from Africa, according to Lumpkin.

The number of legal refugees entering the United States has been dropping in
recent years and that decline is reflected in the decreasing number of new
arrivals served by the District's refugee office.

Meanwhile, the number of illegal "refugees" in the city, mostly from El
Salvador, has been increasing and is estimated to range from 50,000 to 80,000
people, according to federal and local agencies.

"Basically, there is nobody serving [the illegal refugees] and they are
frightened to use what services there are," said the Rev. Harold Bradley, head
of Georgetown University's Center for Immigration Policy and Refugee Assistance.

"The refugees that ORR is serving are the refugees that it is to the political
advantage of the United States to serve," he said. "We're taking care of those
refugees for foreign policy reasons, and that's why you have the State
Department involved in resettling those people."

About 95 percent of the legal refugees who come to the District seek assistance
from the refugee office, Lumpkin said. They are brought here from refugee camps
by volunteer agencies under contract with the State Department. Most speak no
English and many are illiterate in their own languages, he said.

These refugees immediately are eligible to receive welfare payments for up to 18
months, plus food stamps, Medicaid and job training.

Many of these refugees are helped by the D.C. Refugee Service Center, a project
of the Associated Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Washington. At the
center, which is fully funded by the city, the refugees receive such help as job
placement and employment counseling, English classes, and family and personal
counseling.

Lumpkin and his two-member staff, who are part of the city's Department of Human
Services, give most of the office's $2 million budget to private agencies such
as the Refugee Service Center, which actually provide the services to the
refugees.

Undocumented aliens are ineligible for any services that receive federal
funding.

The Andromeda Hispano Mental Health Center, for example, receives a $30,000
annual grant from the refugee office to run a counseling program for Cuban
refugees. None of that money goes to serve the Central Americans who make up
about 75 percent of the center's clientele, said Dr. Ricardo Galbis, Andromeda's
executive director.

"They [the illegal immigrants] are paranoid to begin with," said Galbis. "They
feel unsure of themselves. They have no rights: no medical rights, no legal
rights. [But] they work hard, they're very hard-working people.

"There is a need for more focus on the health needs of the Hispanic population.
They're increasing geometrically. Whether they're legal or not, they're living
here."

Kathy Schrader, director of the Refugee Service Center, said, "It's frustrating
for us because we are caught in the middle and sometimes we have a job we can't
fill but there's nothing we can do" because the center cannot offer the job to
an illegal refugee. The center serves about 2,000 legal refugees a year,
Schrader said.

She said that the number of new cases her center handles each year has dropped
to about 360, almost half the number of persons the center helped in 1981, its
first year of operation.

When illegal immigrants visit the center they are referred to one of the several
other private social service agencies that help Hispanics.

"The numbers [of illegals] really are overwhelming the ability of the agencies
to provide," said Grant Prillaman, director of the Woodrow Wilson International
Center, which helps the illegal immigrants get jobs and learn English.

Other private agencies that receive funds from Lumpkin's office include the
Ethiopian Community Center and the Indochinese Community Center.

"We offer a variety of services all geared toward one thing, to make that
refugee self-sufficient as quickly as possible," Lumpkin said. "It's all geared
to moving the refugees toward the way Americans live and mainstreaming them into
society."

                             July 27, 1985 Saturday

Egypt, U.S. remain split   over contest for UN post

BYLINE: JANE FRIEDMAN; OBS

LENGTH: 590 words

DATELINE: Cairo EGYPT


By  JANE FRIEDMAN
                            Observer News Service
    CAIRO  - The contest for the post of UN High Commissioner of Refugees
 has created strained feelings between Egypt and the United States.

Butros Ghali, 62, State Minister for Foreign Affairs, is Egypt's
 nominee. He is a prominent Egyptian intellectual who played an important
 role in the peace process with Israel and he had expected the United
 States to support him. Instead, Washington is backing a Swiss official of
 the International Committee of the Red Cross, Jean-Pierre Hocke.

The new high commissioner will be chosen in December when the three-
 year term expires. Currently the post is held by a former Danish prime
 minister, Poul Hartling.

The U.S. rebuff comes as a blow to the veteran Egyptian diplomat, who
 studied law and politics in France before being drafted by the late
 president Anwar Sadat. He also headed the respected Centre for Political
 and Strategic Studies in Cairo.

Washington's rejection is particularly hard for Mr. Ghali at this point
 in his career. As a Copt, or Egyptian Christian, future mobility at
 Egypt's Foreign Ministry is limited. An elegant man with a global vision,
 he had hoped to further his career by assuming the refugee post. If he
 does not get the job, Mr. Ghali says he will retire from the foreign
 service shortly.

Sitting in his French-style office in the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Ghali
 wondered out loud about U.S. friendship for Egypt and whether Washington
 really trusts the Egyptians.
    'The U.S. says it wants someone under its domination,' he said.
 'They want a technocrat and not a politician, but it's time that somebody
 from this part of the world assumed responsibility for refugees.'
    The commission was formed in 1951 to take care of all refugees in the
 Middle East.

Today, the HCR protects and shelters almost 10 million refugees
 worldwide. The largest group are Afghans living in Pakistan. Others are in
 the Horn of Africa and in southern Africa and there are also large numbers
 in Central America.

The annual budget of the commission is about $400-million. Most is
 contributed by the United States, the European Community and Japan. The
 high commissioner has usually been chosen by consensus and named by the UN
 Secretary- General. Representatives from donor countries and neutral
 European countries have traditionally filled the post.

Mr. Ghali is not taking the U.S. rebuff lightly; 1985 may well be the
 first time the job of high commissioner is openly contested. Others in the
 running are former Dutch foreign minster Max van der Stoel, Sweden's
 Defence Minister Anders Thunborg and Norway's Ambassador to the UN, Tom
 Braalsen.

Mr. Ghali says when Egypt submitted his name in January, 1985, the
 United States indicated it would back the choice. The backing was not
 formal, he said, but came through messages from State Department
 officials. Then, two months ago, the Swiss proposed Mr. Hocke. Mr. Ghali
 implies the United States put the idea to the Swiss. The United States
 denies it.

Despite his distinguished career, Mr. Ghali was never promoted to the  actual
job of foreign minister, apparently because he is a Copt. Now that  Egypt has an
active foreign minister, Esmat Abdel Meguid, Mr. Ghali wields  less influence.
He has assumed responsibility for Egypt's relations with  Africa.     'After
eight years, I have to change,' he said. 'I want the high  commission to be not
just machinery to support the refugees, but to solve  the problem of the
refugees, a solution in depth. And that's a very heavy  job.'

                               December 24, 1984

Reagan flies in suppplies / US Air Force ordered to fly relief supplies to
Ethiopians

BYLINE: From ALEX BRUMMER

LENGTH: 253 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


President Reagan has ordered US Air Force planes to fly relief supplies to
refugees streaming into the Sudan from Ethiopia amid growing concern about the
spread of famine in Africa.

The first US Air Force plane, a C-130 transport, flew from an Agency for
International Development (AID) storage depot in West Germany to the Sudanese
city of Kassala yesterday.


It was carrying a cargo of portable water tanks, large medical tents and more
than 5,000 blankets for the tens of thousands of Ethiopian refugees who have
crossed into the south-eastern Sudan in search of water and food.

The swift White House response to the refugee problem in Sudan followed an
appeal by the United Nations Commissioner for Refugees on Thursday night.
President Reagan was immediately briefed by the director of AID, America's
foreign aid agency, Mr Peter McPherson, and ordered the use or American military
planes for the first time since the Ethiopia crisis emerged.

According to senior American foreign aid officials, President Reagan is taking a
personal interest in relief operations in Africa and has asked the agency to
keep him continuously informed. AID has told the White House that it fears the
Ethiopia famine could spread to as many as six other African countries.

Although AID has spent almost all its dollars 150 million contingency fund for
famine relief in the first two months of the 1985 financial year, it has begun
temporarily to divert funds from other programmes to meet African demands.
