Church council   gives $200,000   to black groups

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 324 words

DATELINE: Geneva SWITZERLAND


GENEVA  (Reuter) - The World Council of Churches said yesterday it had
 granted $200,000 this year to three black guerrilla and political groups
 fighting South African white-minority rule.

The South-West Africa People's Organization, fighting for the
 independence of South African- ruled Namibia, received $100,000 from the
 council's controversial special fund to combat racism.

The fund is financed by contributions from some of the council's 303
 Protestant, Anglican, Orthodox and other non-Catholic member churches, and
 from governments and anti-racist organizations.

The Geneva-based WCC also gave a grant of $70,000 to the African
 National Congress, the main black guerrilla movement fighting white rule
 in South Africa.

The Pan Africanist Congress received $30,000 for information work,
 assistance to refugees and aid to PAC members released from prison or
 facing political trials.

The grant to SWAPO is to finance legal and humanitarian aid and
 publicity, and the grant to the ANC will assist agricultural and
 vocational training projects for refugees in camps in Zambia, the council
 said.

Another $200,000 was shared among 40 anti- racist groups in West
 Europe, the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, the Philippines, New
 Caledonia and Papua New Guinea. Grants ranged from $1,500 to $10,000.

Grants from the fund, instituted in 1969, are intended for
 humanitarian, social, health, educational and cultural purposes.

WCC general secretary Philip Potter acknowledged at a news conference
 that the fund 'has been the cause of an enormous amount of debate and
 controversy all over the world.'
    But he added: 'It has never been proved that those who have received
 these gifts have used them for any purpose other than those for which they
 have been given.'
    The 1984 grants were approved at a session of the WCC's central
 committee in July but no details were not announced until yesterday to
 allow member churches to be informed officially.

                          September 20, 1984 Thursday

Hostility toward refugees   not justified, official says

BYLINE: VICTOR MALAREK; GAM

LENGTH: 450 words

DATELINE: Geneva SWITZERLAND


By  VICTOR MALAREK
                           Globe and Mail Reporter
    GENEVA  - Moves by many industrialized nations to cut refugee quotas
 drastically are threatening international efforts to solve the plight of
 millions of people stuck in refugee camps throughout the world.

The emergence of xenophobic trends is destroying international
 mechanisms set up to handle the refugee question, according to Poul
 Hartling, high commissioner for the United Nations High Commission for
 Refugees.

Mr. Hartling attributes this growing fear of foreigners to "a strong,
 vocal minority who say 'We don't like foreigners. We don't like people of
 another race, color or religion.' " The time has come, he stressed, to
 send up a warning signal before the special position of refugees is
 irreparably undermined.

Refugees are blamed for economic ills plaguing Western Europe, Mr.
 Harling said. They are seen as a major link in high unemployment, as a
 burden on hard-pressed welfare programs and a significant factor in the
 increase of crime.

But the facts paint a different picture. "Very few refugees abuse the
 hospitality of their host country," he said, citing a study by the U.S.
 Church World Service showing that the vast majority of refugees are
 industrious, and when given the opportunity they quickly become productive
 members of society.

Moreover, UNHRC figures show that the fear of a never-ending flow of
 refugees is unfounded, that in 20 European countries the average
 proportion of refugees in the population is .14 per cent.

The ideal solution for the refugee problem is voluntary repatriation,
 Mr. Hartling said. "If you open the heart of the refugee anywhere in the
 world, in 95 per cent of the cases you will find that he would want to go
 back home." But in most circumstances, repatriation is all but impossible.

Another preferred solution is acceptance in a neighboring country,
 where resettlement and integration are usually easier, he said.
 Resettlement in a distant land is the least preferred solution, yet for
 hundreds of thousands of refugees it represents the only chance to break
 out of the camps and get on with life.

Almost 115,000 refugees, three-quarters of them from Southeast Asia,
 were resettled in 1983. Canada, the United States and Australia received
 the largest portion. However, largely because of worldwide economic
 difficulties, resettlement opportunities are becoming harder and harder to
 secure.

Today there are more than 11 million refugees throughout the world, of
 whom 7.8 million live in camps, largely in Africa, South Asia and the
 Middle East. For as many as a million of these resettlement is urgently
 needed, Mr. Hartling said. Another 2.7 million have been settled or
 resettled.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              June 1, 1984 Friday

A world of refugees

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 572 words


The Immigration Department prides itself on having honed refugee policy to
 a fine art. That policy keeps open two avenues for foreign exiles to win
 residency in Canada. The first, asylum, involves exiles who arrive without
 official okay on Canada's shores and claim refugee status under the Geneva
 Convention. If they can convince Canadian authorities of "a well-founded
 fear of persecution" in their homeland, they are landed here.

The second avenue, resettlement, involves an overseas selection process
 in which Canadian immigration officers apply relaxed immigration criteria
 to the flotsam of four continents, enabling exiles to trade in the rations
 of the refugee camp for a fresh start in Canada. It is this avenue which
 provides the great majority of Canadian refugees.

But resettlement needs serious rethinking. Raphael Girard, a senior
 Immigration official, told a recent conference on refugees that Ottawa
 planned to sponsor 10,000 refugees from around the world for resettlement
 in 1983, but was able to find and choose fewer than 9,000. "We had a
 shortfall of 10 per cent last year," he said. "Our immigration program
 didn't take very well."
    That dismal take invites a double take. How, in a world awash wth an
 estimated 10 million refugees, could Canada fail to fill its quota?
 Moreover, the shortfall is not merely 10 per cent, as Mr. Girard
 indicated, but 25 per cent. Ottawa originally set aside, in addition to
 10,000 slots allocated by specific geographic areas, an extra 2,000 slots
 for which funds were to be earmarked as the need arose.

There is no question that the need existed. The quota of 2,000 for
 Latin America was filled by the end of August, yet none of the 2,000
 unallocated slots was funded. Meanwhile, the quotas set for Africa and the
 Middle East were allowed to go begging. Ottawa was able to fill only 651
 of the 1,000 places reserved for Africa and only 294 of the 800 reserved
 for the Middle East.

The difficulty in finding eligible Africans was real enough, because
 the Organization of African Unity opposes resettlement outside the
 continent except in the case of politically sensitive individuals. But why
 was it not possible to identify eligibles for the Middle East quota? Many
 of the Palestinians who live a precarious existence in the camps of
 Lebanon would no doubt prefer a Canadian winter to a Phalangist "open
 season."
    When Immigration discovered, late in 1983, that it would not fill its
 quotas for Africa and the Middle East, it should have reallocated those
 quotas to other areas of high demand. The logical candidate was Central
 America, where Canada boasts of being the only one of the traditional
 resettlement countries (the United States, Australia) which is actually
 resettling exiles. Another worthy candidate was Indochina. The rate at
 which Vietnamese boat people are resettled from the Hong Kong refugee
 camps has fallen behind the rate at which new ones arrive there.

The deplorable result of this Immigration Department inertia was not
 only that Canada last year admitted one-quarter fewer Government-sponsored
 refugees than it planned, but that it accepted 2,000 fewer than it had
 actually landed the year before. Even in a period of high unemployment,
 these "shortfalls" are unjustifiable. Yet Canadian refugee groups have
 been oddly quiescent. Canadians may no longer believe that "none is too
 many," but they are unduly complacent if they assume that 9,000 is enough.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             July 19, 1983 Tuesday

CANADA HAS A CASE   OF 'COMPASSION FATIGUE'   The search   for a formula   to
solve   refugee plight

BYLINE: SHELDON GORDON; GAM

LENGTH: 1220 words


BY  SHELDON GORDON
    Mr. Gordon is an editorial writer for The Globe and Mail.

THE WORLD is awash with refugees. Their number is estimated at 12  million, and
that includes only those who, in fleeing persecution, war or  economic
exploitation, have crossed a national border. Most live in camps,  subsisting on
rations of despair. They are stateless people in a world  where to be stateless
is the ultimate form of powerlessness. They are the  uprooted of four continents
who yearn to make their way eventually to a  fifth: our own.

As Canadian Immigration Minister Lloyd Axworthy recently warned, the
 refugee crisis could erupt beyond the capacity of the existing
 international system and become a major source of global instability. That
 danger looms not only because the numbers of stateless people are huge,
 but because two-thirds of them are concentrated in the Third World. In
 Pakistan alone, there are 3.5 million refugees from Afghanistan. In
 Africa, there are two million refugees.

A heavy influx into a developing country may depress the living
 standards of its already impoverished domestic population. (Pakistan must
 spend $270-million a year to care for its Afghan guests, and their
 presence has inflated commodity and real estate prices, while pushing down
 wages, in the Northwest Frontier Province.) The arrival of refugees may
 upset a delicate balance between rival ethnic groups in the host country.
 And their presence often creates border tensions between their home state
 and the receiving state.

If, as in the case of the Palestinians, decades pass without the
 refugees being voluntarily repatriated to their homeland, integrated into
 the country of first asylum or resettled in third countries, they may
 become embittered, desperate camp-dwellers, many of whom strike back at
 the international community which has ignored them.

In the aftermath of the Second World War, the United Nations set up a
 "safety net" for refugees, including the High Commissioner for Refugees
 (UNHCR) and the UN Convention on refugees. But this regime, created with
 the upheavals of Europe in mind, is inadequate to the current
 circumstances.

One problem is the Refugee Convention, which requires signatory states
 not to deport illegal aliens to their homeland if, in claiming the right
 of asylum, they are able to demonstrate "a well-founded fear of
 persecution" based on ethnic, religious or political reasons. These narrow
 criteria for asylum exclude people fleeing war or economic oppression -
 who account for most of the world's refugees.

In the United States, immigration authorities are denying refugee
 status to thousands of Salvadoreans, who are considered illegal "economic
 migrants". Only a handful have obtained asylum, and a UNHCR study has
 rapped U.S. Immigration for evicting even Salvadoreans who fit the narrow
 Convention definition of a refugee. To make matters worse, the United
 States deports directly to El Salvador, making it the only country in
 North America to return Salvadoreans to their war-torn homeland. (Canada
 has come to the rescue of 175 Salvadoreans the United States has earmarked
 for deportation.)
    Other countries, such as Mexico, Honduras and Thailand, are providing
 sanctuary for tens of thousands of refugees who do not meet the Convention
 definition. But because these countries are not signatories of the
 Convention, they do so only grudgingly. The UNHCR, which co-ordinates the
 provision of food, shelter and medicine in refugee camps, has to operate
 on sufferance there. The Honduran Government pressured the UNHCR staff
 into withholding food and medical supplies from refugees who were
 resisting the state's efforts to relocate them away from the border.

Although the UN is charged with assuring humane treatment for refugees,
 it has, paradoxically, no authority to stop military attacks on refugee
 camps. As a result, Kampucheans in Thai border camps, Salvadoreans in
 Honduras, Guatemalans in Mexico and Palestinians in Lebanon have all been
 targets of attack.

The Canadian Government has been sensitive to these failings in the
 international system. Ottawa co-sponsored a UN study by Prince Sadruddin
 Aga Khan on the role of human rights violations in creating mass exoduses.
 It tried, unsuccessfully, to have the UNHCR's staff increased to afford
 greater protection to refugees, and recently agreed to accept a few
 hundred released Salvadorean prisoners who, in the absence of
 resettlement, would be vulnerable to attack.

But when it comes to accepting larger numbers of the world's homeless,
 Canada, like the other major resettlement countries - the United States
 and Australia - is suffering from what refugee experts call "compassion
 fatigue". Since the Second World War, Canada has resettled 350,000
 refugees, a creditable figure for a nation which had previously insisted
 "none is too many". This year, however, the quota for Government-sponsored
 refugees has been reduced to 12,000 from 14,000 in 1982.

The reduction includes a drop in the intake of Indochinese refugees,
 even though the number of "boat people" in the Thai camps has not
 diminished since 1981; (and even though the Government of Thailand
 threatens to spurn new arrivals unless there is more resettlement of
 existing camp-dwellers). As for Kampuchean refugees, Ottawa opposes even
 the principle of their resettlement, though the UNHCR has concluded that
 voluntary repatriation, the ideal solution, is a forlorn hope because of
 the continuing war.

Domestic unemployment obviously inhibits Ottawa from accepting many
 more refugees. But Canada could use its influence as a major resettlement
 country - and as the UNHCR's fourth-largest donor - to press for
 multilateral initiatives. Among them:
    (1) Establishment of an early warning system to alert the international
 community to potential mass exoduses, so pressure can be brought to bear
 to improve conditions, or at least so plans can be made to handle the
 outflow.
    (2) Convening a world conference (in Canada, perhaps?) on Indochinese
 refugees to impart new momentum to resettlement efforts, especially
 through private sponsorship.
    (3) Provision of development assistance to encourage refugee
 resettlement within the Third World. This would be possible in developing
 countries which do not suffer from severe population pressures and where
 the integration of refugees might provide skills needed by the local
 economy to increase the living standard of the domestic population.

This was the idea behind the Durable Solutions Fund, which was
 proposed, but never implemented, by the UNHCR in 1979-80. The fund would
 have identified, and channelled foreign aid to, developing countries not
 averse to refugees but lacking infrastructure and money to integrate them
 successfully.

Canada did not support the fund proposal, viewing a development
 assistance role as beyond the UNHCR's function. But an institutional
 alternative could be found. If international aid to link resettlement with
 development is desirable, it could be administered through regional
 organizations such as the Organization of American States or the
 Organization of African Unity.

What is vital, however, is a systematic attempt to provide long-term
 solutions - the opportunity for a productive life and not merely the limbo
 of the refugee camp - for the wreck and flotsam of humanity.

                              The Washington Post

                     March 18, 1983, Friday, Final Edition

Balancing the 'Brain Drain'
An Illiterate Ethiopian Gets Ready for St. Louis

BYLINE: By David B. Ottaway, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: First Section; General News; A30

LENGTH: 612 words

DATELINE: GEDAREF, Sudan


Getchew Garad seems an unlikely candidate to become a resident of St. Louis. But
that is where he's headed in several months, although he doesn't know it yet.

Getchew is illiterate even in his own Amharic language. He is a seasonal farm
worker turned nickel-and-dime trader and lives with his wife, Enanu, their baby
and assorted chickens in a traditional Ethiopian tukal, a round thatched hut
with a dirt floor.

America is as far away as the moon from the life he has known eking out a meager
existence in the rugged and often drought-plagued Ethiopian highlands.

But Getchew, 27, has one thing going for him. He is a "political refugee" from
the revolutionary turmoil in Ethiopia, and that has earned him a ticket to the
United States--thanks to a new resettlement program for a few Africans under the
1980 Refugee Act.

Ethiopians reportedly account for two-thirds of all those now being chosen for
the 3,000 to 3,500 annual quota of refugees from Africa. Some come from centers
in Sudan, others from Somalia, Djibouti and Kenya or simply as individual
applicants at U.S. embassies.

This is because the revolution in Ethiopia, which toppled the late emperor Haile
Selassie in 1974, has created close to a million refugees--the largest group
from any African country. Of this number, 440,000 are here in eastern Sudan and
most of the others in Somalia.

So far, about 2,000 Ethiopians have been resettled in U.S. communities and
another 2,000 are waiting to go, according to Kevin Noonan, who heads the Joint
Voluntary Agency in Khartoum, the group in charge of registering candidates to
be interviewed by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service.

The agency, funded by the State Department, works on behalf of 16 U.S. voluntary
organizations involved in helping refugees get settled.

Many of the Ethiopians who are chosen speak English, are well educated and are
highly skilled. But to avoid accusations of bias or contributing to the "brain
drain" of Africa, the immigration service also is taking some Ethiopians like
Getchew, who have no skills and neither read nor write.

Noonan and others here in Gedaref administering a four-month course in basic
English and "cultural orientation" for the Ethiopian immigrants say those with
skills and language expertise make out fine once they arrive in the United
States. But they say no study has been done yet on those who have neither.

Although no one says so for the record, there are serious reservations among
program administrators here about the wisdom of sending illiterate Ethiopian
peasants to fend for themselves in the United States.

Getchew seems to have no reservations, however, even though he still hasn't been
told where he is going in the United States. He hears from two friends who went
last year that life in America is good, "if you work," although one of them, he
says, is still without a job.

"Everything will be okay if I can find a job and learn to speak and write,"
Getchew said through an interpreter.

"I leave Sudan for security," he said. "I don't care about the difficulties so
long as I'm secure."

Getchew has forgotten most of the English he learned a few months ago, but he
remembers he has to add eight days to the Ethiopian calendar to get the right
date in the Gregorian one. His wife is just starting to speak her first words in
English.

When she finishes the orientation course in April, they will be off to the
United States. Upon arrival, they will be aided at first by the American Council
for Nationalities Services in settling in, finding a job and getting into a
school.

Then they will be on their own, like millions of other immigrants before them.

his wife, Enanu Menelik, and their baby boy. By Steve Hindy for The Washington

                            March 12, 1983 Saturday

U.S., Israeli stands denounced   at close of non-aligned summit

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 563 words

DATELINE: New Delhi INDIA


NEW DELHI  (Reuter) - The non-aligned summit on its closing day condemned
 U.S. policy in the Middle East, called for a halt to the nuclear arms race
 and castigated South Africa and Israel in resolutions to be endorsed at a
 final session expected late last night.

But last-minute wrangling between Iran and Iraq delayed a final
 statement on the Persian Gulf war, a major concern at the five-day
 conference of leaders from 101 Asian, African, Latin American and European
 states.

A strong statement on the desperate plight of developing nations was
 also put up for formal approval by the summit, the Third World's chief
 political forum.

In long declarations on world trouble spots, the summit restated its
 full support for a Palestinian state, and condemned Israel for 'continued
 occupation of Palestinian and other Arab territories and for its
 persistent acts of represssion against the Palestinian people.'
    It called for a 'war crimes tribunal' to try Israel under
 international law for crimes against the Palestinian people, including
 last year's massacre of refugees in two Beirut camps.

The summit accused the United States of violating 'the commitments it
 had undertaken to guarantee the safety and security of Palestinian
 refugees,' and condemned U.S. military and political support for Israel.

It also denounced Washington for trying to impose a Middle East policy
 'prejudicial to the liberation of the occupied Arab and Palestinian
 territories, including Jerusalem.'
    Condemning South Africa for 'systematic and barbarous acts of
 oppression and discrimination,' the summit called for a United Nations
 Security Council meeting to consider action to achieve early independence
 for Namibia (South West Africa).

It accused the United States of pursuing the 'extraneous issue' of a
 withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, which Washington and Pretoria have
 made a condition for Namibian independence.

The summit called for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from
 Cambodia, without naming Vietnam, and urged all states in the region to
 settle their differences through talks. Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia to
 install a pro-Hanoi government in Phnom Penh in 1979, has about 180,000
 troops there.

After bitter argument, non-aligned foreign ministers decided last week
 to leave Cambodia's disputed seat in the movement vacant.

The summit declaration also avoided mentioning the Soviet Union in its
 resolution on Afghanistan, which called for a political settlement on the
 basis of withdrawal of all foreign forces and the right of refugees to
 return home safely.

The resolutions also urged Moscow and Washington to keep East-West
 disputes out of Central America, and called on the United States to adopt
 'constructive positions' in favor of peace in Nicaragua and El Salvador.

The summit demanded the immediate prohibition of the use, or threat of
 use, of nuclear weapons by the five nuclear powers - the United States,
 the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China.

It called for a freeze on the development, production, stockpiling and
 deployment of nuclear weapons, and the speedy conclusion of a
 comprehensive treaty banning ests.

Non-aligned leaders also called for immediate efforts to conclude a
 treaty banning chemical weapons, and to pursue conventional disarmament.

They said the vast amount of money being spent on arms militates
 against the introduction of a new economic order.

                              The Washington Post

                     March 15, 1982, Monday, Final Edition

Why Are We Locking Up Haitians?

BYLINE: William Raspberry

SECTION: First Section; Op-Ed; A15

LENGTH: 713 words


"Racism" is a charge that is used so offhandedly that it has lost much of its
impact.

Yet it's hard to think of another way of describing America's treatment of the
Haitian refugees. Judge Robert Carter, of the U.S. District Court in Manhattan,
came close to calling it by the right name when he ruled last Friday in favor of
eight Haitian "boat

people" who had been refused parole by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization
Service's New York office.

"The parole results during (Charles) Sava's tenure since July 1981 as New York
district director (of the immigration service) demonstrate a gross
maldistribution of releases," the judge said.

"Of 86 Haitians whose applications he received, Sava paroled five, all pregnant
women. Of 91 non-Haitian applications, 90 were released." That record, said
Carter, shows "invidious racial- or national-origin-based discrimination."

Jesse Jackson, who in the last two weeks has discussed the problem with the
pope, with the U.S. Catholic Conference and with the State Department, says it
more plainly:

"It's racism. You look at the combination of concentration camps for Haitians
and the overt cozying up to South Africa, and the official pattern becomes
clear."

John McCarthy, executive director of the Catholic Conference's migration and
refugee service, sees the scandalous treatment of the Haitian refugees as "a
terrible disaster, a scar on our nation--the first time this sort of thing has
happened since the start of World War II, when we did it to the Japanese."

What McCarthy and the others are talking about is the incarceration--in jails,
in prisons and in squalid camps-- of some 2,000 Haitian refugees, most of them
claiming to be political refugees, a status which would lead to their asylum
here. The official U.S. line is that they are economic refugees and not entitled
to asylum.

"It's a distinction without a difference, in substance or in history," Jackson
contends. "The Poles are economic refugees. Solidarity is a labor union. Nowhere
have the Poles said that they wish to change their form of government. They
remain communists. Yet we classify them as political refugees and let them in."

McCarthy makes a similar point. "It's very difficult to buy this
economic-political distinction," he said. "These (Haitians) are desperately poor
people with no rights whatever. And there really aren't that many of them. Only
50 came in during January. Perhaps as many as 50,000 Mexicans cross the border
every day. How many of them are in jail?"

The official explanation is that the Mexicans who come here illegally are caught
only after they have gotten in and taken jobs, and that they rarely resist
deportation (though many of them quickly return). The Haitians, on the other
hand, are intercepted at the border, and, instead of returning voluntarily,
claim refugee status.

McCarthy has heard the arguments, and he dismisses them--on economic as well as
racial grounds.

"We believe the idea of keeping these refugees in hard-rock prisons is morally
wrong. These are lovely people, posing no (crime) problem at all. And it costs a
lot of money--maybe $2 million a month--to keep them locked up. That's my money
they're throwing away, and yet the administration keeps saying we have to reduce
federal expenditures."

McCarthy says he has proposed to take custody of the locked-up Haitians and let
the savings go toward developing jobs in Haiti, thereby reducing the incentive
for the life-risking boat rides to America. "We aren't new at this," he said. "
We have handled a million displacees--10,000 Southeast Asians in September
alone. We have offered, in writing, to take these refugees and find them homes
and jobs at no cost to the government. The government says it has a problem, and
we offer a solution. We'll take them off their hands."

It sounds like an offer no penny- pinching government could refuse. But McCarthy
says the only response he has had was from an immigration official who said it
was necessary to continue the present policy "as a deterrent."

"In a different context, you might say Gethsemane was a deterrent," McCarthy
said. "What they are doing is just morally offensive. I can't tell you why they
are doing it. But I don't see any white faces among the detainees."

                            November 3, 1981 Tuesday

Ottawa to cut back   on Asian refugees,   take more Europeans

BYLINE: THOMAS WALKOM; GAM

LENGTH: 503 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ONT


By  THOMAS WALKOM
                           Globe and Mail Reporter
     OTTAWA  - Canada plans to allow 4,000 fewer refugees from Indochina to
 enter the country next year, but it is allocating 1,000 extra spaces to
 Eastern European refugees.

In a report tabled in the Commons yesterday, Immigration Minister Lloyd
 Axworthy said Canada plans to cut back the total number of immigrants
 allowed into the country as Government-sponsored refugees from 16,000 this
 year to 14,000 in 1982.

These figures apply only to refugees who do not qualify either as
 independent or family-sponsored immigrants.

According to an External Affairs Department official, United Nations
 figures show there are approximately 10 million refugees in the world -
 20,000 of them Eastern Europeans (mainly Poles) in Austria, and 500,000
 Indochinese. Canada said it plans to accept 6,000 Government-sponsored
 refugees from Eastern Europe and 4,000 from Indochina next year.

Although the UN figures show that about 5 million displaced people are
 in Africa, Mr. Axworthy's report said that Canada plans to accept only 500
 Government-sponsored refugees from there.

Noting that there are only a "relatively small number of refugees who
 cannot be resettled on that continent," the report said that Canada must
 accept more than the 400 Africans it took this year.

As for war-torn and poverty-stricken Central America, the report said
 that Canada doubled its refugee target in 1981 "in anticipation of a
 resettlement need which has not materialized to date."
    Thus, the report said, there is no need to increase the 1981 figure of
 1,000 allocated to refugees from Latin America and the Caribbean.

UN figures show that there are about 250,000 refugees in Central and
 South America as well as the Caribbean - with about 100,000 of those from
 El Salvador, a country in the midst of a civil war.

Mr. Axworthy's report said that Canada has already accepted 14 refugees
 from El Salvador "who may be in danger and who cannot count on local
 resettlement or eventual repatriation" as part of this country's
 humanitarian efforts.

Canada also plans to accept 400 refugees from the Middle East in 1982,
 compared to none this year. The UN says there are about 1.9 million
 Palestinian refugees alone in the Middle East.

All in all, Canada will accept 30 per cent of Eastern Europe's
 refugees, .8 per cent of those in Indochina, .4 per cent of those in
 Central and South America, .02 per cent of those in the Middle East and
 .01 per cent of those in Africa.

The report noted that Canada has the highest ratio of refugees to the
 population of seven major countries studied, including the United States
 and Australia.

According to the report, Canada expects to take between 130,000 and
 135,000 immigrants next year, between 134,000 and 144,000 in 1983 and
 between 130,000 and 145,000 in 1984. About 122,000 immigrants are expected
 this year.

These figures include between 20,000 and 25,000 skilled workers a year,
 as recommended by Mr. Axworthy's own Task Force on Labor Market
 Development.

Budget request is cut   for expected refugees

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 198 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


WASHINGTON  (Reuter) - The Reagan Administration told Congress yesterday
 that it expected about 20 per cent fewer political refugees this year than
 previously projected and was cutting its budget request for refugee
 resettlement.

Acting State Department Refugee Affairs Co-ordinator James Purcell said
 he anticipated that only 140,000 refugees would seek resettlement, of whom
 100,000 would be from Indochina.

The Administration originally requested $553-million to resettle
 173,000 refugees, including 120,000 from Asia, 42,500 from Communist
 Eastern Europe, 5,500 from the Near East and 5,000 from Africa, Latin
 America and the Caribbean.

Mr. Purcell told the House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee
 the lower numbers would save $40-million out of the $553-million
 previously requested.

This cut was in line with Mr. Reagan's request for additional budget
 trimming but was not prompted by it, he said, and the new projections were
 not a quota.

He said the Administration intended to request authority from Congress
 for the original higher figures to send 'a political signal' of the U.S.
 commitment to receive refugees to countries of first asylum in Asia and to
 the Soviet Union.

                             April 10, 1981 Friday

Ottawa sets $22 million   to aid African refugees

BYLINE: CP

LENGTH: 453 words

DATELINE: Geneva SWITZERLAND


GENEVA  (CP) - Declaring 'the dimension of need is compelling,' Canadian
 External Affairs Minister Mark MacGuigan said yesterday that Ottawa will
 contribute $22.4-million this year in new and previously unannounced aid
 to African refugees.

Addressing an 84-country conference convened by the United Nations to
 solicit pledges to alleviate the plight of Africa's refugee population,
 estimated as high as five million, Mr. MacGuigan said: 'African concerns
 are world concerns and therefore Canadian concerns.'
    Canada's $22.4-million package of additional assistance includes $16-m
 illion in emergency food aid for Somalia, the Sudan, Ethiopia and Uganda,
 countries where refugee problems are most acute, Mr. MacGuigan said.

The balance, $6.4-million, will be granted to programs of 'different
 international agencies, designed to respond to the highest priority
 refugee needs,' he said, noting that the contribution is 'on a one-year
 basis.' Canada expects to continue making 'significant contributions in
 coming years,' he added.

Mr. MacGuigan stressed that 'solutions (to the plight of refugees) can
 only be found in Africa, by Africans.'
    'We are in fact responding to urgent humanitarian needs. It is up to
 the African people to react to the causes.'
    For the United States, UN Ambassador Jeanne Kirkpatrick pledged $285-
 million, West Germany promised $45-million, Britain about $19.6-million,
 Denmark $10-million and the Netherlands $9.5 million.

Other early pledges included Nigeria's $3-million and $1-million from
 Egypt in medical aid. Fifty other possible donors were still to speak.

The conference started nearly two hours late after Arab countries
 objected to the presence of Israeli Ambassador Joel Barromi.

Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, big potential donors, boycoted the opening
 ceremony and along with Syria, Iraq, Algeria, Libya and Bahrein arrived
 about 90 minutes late for the afternoon session.

African delegates rejected an Arab request that Israel should either be
 barred from the conference or not allowed to speak, UN sources said.

The Israeli ambassador said his country, a contributor to UN refugee
 aid funds, would not have withdrawn if requested.

Soviet bloc countries also stayed away, apparently in line with their
 argument that Africa's refugee problems are a by-product of colonialism.

Siaka Stevens, President of Sierra Leone and chairman of the
 Organization of African Unity, urged all countries to forsake 'bickering
 and conflict' and concentrate on answering this 'SOS message' from
 Africa.

Conditions in many camps are so bad, he said, that 'death comes as a
 relief.'
    The worst refugee problems are in Somalia with an estimated 1.5
 million; Sudan, 490,000; Zaire, 400,000 and Cameroun, 266,000.

                              The Washington Post

                     June 14, 1980, Saturday, Final Edition

Refugee 'Protector';
U.N. Official Oversees Growing Tide Of the World's Displaced Citizens

BYLINE: By Christopher Dickey, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: First Section; A14

LENGTH: 1145 words

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua


"This person here," said Poul Hartling, 65, talking about himself with an air of
incredulity, "is the protector of all the refugees in the world."

That is close to 10 million people.  In one way or another Hartling, a former
prime minister of Denmark and since 1977 the United Nations high commissioner
for refugees, must find ways of coping with all of them.

They are the boat people of Southeast Asia, the persecuted tribesmen of Africa,
Afghans fleeing the Soviet war machine, and soon, as the governments that
invited Hartling here to Central America fear, they may include thousands of
Salvadorans and Guatemalans displaced by the growing turmoil in their homelands.

They are not Cubans, however, at least not as far as Hartling is concerned.

He is not convinced that the majority of Cubans now flooding the United States
were fleeing political persecution so much as seeking to join relatives or find
economic opportunities.  "We have to differentiate between refugees and
immigrants," said Hartling.  "I never said the Cubans were refugees.  My feeling
is that case by case you can find refugees among them.  But taken as a whole you
cannot say they are refugees."

It is obviously a sensitive point with him.  He reiterates, "We are not saying
that any Cuban coming out of Cuba is a refugee.  No never.  Not.  Not."

As a result, though the United States is one of the principal financial
contributors to the high commissioner's office, it is getting only limited help
from Hartling's staff in this currrent crisis.  Primarily they are concerning
themselves with the resettlement of those few Cubans who do not want to remain
in the United States or those President Carter has said cannot.

"We are not looking into 100,000 cases but only into a few hundred," Hartling
said.

For all of Washington's anxieties, the high commissioner suggested, the United
States is capable of coping with the Cuban influx on its own.  Hartling's
resources are put to work in areas that have no means of helping the uprooted
masses who flow across their frontiers.

Hartling talks about the suffering millions in Africa who make up almost half of
the world's refugee population but are largely ignored outside their own
continent.  "They die in the jungle," he said.  "They say to me 'Can't we find a
border to cross?  We want to be boat people.'"

Hartling believes as most people who deal with refugees do, that the preferred
solution to their plight is repatriation.  The second alternative is temporary
resettlement in nearby havens, usually referred to as countries of first asylum.

The least-favored solution is permanent resettlement, but it is for many the
only solution.  And for many of these this means they will find new homes in the
United States, which accepts more refugees for permanent resettlement than any
other country in the world.  Currently, for instance, 14,000 of about 25,000
Indochinese being resettled each month are destined for the United States,
according to Hartling.

The high commissioner does not like to speculate about the future.  "We do not
go around the world looking for problems," he said.  But as he visits Venezuela,
Costa Rica, Honduras, Nicaragua and Mexico he is meeting with government
officials who are extremely concerned about the potential for a new explosion of
refugees in this area within a few years and quite possible within a few months.

Central America is just beginning to recover, a year later, from the massive
flow of refugees out of Nicaragua.  At the height of the fighting last June and
July 100,000 Nicaraguans fled to neighboring Costa Rica and Honduras while
another 800,000 people were displaced within its borders.  Altogether they made
up close to half the population.

The high commissioner's office has plowed almost $5.5 million into their
repatriation, including health and agricultural programs "so they will have
something to return to," as Hartling put it.

The high commissioner also took on the responsibility for several hundred
families of former Nicaraguan National Guardsmen who sought asylum in Honduras
after their defeat at the hands of the Sandinistas.  Partly to avoid political
problems with Nicaragua, these people were never officially declared refugees
and are now, with some difficulty, being absorbed into Honduran society.

But even as the Nicaraguan crisis is drawing to a close, refugees are beginning
to flow out of El Salvador in ever greater numbers.  Officially they only number
in the hundreds at the moment, but, as the terrorism of left-wing guerrillas,
right-wing extremists and an increasingly active Army increases, some of
Salvador's neighbors fear as many as half a million people may try to excape
that tiny, densely populated country.

Guatemala meanwhile is also the scene of rising violence.  If anything
resembling full-scale war breaks out there, floods of refugees, many of them
uneducated and largely unskilled Indian farmers, could be expected to cross the
border into Mexico.

Many Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees could also be expected to come to
Nicaragua, which is struggling just to keep its own people fed, or to Costa
Rica, which is already, in Hartling's words, "A Noah's ark or a Babylon, if you
like," of refugees.

The potential for crisis is enormous, not only for this area but for the United
States.  Washington must cope not only with the officially acknowledged refugees
for whom Hartling is responsible, but with thousands of people who, under
slightly different circumstances would be eligible for asylum in the world's
eyes but are now considered and treated as illegal aliens.

According to U.S. immigration officials in Mexico City substantial numbers of
Salvadorans are apparently slipping into the United States.  Some of them are
technocrats and low level Salvadoran government employees who pay as much as
$500 to smugglers to fly them to the Mexican-U.S. border and slip them across.
Poorer Salvadorans are making their way on buses with the same goal.

They seek the physical security and the economic promise of the United States,
hoping it will be their country of first and last asylum, at least until peace
is restored in their homeland.

Congressman Bill Alexander (D-Ark.), whose constituents are concerned about the
Cuban refugee camp at Fort Chafee and who visited Nicaragua earlier this week as
part of a special presidential mission, is attempting to organize a hemispheric
conference to cope with refugee problems.  Alexander found that the Nicaraguans
were willing to help and tentative plans were laid to hold such a meeting within
the year.

Yet, as Hartling makes clear, the basic problem will never be solved until most
of the refugees can go back to their homelands.  In this and in many other parts
of the world, that time seems increasingly remote.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             May 17, 1980 Saturday

THE REFUGEE EXPLOSION   Not since the Second World War   have there been so many
families   fleeing oppression and war

BYLINE: David Lancashire; GAM

LENGTH: 1079 words

DATELINE: Toronto ON


BY DAVID LANCASHIRE
 IN SOMALIA, a cattle herder squats in the dust of a refugee camp and tells
 in his wife and children, slaughtered before his eyes by Ethiopian soldiers
 . In Lebanon, a woman with a baby in each arm flees from the gunfire in her
 frontier village and trudges to her new home - a tent in Beirut's football
 stadium.

In Florida, a sea-lift brings 45,000 Cubans to asylum in the United
 States in three weeks, and President Jimmy Carter declares a state of
 emergency as thousands more scramble to leave Cuba. In Hong Kong, a leaky
 boat unloads the latest cargo of haggard fugitives from Vietnam.

The woman, the cattle herder, the Cubans and the boat people - all are
 part of a refugee explosion bursting around the world.

The present tide of refugees, swollen by the brushfire wars of Africa
 and the upheaval of Indochina, is the most widespread since the Second
 World War.

The victims are too numerous to count accurately, but the United
 Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva figures the global
 refugee population now surpasses eight million. Another 2.6 million are
 catalogued as displaced persons.

Many more are unregistered, or fail to fall within the UN's strict
 definition of refugees. International Red Cross figures indicate the
 number of uprooted people might approach twice the UN estimate.
    "The seventies were the decade of the refugee, and the eighties don't
 look any better," says Guy Ouellet of the UN High Commission for Refugees
 in Ottawa. "Our worldwide budget in 1970 to look after refugees was $8.3-
 million. This year it is $500-million."
    News events of the past few weeks and months are pushing the total of
 homeless higher.

The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan has driven 710,000 Afghan refugees,
 at the latest count, into neighboring Pakistan, says Guy Ouellet. About
 103,000 Africans have fled from a civil war in Chad, one of the world's
 poorest countries. Four thousand or more Caribbean boat people have sailed
 since January from Haiti to the United States, where they are detained as
 illegal immigrants, not refugees. And the Hanoi Government appears to have
 reopened the exit gates of Vietnam for escapers - the 2,690 Vietnamese
 boat people who reached safe haven in January grew to 5,342 in March.

Refugees from Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos have replaced British
 immigrants as the single largest group of people entering Canada. Last
 year, compared to about 12,800 Britons, 24,573 Indochinese came to Canada
 under an emergency program that will bring in a total of 60,000 by end of
 1980.

Despite recent protests that Canada accepts only the best qualified
 refugees and turns away less suitable applicants, Ottawa immigration
 officials say Canada is proportionately the world's most welcoming country
 for refugees.

Canada defines refugees by the United Nations ruling: "A person who,
 owing to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race,
 religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or
 political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality" and is
 unable or unwilling to return. Between 1947 and May 1 of this year, Canada
 accepted 334,851 refugees.

They include 186,150 Europeans displaced by the Second World War,
 37,149 Hungarians following the 1956 uprising in Hungary, 228 Tibetans who
 followed the Dalai Lama into exile in 1959, 11,943 Czechoslovaks from the
 Soviet occupation of 1968, 7,069 Ugandan Asians expelled by Idi Amin,
 7,016 political refugees from Chile, Argentina and Uruguay, 11,321
 fugitives from Lebanon's civil war, 98 Kurds from a mountain war  in Iraq,
 and since 1975, 45,424 Indochinese.

The average refugee costs the Government $1,500 in settling-in
 expenses, and is usually self-reliant within six months, immigration
 officers say. Refugees are also obliged to repay the cost of bringing them
 to Canada, the officers say, and 95 per cent of them do so.

Despite the efforts of Canada, the United States and other major
 countries of refuge such as Britain, France and Australia (prosperous
 Japan is an exception to this category; the UN says Japan has accepted
 only 325 Indochinese) no solution to the world refugee problem is in
 sight.

After four wars in the Middle East, 1.8 million Palestinians are still
 registered as refugees (with 650,000 of them in camps). Western countries
 have resettled more than 375,000 Indochinese, but another million, mostly
 Cambodians, still huddle in camps in Southeast Asia. Nearly 210,000
 Africans displaced by the war in Rhodesia-Zimbabwe are now returning home,
 but officials say the world's gravest refugee problem remains in Africa.

This is in Somalia, where more than 634,000 people have been driven
 from their homeland in Ethiopia's Ogaden desert. "It has not received much
 world attention, but the problems there are worse than Indochina," says UN
 official Ouellet. Refugees are scattered throughout Africa from Angola to
 Zambia; the Sudan alone is burdened with about 450,000 from Ethiopia,
 Chad, Zaire and Uganda.

Other problems of displaced peoples linger for years, sometimes
 generations, wreaking bloodshed and hardship long after the world has
 forgotten the causes.

Armenians have been seeking a homeland since almost one million of them
 died when they were driven from Turkey in 1915. Armenian vengeance squads
 claim to have committed recently 99 bombings, killings and assassination
 attempts in Europe and the Middle East. In Holland, 40,000 Moluccans who
 lost their territory to Indonesia more than 30 years ago still dream of
 independence. Moluccan gunmen take their revenge on the Dutch.
 Palestinians terrorists have become a world menace.

About 60,000 Chileans have been living in exile since the overthrow of
 President Salvador Allende in 1973. Canadian doctors have examined about
 150 torture victims among South American refugees. In Cyprus, 200,000
 Greek Cypriots have been waiting to return to their homes since the
 Turkish invasion of 1974. Kurdish tribes scattered by Iraqi army in 1975
 are now vying for autonomy in Iran. Israel, whose population is built on
 refugees, last year made room for more than 10,000 Jews who left Iran to
 escape persecution by the Ayatollah Khomaini's followers. Illegal
 immigrants from China pour into Hong Kong at the rate of 1,000 per day.

This month in the Netherlands and West Germany, international
 conferences are discussing ways to co-ordinate the resettling of refugees
 and to ease the financial load of the poorer host countries. But the
 conferences will not halt the exodus.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            March 19, 1980 Wednesday

Western giveaways   creating problems,   Thai unionist says

BYLINE: CP

LENGTH: 557 words

DATELINE: Quebec PQ


QUEBEC (CP) - Canada and other Western countries are fuelling inflation,
 encouraging development of a black market and creating social unrest in
 Thailand by giving food and medical aid to refugees in that country, a
 Thai trade unionist said yesterday.

Snan Vongsuthee, head of the National Congress of Thai Labor, said
 farmers who live along the Thailand-Cambodia border near refugee camps
 feel they are being discriminated against.
    'They see the Red Cross, the United Nations and other international
 agencies giving aid to the refugees when they (farmers) have to work hard
 for a living,' he told a conference on trade unions and human rights.

The attitude of many Thai people toward the refugees was: 'They just
 sit down all day, eat and sleep and they receive assistance. What about
 us?'
    Mr. Vongsuthee said his union was trying to dispel this attitude by
 publicizing the fact that the United States, Canada and most Western
 countries increased aid to Thailand at the same time they began helping
 the approximately 500,000 refugees who poured into that country because
 of fighting in Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.

Problems are unavoidable

The problems caused by establishing refugee camps are unfortunate, but
 probably unavoidable and insoluble, he said later in an interview at the
 week-long conference sponsored by the World Confederation of Labor.

Building the camps caused the price of grass thatching for house roofs
 to triple, he said. In some cases, the camps buy up all the vegetables
 and cooking oil on local markets, depriving Thai residents of adequate
 food.

Young people, their expectations raised by close contacts with
 'rich' Westerners, have found refugees to be eager clients for their
 black-market goods.
    'These young people come back at night from the refugee camps with a
 lot of money and spend their evenings in coffee shops, drinking or
 wandering the streets,' he said.

An African speaker told the delegates, representing 59 countries and
 66 trade union organizations, that no one should envy refugees.

Almost half the refugees in the world live in Africa, said Femmi
 Peters, representing the Gambia Trade Union Congress.
    'To be a refugee is the worst of all fates,' he said. 'To wonder
 day by day what will happen to you, to wonder what will happen to your
 children, to be totally dependent on the good will and charity of others
 is the most degrading of all."

Different view of rights

Speakers from Third World countries emphasized they do not view human
 rights the same way people in Western industrialized democracies do.
 Westerners think of political rights, while people in the Third World are
 struggling to get enough food, clean water, adequate housing and some
 education.
    'Workers in Asia are talking about the basic needs,' Mr. Vongsuthee
 said. 'When we have food, medicine, housing, education, then political
 rights will come.'
    Dominique Agoumba, of the Federation of African Agricultural Workers,
 said people in the Third World should demand another right: To choose the
 type of economic development in their country.

He said both capitalist and socialist countries force African
 countries to conform to their economic systems in order to get aid.

He urged the rest of the world to have faith in Africans' integrity,
 sense of responsibility and ability to choose their own form of economic
 development.

                              The Washington Post

                     August 10, 1979, Friday, Final Edition


Blue Jeans and Boat People, VOA and the Golden Door

BYLINE: By Henry Mitchell

SECTION: Style; Any Day; D1

LENGTH: 1822 words


The Voice of America is not especially grim but then it's not a playpen, either,
and people there take responsibility seriously, their heads full of the 100
million people who listen (in the course of a week) to their broadcasts in
Europe, Asia, Africa, South America and other outlandish places.

It unnerved them a little, at first, to discover the current director, R. Peter
Straus, "wandering about the halls at 2 in the morning in blue jeans and
sneakers" as one highly placed VOA source put it.

Straus really is a New Yorker but got a house in Southwest Washington, five
blocks from the office.

He didn't have a car, but a motorcycle, when he arrived two years ago.  As a
notable muckety-muck, he had a grand reserved parking place and naturally
stabled the old Honda in it.

"Mr. Straus," said a security official late one night, "I am sure you do not
have a motorcycle but there's one in your parking place and -"

"I have a motorcycle," Straus said.

"Oh, God, I was afraid of that.  Well, it's down there with a ticket on it."

Straus' wife commutes from New York on weekends only, and that is the reason he
can be found all kinds of hours in the office, and that is why he is so trim:

"I'm a physical exercise nut," he said, "but not handball, no.  Tennis, jogging,
and I have a not of time for it with my wife (Ellen Louise Sulzberger, married
in 1950) out of town so much."

I mentioned that lately we keep seeing hints in the columns of pundits that the
Voice of America keeps raising the hopes of refugees in Indochina, and asked
what the hell is going on?

"Nine times out of 10," he said, settling back with the air of a man who knows
it's going to take a few minutes, "the job here is challenging and joyful.
Eight times out of 10 it's enjoyable."

I said nothing of the reduced percentage, not being one to nit-pick, and he went
on:

"But sometimes the Voice of America is in the middle and it's not enjoyable.
Take just two examples, the Russian dissidents and the Indochina refugees,
including the boat people.

"We have the obligation to broadcast the news and broadcast it straight.  We do
this 853 hours a week and we are proud of our credibility around the world.

"But when we broadcast news items about, say, Solzhenitsyn's Harvard speech,
which was by no means flattering to the United States, we know it may have
effects.  The Soviet dissidents keep saying it is urgently important to keep
hammering at the plight of dissidents.  But what about some guy in Kiev, say,
who is not a celebrity, not a man of worldwide reputation, who is only a
moderate nuisance to his government.

"I keep thinking, maybe he would be let alone as long as nothing much was said
about dissidents, but maybe his government would crack down on him, hard, if
dissidents are discussed too much in world news.

"Or take the boat people fleeing from Vietnam.  Again, we broadcast the news,
straight.  You've been through the file and read what we've said.  But when we
report that Malaysia and Indonesia are closing their borders to refugees, and
that Hong Kong and Thailand are taking pressure from thousands of refugees, of
course a man thinking of becoming a refugee will figure it out that it's better
for him to go to Thailand than to Indonesia, and in that sense it could be said
the Voice of America directs him where to go."

Or if the Voice carries a pledge from the White House that the refugee problem
has top priority with Carter, and another news dispatch mentions the location of
the Seventh Fleet, it doesn't take much analysis for the potential refugee to
head for the fleet instead of some other direction.

Straus says the wording of refugee news is often agonized over, to make certain
it does not give any refugee the impression he will be safe if he just heads for
an American ship.

There have been two commentaries (editorials) on the refugee problem, prepared
on May 25 and June 15, both of them criticizing Hanoi for expelling the ethnic
Chinese and urging a more humane handling of the exodus.

But it's true that in villages in Vietnam or Cambodia, isolated peasants may
indeed first learn from news items via the Voice that thousands are finding
temporary refuge in Thailand, and are learning their plight is of major concern
to the American government, and this may in fact embolden some to try leaving
who would otherwise have thought their case was hopeless.

It is not the same thing, however, as if the Voice had tried to further American
distaste for Hanoi at the cost of inciting hundreds of thousands to flee, many
of them to their deaths.

It has had little attention, but one of the great developments at the Voice of
America is the clear separation of news from propaganda.

"Our credibility is rising," said Straus, "and we'd like to think it's because
we are fine fellows doing a fine job, but I don't think that has anything to do
with it.

"The way the people who hear the Voice of America perceive the United States has
changed.  They now see the United States as the great power, where formerly they
saw Great Britain.  They are more likely now to take the Voice of America to
heart than the BBC (British Broadcasting Corporation).

"But before I came to this job, the Voice had handled the Watergate scandal with
such objectivity that I think it impressed the world audience.  They thought if
the Voice could report that news, so damaging and embarrassing to the American
government, then probably it could be trusted to report other news without bias
too.

"The traditional way to handle policy interests (propaganda) in all
international broadcasting companies, has been to do it through the news that's
reported.  And the news that's not reported.  But -"

"Just here," I broke in, "take the case of Andy Young sounding off about
American jails being full of political prisoners.  That was certainly news.  I
suppose Voice of America reported it at the time?"

"In 38 languages," said Straus.

"What seemed to make more sense than leaving out damaging news or trying to make
policy (propaganda) points by means of the news, was to have straight news on
the one hand, and policy commentaries on the other," he said.

"I thought, why shouldn't the U.S. government have an occasional say-so, to
argue its own policies before the radio world?  Wouldn't it be better to say to
the world audience, look, here's the straight news.  And now, please listen for
two minutes to a commentary that reflects official American policy."

After all, Straus said, "none of that audience is so unsophisticated as to think
the American government is in broadcasting just for their health.

"But that audience has to have faith, and we have to earn it, that the American
government official viewpoint is contained in the clearly labeled commentaries,
not in slanted or managed news.  In the long run, your best chance is simply to
be honest with the news and then hope they'll listen to the commentaries on
their merits."

There are only about three commentaries a week.  Usually they are broadcast
throughout the world, not tailored for specific countries.  In Africa, he said,
the commentary about the Tokyo Round might not be broadcast on grounds it did
not interest its audience, not on grounds it would be politically or
propagandistically imprudent to air it.

Straus, the day I visited him, wore a shirt of murrey color with a dark tie and
a neat standard-looking suit of blue cord from Arthur A. Adler.  End fashion
flash.

When he is not jogging or roaming the midnight newsroom he gardens with 18 kinds
of geranium and many ivies.

"It's just the size of an overgrown handkerchief," he said.  He does not have a
lot of dogs or cats or parakeets and a lot of the time he's simply waiting for
his wife.  They have four children and both parents, he said, were keen for them
to partake of the real world:

"The real world.  But instead, all four of them are in media jobs."

You never know, as a parent, where you went wrong, and life is too short to
worry about it now.

I asked him what books formed his mind, hoping for Lewis Carroll, Machiavelli,
Castiglione and Gaskell, but refusing to prime the pump with any suggestions:

"Interesting question," he said.  "Which books.  I don't know that I can say."
(Pause.  And I knew he intended to go to his grave before he told me.  People
are often embarrassed to confess which books they found glorious.  Who wants to
admit to "The Anatomy of Melancholy" or "Fairy Tales from Old Japan"?)

"I'll tell you an interesting sidebar about one book," he said.  "My father was
best friends and college roommate (Heidelberg) with Otto Frank, father of Anne
Frank.  He visited us at our house with the manuscript diary.  My father and I
admired it, but thought we were going to have trouble getting it published."

"Probably," I said agreeably.  "The book was marvelous, so naturally you would
have trouble finding a publisher.  How long did it take?"

"About a year and a half," he said.  Finally we found a publisher in Germany.
And once people read it, it was soon all over the world."

Voice correspondents in various countries used to be able to buy their scotch at
embassy commissaries (to put first things first) and had access to classified
papers, and to convenient comfy offices in embassies and to Telex machines and
so on.

Straus thought that if news was to be independent of government tampering then
his correspondents should rent their own offices and find their own means of
transmitting copy, and travel on regular, not diplomatic, passports, and buy
their own scotch at stores, and needless to say the correspondents thought the
end had come to civilization as they knew it.

But once they were weaned, they liked it.  So did ambassadors, who no longer
felt responsible for what correspondents reported (and were no longer chewed out
for what correspondents did).

Straus did not smoke.  He is a very strong man, however, and does not faint if
others do.

He spoke for a bit on the wide range of men, the richness of variety.  If he
were not an American official, he probably would have said a thousand flowers
should bloom.

He seemed to be a happy man.  Of course he does not have three dogs to be walked
and his children are grown, and he can come to the office in blue jeans if he
wants to.Even so, happiness is a gift.

He has family photographs all over the place.  His geraniums are doing fine, and
the Carter administration has gone right along with his ideas for the Voice.
The boat people are in the water - no American can escape the burden of that
fact.  The wretched refuse of a teeming shore, as a wit once put it.  Still, to
be an American, working for the Voice.  It's rather a big deal.  You sense all
this from Straus.

The lady with the lamp in the harbor.  (He's a New Yorker).  And it's still, by
God, a golden door.

                              The Washington Post

                    March 15, 1979, Thursday, Final Edition

Administration Officials Urge Law Change To Widen Diversity of Refugees Admitted

BYLINE:  By Warren Brown, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION:  First Section; A21

LENGTH: 518 words


A revision of U.S. refugee laws would widen the diversity of the refugee
population admitted to this country without necessarily increasing the number of
refugees, Carter administration officials said yesterday.

"Until now our refugee laws have hampered our ability to accommodate the demands
for resettlement in the United States in anything but amakeshift way," said Dick
Clark, a former U.S. senator who ahs been nominated by President Carter to
become U.S. coordinator of refugee affairs.

Clark said the geographic and ideological criteria of current refugee laws are
inherently discriminatory because "they exclude many refugees, particularly from
the Western Hemisphere (Latin America) and Africa."

For example, he said only people fleeing communist governments or countries in
the Middle East are classified as refugees under existing U.S. laws.  The
statutes ignore the plight of persons escaping persecution under right wing
governments, or of those fleeing racism or civil war in Africa, he said.

"As a result, over the past 23 years we have repeatedly had to deny needy
refugees," said Clark, one of four administration officials testifying before
the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday on behalf of legislation designed to
overhaul current U.S. refugee laws.

The legislation, which is expected to increase controversy over an already
emotional issue, was fashioned by the administration in conjunction with Sen.
Edward M. Kennedy (D-Mass.) and Rep. Peter W. Rodino Jr. (D-N. J.), chairmen of
the Senate and House Judiciary committees, and Rep. Elizabeth Holtzman (D-M.
Y.), chairwoman of the House subcommittee on immigration, refugees and
international law.

Kennedy, Rodino and Holtzman jointly introduced the bill Tuesday.

Expand the definition of "refugee" to include any person coutside of his or her
country who is unwilling or unable to return to that country because of
persecution or a wellfounded fear of persecution because of race, religion,
nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion."

Establish new rules and procedures designed to admit refugees to the United
States on a more equitable and orderly basis.

Raise the ceiling for the "normal flow" of refugees to the United States from
17,400 to 50,000 annually.

Limit the U.S. attorney general's parole authority -- frequently used to admit
large groups of refugees outside the courrent statutory ceiling -- to its
intended use, the admission of individual refugees on an emergency basis.

The Judiciary Committee hearing-yesterday indicated that much of the opposition
to the legislation probably will be generated by the proposals to expand the
definition of "refugee" and to raise the "normal flow" ceiling.

But Clark said in response to panel questions that the legislation "clearly does
not" encourage a massive increase in refugees to the United States.  In fact, he
said, there may be no increase at all.

"The president may also determine to admit fewer than 50,000 refugees in a given
fiscal year -- letting the unused numbers lapse," Clarke said.

                              The Washington Post

                     March 8, 1979, Thursday, Final Edition

Carter Seeking Major Revision Of Refugee Laws;
Carter Seeking Major Revision of Refugee Laws

BYLINE:  By Christopher Dickey, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION:  First Section; A1

LENGTH: 769 words


The Carter administration expects to submit to Congress today the first
comprehensive overhaul of U.S. refugee laws since 1952, according to State and
Justice department officials.

The bill, written during five months of close consultation between the
administration and the Senate Judiciary Committee staff, comes at a time when
the number of refugees in Southeast Asia, Eastern Europe, Africa and Latin
America has reached crisis proportions.  There are now more people seeking
permanent resettlement outside their homelands than at any time since the end of
World War II.

The new legislation provides for a normal annual flow of at least 50,000
refugees a year into the United States, but the president, after consultation
with Congress, could raise that figure before the beginning of any given year.

If an emergency situation arises, such as the surge of hundreds of thousands of
refugees who have fled Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia in recent months, the
president would also have the power to admit as many of them as he deemed of
special concern to the United States.  The legislation does not set a ceiling on
the number who can be brought into the country under such circumstances.

Since World War II an average of about 40,000 refugees a year have been allowed
into the United States, including the massive influxes after the Cuban
revolution and the fall of Saigon.

The new legislation calls for considerable federal assistance in the relocation
and resettlement of the refugees, including extensive educational programs.
Most refugees would be eligible for federally subsidized welfare assistance for
up to two yeas after their arrival, though past experience suggests that the
vast majority are financially independent of government aid after a few months.

An administration study that accompanied a recent draft of the bill estimates
the total cost to the taxpayer for refugee relocation and resettlement at just
over $1 billion dollars over the next five years if the flow is kept to 50,000.

If the influx is 100,000 a year, however, the five-year cost would be about $1.7
billion.

The analysis suggests that "most of the same costs would be incurred in any
event if a comparable number of refugee admissions were made available under
existing law."

At present the only people who may be admitted under normal procedures are those
fleeing communist regimes or the Middle East.  As a result it has been extremely
difficult for refugees from right-wing oppression to obtain asylum in the United
States.

A proposed new definition of "refugee" would apply worldwide to anyone who is
outside his or her country and unable or unwilling to return because of
persecution, or a well-founded fear of it, stemming from race, religion,
nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion.

Because of the limited definition in the past, and the fact that only 17,400
refugees a year were allowed into the United States even if they met it, most
refugees have had to come into the United States under the emergency "parole
authority" of the attorney general.

This provision in the current law was originally intended to allow in only
individual refugees under highly specialized circumstances -- not, as has been
the practice since the mid-1950s, scores or even hundreds of thousands of
displaced people at a time.  Returned to its position as a limited measure, the
parole authority remains a part of the administration bill.

Sen. Edward M. Kennedy (D-Mass.) has been a prime mover in attempts to revise
refugee law.  He and House Judiciary Committee Chairman Peter W. Rodino Jr.
(D-N.J.) are expected to introduce the administration proposal.

"For too long our policy toward refugee assistance [has] been ad hoc and has
lacked effective planning and efficient programming," Kennedy said recently.
"We have admitted refugees in fits and starts because our immigration law has
been inadequate, discriminatory and totally out of touch with today's needs."

Previous legislation was stalled in the Senate Judiciary Committee but Kennedy
-- who is now to the committee chairman -- said that he is optimistic about
passage of the administration's bill.

Currently there are at least 200,000 refugees in Indochina alone who would be
affected by the legislation if it passes.

At present, both Australia and France accept more Indochinese refugees in
proportion to their population than the United States does.  Israel, Germany and
Britain have all resettled large numbers of refugees for whom they feel they
have special responsibilities.

                Sentinel & Enterprise (Fitchburg, Massachusetts)

                            March 15, 2018 Thursday

Hundreds become citizens at Gardner ceremony

BYLINE: By Amanda Burke, aburke@sentinelandenterprise.com

SECTION: NEWS; Local

LENGTH: 530 words


GARDNER -- Chandra Ramdama fled Bhutan in 1992 and spent two decades in a Nepali
refugee camp, where his children received no formal education. He spent nights
under plastic-tarp tents and watched countless other refugees succumb to
illness.

Ramdama is one of 225 people from 59 countries who on Wednesday became the
nation's newest citizens, having each been sworn in during a naturalization
ceremony at the Mount Wachusett Community College theater.

"We were in Bhutan and it wasn't our country, we were in Nepal and it wasn't our
country. We spent 20 years without any identity, and now we are getting
citizenship, so this is a proud moment," he said, his son Purna translating for
him.

The 85-year-old and his family were accepted into the United States' refugee
program five years ago, according to Purna, who wore a suit adorned with a pin
shaped like a soaring bird on the lapel.

The soon-to-be-naturalized U.S. citizens sat in a section of the theater, and
family packed the remaining seats.

Some cradled children, others held hands, and all applauded as Gardner Mayor
Mark Hawke, Mount Wachusett Community College President James Vander Hooven,
former state Sen. Stephen Brewer and U.S. District Court Chief Magistrate Judge
David H. Hennessy spoke.

"You are the story of America, and you always have been the story of America,"
Brewer said.

Clauther Vincent, 23, of Lowell, immigrated to the United States in 2010. He
joined the U.S. armed services, and in three months leaves for his first
overseas deployment to Africa.

He was a lawful permanent resident before Wednesday, when, in uniform, he led
the ceremony in the Pledge of Allegiance.

"As a kid in Haiti you see the many benefits of living in the United States," he
said, smiling. "Today feels special, because now I have the VIP status."

Wendy Puello's father brought her from the Dominican Republic to New York 30
years before she became a U.S. citizen, just like her three children.

"I have goosebumps," she said, running her hand up her arm. "I can't explain it,
I just feel so happy."

Hundreds of thousands of people become naturalized citizens annually. For some,
being able to vote in a nation where they have lived for years was a push toward
seeking citizenship.

Nuno Rodrigues, 46, immigrated from Portugal with his parents who sought work.
That was 40 years ago. Today, Rodrigues, a road construction worker from Ludlow,
looks forward to this year's election.

"Like they say, every vote counts, and if I'm going to have opinions, have
something to say, I must be able to vote," he said.

Vincent McDonald, 65, said when he was a child, his parents moved his family off
their farm in New Brunswick. At the time, large numbers of residents of the
province were leaving as earning a living by farming became increasingly
difficult, he said.

His father started a machine shop, and his brother fought with the Americans in
the Vietnam War. He narrowly missed being drafted himself, he said, because the
war ended three months before his number was expected to be called.

Just over 55 years later, on Wednesday, he felt just a bit more patriotic.

"This Fourth of July is going to be a little bit extra special for me," he said.
