why at this particular point in history? This paper argues that the balance of
factors influencing refugee resettlement decisions has shifted in recent years
due to significant political changes combined with the increasing influence of
internal pressures from various interest groups and Congressional allies. As a
result, Africa has moved to the forefront of U.S. refugee resettlement decisions
within the past decade, a fact which on its face appears primarily humanitarian,
but in reality is much more complex.

A. The End of the Cold War

   While the Refugee Act of 1980 established a broader refugee definition that
first opened the possibility of resettlement to Africans, in reality the
effective determination of who was to be resettled to the United States did not
change significantly until the end of the Cold War.  n47 "The United States
continued to view refugee admissions as an extension of its foreign policy even
in the early eighties," stated Mark Hetfield, Senior Vice President for Policy
and Programs at the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society. "It was seen as to our benefit
to resettle refugees from certain countries so we could showcase the
shortcomings of our opponents and the relative benefits of our democracy. The
idea was to resettle people from countries that were our political adversaries."
n48

   The end of the Cold War truly paved the way for increased African refugee
resettlement to the United States in two respects. First, as the Cold War came
to an end in the late 1980s and early 1990s, there was a corresponding decline
in U.S. resettlement of refugees from Southeast Asia and the former Soviet
Union, which had previously comprised roughly 80 to 90 percent of  [*442]  the
U.S. refugee resettlement program.  n49 In 1989, seventy countries, including
the United States, instituted the Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA) in an
effort to better manage the flow of refugees from Southeast Asia.  n50 The CPA
implemented a formal process of screening Southeast Asians for refugee status
and returning those who did not qualify. Second, around the same time, Africa
began to play a more significant role in U.S. foreign policy with the deployment
of U.S. troops to Somalia in 1992 and Liberia in 2003.  n51 Now that
anti-Communist ideology no longer dominated U.S. refugee resettlement decisions,
there was room--both within the new definition of a refugee enacted in 1980, and
within the overall resettlement allocation figure--to accommodate refugees from
countries other than those in Southeast Asia and the former Soviet Union.

B. The Influence of Non-Governmental Organizations

   By the time the Cold War ended, non-governmental organizations were in a
strong position to act as a lobbying force to influence U.S. refugee
resettlement decisions. The Refugee Act of 1980 created a more structured format
in which NGOs could bring their concerns to the table at an annual Congressional
hearing on refugee admissions. With foreign policy concerns and anti-Communist
ideology no longer the primary factors influencing resettlement decisions, NGOs
had more room to maneuver. NGOs regularly advocate for the State Department's
Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) to keep the overall cap on
admissions as high as possible. According to Kelly Gauger, Program Officer for
East Africa in the Office of Refugee Admissions, PRM takes seriously the
recommendations of NGOs regarding the annual refugee ceiling. It is aware that
in the minds of many NGOs, the annual ceiling is always too low.  n52 Once the
admissions ceiling is set, NGOs treat the ceiling as a target, urging the
government to fill all of the admissions slots it allocates for a given year.
n53 Observers have noted that this advocacy appears to significantly influence
PRM's recommendations on the annual refugee ceiling.

   Refugee resettlement agencies have particularly championed the African cause
in recent years. According to Mark Hetfield, "[i]t was an obvious question of
equity: most of the world's refugees are African, and yet they were not being
resettled [to the U.S.]."  n54 Moreover, NGO leaders, human  [*443]  rights
activists, and U.S. government officials have become increasingly aware of the
problem of protracted refugee situations worldwide, particularly within Africa.
According to a recent estimate, "[t]he majority of the more than three million
African refugees have been in exile for over ten years."  n55 African refugee
camps, initially regarded as a temporary solution to emergency refugee flows,
are becoming more permanent than many would like.

   U.S. government officials initially were optimistic that African conflicts
would end, and many looked to countries of first asylum within Africa to handle
the refugee crisis on the continent.  n56 As Bill Frelick, Director of Refugee
Policy at Human Rights Watch, stated:


     There was a prevalent assumption for many years that there was no need
     to resettle out of Africa because African host countries were more
     generous and kept their borders open; their borders were more porous,
     and kinship ties often extended beyond the colonially created borders,
     so resettlement wasn't needed as a durable solution as it was in other
     places.  n57


Over time, however, it became apparent that conditions in African countries of
first asylum were deteriorating.

   The hospitality of African host countries began to decline towards the end of
the Cold War.  n58 African host countries were "warehousing" refugees in
dangerous camps, often located in isolated and insecure border areas. In some
cases, refugees were not able to return home after more than a decade.  n59 Some
countries, such as Kenya in the early 1990s, began to talk of moving refugee
camps to the countries from which the refugees had initially fled.  n60 The need
for resettling African refugees to countries outside the continent became
increasingly apparent. In addition, since refugee resettlement agencies had
already demonstrated the capacity to resettle over 230,000 refugees to the
United States during the Cold War years, these agencies felt they could easily
increase African numbers since there was a significantly lighter caseload now
coming out of the Soviet Union and Southeast Asia.  n61 As  [*444]  momentum
grew around the idea of increasing African refugee resettlement to the United
States, NGOs began to place increased pressure on Congress in order to obtain
results.

C. <>Leadership by the Congressional Black Caucus<>

   In order to promote increased African refugee resettlement, a coalition of
refugee resettlement organizations in Washington, D.C., known as the InterAction
Commission on Migration and Refugee Affairs (CMRA), took select Congressional
staff members on three separate trips to Africa during the late 1990s.  n62
Staff members working with the Congressional Black Caucus were among those
invited to take a first hand look at the refugee situation on the ground in
Africa.  n63 Democratic members of the Congressional Black Caucus held
leadership roles at the time within both the House Judiciary and International
Relations Committees, two of the most influential committees on refugee
resettlement issues. The Judiciary Committee has specific jurisdiction to
consult with the Secretary of State and President about overall refugee
resettlement numbers and refugee group designations, and the International
Relations Committee authorizes the amount of funds UNHCR receives from the
United States.  n64 With Congressional Black Caucus members as leaders on both
these Committees during the mid-1990s, the Caucus was ideally positioned to help
refugee advocates push for their cause.  n65

   Each of CMRA's trips lasted from seven days to two weeks and accommodated
twelve to fifteen people, including NGO representatives and a bipartisan mix of
Congressional staff members. NGOs sponsored the travel of some Congressional
staffers, while those on the Judiciary and International Relations Committees
were sponsored by Committee funds.  n66 In 1996, the first delegation traveled
to refugee camps in Kenya, and then examined refugee issues in Ethiopia,
Somalia, and along the Burundi-Tanzania border. The following year, a second
delegation traveled to West African refugee camps in Guinea, Liberia, and Cote
d'Ivoire. In 1998, a third delegation met with Sudanese refugees in Egypt before
continuing on to Russia, Azerbaijan, Kosovo, and Bosnia.  n67

   The trips that CMRA organized helped bring Congressional Black Caucus  [*445]
members on board to support increased African refugee resettlement to the United
States. The cause seemed natural to many members of the Caucus and its staff,
who felt a sense of ancestral solidarity with African refugees.  n68 Stephanie
Peters, who served as Minority Counsel to the House Judiciary Committee  n69
between 1995 and 1999 and participated in each of the three trips CMRA
organized, explained the connection she and other Black Caucus members felt
toward the issue of African resettlement:


     We saw it as a core issue of who's in the room and who's at the table.
     If you didn't have someone of African descent at the table, then who
     got resettled in this country was a reflection of the UNHCR staff at
     that particular camp, who were typically Europeans. Our point was, why
     was it easier for a UNHCR protection officer to determine that a
     European refugee rather than an African refugee was eligible for
     resettlement to the United States?  n70


Peters and other delegation members returned from each of CMRA's trips after
Congress' August recess, just in time to take action before the President's
annual refugee allocation determination at the beginning of the fiscal year on
October 1. As Minority Counsel, Peters worked with the leadership of the Caucus
to draft a letter to Congress on the issue of African refugee resettlement to
the United States. In 1998, following CMRA's third trip to Africa, the number of
resettlement spots allocated to African refugees jumped significantly, from
7,000 in 1998 to 12,000 in 1999, suggesting that the Caucus was successful in
its advocacy.  n71 Indeed, several individuals interviewed for this paper
identified the Congressional Black Caucus as one of the most influential groups
advocating over the past decade for increased African refugee resettlement to
the United States.  n72

D. The Search for Large, Self-Contained Refugee Groups

   At the same time that the Congressional Black Caucus and refugee resettlement
NGOs were calling for an increase in African resettlement, UNHCR and the U.S.
State Department were seeking to fill the void in the refugee program left by
the end of the Cold War. As the number of refugees from Southeast Asia and the
Soviet Union decreased, the State Department  [*446]  was hard pressed to fill
the refugee slots it had allocated: "There was always a worry about the [refugee
] pipeline--finding groups to resettle became the clarion call in the 1990s."
n73

   Filling the allocated refugee slots was more difficult than one might imagine
because the United States selects refugees according to a three-tiered priority
system for refugee resettlement established by the Refugee Act of 1980. Priority
level one (P-1) status refugees are those most in need of resettlement who have
been referred to the U.S. government by the UNHCR or a U.S. Embassy.  n74 This
category typically includes torture victims, refugees at risk of refoulement,
former political prisoners, women at risk, and those in need of urgent medical
care.  n75 Priority level two (P-2) status is accorded to specific groups within
certain nationalities who are of "special humanitarian concern" to the U.S, as
determined by the President, Congress, and PRM. Members of a group of "special
humanitarian concern" are presumed to possess the key criteria for refugee
status--"a well-founded fear of persecution" on account of one of the five
grounds enumerated in the UN Refugee Convention.  n76 The majority of refugees
admitted to the United States since the Refugee Act of 1980 have been admitted
under P-2 status as members of a group of special humanitarian concern to the
U.S. government.  n77 Finally, priority level three (P-3) status is family-based
and limited to certain nationalities.  n78 Immediate family members of refugees
from select countries who are already residing in the United States are eligible
for resettlement under this category.

   For practical reasons, the U.S. has traditionally focused on processing P-2
status refugee groups. P-1 referrals are particularly labor intensive, each
requiring extensive documentation, and P-3 status is so narrowly defined by
nationality and family relationship that few refugees qualify in a given year.
Accordingly, P-2 group processing procedures are considered much easier and more
efficient than making P-1 and P-3 referrals for many individual refugees.  n79

   During the mid-1990s, the State Department began to focus on finding new
large, self-contained groups of individuals with persecution claims for P-2
referral.  n80 This was due largely to the change in refugee flows after the end
of the Cold War. Many refugees from Southeast Asia and the former Soviet Union
had been admitted to the United States before this three-tiered  [*447]
priority system was put in place, and later were admitted as P-2 groups of
"special humanitarian concern."  n81 As these large P-2 groups began to vanish,
the United States found that filling the remaining allocated refugee slots with
P-1 or P-3 referrals was impractical. In addition to the practical difficulties
of completing P-1 referrals, there was no political will at the time to increase
the manpower necessary to make more individual P-1 referrals.  n82 Filling the
allocated slots with P-3 referrals also seemed difficult because of the
category's narrow scope.

   At the same time, NGO representatives and members of the Congressional Black
Caucus were applying constant pressure on Congress and the President to increase
African refugee resettlement. The United States was presented with several
groups in Africa that fit the P-2 referral criteria, including the Sudanese Lost
Boys and the Somali Bantu. Since these and other African groups fit the bill,
the United States began to significantly increase its refugee resettlement
allocation for Africans beginning in the mid-1990s.

E. Conclusions

   Many leaders in the field, including representatives of governmental agencies
and NGOs involved in the resettlement process, believe that in recent years
humanitarian concerns have emerged as a more important principle of refugee
resettlement decisions, while foreign policy motives have faded into the
background. The United States' decision to select the Somali Bantu and Sudanese
Lost Boys for resettlement is pointed to by many as an indication of a more
humanitarian approach. Kelly Gauger of PRM stated that resettlement of these
groups "is reflective of the fact that the program has become a true rescue
program, not based on foreign policy or finding people who will assimilate
well."  n83 Bill Frelick, a long-time critic of the U.S. refugee resettlement
program, also thinks that a significant shift toward a more humanitarian
approach to resettlement has finally taken place:


     The United States was willing to take the Lost Boys, who were not as
     skilled or literate or had the abilities or capacities of some of the
     other groups that could have been chosen. This shows, I think, that
     there was something genuinely humanitarian that underpinned the
     decision to move in the direction of identifying these new groups.
     n84

   During interviews with representatives of government agencies and
nongovernmental organizations involved in the United States' refugee
resettlement  [*448]  process, a general consensus emerged that the U.S.
government's decision to select the Somali Bantu and Sudanese Lost Boys for
resettlement reflects a more humanitarian approach to resettlement in
significant contrast to past trends.

   The preceding discussion illustrates, however, that it was not humanitarian
concern alone, but rather a complex mix of factors that motivated the United
States' decision to increase African refugee resettlement to the United States.
The Refugee Act of 1980 created a more formal structure for the U.S. refugee
resettlement program that opened more space for dialogue on resettlement. The
end of the Cold War permitted a shift away from the overpowering influence of
foreign policy objectives on refugee resettlement decisions. These two changes
made room for new factors to begin to mold resettlement decisions. Interest
groups and their Congressional allies rose to the occasion and began vocally
advocating for African refugees, a population that had long been neglected in
U.S. resettlement history. All of these factors culminated in what many view as
a more humanitarian approach to refugee resettlement, as opposed to the
geopolitical approach that had previously dominated U.S. refugee resettlement
policy. Statistics show that African refugees have benefited significantly from
the political changes that have occurred over the past twenty-seven years, as
their allocated resettlement number has risen to more than fourteen times the
initial designated level in 1980.  n85

   This discussion is not intended to minimize the genuine humanitarian need of
the many refugee groups the United States resettled before African refugees
became a primary focus of the resettlement program. By definition, every refugee
in the world has suffered and is cause for humanitarian concern. For this
reason, it is often difficult for resettlement host countries to choose among
the millions in need, and indeed there is no perfect formula for doing so. Up
until the end of the Cold War, the four major influences on U.S. refugee
resettlement identified in Section III coalesced in select refugee groups from
Southeast Asia and the Soviet Union, making these groups the most obvious
choices for U.S. resettlement. With time and political change, however, it has
become more challenging to point to individual refugee groups that clearly
represent the combined interests of an increasingly diverse American community
concerned with refugee resettlement. The United States now appears to be
prioritizing those refugee groups that have the most vocal and influential
advocates among interest groups and within Congress. The resettlement of two of
these groups, and the interplay of the factors involved in their selection, is
explored below.

    [*449]  V. RESETTLEMENT OF THE SOMALI BANTU AND SUDANESE LOST BOYS

   The exponential growth in African refugee resettlement has not gone unnoticed
within the United States. More and more African restaurants are popping up in
American cities near the enclaves of Asian restaurants established by other
refugees and immigrants in previous decades. African refugees now work alongside
other immigrant and American co-workers in factories, flower nurseries, grocery
stores, restaurants, and other businesses.  n86 Some have started
community-based organizations to assist other African refugees, or started their
own NGOs to provide aid to those still living in Africa.  n87 The American media
has followed the arrival and progress of African refugees with interest in
recent years, turning the spotlight on two groups in particular, the Sudanese
Lost Boys and the Somali Bantu.

   The average American, if asked why the Lost Boys and the Somali Bantu were
brought to the United States, would likely assume that their resettlement was
primarily a humanitarian decision on the part of the United States. The American
media has certainly focused on highlighting the dramatic and sympathetic stories
of both of these groups. The Sudanese youth popularly referred to as the Lost
Boys were displaced during the war in Sudan as they fled attacks on their
families and villages or fled rebel armies trying to force them into combat.
n88 The boys fled their families and homes on foot and escaped together to
refugee camps first in Ethiopia, and then in Kenya, with many dying along the
way due to disease, exhaustion, attacks by wild animals, and heavy rains.  n89
Those who survived the epic journey spent the next several years of their
childhood in Kakuma refugee camp in arid northwestern Kenya.

   The Somali Bantu are a minority group who survived a legacy of slavery and
continual marginalization and exclusion from mainstream society in Somalia. Many
Somali Bantu were robbed, raped, and murdered during  [*450]  Somalia's civil
war in the early 1990s.  n90 Their history of persecution, however, dates back
to the early nineteenth century.  n91 After Somalia's independence from Italy
and Britain in 1960, Somali authorities adopted a policy designed to prevent the
Somali Bantu's social, political, and economic development.  n92 The Somali
Bantu were largely excluded from formal education, and many became landless as
government and political elites displaced them from their farms.  n93 Then in
October 1992, after their villages were attacked by dominant clan Somali, the
Somali Bantu began to flee southern Somalia to refugee camps in northern Kenya.
n94 They lived for over ten years primarily in Dadaab, an arid, isolated, and
dangerous refugee camp in Kenya, before being resettled to the United States.
n95 Even in the camp, the Somali Bantu reported being persecuted by their
neighbors and attacked at a rate that "was disproportionate to their population
in the wider camp community."  n96

   The factors motivating the resettlement of these two groups demonstrate the
new dynamics underlying the U.S. refugee resettlement program, and also
introduce certain influential factors unique to these groups. Understanding the
reasoning behind the U.S. government's decision to select these two groups for
resettlement may help refugee advocates better predict which groups may be
targeted for resettlement in the future, and how best to influence the
decision-making process.

A. Special Interest Groups and the Sudanese Lost Boys

   Christian organizations in particular played a pivotal role in advocating for
the Sudanese Lost Boys' resettlement to the United States. "In my experience,
Christian groups have been instrumental in focusing U.S. government attention on
Sudan," stated Kelly Gauger of PRM.  n97 Indeed, a whole range of Christian
organizations and faith-based human rights advocates, including evangelical
Christians, have adopted the Sudanese as their cause due to widespread
persecution of Christians in the Sudan.  n98

   Initially, many evangelical Christian groups were interested in encouraging
humanitarian aid to Sudanese refugees or negotiating a peace agreement within
the country, rather than encouraging refugee resettlement to the United States.
n99 The Midland Ministerial Alliance, located in the hometown of U.S. President
George W. Bush, and Samaritan's Purse, run by the son of  [*451]  the well-known
evangelical Christian Billy Graham, are two Christian organizations that have
been particularly active in advocating for peace in the Sudan.  n100 While these
and other evangelical organizations have been most vocal in calling for
solutions within Sudan, their strong voices on the issue have also indirectly
influenced refugee advocacy by Christian-affiliated resettlement organizations
in the United States and by evangelical Christian government officials.
Influential Christian politicians in Congress, such as Republican Senator Sam
Brownback of Kansas, saw Sudanese refugees as a particularly worthy group for
resettlement.  n101 Brownback pushed alongside members of the Congressional
Black Caucus to encourage the United States to accept the Sudanese Lost Boys.

   In addition to evangelical Christians, some of the more traditional players
in resettlement decision-making have also taken a special interest in Sudanese
refugees. Religiously affiliated refugee resettlement agencies--such as World
Vision, the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, Lutheran Immigration and
Refugee Services, and the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society--helped influence the
United States' decision to accept the Sudanese Lost Boys for resettlement.  n102
At the same time, secular resettlement agencies--such as the Ethiopian Community
Development Council and the International Rescue Committee--were also pushing
for resettlement of those who fled Sudan.  n103

   Bill Frelick of Human Rights Watch commented on the unusual confluence of
advocates that came together on the issue of Sudanese refugee resettlement:



     There was a very interesting convergence of Left-Right bedfellows
     regarding refugees in Sudan that you rarely see in other parts of
     political Washington, D.C. The Congressional Black Caucus, which is
     overwhelmingly Democratic and liberal, and the Christian Evangelical
     Right, which is overwhelmingly White Republican, both took a very
     strong interest in Sudanese refugees.  n104


As interest groups from both ends of the political spectrum joined their voices
to call for increasing resettlement of Sudanese refugees, the U.S. government
listened. The United States targeted the Lost Boys for resettlement to the
United States following a referral in 1999 by UNHCR and the  [*452]  U.S. State
Department.  n105

   A Presidential report on proposed refugee admissions issued in July 2000
further reflects the United States' particular concern with the persecution of
Christians in Sudan:


     In the North, where many of the four million internally displaced
     Sudanese (mostly Southerners) live, harassment and persecution of
     Christians, including arrests of clergy on apparently trumped-up
     charges, and refusal to issue building permits for churches and
     church-related buildings is the rule rather than the exception ... The
     U.S. admissions program has in recent years increased its focus in
     Egypt, Ethiopia, and Kenya on these Sudanese victims of religious
     discrimination and persecution.  n106


The excerpt above falls under the heading "Religious Freedom in Africa," which
is notably the only topical subheading in the report's discussion of refugee
flows within Africa, even though persecution on other grounds is widespread as
well.  n107 The editorial choice to single out religious persecution within
Africa in this Presidential report, combined with the vocal advocacy of numerous
Christian organizations and politicians, suggests that religious interests
strongly influenced the U.S. government's decision to resettle the Lost Boys.

   The Lost Boys also appealed to refugee advocates and decision-makers because
they fit the refugee profile that was at the center of U.S. interests at the
time. The Lost Boys were a prime example of a protracted refugee situation, as
they spent their entire adolescence living in a refugee camp with no durable
solutions available.  n108 They were also an easily identifiable, discrete group
that could be processed and resettled relatively quickly. The Lost Boys made a
strong impression on representatives from the State Department who traveled to
Kakuma refugee camp in the late 1990s. These PRM representatives helped drive
the final determination to designate the boys as a P-2 group for resettlement.
n109 As Mark Bixler, author of <>The Lost Boys of Sudan: An American Story of
the Refugee Experience,<> <><>explained: "There were a variety of factors
that[,]... taken together, led to an increase in Sudanese Lost Boy resettlement.
They wouldn't have meant much if they had happened separately, but they all came
together at the right time."  n110 As a  [*453]  result of this confluence of
events, roughly 3,800 Lost Boys have been resettled to the United States since
1999.  n111

B. Humanitarian Resettlement and the Somali Bantu

   The history of the Somali Bantu resettlement seems to indicate that there
indeed may have been a strong humanitarian motive behind the United States'
selection of this group. Resettling the Somali Bantu was neither politically
advantageous nor practical from the standpoint of domestic immigration policy.
These refugees were at considerable risk within Africa, however, and their
resettlement to the United States seems a logical choice when viewed in light of
the resettlement program's objectives at the time. Some conclude that the Somali
Bantu resettlement is proof that the U.S. government has become increasingly
willing to use refugee law as a means of addressing humanitarian concerns.

   In contrast to the Sudanese Lost Boys' resettlement, religious groups and
religiously-affiliated politicians do not appear to have played a large role in
the United States' decision to resettle the Somali Bantu. Because the Somali
Bantu are mostly Muslim, their persecution did not elicit the same popular
uprising of support from Christian organizations in the United States that
accompanied news of persecution in the Sudan. There are notably no Muslim
organizations among the NGOs responsible for refugee resettlement in the United
States.  n112 Although some Muslim organizations have tried on occasion to enter
the U.S. refugee resettlement arena, they have faced difficulty due to a lack of
national networking.  n113 As a result, religious organizations and politicians
made few, if any, efforts to advocate for resettlement of the Somali Bantu to
the United States.

   Prior to their resettlement, it was widely predicted that the Somali Bantu
would have great difficulty in adjusting to life in the United States. "With the
low literacy and English levels, large families, no U.S. support system and an
almost total lack of exposure to technology and urban life, Somali Bantus will
struggle to gain self sufficiency and a foothold in U.S. Society," one author
predicted in Refugee Reports, a publication of Immigration and Refugee Services
of America.  n114 The Somali Bantu are among the most culturally dissimilar
refugee groups that have been selected for integration into American culture.
n115 They have a high rate of illiteracy due to their exclusion from formalized
education, tend to form polygamous marriages,  [*454]  are mostly Muslim, and
their language--Maay Maay--has only recently been codified.  n116 Although some
gained limited exposure to urban ways of life while living in refugee camps,
most Somali Bantu refugees were unaccustomed to using electricity, flush
toilets, telephones, and kitchen and laundry appliances before their
resettlement to the United States.  n117

   The Somali Bantu did, however, fit the profile of the African refugee groups
the United States was targeting. They were another protracted refugee situation
with no apparent durable solution. The Somali Bantu had been living in refugee
camps in Kenya for over a decade and continued to suffer persecution, even in
exile, due to the persistence of the oppressive clan structures in the camps:



     The Somali Bantu ... [were] a group that in the clan culture of
     Somalia were the equivalent of the Untouchables in India, people that
     basically didn't even fall within that clan structure because they
     weren't even seen as having their origins in Somalia in the first
     place; and so they were essentially the Untouchables in Dadaab as
     well.  n118


Repatriation was not an option for this persecuted clan, for no one would
protect them in Somalia, and they faced unending persecution in their countries
of first asylum. For those concerned about protracted refugee situations in
Africa, the Somali Bantu were an obvious group in need of assistance.

   Furthermore, the Somali Bantu were an ideal group for P-2 resettlement status
because they were physically identifiable and because their persecution claims
were, in some sense, already familiar to the U.S. government. The Somali Bantu
share distinct physical features which make them easily identifiable, including
a kinkier hair texture than dominant-clan Somali and a distinctly-shaped nose.
n119 In addition, two other Somali ethnic minority groups had already been
successfully resettled to the United States under P-2 status, laying a firm
foundation for the Somali Bantu resettlement. The Somali Benadir, who were
resettled to the United States in 1995, helped pave the way for the Somali
Bantu.  n120 Because members of the Benadir ethnic minority had similar
persecution claims, the U.S. State Department was able to resettle the Benadir
relatively efficiently.  n121 Although the State Department still conducted
individual refugee status determination interviews for each refugee, the
interviews could be less-detailed since the individuals'  [*455]  stories were
similar.  n122 The Somali Barawa were the next ethnic-minority African group
resettled to the United States under P-2 status in 1996.  n123 Like these two
groups, the Somali Bantu were an ethnic minority that didn't have a majority
clan to protect them.  n124 By the time the Somali Bantu were recommended by the
UNHCR in 1999, they seemed like a straightforward choice for P-2 resettlement to
the United States.

   Given the extreme difficulty the Somali Bantu were predicted to have in
adapting to American life, it seems particularly significant that the U.S.
government selected them for resettlement. Several of the NGO and government
leaders interviewed for this paper pointed in particular to the Somali Bantu
resettlement as proof of the increasingly humanitarian focus of the United
States refugee program.  n125 As Mark Hetfield remarked, the decision to
resettle the Bantu "really speaks volumes about how flexible the refugee program
is and can be in terms of responding to refugees no matter what their needs
are."  n126 Notably, this flexibility of the U.S. refugee resettlement program
appears to be a recent development made possible by the end of the Cold War. It
remains unclear whether refugee resettlement selection in the future will remain
as flexible as it is today.

   VI. THE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES OF LARGE-SCALE AFRICAN REFUGEE
RESETTLEMENT

   Thus far, this paper has described in detail the complex dynamics
underpinning the United States' increased focus on African refugee resettlement,
in particular on the Somali Bantu and Sudanese Lost Boy resettlements. This
discussion raises new questions: what is the significance of continuing to
resettle African refugees to the United States? What are the challenges and
opportunities presented by this large-scale resettlement, both for the United
States and for Africa? The next portion of this paper will offer some possible
answers to these questions.  n127

A. Impact on Global Refugee Flows

   One of the primary arguments that scholars and refugee advocates raise for
resettling large numbers of refugees to the United States is the need to spread
the worldwide burden of refugees among those countries best able to assist them.
This concept of burden-sharing is particularly applicable in the African  [*456]
context. Today, most refugee flows occur in Africa and southern Asia, and the
brunt of these refugee burdens is primarily borne by neighboring states.  n128
Coincidentally, these states are often least-equipped to handle the refugee
flow, both economically and politically. The imbalance that results is striking:



     Some of those least capable of bearing these burdens have in fact
     carried a disproportionately large share of them. This is most
     strikingly true of some African states that often serve as countries
     of first asylum for many of the most wretched refugees. Conversely,
     some of the states that are most capable of incurring refugee burdens
     have stood on the sidelines watching.  n129


Despite the very apparent need for increased burden-sharing, "no strong norm of
refugee burden-sharing currently exists in international law or practice."  n130
Indeed, "[t]he vast majority of countries ... make few or no resettlement offers
even though some of them have ample resources for doing so."  n131 As one expert
notes, "effective burden-sharing requires efforts to reduce the burdens on all
countries and spread them over time."  n132

   Many countries may be reluctant to share the worldwide refugee burden out of
a fear that doing so creates a "pull factor" that will attract an increasing
flow of refugees.  n133 Once word of the resettlement of certain populations
gets out, members of those populations who may have otherwise chosen to stay in
their countries of origin may flee to countries of first asylum in the hope of
eventually being resettled to desirable host countries. This phenomenon occurred
during the Somali Bantu resettlement, when some Somali Bantu who had initially
resettled on their own in Tanzania chose to return to Kakuma refugee camp in
Kenya in the hope of being selected for resettlement to the United States.  n134
Bill Frelick of Human Rights Watch commented on the particular problems that the
resettlement pull factor can create:


     Resettlement can be a tricky enterprise in terms of the dynamics in
     refugee camps and refugee situations. Refugee resettlement can cause a
     lot of damage if it's done poorly. When there are a limited number of
     spots available and you start advertising that you're beginning a
     refugee resettlement program, it can create a stampede, precipitate
     some really  [*457]  ugly, overheated situations, and produce almost
     hysterical kinds of reactions where people are committing fraud and
     doing things they wouldn't ordinarily do. Out of desperation, they
     have unrealistic expectations and get caught up in the contradiction
     between false hopes and bitter realities. Resettlement can be quite
     counter-productive if it's not done properly.  n135


Frelick's comment illustrates the significant potential drawbacks of large-scale
resettlement, both for the resettlement-receiving country and for the host
country of first asylum.

   Despite the risk of a pull factor, the United States has historically been
willing to admit more refugees than all other resettling countries combined,
likely in part because of the international goodwill that large-scale
resettlement creates for the United States. Resettlement offers refugees
economic and educational opportunities that can help them rebuild their home
countries. By accepting African refugees for resettlement, the United States
also indirectly channels funds and education into Africa. Many African refugees
resettled to the United States provide significant financial support to their
family members and friends in Africa by sending part of their earnings home.
n136 Thus, the employment of one refugee in the United States often has a
multiplying effect that financially benefits not only that individual, but a
network of other refugees abroad who receive his or her remittances.

B. Effects of Resettlement on African Refugees, Countries of Origin, and the
United States

   The education that refugees receive in the United States can also eventually
benefit their home countries. The Sudanese Lost Boys resettled to the United
States were particularly enthusiastic about the opportunity to receive an
education they would likely have been unable to access in Sudan.  n137 Some of
those who have received college degrees in the United States have used their
education to start non-profit organizations to aid Sudan.  n138 One Lost Boy
resettled to New York, for example, launched a non-profit organization in 2005
called Water for Sudan.  n139 In addition, the less formal social and political
education that resettled refugees receive by virtue of living in the United
States may inspire them to incorporate similar values and political and social
practices into their home countries, if they choose to return home  [*458]  in
the future. A recent newspaper article reports that "[T]he Lost Boys have now
become vital participants in the reconstruction of Sudan. In addition to
organizing relief missions and fundraising campaigns, the Lost Boys have become
vocal advocates for peace in their homeland."  n140 Resettlement therefore acts
as an indirect means of spreading democracy, financial support, and education to
formerly war-torn countries.

   While resettlement can be beneficial to both refugees and their receiving
host countries, the process is also costly for both parties. In order to be
resettled, a refugee has to be uprooted yet again and moved from the country of
first asylum to the resettling third country, which often has a very different
language, culture, and way of life than the refugee is accustomed to. This
second uprooting and readjustment can have emotional, mental, and physical costs
for the refugee.  n141 The host country must then either pay to assist the
refugee upon his or her arrival, or must bear the burden if the refugee fails to
assimilate.  n142 According to a 2003 analysis by the Center for Immigration
Studies, over five billion dollars per year are spent on Temporary Assistance to
Needy Families (TANF), food stamps, Supplemental Security Income (SSI), and
Medicaid for refugees in the United States.  n143

   Although many countries cite economic concerns as justification for not
offering permanent refugee resettlement, these concerns appear to be largely
unfounded, particularly in countries like the United States that already have
relatively strong and stable economies. Studies show that despite the initial
costs, refugees "tend to lift regional economies over time by starting their own
businesses, purchasing homes, and becoming consumers."  n144 Mark Hetfield
describes refugee resettlement as "an investment that generally pays off'
because the United States refugee resettlement program is a relatively
inexpensive system where the emphasis is on early employment and self-support,
rather than providing years of aid to refugees.  n145

C. Social Impact on Resettled Refugees and Affected Communities in the United
States

   Even while the refugee resettlement "investment" may usually pay off for both
parties in the long run, the short term costs can be significant on the personal
and social level. Some refugees face severe culture shock upon resettlement to
the United States, and American citizens may also experience  [*459]  severe
culture shock in adjusting to their presence.  n146 The cultural clashes that
the Sudanese Lost Boys and their American host communities experienced in
adapting to each other after the boys' initial arrival has been well-documented
in the award-winning documentary film, Lost Boys of Sudan.  n147 The decision to
resettle the Somali Bantu raised strong concerns regarding cultural clashes.
Vocal protest against the Somali Bantu's arrival erupted in the cities of
Holyoke, Massachusetts and Cayce, South Carolina prior to their resettlement.
n148 Some suggest that the Somali Bantu would arguably have been better off if
they had been resettled in a neighboring country more similar to their own.
n149

   Those opposed to large-scale African resettlement to the United States are
not necessarily xenophobic, but rather may have the long-term interests of the
refugee-producing country in mind. Opponents of increased resettlement often
cite the drawback of potential "brain drain" from developing or war-torn
countries. Indeed, in cases like Cuba and Vietnam, the United States imported
through its resettlement program many of the citizens most likely to create
positive change in those countries.  n150 This issue raises a valid concern in
relation to the Sudanese Lost Boys as well, since they are members of the
generation most likely to be able to assist in rebuilding Sudan.

   The potential loss of leadership capabilities that occurs through
resettlement need not be permanent, however. Refugees can later choose to return
to their countries of origin and help rebuild them, using the knowledge and
experience they gained in the United States. Initially, there were high hopes
among the Lost Boys themselves and other Kakuma camp residents that U.S.
resettlement would empower these young men with the tools necessary to serve as
future leaders of their country.  n151 Prior to the Lost Boys' departure,
Sudanese elders in the camp urged the youth to focus on obtaining an education
in the United States, and later return to help facilitate peace in their
homeland. The Lost Boys are just now making their initial visits back to Sudan
since a fragile peace has been restored.  n152 The potential benefits of this
reverse migration are yet to be fully discovered, although initial reports are
promising.  n153

   With African refugees now being resettled to the United States in larger
[*460]  numbers, it is valuable to consider the potential challenges and
opportunities of this increase, both from a domestic and international
perspective. The future of the African resettlement program in the United States
will depend largely on the relative weight U.S. government authorities place on
these various factors, and how these factors balance out in light of political
and humanitarian interests.

   VII. THE FUTURE OF AFRICAN REFUGEE RESETTLEMENT TO THE UNITED STATES

   Many of those in the refugee resettlement field seem to accept the challenges
and opportunities of refugee resettlement as a given, and continue to regard
resettlement as a positive solution for particularly vulnerable refugees. With
regard to African refugee resettlement to America in particular, most
individuals interviewed for this paper would not advocate for either a
categorical increase or decrease in African numbers. Rather, they stressed that
the U.S. refugee resettlement program must remain flexible enough to turn its
attention to wherever the world's greatest need may lie at any given time.

   Bill Frelick of Human Rights Watch captured the sentiment of several of those
interviewed on the subject:


     I wouldn't advocate for any continent, nationality, whatever <>per<> <
     >se.<> I am a globalist, and I think ideally you want to pick the most
     vulnerable people for whom resettlement makes the most sense, and
     where that might do the most to leverage first asylum ... on a
     case-by-case basis.  n154


Sandra Mullins, Executive Director of Refugee Resettlement and Immigration
Services of Atlanta, echoed this sentiment: "The U.S. will always make decisions
based on its own interest, but if we continue to look at where the humanitarian
need is, it has to continue to be open to where the worst situation in the world
is."  n155 Assuming that resettlement is the best durable solution for at least
some refugees, then as long as African refugees remain among the most vulnerable
in the world, they should continue to be resettled to the United States.

   The few individuals interviewed who felt the African resettlement allocation
should be raised above its current level were concerned about the protracted
refugee situations within Africa.  n156 They acknowledge, however, that refugees
in protracted situations pose significant logistical processing challenges. For
example, some "long-stayers," who have been living in  [*461]  camps for a
decade or more, are so far removed from the place and time of their persecution
that they may no longer be able to articulate a valid refugee claim during State
Department resettlement interviews.  n157 Despite these challenges, recent
trends suggest the United States will continue to address protracted refugee
situations in Africa, as long as it is able to find other large, self-contained
groups like the Somali Bantu and Sudanese Lost Boys to resettle.

   Still, some argue against continued large-scale resettlement of African
refugees to the United States in spite of the heavy burden Africa bears. They
reason that money would be better spent on intraregional resettlement of African
refugees within the continent itself. If the United States and UNHCR invested
more resources and energy in resettling African refugees locally, the aid could
potentially help boost the economies of African host countries. Moreover,
intraregional resettlement often seems most reasonable from a cultural and
linguistic standpoint. In the context of the Somali Bantu resettlement, for
example, Mozambique and Tanzania, whose people have historic and cultural ties
to the Somali Bantu, were initially willing to resettle the group.  n158 These
countries later backed out, however, due to a lack of resources and fear of
political instability.  n159 One critic argues that if UNHCR had offered these
countries more financial, logistical and political support, they would have been
willing to carry through with the resettlement.  n160

   Yet most individuals interviewed for this paper assert that intraregional
resettlement within Africa is impractical. Many African countries are
financially unable to offer permanent resettlement, are struggling with civil
war, or fear refugee resettlement will contribute to political instability
within their borders.  n161 African nations have therefore been historically
unwilling to offer permanent resettlement, with the recent small-scale
exceptions of Burkina Faso, Benin, and South Africa.  n162 UNHCR has only
recently established a resettlement trust fund to help Burkina Faso and South
Africa offer permanent resettlement to some refugees.  n163 Providing
resettlement aid to more African countries may not be a viable solution,
however, since many African governments are corrupt, and local populations may
resent having money earmarked for refugees when many of the countries' own
citizens are also suffering. Due to these complications, only limited efforts
have been made to resettle African refugees to a third country on the African
continent.  n164

    [*462]  Many African refugees prefer resettlement to the United States over
intraregional resettlement, despite the potential mental and physical costs of
adjusting to a culturally and linguistically distinct country. One Somali Bantu
man who established a community organization for Somali Bantu refugees in
Atlanta, Georgia, poignantly expressed his preference for U.S. resettlement over
resettlement in Africa:


     The situation is always volatile in Africa, so it is not as reliable.
     Africa has never been a reliable or stable place to live, raise kids,
     and stay. It is not a good place to stay if you are a minority because
     there is not enough power sharing. I remember my father could not save
     $ 100 per year, and here I can save $ 100 per month; and I feel my
     children have a very bright future that does not depend on their clan
     or their culture, but on how hard they work and what a good parent I
     am. They can have the same opportunities here as other Americans.
     n165


In addition to the educational and career opportunities available in the United
States, many African refugees also appreciate the availability of public
benefits such as food-stamps and Medicaid, and the freedom from diseases, such
as malaria, which are prevalent in parts of Africa but virtually unknown in the
United States.  n166

   Given that intraregional resettlement within Africa is commonly regarded as
impractical, that many African refugees prefer being resettled to America, and
that resettlement of large self-contained African groups appeals to the United
States' current resettlement policy, it is likely that large-scale resettlement
of Africans to the United States will continue over the next several years. If
African resettlement is indeed to continue, as many feel it should, then the
United States may need to reevaluate the current level of financial assistance
it provides to resettled refugees through its resettlement program. Much has
changed over the past twenty-seven years since the Refugee Act of 1980 was
passed. New resettlement policies and new refugee populations may call for new
strategies and proposals for change.

   VIII. PROPOSALS FOR CHANGE

   This section offers two specific proposals for change drawn from the
information gathered during interviews for this paper: the United States should
increase both the budget allocated for refugee resettlement and the dialogue
between NGO representatives and members of Congress regarding resettlement
allocation. Most pressingly, if African resettlement is to continue at current
levels, then the United States needs to re-examine the amount of its
resettlement budget. For while the U.S. government has demonstrated  [*463]  an
increased commitment to resettling African refugee groups in recent years, it
has not shown an equal commitment to increasing the resources allocated to
resettlement. As a result, resettlement agencies are under great financial
strain, and some refugees are struggling in their effort to thrive in their new
homeland.  n167

   Since the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, the government of the
United States has diverted money away from resettlement to focus on terrorism.
n168 In addition, the resources designated for resettlement have also failed to
keep up with inflation over the years.  n169 As a result, since 2002 the
resettlement budget has become a pressing issue for the Bureau of Population,
Refugees, and Migration.  n170 Refugee resettlement agencies have also felt the
effects of this tight budget, particularly in their efforts to resettle the
Somali Bantu.  n171 "We're glad the U.S. decided to resettle this group, but
then-needs are so tremendous and far-reaching. Their need continues well beyond
the initial three-month commitment the government expects us to make," stated
John Arnold, Resettlement Director at World Relief in Atlanta, Georgia.  n172
Despite the efforts of NGOs to assist them, initial anecdotal reports show the
Somali Bantu are struggling to find appropriate employment, gain economic
self-sufficiency, and learn English; and for many, their eight months of
government cash assistance has already run out.  n173 Abdullahi Abdullahi, who
runs the Somali Bantu Community Center in Atlanta, agrees that the current level
of assistance resettlement agencies are able to provide is inadequate,
emphasizing that some of the Somali Bantu need round-the-clock help in
navigating through a culture so different from their own.  n174 Refugee
resettlement agencies simply do not have the resources necessary to provide the
Somali Bantu with the level of assistance they require.  n175

   The need for increased resettlement funds seems to reflect the U.S.
government's failure to dedicate the same level of resettlement assistance that
it has made available in years past. Historically, other groups that have been
challenging to resettle due to cultural dissimilarities, such as the Hmong of
Southeast Asia, have received greater assistance from the government and
resettlement agencies:


      [*464]  When we look at the Hmong who were resettled twenty-five
     years ago, there were three years of [government] assistance available
     at the time. Today, it's typically eight months, which is okay if you
     have family here and are sponsored [by your relatives]. But the Somali
     Bantu had no family here, and had no community on which they could
     depend.  n176


During the Cold War era, many of the refugees selected for resettlement already
had connections to the United States, including resident family members.  n177
As a result, they could more easily find a community of support upon their
arrival. In contrast, the Somali Bantu are "free case refugees" who are
resettled to the United States without a sponsoring relative to support them.
n178 Dan Van Lehman, who has worked in the refugee relief field in both Africa
and the United States, stresses that free case refugees such as the Somali Bantu
require greater assistance upon their arrival in the United States to help them
integrate and adapt to their new surroundings.  n179 Now that the United States
has shifted its resettlement selection policies to focus on free case refugees,
it must be willing to support them. Otherwise, "without appropriate assistance
for those who are truly vulnerable, people coming here could be entering an
intergenerational cycle of poverty," which is hardly a humanitarian act on the
part of the United States, and could have dire consequences for both African
refugees and their American neighbors.  n180

   In addition to increasing resettlement funds, the U.S. government should also
consider increasing the level of dialogue between NGO representatives and
members of Congress at its annual Congressional hearing on resettlement
allocation. Although NGOs are regularly invited to provide input at the hearing,
some argue there has been less constructive dialogue at the hearing than in
years past. One person familiar with the process, speaking on condition of
anonymity, described recent hearings as a kind of "farce:"


     We used to go in there, raise issues, they would respond, we would
     respond--there was a lot of give and take, so you can actually build
     some kind of consensus or agreement to disagree. Whereas now, the way
     it's worked in the last few years is you march into a conference room
     in Roslyn, [Virginia], you read your statement, they record it, and
     then you leave. That's not a consultation, that's a monologue that
     they may or may not be listening to ... And if you don't have
     dialogue, you're not going to really affect the process.  n181


Many NGOs are still able to make their viewpoint heard through the voices
[*465]  of their Congressional allies. Less time and energy would be lost,
however, if the "middle man" were eliminated and members of Congress were
willing to engage in direct dialogue with NGO representatives at Congressional
hearings. Given that refugee resettlement agencies often have the most nuanced
understanding of resettlement challenges and the specific needs of the groups
they work with on a daily basis, it seems essential that they play a more
integral role in dialogue regarding the U.S. resettlement allocation and budget.

   On its face, at least, the United States' current resettlement policy seems
increasingly humanitarian by virtue of the fact that the United States is now
accepting African refugee groups who have long been in need of resettlement. In
order for this humanitarian element to become more firmly rooted, however, the
United States must be willing to engage in more dialogue and dedicate more
resources to understanding and addressing the real needs of African refugees.

   IX. CONCLUSION

   Over the past twenty-seven years, a broad and diverse coalition of advocates
has pushed hard to achieve a shift in U.S. refugee resettlement policies. As a
result, the United States began opening its doors to groups like the Sudanese
Lost Boys and Somali Bantu, groups unlikely to have been chosen for resettlement
under Cold War-era resettlement policy. The large self-contained nature of these
and other African groups appealed to the U.S. government, as it responded to
pressure from advocates to keep its overall refugee resettlement cap high and to
continue to fill its annual allocated resettlement slots, a task that became
more complicated as Cold War refugee populations began to vanish.

   Even as history and resettlement policies have changed, one fact has remained
constant: there are more refugees on the earth than resettlement host countries
are willing or able to assist. Moreover, there is no perfect formula for
selecting among the millions of refugees who demonstrate a genuine need for
resettlement. During the Cold War years, the philosophy of the U.S. government
was to select those refugee groups that best matched its foreign policy and
domestic self-interests. The U.S. government's method of selection appears to
have become somewhat less internally focused in recent years, as reflected by
its decision to exponentially increase the resettlement of African refugees.

   This new, more flexible resettlement policy on the part of the United States
is a positive development from a global perspective. When the U.S. government
makes resettlement decisions primarily according to its geopolitical interests,
it risks overlooking many of the world's poorest and least powerful countries
that are least capable of providing for the refugees pouring across their
borders. Kenya, for example, which provided temporary refuge to both  [*466]
the Sudanese Lost Boys and the Somali Bantu, is essentially an island of
relative safety in a region of conflict. Because the country is so isolated, the
Kenyan government is overwhelmed by its refugee burden and seems to have little
choice other than to warehouse refugees in remote camps along its borders,
rather than allowing refugees to integrate among the local population.  n182
Protracted refugee situations like those in Kenya are particularly disturbing to
refugee advocates, as groups like the Somali Bantu and Sudanese Lost Boys have
wasted years of their lives languishing in refugee camps.

   Fortunately, the U.S. refugee resettlement program has become increasingly
flexible and willing to address such protracted refugee situations. The
challenge will be for the United States to remain flexible over time and willing
to help relieve the world's refugee burden where it is greatest, which may mean
continuing to accept refugees from some of the world's poorest countries. By
doing so, the United States can continue to provide education and resources to
those--like the Lost Boys and Somali Bantu--who may need assistance the most. If
the U.S. government continues to extend a helping hand to such refugee
populations, however, it must be prepared to provide an adequate level of
assistance to them upon their arrival in the United States, so that America can
truly be a land of opportunity for all its citizens, both born and naturalized.

FOOTNOTES:





n1  These meetings with refugees in Atlanta were part of my volunteer work with
the International Community School (ICS), an innovative charter school targeting
refugee and immigrant children in the Atlanta area. ICS was founded in 2001 to
respond to the needs of the growing refugee and immigrant population in Atlanta,
Georgia, many of whom are African. See International Community School,
www.intcomschool.org (last visited May 15, 2007).





n2  See Appendix A.





n3  "Lost Boys" is a reference to the fictional group of orphaned youth from the
popular children's novel, PETER PAN. The media commonly uses this term to refer
to the Sudanese youth who were resettled to the United States, although many of
the boys do not like this name.





n4  The Hmong from Southeast Asia are one of the only other comparable groups.





n5  This informal coalition will be referred to in this paper as "interest
groups and Congressional allies."

organizational affiliations.





n7  I would like to thank all of those I interviewed for their thoughtful
comments and for their time. This paper was greatly enriched by their
contributions.





n8  Canada, Australia, and the Scandinavian countries (Denmark, Norway, and
Sweden) also accept a significant number of refugees for resettlement each year.
In 2005, the United States resettled 58,813 refugees (out of 70,000 spots
allocated); Australia resettled 11,654 refugees; Canada resettled 10,400
refugees; and the Scandinavian countries combined resettled 2,495 refugees.
UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES [hereinafter UNHCR], REFUGEES BY
NUMBERS: 2006 EDITION 17 (2006), available at
http://www.unhcr.org/basics/BASICS/4523b0bb2.pdf.

n33  Martin, supra note 29, at 93; Zucker, supra note 29, at 171. In the late
1950s, President Eisenhower used the parole power to bring over 30,000
Hungarians who were fleeing Soviet intervention in their country, but who did
not meet the strict UN Convention definition of a refugee. ALEINIKOFF, supra
note 15, at 806. The parole power was later invoked again in the interest of
anti-Communist ideology during the 1960s and 1970s to resettle thousands of
Cubans to the United States. Id. Refugees who are paroled into the country in
this way often do not meet the UN Convention definition of a refugee. Barnett,
supra note 26, at 2.





n34  Steinbock, supra note 16, at 989-90. The parents, spouses, and unmarried
children under 21 of refugees and asylees from select countries may be granted
priority level three ("P-3") status for family reunification purposes. To obtain
P-3 status for a family member, a refugee or asylee in the United States must
file an Affidavit of Relationship, which is reviewed by USCIS. This process is
distinct from the 1-730 Refugee/Asylee Relative Petition, which is a separate
avenue for bringing the relatives of refugees and asylees to the United States.
Beneficiaries of an 1-730 petition may be located in their country of origin and
need not establish a refugee claim. See U.S. Dep't of State, U.S. Dep't of
Homeland Security, and U.S. Dep't of Health and Human Services, Proposed Refugee
Admissions for Fiscal Year 2007: Report to the Congress, 20 (Oct. 2006),
available at http:// www.state.gov/g/prm/rls/rpt/2006/73619.htm.

n59  Loescher, supra note 55, at 159. "'Warehousing' is the practice of keeping
refugees in protracted situations of restricted mobility, enforced idleness, and
dependency--their lives on indefinite hold--in violation of their basic rights
under the 1951 UN Refugee Convention ... En camped or not, refugees are
warehoused when they are deprived of the freedom necessary to pursue normal
lives." Merrill Smith (Ed.), Warehousing Refugees: A Denial of Rights, a Waste
of Humanity, in U.S. COMMITTEE FOR REFUGEES AND IMMIGRANTS 2004, World Refugee
Survey 2004, available at http://www.refugees.org/data/wrs/04/pdf/38-56.pdf.

n86  See, e.g., Ben Jacklet, Bantus Find a Niche in Nurseries, PORTLAND TRIB.,
Nov. 30, 2004, available at
http://www.portlandtribune.com/news/story.php?story_id=27316. Resettlement is
not the only source of Africans in the United States. Many Africans immigrate to
the U.S. each year through the Diversity Visa Program, for example. Most of
these African immigrants are upwardly mobile professionals, since the Diversity
Visa lottery exclusively admits foreigners with a certain pre-existing level of
education and job skills. The Diversity Visa applicant pool is self-selecting on
an economic level as well, because applicants are required to pay a set fee
which is more than many individuals in developing countries can afford. See
Salih Omar Eissa, Diversity and Transformation: African Americans and African
Immigration, IMMIGR. L. TODAY, July-Aug. 2005, at 38.

n88  U.S. DEP'T OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (DHHS), OFFICE OF REFUGEE

sent them to Ethiopia, where they could receive an English-language education.
The few schools operating in Southern Sudan in the 1980s were required by the
government to teach in Arabic, a language the Southern Sudanese associated with
their oppressors in the North. Phone interview with Mark Bixler, supra note 72.
